HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Time to Confront Health-Care Issue

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
ADMINISTRATION officials, members of Congress and executives who buy or provide health care are girding for a broad debate on the future of the troubled medical system.
The problems include access to care for the 37 million Americans not covered by health insurance, long-term care for the elderly and spending that is expected to exceed $600 billion, about 12 percent of the gross national product in 1990.
Insurers are feeling pressure to loosen restrictions that are blamed for increasing the numbers of the uninsured, but there is widespread reluctance to spend even more money for change.
''I expect a national debate, vigorous discussion on the issues of long-term care, providing for the medically uninsured and other problems,'' said Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services. 
Employers and Government officials say rising health costs threaten competitiveness and the efforts to reduce budget deficits. But some say the cost and access issues cannot be separated.
Two-thirds of the uninsured have full-time jobs, often at businesses with fewer than 25 employees, regarded as expensive to insure. Many small employers have dropped insurance. And people who have had expensive illnesses are often denied coverage.
Insurers have met with members of Congress and physicians' groups to discuss limiting rate increases and restrictions on coverage. ''I have a feeling that the insurance industry knows that there will have to be changes,'' said Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia.
Bernard R. Tresnowski, president of the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association commented: ''The answer may be to permit insurance carriers to operate in that market under certain standards of behavior.''
A Government commission is scheduled to present a health-care plan to President Bush in March. Senator Rockefeller, the group's chairman, has suggested that employers be required to provide health insurance for their employees or to pay a tax to a fund to protect uninsured people.
Mr. Rockefeller said the Administration would face a fight in Congress if Mr. Bush proceeds with a reported plan to cut $8.5 billion from the Medicare and Medicaid budgets next year.
Mr. Rockefeller's group has not said how much the Senator's suggestion would cost. But Deborah Steelman, a Bush Presidential campaign adviser and chairwoman of an advisory council on Social Security, said the annual cost of comprehensive improvements might be $30 billion to $50 billion.
Although such costly changes are unlikely in 1990, Ms. Steelman said, a first step could be to expand the Federal-state Medicaid program. ''To bring in everyone who is under the poverty line, including single men and kids up to 18, as well as pregnant women and people with traumatic illnesses might cost $10 billion,'' she said.
Representative Bill Gradison, Republican of Ohio and a vice chairman of the Congressional commission, would go further. He said he wants to ''break the tie between Medicaid and poverty, so people above the poverty line can participate.''
Mr. Gradison noted that Congress has started in that direction by extending Medicaid eligibility for pregnant mothers and young children. ''But nothing comprehensive can be done without some new source of revenue,'' he said. ''We are moving closer to the kind of crisis that might force action to be taken. An increasing number of hospitals are eliminating whole services such as emergency rooms or trauma centers, or just closing their doors completely.''
Robert N. Beck, an executive vice president at the Bank of America, said that in Los Angeles, ''three hospitals have closed their emergency rooms, which puts more pressure on the county hospital.''
Establishing standards of proper medical care is a priority for many physicians. ''We see 1990 as the beginning of the era of accountability in the medical profession,'' said Dr. James S. Todd of the American Medical Association. He cited a new law that would revise Medicare payments, based on such criteria as the doctor' time, training, overhead expenses and intensity of effort.
Recommendations will come from several influential quarters. In addition to the reports due from the Congressional commission and Ms. Steelman's council, employers in the Washington Business Group and the National Association of Manufacturers are also drafting policy proposals. ''Employers, unions, medical groups, everybody is coming up with their own solutions,'' Mr. Wardrop said. ''But if we don't reach some consensus, the number of Americans without access will go to 40 million, costs will rise to 15 percent of the G.N.P., and the quality won't get any better.''

HEADLINE: WALL STREET OUTLOOK;
Market-Value Index Set Record During Year

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
With economic conditions becoming more treacherous and takeovers less trendy, the companies that simply did what they said they were going to do walked away last year as the big winners on the American Stock Exchange.
Included on the list of top percentage gainers were some companies whose distinction appears to be that their earnings have improved nicely, like Old Spaghetti Warehouse Inc., a small but growing chain of restaurants, and Keane Inc., a Boston-based purveyor of computer software.
Over all, the Amex market-value index hit an all-time high of 397.03 on Oct. 10, and closed the year at 378, up by 23.5 percent. That fell short of the 24.8 percent advance by the New York Stock Exchange composite index, and the 27 percent climb by the Dow Jones industrial average. But the Amex gain exceeded the 19.3 percent rise by the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter issues. In 1988, the Amex's index outperformed the other gauges, posting a 17.5 percent annual rise. 
 
Aided by Oil and Gas
With a heavy concentration of smaller listings, the Amex might have trailed the 1989 pack by a wider margin were it not for its unusual number of oil and gas listings, said William M. LeFevre, the market strategist for Advest Inc. The sector enjoyed a good fourth quarter because of rising oil prices and the cold weather.
Volume on the Amex rose by 24.3 percent over the 1988 levels, to 3.1 billion shares, for a daily average of 12.4 million shares. That was short of the exchange's all-time high in 1987, when 3.5 billion shares changed hands.
The Amex's worst performers had more than their share of headaches. Manufactured Homes Inc., a retailer of mobile homes whose shares tumbled from $6.25 to 56 cents through the year, said it was having severe cash flow problems because of insufficient financing for its retail customers, and its auditors questioned whether it could survive as a going concern. The company declined to comment.
 
Centrust Spending Criticized
Centrust Savings Bank, the next worst performer, saw its once high-flying stock fall to 56 cents, from $5.75, by the year's end. The Florida-based institution has been sparring with industry regulators over criticism that it spent lavishly on art and other management perquisites despite heavy operating losses.
Enviropact Inc., a provider of environmental services, was unable to pay a tax bill, prompting its auditors to question the company's ability to survive as a going concern. Lawrence Turner, an outside director, said the company had since sold a division to pay the tax but must live with the stigma until its next audit. ''Unfortunately, there's no process for getting that relieved,'' he added.
Finally, political events abroad appeared to have both helped and hurt. For instance, the stock of the Compudyne Corporation, a maker of military electronic equipment, dropped by 72 percent over the year because of losses on fixed-price development contracts, a problem the company believes will be overcome in 1990.
But fears that military spending may be one casualty of peace has not helped Compudyne woo investors. ''It's not going to be high on a list of buys,'' said Stephen Henn, the company's treasurer.
On the other hand, the Stevens Graphics Corporation, a maker of printing presses, may have benefited when it landed some contracts in the Soviet Union, cracking what is expected to be a blossoming market for Western goods in that country.

HEADLINE: With Rural Towns Vanishing, States Choose Which to Save

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: McCLUSKY, N.D., Dec. 29

 BODY:
Since the 1950's half the people and most of the businesses have left the barren buttes and prairies of Sheridan County in central North Dakota. The county has no doctor, no hospital, no traffic light, no Greyhound bus service and more ghost towns than live ones.
McClusky, the county's biggest town, might not be here if it were not the county seat, residents say. It has barely 600 people and a withering Main Street dotted with storefronts that have been closed for years. Nobody can remember when a new building last went up.
Watching shops close and towns disappear is ''like sitting there dying and waiting for someone to set the date for your funeral,'' said Darvin Engel, the Mayor of McClusky. 
Sheridan County is like hundreds of declining rural counties around the country facing questions about their survival that pose tremendous ethical and economic quandaries for state governments with limited resources.
In the years since the farm crisis laid waste to many rural communities, many states, by active policies or by inaction, have been resorting to a kind of economic triage - promoting economic development in thriving towns and counties while permitting weaker ones to die. The strategy, directly or implicitly, works in much the same way that a battlefield triage system favors treatment for the wounded who are most likely to live.
Because the idea is not a popular one in rural states, few state officials will openly acknowledge that they rely on this kind of economic strategy.
But scholars say most states are already engaged in some form of triage, whether they expand roadways in some counties at the expense of others or whether they choose not to show companies certain towns ''because they know there's no hope,'' said Mark Lapping, a professor of regional and community planning at Kansas State University who is director of the Kansas Center for Rural Initiatives.
Professor Lapping, who has written several books espousing the theory, said: ''You can't fix every rural bridge. States don't want to throw good money after bad. They don't say they will aggressively pursue this policy - they just hang back and let it happen. They just surrender to market forces.''
Nobody knows precisely how many small towns around the country have vanished in recent decades. Unincorporated towns of less than 1,000 people, which are among those most likely to disappear, are not even monitored by the Census Bureau. Calvin Beale, senior demographer in the Agriculture Department, said that each decade about 200 previously incorporated towns across the country fail to show up in the census, although he said there was no way to know from the statistics why the town governments disbanded.
 
Urgency in North Dakota
Mark Drabenstott, assistant vice president and economist of the Federal Reserve Bank in Kansas City, Mo., said that given scarce public resources in farm-dependent regions, state governments have two choices. ''Spread your development efforts very thinly over all communities and have little chance of those efforts succeeding,'' he said, ''or concentrate those efforts on a fewer number of communities and have a much higher chance of success.''
States across the Middle West are already struggling with this dilemma. Kansas recently formed a commission to study ways to direct resources to larger towns that officials envision as regional anchors in rural areas. Such a policy, many economists say, will inevitably draw resources away from declining towns.
And here in North Dakota, the economic questions appear even more urgent. The state, which has been losing jobs and people for most of this decade, is in the second year of drought and has yet to recover from the farm crisis of the 1980's.
In early December, North Dakota voters repealed a tax increase that was intended to offset a $100 million budget deficit that has led the state to make across-the-board cuts in all its services.
North Dakota's Governor, George Sinner, said the state was facing some painful choices about where the money would go.
''The state wants to keep every community it can,'' said Mr. Sinner, a Democrat. ''But when you have a declining population and tax base and have to keep the schools going and the highways going and the medical services and the nursing homes, it's going to be almost impossible to keep these communities alive. The state just can't do it all.''
 
The First to Go
What this means in North Dakota and other mostly rural states is that essential services and perhaps even entire counties will probably be consolidated to avoid redundancy and to assure that at least some communities survive, economists say.
''There are going to be some rural communities that prosper at the expense of dying neighbors, and I fully expect the trend to continue,'' Mr. Drabenstott said.
William C. Davis, North Dakota's director of industrial development, said that in the move toward regionalization, ''the towns that don't have much of a trade area and don't have any primary government service will be the first to go.''
Whether a state should permit this is far from settled. Roland Vautour, Under Secretary of Agriculture for Small Community and Rural Development, said that the will of the people should be the determining factor in deciding the fate of a community. Life or Death? ''The leadership has to come from the local area,'' Mr. Vautour said. ''The government ought not to be playing big brother in saying Community A should expire and Community B should prosper. How do you make that call?''
Professor Lapping suggests several other factors that states should consider in answering the difficult question of which towns will live and which will die: size (generally, for a town to survive, he says, it needs at least 2,500 people), economic diversity, corporate investment from outside the community, the willingness of residents to invest there, easy accessibility, and a relatively young population.
Sheridan County misses on almost all counts. A recent study by two Rutgers University scholars ranked Sheridan County among 10 deeply distressed North Dakota counties.
Each of the 10 counties has no more than four people per square mile, poverty rates of at least 20 percent and new construction of less than $50 per capita, as against the national average of $850 per capita, according to the study by Frank Popper, chairman of the Urban Studies department at Rutgers, and his wife, Deborah Epstein Popper, a geographer at Rutgers.
Complicating the problems of these counties is that their populations are steadily shrinking and aging. The median age in Sheridan County is more than 38 years, as against a median age of 27 in the state's two urban counties, according to Census Bureau data. And while the population in the United States has doubled since 1930, the population in Sheridan County has dropped by two-thirds, from a peak of 7,373 people in 1930 to about 2,500 last year spread out over nearly 1,000 square miles.
The county looked different just a few decades ago, when Mayor Engel was growing up. ''We used to have four grocery stores, two or three cafes, three creameries, four car dealerships, five service stations,'' Mr. Engel said. ''It doesn't seem possible, but it was.'' 'You Need People'
The problem now, Mayor Engel said, is: ''You need people, is what you need. And we don't have people.'' The numbers tell the story. In what has become a nationwide trend, the number of farms in Sheridan County declined by nearly half from 1950 to 1982, to 495 from 881. And in the past year, the Federal Farmers Home Administration has had to write off $1.9 million in outstanding debt that Sheridan County farmers were unable to pay, said James Pellman, supervisor of the agency's office in Sheridan County.
The county is almost solely dependent on farming and ranching, and residents attribute the county's downturn to the recent drought, low grain prices during much of this decade and Federal farm initiatives like the Conservation Reserve Program, which pays farmers to take marginal land out of production.
They admit that they have been unable to organize themselves and devise plans to attract businesses. But they say the state has a responsibility to help struggling communities like theirs.
''Nobody's investing in Main Street McClusky,'' said Walter Lipp, the county's prosecutor and only lawyer. ''The state seems reluctant to put money in rural areas. You go to meetings and they make a lot of promises, but they don't deliver.''
While places like Sheridan County look for aid, the state's current approach is to save only the towns that take steps to help themselves. The state offers low-interest loans and matching funds to communities that ''take the initiative,'' by raising money of their own to attract businesses.
A few years ago, the thriving town of Park River in northeastern North Dakota went to the state with a proposal for a high-technology plant to harvest fresh mushrooms, which were hard to come by in North Dakota. The town of 2,000 people offered to spend tens of thousands of dollars to improve the site and provide low-cost power. The state provided a low-interest loan of $380,000. Last fall the Midwest Mushroom Company began marketing mushrooms to wholesale distributors in four states.
 
'The Way the World Works'
As for those communities that do not or cannot come up with the money for such proposals, Mr. Sinner said: ''That's just the way the world works. There's a limit to what we can do.'' Some local officials and planners say that recent tough times may have actually improved some communities' chances for success. ''Most of our business have been hit by hard times in the past, and they're down to the point where they're lean and mean,'' said Paul Patterson, a community development executive in western Nebraska. ''They can make a profit and they'll rebuild and expand.''
But that seems somewhat illusory to people like Dr. Schindler, who looked out upon his office's waiting room, barren and empty of patients, and spoke with both wishfulness and resignation.
''You could talk to a hundred people, and it's the same story,'' Dr. Schindler said. ''We're going downhill - that's what's happening. There are hundreds of little towns just like us. I don't know what our fate is. If we hold our own, we'll be lucky.''

HEADLINE: Price-Shaken Argentina Halts the Money Flow

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 2

 BODY:
As grocery store workers were busy doubling prices and pharmacies opened with nearly bare shelves, the Government of President Carlos Saul Menem undertook a new plan today to turn back inflation by making Argentina's currency a scarce commodity.
The Government said it would print no more of the currency, called the austral, despite inflation that may have reached 100 percent since Christmas, and it urged people to hold onto to those they have until prices begin to retreat.
Economy Minister Erman Gonzalez promised that the plan he announced late Monday ''will allow the austral to stop being the symbol of our self-destruction.''
Although some political leaders expressed concern about social unrest, the public faced today's situation with calm. Most people seemed to be trying to follow Mr. Gonzalez's advice to avoid buying anything but necessities. Banks and foreign exchange houses were ordered to remain closed today, a factor that probably contributed to the sense of calm. 
 
Chaos Likened to 1976
Antonio Cafiero, Governor of Buenos Aires Province and leader of Mr. Menem's Justicialist Party, said the economic situation ''is becoming insufferable for the majority of Argentines.'' He also said that the current economic chaos is worse than that preceding the 1976 military coup against the Government of Isabel Peron.
At that time, he said, the foreign debt was just 10 percent of the $60 billion-plus it totals today, the country was producing 15 percent more in goods and services and there was full employment.
Last week, the commanders of all three military branches warned separately that the economic situation put democracy at risk, but they insisted they continued to support the civilian Government. This is thought to be the first time military leaders have spoken out on a political or economic matter not directly related to the armed forces since giving up power at the end of 1983.
Besides idling the mint's presses, the new policies announced by Mr. Gonzalez included the halting of cash payments of interest on internal-debt bonds and on large short-term deposits in banks, both favorite investments of financial speculators here, plus measures to attract to the exchange markets some of the large store of dollars held by big corporations. Credits Sought From U.S. While rejecting the idea of outright ''dollarization'' of the economy that had been proposed last week by some Menem advisers, Mr. Gonzalez said Argentina was seeking emergency credits from the United States and the International Monetary Fund to increase hard-currency reserves as a prelude to linking the value of the austral and the level of the country's reserves.
Argentina has been troubled by high inflation for decades, but it culminated at 200 percent for one month in July as Mr. Menem was succeeding Raul Alfonsin in the presidency. Wage and price accords quickly brought down monthly inflation to a single digit, and the new Government promised to reduce public expenditures and sell off big, inefficient state companies as part of a broad restructuring of the economy.
The size of the foreign debt, the third largest in Latin America, is not directly related to the present crisis because almost no interest has been paid on it for nearly two years.
The promised restructuring has been slow, accompanied by squabbling and resignations within the Menem economic team. At the beginning of December prices took off again, as did financial speculation in the large markets involving dollars and Government debt paper.
 
The Austral Collapses
Before Christmas, economists were predicting that inflation in December would reach 50 percent, but last week it appeared to soar far beyond that. Official figures have not been made public.
At the same time, the austral collapsed on foreign exchange markets. Last Thursday, the last day financial markets operated, it closed at just under 2,000 to the dollar. One week earlier, it stood at about 1,200, compared with 650 at the start of December.
Part of the reason for the periodic run on dollars here is the glut of cash in australs that comes onto the market every seven days when banks pay off the interest on short-term deposits or when holders of Government debt paper collect the interest. Short-term interest has reached as high as 600 percent a month in recent weeks.
Mr. Gonzalez said the Government had decided to dry up that periodic flood of australs - which speculators usually use to buy dollars, thereby driving up the dollar price - by paying the interest in long-term, dollar-denominated bonds that will, in turn, pay dollar interest at relatively low international rates.
 
Pressure on Companies
The minister said that by restricting the austral-interest payments, the Government also hoped to force big companies to sell off some of their hoards of dollars to get the australs to meet tax payments and pay suppliers. Several billion dollars are thought to circulate in Argentina in a sort of parallel dollar economy.
Mr. Gonzalez said that dollar reserves in the Central Bank amounted to $880 million, down from about $2.5 billion two months ago, and that the country's gold was worth $1.4 billion. He said those resources would be pledged to back up the australs in circulation once the Government had obtained international help.
He did not say how much Argentina was seeking from the United States, but newspaper reports in recent days said officials had talked with Terence Todman, the United States Ambassador, about figures ranging from $500 million to $1.5 billion.

HEADLINE: U.N. Takes Step Toward Global Climate Pact

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 2

 BODY:
After difficult negotiations, the nations of the world have laid the groundwork for an accord between rich and poor countries on protecting the atmosphere and encouraging ecologically sound development.
The agreement, reached at the 1989 United Nations General Assembly session, which ended late last month, commits the 159 member countries to draft a treaty on stabilizing the earth's climate and convene a world conference in Brazil in 1992 to discuss ways of reducing the environmental impact of economic development.
As now envisioned, the climate treaty would be adopted at the 1992 conference and would require signers to take appropriate action to prevent warming of the earth's atmosphere, setting goals on such issues as the destruction of forests and the emission of so-called ''greenhouse gases'' which trap heat in the atmosphere. 
At the same time the 1992 environmental conference will try to establish a consensus in favor of a more environmentally sound approach to development, with the industrialized countries offering to help the third world meet the additional costs involved. But while the United Nations unanimously approved the plan for a conference, diplomats say agreement was reached only by papering over differences on delicate issues that could still disrupt a final accord in 1992.
The most important relates to the underdeveloped countries' demands for affordable access to the new technology that they say they will need to make their development environmentally benign.
Many developing countries also believe that the industrialized world's growing environmental concern offers them a chance to press for a wide range of economic concessions in return for cooperation.
Arguing that poverty itself promotes environmental degradation by encouraging deforestation or overgrazing, they are pressing the industrialized countries to make debt relief and higher prices for their exports part of the final package.
This led to a dispute between the industrialized and developing countries at the General Assembly, with the industrialized countries trying to entrust preparation of the climate treaty and the 1992 conference to technical experts, while the third world sought to put the work under its political control.
The final compromise gives the main task of drafting the climate treaty to the United Nations Environment Program and the World Meteorological Organization, as the industrialized countries wanted. But the 1990 General Assembly session will give instructions to the negotiators.
Developed countries also strove to put the United Nations Environment Program in charge of planning the 1992 conference, with the preparatory meetings in Geneva, where third-world countries are less well representated than in New York. But the third world gave the job to a committee of the General Assembly, with meetings divided between New York, Geneva and Nairobi.
 
No Specific Pledges of Help
The industrialized countries accepted that the developing world needs help in combating environmental degradation, particularly through easier access to Western technology. But they refused to give specific pledges before the 1992 conference and completion of the climate convention.
The United States, in particular, argued that most environmentally safe technology - such as solar cells for electrifying villages or ''scrubbers'' for smokestacks - belongs to private corporations and cannot be given away by governments.
India, Sweden and several other countries tried to solve this problem by proposing an international fund, financed from taxes on pollution and voluntary contributions, to finance the purchase of enviromentally sound technology by developing countries.
But the industrialized world would go no further than saying the 1992 conference should ''consider'' such ideas and ''explore the concept of assured access for developing countries to environmentally sound technologies.''

HEADLINE: Bush Picks a Panama Envoy And Sends Team There, Too

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
President Bush today announced the appointment of a veteran diplomat, Deane R. Hinton, as the new United States Ambassador to Panama.
Mr. Hinton, 66 years old, the current Ambassador to Costa Rica and a career Foreign Service officer, helped shape United States policy in El Salvador as envoy there in the early 1980's and was sharply critical of abuses by its army. Mr. Hinton, who has also served as Ambassador to Pakistan, will replace Arthur Davis, a political appointee who is retiring after three years in the post.
A White House statement said that he President had given Mr. Hinton a recess appointment, permitted because Congress is not now in session, that enables him to serve without Senate confirmation until the next Congress is inaugurated in January 1991.
Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger and other senior Administration officials flew to Panama today to discuss with the new civilian leaders there the entire range of problems the country is facing, particularly ways in which Washington can assist the recovery of Panama's battered economy. 
 
Not About Noriega, He Says
Mr. Eagleburger denied reports that the purpose of the trip is to negotiate the fate of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who spent a ninth day today in the Vatican diplomatic mission in Panama City.
He acknowledged that the issue may be discussed in his meetings scheduled for Wednesday with Panama's President, Guillermo Endara. ''Noriega's situation is not on my list of things to discuss with Endara,'' Mr. Eagleburger said before leaving for Panama. ''But if he brings it up, I'm happy to talk with him about it.''
Although the Bush Administration has wanted to replace Mr. Davis for some time, it was unable to do so after the United States withdrew its recognition of the Noriega-led Government in May. Mr. Davis was recalled from Panama after General Noriega voided the presidential election, but returned immediately after the American military intervention last month.
''The idea was a new government, a new guy,'' a State Department official said in explaining the appointment of Mr. Hinton. ''There was a sense that we needed someone with a lot of experience, particularly in the region.''
In Congress, the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, called Mr. Hinton highly qualified for the post because of his ''wide-ranging experience and expertise in Central America.'' But Senator Mitchell objected to the recess appointment, adding he hoped that President Bush would send the appointment to the Senate after Congress convenes Jan. 23 ''for formal consideration and thorough hearings.''
The Administration remained formally silent today about its talks with Vatican and Panamanian officials. What of Ex-Strongman? But an official said that Mr. Eagleburger was likely to reiterate publicly stated policy that General Noriega should come to the United States to stand trial on drug-trafficking charges, and a State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said today that the United States remained committed to bringing General Noriega to this country, where he is under indictment by two Federal grand juries.
In the last week, President Endara has shifted his position from opposing the extradition of General Noriega to favoring his arrest by the United States. However, Washington and the Vatican are engaged in a delicate diplomatic tug-of-war, with the Vatican taking the position that he must be turned over to the new Panamanian Government.
In Rome, the Vatican's chief spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, confirmed today that a church Latin American expert, Msgr. Giacinto Berloco, had been sent to Panama to help resolve the impasse. Despite Monsignor Berloco's presence in Panama, Mr. Eagleburger said he has ''no intention of talking to anybody in the church.''
The dispatching of the Eagleburger team and the appointment of Mr. Hinton are part of an effort by the Bush Administration to bolster Mr. Endara's standing as a political leader and shift the focus away from his dealings with the American military, a senior Adminsitration official said today.
 
'Part of That Process'
''It's important that Endara be seen dealing with non-military people, and sending a high-level diplomatic mission and a senior diplomat as Ambassador are part of that process,'' the official said.
In addition to Mr. Endara, Mr. Eagleburger and his colleagues are to confer on Wednesday with Panama's two vice presidents and with leading businessmen.
Panama faces the task of rebuilding a economy destroyed both by the American invasion and by two years of economic warfare with Washington that included economic and financial sanctions.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: AID TO WARSAW;
$1 Billion Fund Set Up to Back Poland's Currency Program

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The United States and 14 other industrialized countries, having promised to help Poland overhaul its currency, have established a $1 billion fund to support Warsaw's efforts to make its currency partly convertible into dollars and other hard currencies, the Treasury said today.
As a result, for the first time in 40 years Poles will be able to settle hard-currency commercial transactions in their own currency, the zloty. The move is part of the new Government's effort to replace central planning with a market-oriented economy.
The limited convertibility would be similar to the situation in many European countries after World War II before many currencies were made fully convertible in the late 1950's. 
 
Defending the Zloty
The money may be used by Poland's central bank to intervene in currency markets to defend a new rate for the zloty, which has just been devalued from 6,600 zloties to the dollar to 9,500.
Although industrialized countries have been in negotiations on the currency program since early last fall, today's announcement provides the first details about the terms and workings of the plan and who the donors are.
West Germany is making $250 million available, the largest donation. The United States has contributed $200 million, part of an $839 million three-year package of assistance for Poland that Congress approved late last year.
Other leading donors are Japan, $150 million; France, $100 million; Britain, $100 million; Italy, $100 million; Switzerland, $30 million; Canada, $25 million; Austria, $20 million, and Spain, $14 million.
The fund, which the Poles have to repay every quarter, is to operate for a year, but may be renewed under certain circumstances, said David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for international affairs.
The Poles will be able to draw up to $300 million initially. Larger withdrawals may be made only upon approval of a consultative committee made up of the contributor Governments.
The Polish economic program has been worked out with the International Monetary Fund, and the United States has taken the lead in setting up the fund. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is acting as agent for the donor governments.
 
What the U.S. Could Gain
The stakes for Washington, Mr. Mulford said, are ''the transformation of Poland into a market-oriented economy.''
Critical to the transition, he noted, is the creation of some degree of convertibility and realistic price levels, so that Poland can more easily trade with the rest of the world.
Limited convertibility means that in transactions not related to international trade, it will be harder for Poles to convert zloties into dollars.
For years, the Soviet Union has considered making the ruble convertible. But most economists believe that Moscow would have to introduce market-oriented economic changes similar to those being tried in Poland, where wages are being restrained, subsidies cut, price controls removed and money supply growth reduced drastically.
The results in Poland, just about everyone agrees, are likely to be, at least initially, economic pain, higher unemployment and bankruptcies.
 
Moscow Applies Some Limits
Moscow recently announced intentions to maintain its centrally planned economic system for some years more.
But some Eastern bloc countries, including Czechoslovakia, Rumania and East Germany, could well follow the Poles toward a market economy, many economists say.
Mr. Mulford declined to comment on what the United States and other industrial countries might do for these countries, noting that it would depend on the circumstances at the time.
Poland is expected to get further assistance next month, Mr. Mulford said, when it sits down with the so-called Paris Club of creditor nations to negotiate a rescheduling of its debt.
He predicted ''generous terms,'' in which Poland would probably be given ''longer than 10 years'' to repay its obligations.
Altogether, Poland owes Western institutions some $39 billion: $27 billion to governments and $12 billion to commercial banks.

HEADLINE: Strike Leaves Deep Vein of Anger in Coal Country

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Va., Jan. 2

 BODY:
There were no celebrations in the coal towns of Appalachia today, no banners unfurled, no outward signs of joy that there may soon be an end to one of the nation's longest and most bitter miners' strikes.
One reason the 1,700 striking miners are holding back emotionally, after the initial euphoria that accompanied a tentative agreement, is that they have not seen the contract that their union and their employer announced Monday, on the 270th day of the strike and after weeks of intensive Federal mediation between the United Mine Workers of America and the Pittston Coal Group.
Union leaders hope to present the contract to the rank-and-file in the next 10 days, but first leftover lawsuits and fines levied against the union during the strike must be resolved. The settlement also needs the approval of the union's pension trustees.
Another reason the miners are slow to celebrate is that damage done by the strike has been emotional as well as financial, and those kinds of wounds do not heal in a day - or maybe ever, people here say. 
''This is the longest and most painful strike I've seen in 30 years,'' said the Rev. Jack M. Carnley, pastor of the Assembly of God Church here. ''Friends and families have been alienated emotionally, and there has been a lot of duress on everybody. In some families, the husband is union and the wife is company. The wife has to cross picket lines, where rocks have been thrown and where people ask the man, 'What's your wife working for?' It's going to take quite some time to heal these wounds.''
 
A Summer of Violence
A primary source of the bitterness and family strife is that Pittston, in a break with industry tradition, hired replacement workers during the strike and has kept most of its 30 mines and preparation plants open since the strike began April 5.
The strikers say this tactic has prolonged the strike, increased tension between the working salaried employees and the striking miners and kindled feuds among replacement workers and their neighbors and families. Strike-related violence and vandalism were daily occurrences during the summer, but have now become sporadic.
St. Paul is typical of the small struggling towns in the Appalachian coal region, and the pain its residents feel is common as well, union officials said. The town supported the strikers and let the union use its school football field for rallies, like the one the Rev. Jesse Jackson addressed on Labor Day. This is the kind of place where even the Mayor, Jack Kiser, is a striking miner.
Mr. Kiser, like most others interviewed here today, said he was relieved that an agreement had been reached. He said he was confident that union leaders had negotiated adequate health benefits and job security, two core issues.
 
Hard to Be Happy
But Mr. Kiser said it was hard to be happy, because the strike had caused so much pain in so many ways: ''Who knows, for example, how many young people got out of school this year and left home for good, saying, 'I'm not going to fool with the coal fields; I'm going to go work and live someplace else' ?''
The strike hurt one young family that was trying to move back home to St. Paul. ''My husband was promised a mechanic's job at a garage here, and we came back from Richmond in June,'' said Sharon K. Stevens, who paused in her shopping at the Piggly Wiggly supermarket. ''When we got here with our three kids, there was no job. They said business was off because of the strike. We've been getting by on food stamps and help from social services and the church. But if things don't straighten out soon, we'll have to go back to Richmond.''
For many years, young people have been moving away from towns like this one. Unemployment in the area was 9 percent last year, almost double the national average and more than double the state average, according to the Census Bureau.
 
Memories of Boom Times
The average family income in 1987, the latest year for which figures are available, was $10,012, far less than the state and national averages, according to the Census Bureau.
St. Paul, which sits in a valley next to State Highway 58, is a dreary patch of brick and frame houses that date most from the 1940's and 1950's, when St. Paul was a boom town.
Now the five downtown blocks look decrepit. There is a long-closed movie theater, a dilapidated hotel, several beauty shops, second-hand shops and the modern Piggly Wiggly supermarket. A new shopping center, on the outskirts of town, provides some new life for the region at the same time it drains business from downtown.
There is no longer a company store, but St. Paul is still a company town.
''Sixty percent or better of everything in town is related to mining, and most of the 1,200 people in town are dependent on Pittston,'' said Mr. Kiser.
 
Relief on the Other Side
Salaried mining employees, too, are relieved that the strike may soon be over. ''People understand that the management people have to do the job,'' said James W. Steele, a Pittston engineer who has worked during the strike. ''They really don't hold it against me personally, but the tension has been there.''
This strike has not meant financial ruin for the miners, who had two years to prepare for the strike and have received $225 a week in strike pay since April. They also received a $1,000 Christmas bonus, and the union has helped some families meet payments for car loans and mortgages.
But small businesses, particularly those that sell non-essentials, have been hard hit.
Eugene D. Stewart, owner of a furniture and appliance company in the new mall, said business had been slow since strike talk began two years ago. ''We sell things that people don't need to eat or drink,'' he said. ''I'm hoping that there will be a lot of pent-up demand for furniture.''
 
Bitterness on the Line
But it is the the nonunion people who have worked through the strike, the people who suffered the most humiliation, who speak most enthusiastically about the agreement.
''I'm real glad it's over,'' said Wayne Meade, a 38-year-old nonunion truck driver who said it may take ''five or more years'' for him to mend relationships torn by the strike. He works for a company that transports coal for Pittston, and every time Mr. Mead drove across the picket line he saw many of his lifelong friends - and his brother.
''The whole community felt that we've prolonged the strike by hauling coal, that what we done is beating them out of a job,'' Mr. Meade said. ''My brother doesn't blame me, but some of the people I grew up with and went to school with don't treat me as friendly anymore.''
''But I don't hold it against them,'' he continued. ''They got to do what they got to do, and I got to do what I got to do to provide for my family.''
Mr. Carnley said he and his parishioners have prayed for a fair and equitable settlement. Now, he said, they will pray for peace.

HEADLINE: Labor Dispute in Louisiana Ends With Ecological Gain

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The end of a long, bitter labor dispute against a major Louisiana chemical maker has left in its wake not just a new contract but a new toughness in the state's environmental movement.
Leaders of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union say they won the new contract in December largely because of a campaign against the BASF Corporation that included charges that the company was a habitual polluter. More broadly, the union says, its campaign succeeded in making industry in Louisiana and elsewhere behave more responsibly toward the environment.
William Fontenot, environmental specialist in the State Attorney General's office, concurred. He said that in the five years, the union ''has raised the level of consciousness about the environment in Louisiana'' and has helped persuade the state to regulate industry more closely. 
 
Company Denies Role
But Richard Donaldson, industrial relations manager for BASF, said the union's ''corporate accountability campaign was not an issue at the bargaining table.''
Mr. Donaldson said the dispute was settled because both sides were ''anxious to make an agreement.'' He said the company needed more workers because business had boomed at its petrochemical complex in Geismar, along the Mississippi between New Orleans and Baton Rouge. There BASF makes antifreeze, chemicals for permanent-press fabrics, and other products.
The environment was not an issue in June 1984, when BASF locked out 370 workers who charged that a proposed new labor contract was unfair.
At that time, with the petrochemicals business in a slump, management had asked for an eight-month freeze on pay and wanted the union's permission to change maintenance workers' pay structure - in effect, cutting most salaries. Management also asked the workers to pay a greater share of their health insurance premiums while cutting benefits, and it wanted to eliminate job protection for seniority.
By the June 1984 contract deadline, BASF would not let the workers stay on the job under the old contract. It locked them out and hired temporary replacements, running the plant at full capacity with 100 fewer workers. The union charged that the plant was unsafe because the workers were unskilled.
In 1987, the company allowed production workers to come back without a contract, and BASF says the lockout ended then. But 110 maintenance workers were not taken back because a nonunion subcontractor had filled their jobs. The status of those workers has been an issue since then.
 
Locked-Out Workers Return
Under the new contract, approved Dec. 18, the 110 maintenance workers will be allowed to return to the plant as production workers, after training. The locked-out workers will receive raises and credit for seniority, but no credit in pension plans for time away from the jobs.
Using money from dues, the international union's defense fund and contributions from locals around the country, the union attracted the attention of people here in Louisiana and elsewhere with what a BASF spokesman, Robert G. Thoma, called a ''scorched-earth campaign that's meant to destroy the company.''
The union placed questions on billboards near the plant asking, for example, ''Is BASF the Gateway to Cancer Alley?,'' a reference to pollution generated by industry along the river where BASF is situated.
In the months following the lockout, union members worked with environmental groups to protest that a $66,700 fine against BASF for five air pollution violations was too small. A state appellate court has ordered the state to recompute the fine on the basis of economic benefits that BASF gained by not installing proper pollution controls.
 
'The Public Expert'
The local's chief negotiator, Ernie Rousselle, said the campaign was an ''intensification'' of what the union has done in other regions.
Paul Templet, the state's top environmental official, called the union ''the public expert'' on pollution. ''They had their own technical people,'' he said. ''They prepared papers and gave them to us. It made us very careful about how we dealt with the company, knowing there were technical experts on the union side.''
Union members, accompanied by spouses and children, packed state hearings on environmental issues. They wrote letters and carried petitions urging stronger environmental controls on industry. They joined conservation groups. One union member, copying machine in tow, combed state records for data on petrochemical plants.
During the lockout, union members took advantage of their slack time for some self-education. Darren Stevens, who had been an electrician at BASF, now plans to study for an advanced degree in environmental science. ''I don't want to go back out into any chemical plant,'' Mr. Stevens said.

HEADLINE: Let Marketplace Repair Our Crumbling Nation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Felix G. Rohatyn's proposal to set up state infrastructure banks to cure deficiencies in the national infrastructure (''To Repair Our Nation,'' Op-Ed Dec. 17) is not only unnecessary, but also downright mischievous. While Mr. Rohatyn is not specific about who would make the investment decisions, his proposed combination of a state taxing effort, public employee pension funds and Federal guarantees is unlikely to improve the processes that have brought about our miserable situation.
A better starting point would be to recognize that roads, railways and airports are assets to which can be applied the same market principles that are used successfully in industry and commerce. If markets were allowed to work in the case of, say, airports, the owners of the few that are congested would raise their landing fees, and travel would be diverted to the hundreds that have spare capacity. High profits made by some airports would attract appropriate investment to relieve specific shortages. No market signals of this kind would be available to help Mr. Rohatyn's infrastructure banks. 
Roads are another case in point: although road space in and around Manhattan is frequently crowded, tolls are not raised, and road space is not priced, despite the teachings over the last 30 years of Columbia University's William Vickrey. Economic charges for congested roads would allow our roads to be used more efficiently and would raise funds for justified improvements.
Even if facilities are not privatized, allowing the private sector to invest in profit-making ones would go a long way to do the things - such as raising economically justified user charges - that only government can do.
As Alfred Kahn wrote in 1984: ''The market does not solve all our problems, but it takes a special kind of idiocy to refuse to let it do jobs it obviously can do.''
 
GABRIEL ROTH
 Washington, Dec. 18, 1989
The writer is a civil engineer and transport economist.

HEADLINE: Tap Transport Trust

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I welcome Felix G. Rohatyn's suggestion of state banks to finance the repair and expansion of America's infrastructure (Op-Ed. Dec. 17).
He proposes that the Federal Government guarantee the municipal pension funds that would support his proposed state infrastructure banks. I believe the Federal Government should do more. Thanks to glasnost, it can. In the wake of the dramatic developments in Eastern Europe, Congress can and should change the way it treats the transportation trust funds for which it is steward.
Those funds, containing some $25 billion in user fees, were designed to maintain and improve the infrastructure, not to help paper over the budget deficit.
The trust fund dollars can provide significant seed money for infrastructure banks - either the national one I have on occasion proposed or the chain of local ones Mr. Rohatyn envisions. These monies would represent a truly national source of funding, complementing the local pension fund assets Mr. Rohatyn would tap.
If we cannot move our people and our goods, if we cannot dispose of our solid waste, how can this nation continue to exert economic leadership?
A recent study by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago indicates that each dollar invested in public works increases total labor productivity by approximately 73 cents.
The future of our highways, our bridges and our airports is a national problem. Their state of readiness should be a national priority. Surely they deserve to be among the first -if not the first - beneficiaries of the ''peace dividend'' from Pentagon budget cuts. Our nation's strength -its very economic survival - demands it.
 
JOSEPH M. GIGLIO
 New York, Dec. 20, 1989
The writer, senior vice president of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, was chairman of the National Council on Public Works Improvement.

HEADLINE: Let Marketplace Repair Our Crumbling Nation;
Not With Pension Funds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Felix G. Rohatyn's concept that public pension funds be used for state infrastructure banks (Op-Ed, Dec. 17) is flawed on three important grounds: (1) The Federal Government is swamped by its loan guarantees - $5 trillion worth according to the Comptroller General. In the wake of the savings and loan and Department of Housing and Urban Development bailouts, it's unrealistic to think it will go further and provide guarantees to state pension funds. (2) Government infrastructure borrowing is done in the tax-exempt market, at low rates of interest. On the other hand, pension funds have a fiduciary requirement to earn high rates of interest. Who will subsidize whom? (3) State infrastructure banks sound like state ''off-budget'' funds. They would allow governors to make spending decisions without legislative approval and public scrutiny.
Finally, if such a scheme is ever approved (and Mr. Rohatyn is not the first to suggest it), it will be, as always, the taxpayers who will foot the bill.
 
EDWARD V. REGAN
Comptroller, State of New York
 Albany, Dec. 20, 1989

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Is This Justice Necessary?

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
Surely the United States can't really want custody of General Noriega. It's understandable, of course, that President Bush should pretend he does. Having sent the Army to unhorse a tinpot Caesar, he is obliged to huff and puff about having him handed over to Yankee justice.
This much is consistent with his effort to persuade the world that sending strategic bombers and the 82d Airborne to Panama isn't much different from sending a bailiff to serve a summons on a recalcitrant felon. 
Since a Florida prosecutor had got the general indicted on drug charges, the President could insist he was just carrying out his oath to execute the laws of the United States. This was a noble position for the President to take, but would become awkward if he actually had to execute the law as it applied to Noriega.
The general's flight to sanctuary in the Vatican's embassy seemed such a happy event for Mr. Bush that some people suspected it had been slyly engineered by his agents on the scene.
Once the Vatican had the general, the ancient tradition of holy sanctuary might oblige it to arrange an exile in some convenient St. Helena. In any case the United States was shed of what could have been a monumental pain in the neck if Americans had got the cuffs on him.
To this point everything looked dandy. Tyranny was overthrown, democracy was restored, Bush had justified a military invasion (''Just Cause'') as a law-enforcement operation, and Noriega was somebody else's problem.
Then came the Army's clownish boom-box bombardment - American soldiers drawn up at the Vatican embassy in Panama, playing rock music full blast around the clock to make life hellish for the Pope's emissaries.
Suddenly we seemed to be in Dr. Strangelove country. Punishing the Vatican with heavy-metal rock? Could Gen. Buck Turgidson be behind this strategy? Or was he acting on orders from the big fellow in Air Force One? (''Hit those holy men with every decibel in freedom's arsenal!'') If the U.S. was still just pretending it wanted Noriega, the act had turned into farce so low that the audience was recoiling instead of laughing. But wait a minute - can it be? - is it possible George Bush really does want Noriega in a Miami courtroom?
The sensible aim of American foreign policy surely is to be rid of Noriega as soon as possible so we can get on to important things. In Panama the important thing might be getting the economy back on its feet. Throughout Latin America the important thing might be to subdue angry suspicions that the bad old gringo will never take his boot off the Latin neck.
It's hard to see how pictures from Miami of Noriega in chains could help us much in Latin America. Loathsome the general may be, but he is also a Latin American while the chains are Yankee iron, and the symbolism does not help our cause. Imagine, if you were a Latin American, how many questions you might start with the words ''And anyhow . . .''
''And anyhow, what entitles the United States to indict Latin leaders, then send armies to carry them off to North American courts?''
''And anyhow, loathsome though Noriega may be, hasn't the United States historically propped up Latin tyrants just as odious who played Washington's game?''
''And anyhow, isn't the true case against Noriega not that he was odious and loathsome, but only that he did not show respect for Washington's game?''
The prospect of Noriega on trial must cause shudders among North Americans familiar with our bizarre legal system. For instance, since American justice is justice delayed it's easy to imagine Noriega turned into a hero of sorts in south Florida long before a trial begins.
In most trials the public quickly loses sympathy for the case's victim and chooses up sides for and against the accused. In a strongly Hispanic community like south Florida, it might be hard to convict a Noriega who could portray himself as a martyr to Anglo justice.
Press freedoms are easily exploited to turn trials into circus. Human-interest stories of Noriega's childhood sufferings. Television appearances with Diane Sawyer, Barbara Walters, Connie Chung. Grocery tabloid scoops about his use of voodoo to contact his sainted mother.
A good trial sets the great American engines of claptrap running out of control. Look at the Oliver North case. While the public relishes the debate -hero or rat? - North entertains tiny tots with his lovable reading.
Thus is Frankenstein's monster built in the media age.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1162 words

HEADLINE: For Dinkins and Fernandez, First Day on Job Is Brisk;
Mayor Seeks Advice On Budget Problems And Welfare Chief

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins began his first real day on the job yesterday with a sunrise appearance on national television, an impromptu breakfast and walk with senior aides and meetings with friends and advisers on how to handle the simmering stew of a city he inherited Monday.
''I won't ask, 'How'm I doing?' '' with the people of New York as Mayor Edward I. Koch often did, Mr. Dinkins told Bryant Gumbel of the NBC News ''Today'' program just after 7 A.M. ''I'll ask, 'How are you doing?' ''
The new Mayor spent much of the rest of the day posing variations on that question to clergymen, financiers, fellow politicians and his own top aides. But he disclosed few specifics of the talks, which centered mostly on the budget gap the city faces.
''I can give you no numbers right now,'' Mr. Dinkins told reporters at City Hall at midday, after meeting with his four deputy mayors and his budget director. 
Mr. Dinkins did say that of the several dozen posts he has yet to fill, one of his most urgent priorities is finding a new commissioner for the city's Human Resources Administration, the sprawling social services agency that oversees everything from day care for children to disbursement of welfare payments to programs for the elderly.
 
The 'Toughest Job' in New York
''I believe the Human Resources commissioner to have the toughest job in the city of New York, tougher than being mayor, tougher than being police commissioner, tougher than being chancellor of the Board of Education,'' Mr. Dinkins said. ''It's just tremendously important that we get the right person.''
He said his search committee had interviewed ''a tremendous number of people, I mean like 40'' and was still working. Some people close to the search have said it has been confused, with competing interests and candidates and no clear favorite. Some candidates are said to have taken themselves out of consideration.
Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that some people ''have perhaps determined they do not wish to serve,'' but said, ''We've got some candidates willing to serve.'' One senior Dinkins aide said later, ''The problem is finding the kind of person needed, not candidates.''
 
A Strolling News Conference
After his appearance on ''Today'' at Rockefeller Center, the new Mayor arrived at City Hall in lower Manhattan about 8 A.M., bumping into his First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, and his Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero.
He promptly led them and some other aides and reporters on a brisk march across the street to Ellen's Coffee Cafe, which is to City Hall what Sardi's is to Broadway. There he ordered wheat toast, coffee and a large orange juice before strolling back across the street in a Trumanesque walking news conference.
Then came meetings with the City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, the new Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, and the Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone. Lunch was a turkey sandwich on wheat at his desk.
Taking note of the revised charter that took effect as he was sworn in, Mr. Dinkins named Eric Lane, the executive director of the Charter Revision Commission that drafted the new government, to head a mayoral task force to oversee its implementation.
 
Ambivalence About Charter
Mr. Lane, who said he thought the temporary job would last no more than a year, will help advise the administration on the creation of the various new boards and panels that, together with the Council, will assume the functions of the Board of Estimate, which has been abolished.
Mr. Dinkins, who differed with many of the charter panel's ballot proposals last year but ultimately supported them on Election Day, was asked why he appointed Mr. Lane.
''He won,'' he said with a laugh. ''The people in their wisdom have spoken; we've adopted a different process, and I see my job as trying to implement the process that the people have said they wish. And who better to assist in that cause than the fellow who helped draft it in the first place?''
But the Mayor also seemed to show anew his ambivalent feelings about the Charter. As a member of the Board of Estimate, he had argued until last spring that the board should be preserved. By midsummer, he began saying publicly that he could not conceive of opposing the proposed charter that abolished the board. Yesterday, he said he had favored preserving the board, ''even as a candidate for mayor.''
 
More Economic Advice
Later, Mr. Dinkins met to talk ''about social awareness-type problems'' with the Rev. James A. Forbes, senior minister of the Riverside Church, Bishop Francis Mugavero of Brooklyn and Dr. Mathilde Krim, the internationally recognized AIDS expert.
Still later, after a talk with his council of economic advisers, which includes Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, David Rockefeller, the retired head of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and Joseph Flom, the lawyer, Mr. Dinkins said only, ''I never talk with these men that I don't come away with some insights.''
Asked what he had come to the meeting to say, Mr. Rockefeller smiled and said, ''I came to listen.'' Mr. Rohatyn said, ''I think this is a very fine man, David Dinkins, and I think that's very important.''
As Mr. Dinkins found his way around his new office, the government bureaucracy went on, even in departments whose heads resigned before the end of the Koch administration. The Human Resources Administration, for example, has been headed by an Acting Commissioner, Doby L. Flowers, since William J. Grinker left on Nov. 19. But the Transportation Commissioner, Ross Sandler, who is a month shy of his fourth anniversary in office and who is a candidate for reappointment, remained at the helm.
 
Orphans of Transition
Mr. Dinkins said he hoped to fill posts like health commissioner, housing commissioner, sanitation commissioner and environmental protection commissioner as soon as possible. But he said he was not distressed by the pace of his appointments.
The Mayor acknowledged that Woodrow A. Myers Jr., the Indiana State Health Commissioner, was one of the candidates under consideration to be the city's health commissioner. He called him ''an imposing figure of great ability,'' but would neither confirm nor deny reports that he had been chosen.
Perhaps the strangest orphans of the transition, at least temporarily, are the staff members from Mr. Dinkins's office as Manhattan Borough President who have been told they will have jobs in the new administration, but have not been told which ones.
Those aides had to leave their offices in the Municipal Building to make way for the new borough chief, Ruth W. Messinger, and reported to mayoral offices in the old Tweed Courthouse at 52 Chambers Street, helping with the transition or waiting for word.
''They're there and they have things to do,'' said Bill Lynch, the Deputy Mayor for Intergovernmental Relations. ''Placing people is a big job.''

HEADLINE: Local Military Contractors Cautiously Brace for Peace

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
As relations warm with the Soviet Union and talk grows in Washington of smaller defense budgets, military contractors in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and communities dependent on military bases are girding themselves for what might become leaner times.
Industry analysts and economists, however, caution that no drastic job cutbacks are expected soon among the region's 10 largest military contractors, which employ about 100,000 people in the three states.
They note that some companies, like Pratt & Whitney of East Hartford, Conn., the jet-engine maker, long ago diversified into non-military products. They also point out that contracts for some weapons, like the $2.3 billion Trident submarines built at the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton, Conn., run into the mid-1990s.
 
Hard to Cut Off the Spigot
''You can expect reductions, but it is really difficult to cut off the spigot,'' said G. Ronald Hertenstein, research director for Forecast International, a defense and aerospace analysis firm in Newtown, Conn. 
The outlook for the region's 57 military installations is less clear, because analysts are unsure whether demobilization in Europe would speed Defense Department plans to shut down bases.
Some analysts believe that budget cutbacks will trim military installations next year more than than expensive weapons contracts. But they also note that base closings can generate intense opposition.
Overall, about 60,000 military personnel and 42,000 civilians are stationed at bases in the three states, ranging from Fort Drum and the Staten Island Homeport in New York to Fort Monmouth and McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey to the Navy's submarine base in Groton, Conn.
 
'Bases Were Going to Close'
Last year, Fort Dix, in Wrightstown, N.J., was turned into a National Guard and reserve training facility. It lost about 25 percent of its 4,100 permanent military and civilian personnel and the 8,000 Army trainees billeted there.
''Bases were going to close as a budget priority, peace or no peace,'' said Steven R. Malin, an economist with The Conference Board, a non-profit business research organization based in Manhattan.
Overall, about 800,000 jobs in the three states are tied, directly and indirectly, to military contracts, subcontracts and bases. The states also rank among the top ten for receiving military contract dollars, receiving more than $16 billion in contracts in the 1988 fiscal year.
Economists warn that any analysis would be premature until President Bush presents his budget to Congress this month.
But Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in Manhattan, predicted that, for now, the industry will be hurt less than Wall Street, which he said has lost 27,000 jobs since 1987 and which he expects to lose 10,000 more within 12 months.
''Certain companies and certain geographic areas may feel a pinch, but not as much as you might think,'' he said. ''Defense spending is not going down to zero.''
Dr. Kellner said that diversification has already taken hold in many defense-dependent areas, like Long Island, where tourism adds $7.9 billion to the local economy each year, while military contracting adds only about $3.8 billion.
Even Grumman Aircraft in Bethpage, L.I., one of the area's largest military contractors, has started diversifying, making commercial aviation parts and data systems.
The company, which is widely thought to be the most vulnerable to defense cuts in the region, also plans to turn almost half its 500-acre headquarters into a shopping center, offices and a 300-room hotel.
 
Depending on One Customer
''It didn't take any foresight to realize it isn't wise to be dependent on a single customer,'' said a Grumman spokesman, Sandy Jones.
Analysts also believe that the region's strong economy, particularly its low unemployment, will soften any cuts. In Groton, the worker shortage is so acute that Electric Boat has 1,000 unfilled jobs and recently shifted 550 jobs to its shipyard in Charleston, S.C., where recruiting is easier.
''The labor shortage cushions the blow,'' said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. ''Over the course of three to five years it will not be that severe.''
Such optimism is not universal. Some lawmakers, particularly those representing areas with large military contractors, view the possibility of budget cuts with alarm.
''There will be a significant impact,'' said Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Democrat from Bozrah, Conn., who represents the Groton-New London area, which is heavily dependent on Electric Boat. ''The question is how gradual it will be, and whether we will develop a response.''
Connecticut is the most defense-dependent of the three states. With over $4.9 billion in defense contracts, it has more than all but seven other states, and its $1,531 per capita in military spending makes it second in the nation after Virginia.
Its leading contractor, with $2.3 billion in contracts, is the United Technologies Corporation of Hartford, which operates the Pratt & Whitney jet engine plant in East Hartford, the Sikorsky Aircraft helicopter plant in Stratford; the Hamilton Standard propeller and aerospace controls plant in Windsor Locks, and the Norden Systems radar and electronics factory in Norwalk. Combined, the companies have 49,000 employees.
 
Butter, Not Star Wars
United Technologies officials believe that many of their military products are bread and butter items like Sikorsky helicopters and Pratt & Whitney fighter jet engines, rather than high-technology research projects in the Strategic Defense Initiative, which are widely thought to be more vulnerable to budget cuts.
They feel confident that the company's diversification will help offset any sharp loss of contracts. At Pratt & Whitney, for example, only 35 percent of its contracts come from the military.
They also hope new relations between the United States and the Soviet Union will lead to more foreign sales. Pratt & Whitney officials are looking to Aeroflot, the huge Soviet airline, as a potential customer.
 
Overseas Sales Growing
Much the same is true at Sikorsky, which laid off 350 workers in July and 150 last month. Overseas sales are expected to help make up for any cut in military spending. Last year 25 percent of its sales were foreign, compared with 6 percent in 1984.
''We derive only about 25 percent of our overall sales from the government,'' said Dan Harrison, a company spokesman. ''That is down from a high of about 75 percent a decade ago.''
The second largest defense contractor in the state, with $1.5 billion in contracts, is Electric Boat, with 17,500 workers. It will rely on time more than diversification.
The company, a subsidiary of General Dynamics of St. Louis, has 16 submarines under construction and recently got a contract for its 17th Trident and several attack submarines.
 
Muttering 'The P-Word'
Company officials and union leaders, who often refer to the prospects for peace as ''the P-word,'' believe the orders will keep the shipyard busy for at least five more years.
''We still have quite a backlog of work, and right now I don't see it disappearing,'' said Joseph W. Messier, president of the Metal Trades Council, which represents 8,400 Electric Boat workers.
In New York, military spending is less concentrated, although the state ranks fourth in it behind California, Virginia and Texas.
On Thursday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced the formation of a panel to help local companies that lose military contracts shift into other products.
 
Tomcat Orders Dwindle
Grumman, with $2.8 billion in contracts, accounted for more than a third of all the military dollars won by New York companies in 1988. Although it has pared its payroll to 18,400 from 25,000 three years ago, company officials are not forecasting many future layoffs, even though the Navy's need for $50 million F-14 Tomcat fighter planes has dwindled.
''The company has been diversifying for at least 10 years,'' Mr. Jones said. ''Our backlog today is the most diversified it has ever been. Only about half of it is with our traditional customer. And it is not a result of what has happened with perestroika.''
The next four largest contractors in New York receive far less money and are scattered throughout the state. They are General Electric plants in Syracuse, Utica and Binghamton, where equipment for radar, aircraft electronics and nuclear reactors for submarines are built; Unisys, which builds navigation and electronics systems in Great Neck, L.I.; Black River Construction, a consortium expanding Fort Drum near Watertown, and IBM, which develops communications equipment in Owego.
New York has 36 military installations with 27,040 military personnel and 19,484 civilians. Connecticut has six installations with 7,423 military and 5,040 civilians. The prospect of base closings is perhaps most troubling, however, in New Jersey, which is still smarting from the Fort Dix reductions. The state has 15 installations with 25,127 military and 18,623 civilians.
The state ranks tenth in the nation in military contracts.
The state's leading contractor, with $976 million in contracts, is General Electric, which operates a satellite plant in Princeton. Other large contractors include ITT in Nutley; Singer Co. in Little Falls and Allied-Signal of Morris Township.
''There is going to be an impact,'' said Michael Ascolese, a spokesman for Allied-Signal, which received about $110 million in defense contracts last year and produces avionics equipment in Teterboro, N.J. ''But it is not going to be an immediate drastic impact.''

CORRECTION-DATE: January 24, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 3 about the effect of Pentagon cutbacks on New York, New Jersey and Connecticut referred incorrectly to the status of Fort Dix, near Wrightstown, N.J. Under a Defense Department plan, the Army is to stop using the fort for basic training by 1995, but reductions in permanent personnel or trainees have yet to occur.
