HEADLINE: A Deficit of $65 Million Is Seen in Connecticut

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Budget officials said today that falling sales-tax revenues and rising welfare costs will leave Connecticut with a budget deficit of $65 million for the fiscal year ending June 30.
The announcement, coming six months after the state enacted the largest tax increase in its history to solve last year's problems, erased the hopes of state officials who had hoped to avoid budget pain in an election year.
Gov. William A. O'Neill, flanked at a news conference by dozens of commissioners and department heads called to the Capitol for a budget briefing, said that in response to the projections, he had ordered an immediate 2 percent cut in appropriations for most agencies, a reduction of 2,000 state jobs over the next 18 months, and curtailment of overtime, travel expenses and consulting contracts.
Mr. O'Neill said the appropriation cuts would save about $20 million over the next six months, while the job cutback would save perhaps $80 million a year once it was fully in effect in 1991. But he said that with continued weakness in consumer spending, sales-tax revenues - which contribute two-thirds of the state budget - could fall further still. 
 
'Everything Is on the Table'
''If the income isn't there, the outgo can't be there, either,'' Mr. O'Neill said.
Mr. O'Neill said that ''as of this moment'' he did not intend to ask for further tax increases when he presents his budget to the General Assembly next month. But he stressed repeatedly that ''everything is on the table'' as the budget situation unfolds.
Budget officials said the numbers have spiraled downward in just the last few months. The last projection, for example, a month ago, called for a $3.2 million surplus for the fiscal year ending June 30. Three months ago, the projected surplus was $92.9 million.
The General Assembly's Office of Fiscal Analysis has projected a deficit of $51.5 million in the current fiscal year and a shortfall of $417 million in the next.
 
Long-Term Care for Elderly
The state's Secretary of Policy and Management, Anthony V. Milano, said the projected $65 million deficit reflects nearly $55 million in higher-than-expected Medicaid payments, particularly for long-term care for the elderly.
He said that $25 million more in housing and energy costs have resulted from a recent court order requiring the state to provide long-term shelter to homeless families, who were previously put up in motels for a maximum of 100 days.
And the sales tax, raised to 8 percent from 7.5 percent on July 1 and the highest state sales-tax rate in the nation, has brought in $27 million less than expected. Corporate income taxes have brought $25 million less. Connecticut has a tax on dividends and interest but no broad-based income tax.
Mr. Milano said that the effects of cutting 2,000 state jobs will not be felt immediately, and will also be partially obscured by an early-retirement package that induced about 3,000 workers to leave their jobs over the last six months.
 
Jobs Will Be Eliminated
About 1,000 of the new job cuts, for example, will be applied to jobs that are now unfilled because of the retirement plan, he said. The remaining 1,000 will be eliminated as they open up because of future retirements, transfers and deaths, he added.
Mr. O'Neill said he hoped residents would not be hurt by the employment cuts, but they probably would be inconvenienced, if only by longer lines for things like driver-license renewals. Emergency services, he stressed, will be maintained.
Mr. O'Neill, whose popularity dropped last year after he signed into law almost $900 million in higher taxes, has vowed to run for re-election to a third four-year term this fall if his health permits. Asked whether the new numbers and the likelihood of another difficult legislative session gave him any reason to reconsider his decision, Mr. O'Neill responded that he was more determined than ever.
Mr. O'Neill's Republican challengers, who already are using last year's tax increases as a main element of their attacks, also seemed determined to use the new budget figures for all they're worth politically.
United States Representative John G. Rowland, for example, generally said to be the Republican front-runner, said in a statement that he thought the budget news had ''dashed the optimism and hope that Connecticut residents brought to the start of this new decade.''

HEADLINE: State of State: Proposals by the Dozen

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The annual State of the State address, which Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will deliver here on Wednesday, is often described as a road map for the coming year, filled with gubernatorial directives and proposals. But it also has its share of dead ends.
In last year's State of the State Message, for example, Mr. Cuomo described almost 300 different matters as requiring attention, either through action by a state agency or vote of the Legislature.
And despite action in many areas, at least half the ideas the Governor described last year are undone or in what state spokesmen call pilot stages. 
The incipient programs include major proposals like creating special residences for families with a member suffering from AIDS and more modest initiatives like an educational campaign on the safety of eating fish from the ocean near New York. Three agencies - the Departments of Health, Environmental Conservation and State -are still working to coordinate the fish campaign, although a brochure has been published, spokesmen said.
 
The Length of the List
Many of the Governor's proposals that did not come to pass fell victim to disagreements between him and an often contrary Legislature. Ideas he cites in the State of the State Message often emerge as bills that his office submits to lawmakers; of 167 such bills offered last year, 57 became law, according to figures supplied by Mr. Cuomo's office.
Administration officials point out that the Governor always proposes far more than he knows can be accomplished in a year and therefore does not worry about what will not get done.
''It's really an aspiration, not an expectation,'' Mr. Cuomo's spokesman, Gary Fryer, said of the address. ''If any Governor actually accomplished everything in the State of the State,'' he said, ''then he or she should be impeached, because obviously that person wouldn't be trying hard enough.''
Some of the Governor's ideas have perennially gone down to defeat. But he continues to propose them anyway, often using partisan terms to fault Republicans for the lack of progress.
 
Declining Success Rate
The Governor has almost always called for a new penalty of life without parole, his alternative to the death penalty, for some murderers and for a bill to divest the state's holdings in companies that do business with South Africa. Lawmakers have rejected both.
The Governor's success rate last year was unusually low. He gained passage of about a third of the bills he sent up while in most previous years the rate was 50 to 60 percent, his counsel, Evan A. Davis, said.
Last year it sometimes seemed that the Legislature's highest priority was to adjourn by early summer, and in the press of time, Mr. Cuomo proposed dozens of less controversial measures that were simply not taken up.
Still, many measures were left hanging at the close of the session, and the Governor's staff was criticized for not pushing to have them resolved. ''For a variety of reasons, some of which would have to be traced to the Governor himself, a lot of good ideas never seemed to get a serious hearing last year,'' said Lee Wasserman, executive director of the Environmental Planning Lobby.
Among the proposals Mr. Wasserman cited were a tax to combat land speculation in the Adirondacks and a bill to allow citizens to sue suspected polluters.
The proposal for the AIDS residence is still getting off the ground. Officials have selected a site in the Highbridge section of the Bronx for up to 40 families. But the opening of the center is still at least a year away, a spokesman for the Social Services Department, Paul Elisha, said.
 
Battle Against Inflation
In some cases, it is difficult to say whether certain of the Governor's goals were achieved. For instance, citing the need for fiscal restraint, he repeatedly called for an increase in the state budget that would be below the inflation rate.
The ultimate increase in spending voted by the Legislature was 5.1 percent. But it is hard to say whether that will represent less than the inflation rate.
The national inflation rate is 4.7 percent, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and there is no official rate for New York State. But aides to Mr. Cuomo, pointing to high inflation in the New York City metropolitan region, estimate the annual inflation rate to be ''somewhere between 5.2 and 5.3 percent,'' said Anne M. Doyle, a spokeswoman for the budget division. Using that standard, the administration can maintain that New York met its goal.
Roadblocks from the Legislature are hardly surprising, especially because the State Senate is controlled by Republicans.
''Are we consciously giving the Governor a hard time?'' asked Senator Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Saratoga Springs and a frequent critic of Mr. Cuomo. ''Oh no. Don't say that. Let's just say we often have different priorities.''
Beyond that split and the rush to adjourn, some officials - Democrats, mainly - said new ideas moved more slowly last year because there was new leadership in the Republican-controlled Senate.
''You have to take that into account,'' James A. Yates, counsel to Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, said. ''The Governor's people threw a lot of bills out there. But I think there was more of a wait-and-see attitude on the Republican side.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Assembly chamber in Albany was prepared yesterday for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's annual State of the State Message by Alfred Lettieri, left, and Dennis Mauro. Mr. Cuomo is expected to propose the largest environmental bond issue in state history in the message today. (NYT/David Jennings)

HEADLINE: Bronx Councilman in Line For Top Post on Land Use

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
As the New York City Council begins assuming greater powers under a new charter, its leadership has hired staff members, raised salaries and shaken up its most important committess.
The maneuvering is expected to continue today with the naming of Councilman Jerry L. Crispino of the Bronx to head the newly created Land Use Committee, which will regulate virtually all public and private land use in the city. At the same time, Herbert E. Berman of Brooklyn is to replace Councilman Michael DeMarco of the Bronx as head of the Finance Committee.
Traditionally, City Council committees have been divided among the boroughs, and it was fairly certain that Mr. DeMarco would lose his position once it was decided that Mr. Crispino would take over Land Use. Mr. DeMarco has often feuded with Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, who assigns committee posts. 
''The Bronx couldn't have both,'' Mr. Vallone said, adding that his criteria for making assignments was ''ability, seniority and geography.''
''In all appointments that you make, that has to be taken into consideration,'' he said.
 
Some Civic Groups Upset
The decision to appoint Mr. Crispino has upset several civic groups and advocates for low-income housing. The groups questioned Mr. Crispino's experience for the post, campaign contributions that he has received from the real-estate industry and his ability to devote time to what most expect to be an all-consuming assignment. Mr. Crispino also has a law practice.
Records of the New York City Campaign Contribution Board show that Mr. Crispino received $240 last year from the real-estate developer Donald J. Trump. The Councilman said he also received a contribution from the Real Estate Board, ''and probably from my next-door neighbor.''
''If anyone is going to give me $200 or $300 and think that will have any influence on me, they're dead wrong,'' Mr. Crispino said. ''I've been a councilman for 15 years, and no one has ever questioned my integrity.''
 
One Group Disappointed
But Christoper Meyer, legislative director of the New York Public Interest Research Group, said his organization was disappointed with Mr. Crispino's selection.
''The chairman is going to have a pretty full plate, and the position needs a full-time legislator,'' he said. ''This is a very important committee, arguably the most important.''
The new committee will have three subcommittees because ''land use will involve almost half the work of the Council,'' Mr. Vallone said.
He would not confirm the members of what he called the ''Land Use team.'' But some Council members said that in addition to Mr. Crispino as chairman, the committee would include Robert J. Dryfoos of Manhattan, Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens and Priscilla Wooten of Brooklyn, each of whom will head a subcommittee.
Mr. McCaffrey, a former Community Board member and an important part of the Queens Democratic organization, has served on the Council's committees on aging, parks, public safety and transportation. Ms. Wooten has been a member of Council committees on civil service, consumer affairs, health, parks and youth.
On Sept. 1 the Land Use Committee will assume from the Board of Estimate power over all land-use decisions in the five boroughs, likely making its chairman one of the most influential figures in the city. Land-use decisions are often the most politically charged and difficult matters that face municipal government.
 
Concern About Experience
''That is probably the most critical appointment that will be made for chair of a city committee,'' said Bonnie Brower, executive director of the Association of Neighborhood and Housing Development. Of Mr. Crispino, she said:
''He has not served on the housing and development committee. He has not served on economic development. He has not served on environmental protection. As far as I can determine, he hasn't served on any committee or been involved in any issue that would prepare him for taking the lead in one of the most critical areas facing the city.''
Mr. Vallone said the concerns about Mr. Crispino were unfounded.
''He was formerly a deputy commissioner for the City Department of Real Estate,'' Mr. Vallone said, ''so he has the credentials. But no Council member can have the experience for this job, because it's a new experiment.''
He said Mr. Crispino, who is 59 years old and has been on the Council since 1974, was an ideal candidate because he was ''very deliberate and a very open person to every point of view.''
Mr. Crispino has served as chairman of the Committee on Health and the Committee on Public Safety.
 
Pledge to Avoid Conflicts
The Bronx Councilman said part of his law practice included some real-estate matters. He represents people selling one- and two-family houses and occasionally multiple dwellings, he said.
And while he said that he would not close his law office, he wrote to Mr. Vallone saying, ''I and my associate have not in the past, nor will we in the future, represent real-estate developers or others likely to have business before the new Land Use Committee.''
Questions have also been raised about Mr. Dryfoos, the expected new head of a subcommittee on zoning and planning, and his work as a lawyer in co-operative apartment conversions. Mr. Dryfoos said yesterday that he would divest himself of any work involving co-op conversions.
The committee changes will be announced today during the Council's meeting. The full Council will have to vote on the appointments, but Mr. Vallone is believed to be firmly in control.
But Mr. Berman, who is expected to replace Mr. DeMarco as finance chairman, said, ''I've been around too long to expect anything until it happens.''

LENGTH: 803 words

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Lessons

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
American grade schoolers can be forgiven if they occasionally confuse their classrooms with aviaries.
Teachers routinely assign them to reading and math groups, designating them as robins, bluebirds or cardinals - euphemisms for smart, average and not-so-swift.
The ornithological approach to classroom management is a form of ''tracking,'' or putting students in classes with peers of similar ability. It is a practice notable for its pervasiveness and for the absence of scholarly evidence that it works. 
Last June the Carnegie Council on Adolescent Development called for an end to tracking in middle schools, characterizing it as ''one of the most divisive and damaging school practices in existence.'' A growing number of educators agree that tracking is, indeed, for the birds.
Tracking was the 19th century's answer to the built-in conflict of public education in a democratic society: how to achieve academic distinction while trying to teach everyone. The Solomonic solution was to differentiate, with rigorous courses for those deemed able to handle them and watered-down alternatives for the rest.
The most extreme tracking occurs in high schools, where students are routed into academic, general or vocational programs that become, in effect, schools within schools. Elementary schools usually maintain heterogeneous classes for most instruction, sorting students for only reading and math. Middle schools use variations on both.
The theory of tracking seems sound enough. Common sense suggests that students do best in a comfortable environment where the teaching is geared to their level. Tracking means that teachers do not have to ''teach to the middle'' at the risk of confusing slow students and boring the brightest.
In practice, though, tracking does not always seem so wonderful. Robert Slavin of Johns Hopkins University recently surveyed research in which students were randomly assigned to heterogeneous and tracked classes and concluded that ''as far as achievement is concerned, the effects for both high- and low-achieving students is neutral.''
Adam Gamoran, a sociologist at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, questions Mr. Slavin's reading of the evidence, arguing that high-achievers gain by tracking and low-achievers lose. ''The overall result is no change, but the resulting inequalities are considerable,'' he said.
In a 1986 article in the education journal Phi Delta Kappan, Jeannie Oakes, a Rand Corporation social scientist, argued that the students in the lower tracks - that is to say, most students - ''suffer clear and consistent disadvantages'' from the practice, including low self-esteem and low expectations that become self-fulfilling prophecies.
A major reason, she said, is that the top tracks get the best teaching.
At the Niedig Elementary School in Quakertown, Pa., near Allentown, the teachers scrapped reading and math groups as counterproductive. ''It was fine to have the teacher concentrate on a small group of students for a while,'' the District Superintendent, George E. Taylor, said. ''But while this was happening, the other groups ended up with worksheets and busywork.''
Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, argues that, given its deep roots, tracking will never be eliminated from ''didactic'' classrooms where teachers do most of the talking. But why not reframe the issue by getting away from ''didactic'' classrooms?
A number of solutions have been proposed. Mr. Slavin's research has produced abundant evidence that cooperative learning - in which small groups of students work together on problems - is highly effective. ''Say you're working on solving simultaneous equations,'' he said. ''The slow students do well, and the high achievers, who probably do a lot of the explaining, get a deeper grasp of the material.''
Schedules can be changed. In Bolton Landing, N.Y., on Lake George, all high school students take the same high-level Regents courses in English and social studies for five periods a week. Then a sixth period is devoted to individualized instruction - enrichment for the top students and remedial work for those having trouble. ''Getting rid of tracking has made for a much more harmonious social climate in the school,'' the Superintendent, Dalton F. Marks, said.
Computer-assisted instruction offers another alternative by allowing students in the same classroom to work at different paces. Steve Anderson, principal of the Cougar Valley Elementary School in Silverdale, Wash., said this could solve the problem of what to do with bright but socially immature students who typically skip a grade or two. ''Now you can meet their intellectual needs without sacrificing social ones,'' he said.
In short, birds of a feather need not flock together - at least in classrooms.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Reaction Mixed to Certification Plan

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
An agreement among seven Northeast states that will ease restrictions for teachers who want to cross state lines for a job is getting a mixed reaction from educators.
Under the agreement, reached last month and due to take effect in April, teachers certified in any of the six New England states and New York will be eligible for a ''regional credential'' that allows them to teach most subjects in any of the other states. In most cases, the credential will be valid for two years, during which teachers must fulfill any unmet certification requirements in the new state.
Many educators say the arrangement will allow teachers to move in response to supply and demand for jobs and will attract new teachers to the region. In addition to New York, the participants are Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont. Critics note that not all the states are fully cooperating in the agreement, and they say the credential does not address other obstacles to teacher mobility. For example, often teachers who move cannot begin a new job until they have met teaching certification requirements in their new state, which means facing a period of unemployment. 
 
'A Good Sell' for Teachers
Susan Tave Zelman, an associate commissioner for the Massachusetts Department of Education, said the new regional compact is ''a good sell'' for attracting teachers to Northeast states. ''You say, 'You come here to get certified, and you'll be eligible for a regional teaching certificate for six other states,' '' she said.
Rosanne K. Bacon, president of the Massachusetts Teachers Association, said the compact may also force states within the region to raise teachers' salaries.
The two states not fully cooperating are Maine, which will give teachers only one year instead of two to fulfill state certification requirements, and Connecticut, which will accept the regional credential only for teachers of industrial arts.
Betty J. Sternberg, a Connecticut education official, said, ''We have what we consider to be very rigorous certification standards which our board and commissioner do not want in any way to tamper with.'' She added that because the pay scale in her state is one of the highest in the United States, Connecticut has had no problem attracting teachers.
The bigger sticking point is that the regional plan does not preserve seniority-based salaries and pensions.
 
'Back to a Beginning Pay'
''Right now one of the biggest barriers to teachers is that they can have 15 years of experience and when they move they have to go all the way back to a beginning salary,'' said Bella Rosenberg, assistant to the president of the American Federation of Teachers, a national teachers union.
Paul L. Devlin, president of the Massachusetts Federation of Teachers, called the regional credential ''a good beginning,'' but said teachers must be able to preserve accrued pensions.
Last summer Rhode Island became the first state to pass a law allowing teachers to take accrued pension money with them when they move in or out of state, provided the other state involved has a reciprocal agreement. So far, no other state has passed such a policy, although similar legislation is pending in Massachusetts and under study in several other states.
David P. Crandall, executive director of the federally supported Regional Laboratory for Educational Improvement of the Northeast and Islands, which helped develop the credential, acknowledged there are shortcomings. ''I think what we're seeing here is the realities of what happens when you jump onto a moving train,'' he said. ''It may not be ideal, but when you're working with seven independent jurisidictions, it's pretty significant.''
The Northeast Regional Credential was formed by the seven states as part of a larger project, the Northeast Common Market, undertaken two years ago in an attempt to study and improve education in the region.
Other states, including New Jersey and Pennsylvania, have expressed an interest in joining the compact, said Rick Basom, a program director at the Regional Laboratory.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Stephen Holden

 BODY:
Among the innovations the 1980's brought to pop music were the rise of MTV, home videos, the compact disk and rap. But what comes next? The heads of three major record companies were invited to speculate on what the 90's might hold for pop music technologically, stylistically and in the techniques for breaking - record company parlance for commercially establishing - performers.
Bob Krasnow, the chairman of Elektra Records, signed Tracy Chapman to the label and is known for his progressive tastes. Tommy Mottola, the president of CBS Records, oversaw the company's economic turnaround in the fall. The turnaround was led by the Boston group New Kids on the Block, whose three albums have sold more than 14 million copies. Clive Davis, who started Arista Records 15 years ago, helped pilot the careers of Barry Manilow and Whitney Houston and signed Milli Vanilli to the label. 
Here are their reflections and predictions.
 
Bob Krasnow
''We're in for a very explosive decade and a very positive one,'' said Mr. Krasnow of Elektra Records. ''Going into the 90's, the main forces at work on music are technology, the world's ability to communicate with itself and the fact that Rome is burning.
''The record industry has always been a leader in mirroring the social qualities and inequities of life. The Watergate years followed by the Reagan years of uncaring have set up an incredible dam of feeling that is now just beginning to break. People will become much more involved in improving both the ecological and the social environment, and the music will reflect that.
''I've always thought that it was possible to dance and think at the same time, and in the 1990's that possibility will become reality.
''At the same time, we have the emerging climate of world music. It's no longer so strange to hear a record in a foreign language anymore. At the same time that we've been finding more receptivity in the world market for American music, we're importing music from places like Bulgaria, France and Brazil that either celebrates a great ethnic tradition or a life style, like the Gipsy Kings.
''Quincy Jones was right when he said that rap is the jazz of the 90's. These records are very hip and draw on a lot of jazz as well as on James Brown. And from a message point of view, there's certainly a lot going on.
''Music video should represent a third of our dollar volume by the mid-90's. We've had a lot of success with home videos featuring Motley Crue, Metallica and Anita Baker. By the mid-90's, you should be able to buy a video in a compact-disk form and be able to play it either as a video or as an album.''
 
Tommy Mottola
''CBS has been looking for alternative ways of breaking new artists,'' said Mr. Mottola of CBS Records. ''What we want to do is to take exceptionally talented people we feel have staying power and break them, although it may take two or three albums to do it. We're not interested in one-hit wonders. The result will be more diverse kinds of developing artists, whose music is not necessarily linked to Top 40 radio formats.
''Touring is going to become a major factor once again in breaking new artists. The club scene will also become super important, whether the clubs be jazz, rhythm-and-blues or rock-oriented.
''Rap is going to be around for a while, though in a couple of years it may develop into a pop hybrid that involves more music and singing and less pure rapping.
''Home video will become a much bigger area with consumers. We already see retail stores in which home video takes up half the floor space and prerecorded music the other half. I don't know what will happen with the music-video channels. Just as we are not going to be led by radio programmers' tastes, we're not going to look to video channels for trends, but rather present artists we think make great music and have a lot to say.
''Acoustic music is going to grow and develop. It's been refreshing to hear music as pure as that made by Tracy Chapman and the Indigo Girls. They've helped make audiences aware of the quality of the song and, in particular, the lyrics. Lyrics in the 90's are going to mean everything, since people will be looking not only for new rhythms but for important messages. Though I don't have a crystal ball, I think the 90's could be the most inspired decade for pop in the last 30 to 40 years.''
 
Clive Davis
''The record business itself is healthy, and I think it will continue to grow,'' said Mr. Davis of Arista Records. ''The technology of the compact disk and the portability of the cassette have insured that. Music video has been very valuable as a promotional item, and I think it's here to stay. Long-form videos have shown that they have commercial appeal and that they are no threat to the compact cassette.
''Right now, pop music really has no stylistic direction. Most of the music is for entertainment purposes. The predominant sound is a combination of pop bands and heavy metal.
''In the 1990's, I'm looking forward to new leaders in the sense of the Dylans, the Springsteens, the Princes or a new Joni Mitchell. I am encouraged that music had room for someone like Tracy Chapman, who was like a breath of fresh air. But we need more artists like her to provide meaning to the music beyond entertainment.
''When I think of all the changes that have gone on this past year in Eastern Europe, I think of the Patti Smith song ''People Have the Power,'' which we put out last year, but that didn't achieve the momentum it should have. It may be one of the most telling songs of the last two years because it so aptly describes what's going on. People do have the power. I would be disappointed if the pop lyrics of the 90's didn't have some of that pungency.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Americans Are Coming

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
TO Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, the case for discouraging European imports of American television programming is self-evident. ''Have we the right to exist, to perpetuate our traditions?'' he asked broadcasters meeting in Paris in October. They approved guidelines for 1992 limiting American programs to 50 percent of air time.
But to Eli Noam, a Columbia University economist and member of the New York State Public Service Commission, Mr. Delors's logic is far from self-evident. Restrictions on imported programming, he argues, are based on a misunderstanding of economics - a misunderstanding nurtured by cultural snobs and public television bureaucrats. 
In a forthcoming book on the globalization of television, Mr. Noam debunks the conventional wisdom that Americans would inevitably dominate an increasingly competitive programming market. Open international competition might reduce the national identity of some types of shows, he concedes, but it would almost certainly serve the interests of European producers and consumers.
European television now buys a substantial portion of its entertainment programming at bargain rates from America. For many European analysts, including the conservative Government of Margaret Thatcher, the explanation is simple: Americans dump television software in foreign markets at bargain rates - the way Koreans allegedly dump steel.
Once Americans have made a show for the domestic market for, say, $700,000, the cost of delivering copies of the film or video to a foreign television network is next to zero. It thus pays to sell programming in Europe for whatever the traffic will bear, even if that amounts to only $30,000 or $40,000. And European producers who try to compete are hopelessly underpriced.
But as Mr. Noam argues, the European tail ought to be able to wag the American dog: Once a program is domestically produced for, say, British television, it should pay the owners to sell it on the other side of the Atlantic for a tuppence.
As every fan of ''Masterpiece Theater'' knows, Europeans do export some programs. Moreover the American buyers - mostly public television and cable networks - do manage to obtain the programming below production cost. But Europeans contend that the relationship is still not symmetric because there is a bigger audience in Europe for middlebrow American imports than there is in America for highbrow European shows.
That may be true, Mr. Noam suggests, but it hardly justifies protectionism. American producers would presumably be delighted to charge more to their European customers. They cannot because European national networks informally (and sometimes formally) conspire to keep down costs by refusing to bid against each other.
These anti-competitive buying arrangements work with a vengeance. The European Broadcast Union, the sole European bidder for rights to the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, paid just 17 cents per household. ABC-TV, by contrast, paid $1.76 per household for American broadcast rights because it had to compete with NBC and CBS.
The European cultural chauvinists are thus caught in an economic bind. If they enforce tough restrictions on American imports, they will need to fill the air time with more locally produced programming. And that programming is sure to be less popular or more expensive than the American shows they are now buying - otherwise there would have been no point to the restrictions.
In any event, Mr. Noam suggests, technological change and increased competition among European networks are likely to undermine the coalition backing protection.
Europe's public television monopolies are losing the battle to keep alternative programming off the air. And as the new boys on the block, private cable and direct broadcast satellite networks like Rupert Murdoch's Skyvision have powerful incentives to pay premium rates for the splashiest programming. The higher prices commanded for American shows will in turn increase the financial incentives for their European competitors to produce comparably slick mass-market programming.
That may mean the decline of a distinctly European style of television. But as Mr. Noam points out, European citizens of the global village may not mourn the loss for long. In late 19th-century Germany, he notes, the Kaiser's loyal followers preferred group calesthenics developed during the Prussian war of liberation to team sports from alien England. ''How many Germans citizens today,'' he wonders, ''know that their indigenous culture is being eroded by attendance at soccer games?''

HEADLINE: Bank of Boston Acts to Offset Bad Property Loans

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Bank of Boston Corporation yesterday announced additional losses from its real estate lending but said it expected to break even in the fourth quarter as the losses were offset by profits from selling most of its credit card business to the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the restructuring of its pension fund.
As the largest banking company in New England, the Bank of Boston has been hit hard by the weakness in real estate in the region. After lending heavily to construct new condominiums and office buildings when real estate prices were rising rapidly, the bank has had trouble collecting on loans to developers now that real estate prices are weak and vacancies are rising.
About three months ago, real estate problems caused the bank to set aside additional reserves, which resulted in a $125 million loss for the third quarter. In the fourth quarter, the Boston banking company said it was adding $280 million to its reserve for loan losses, and would write off $300 million of loans. 
 
Real Estate Holdings Climb
The banking company's holdings of real estate, mostly acquired through foreclosure on bad loans, rose to $600 million from $300 million, and $200 million more of loans became non-performing during the quarter. Non-performing loans, which are 90 days in arrears or whose prospects are poor, declined to $1.1 billion at the end of the year from $1.5 billion on Sept. 30 because of the $300 million charge-off and the increase in real estate holdings.
To offset the losses from real estate, the Bank of Boston said yesterday that it had sold $645 million of credit card receivables to Chase, which has been a heavy buyer of credit card receivables this year. Chase paid a premium for the receivables, resulting in a pretax profit of about $145 million for the Bank of Boston.
The Bank of Boston also added about $50 million to its fourth-quarter earnings by financing a part of its pension plan with annuity contracts purchased from insurance companies. The gain occurred because the pension plan held stocks, bonds and other assets whose value exceeded the cost of the annuity contracts.
 
Stock Rises 75 Cents, to $19.75
Bank of Boston stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $19.75. In addition to the stimulus from the large gain in broad stock market indexes, analysts said the rise in Bank of Boston stock reflected speculation by some buyers that the company was nearing the end of its problems.
Thomas J. Tisch, who in combination with other members of his family has bought more than 6 percent of Bank of Boston's stock since late October, said last week that even if the company was to announce additional loan losses, he was convinced that it was a fundamentally sound company whose stock was ''over penalized'' by the troubles of the region's economy.
Several analysts cautioned that problems in the New England economy were not diminishing and that banks in that region might find even more troubled loans in the future.
Ira Stepanian, the chief executive at the Bank of Boston, said that the New England economy deteriorated in the fourth quarter and that there are ''continuing uncertain economic conditions for 1990.''
Virginia Adair, a banking analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert, said that ''I expect there will be at least two more quarters of continued problems at Bank of Boston, with increases in loan loss reserves and increases in nonperforming assets.''
For Chase, the purchase of Bank of Boston's credit card business was the fifth acquisition in the last 12 months. Including another small purchase at the end of 1988 from the Investors Savings Bank in Richmond, Chase has purchased about two million credit card accounts this year, while adding a million accounts through its own marketing efforts.
David J. Cornell, a vice president at Chase, said that pretax profits of 4 to 4.5 percent on credit-card receivables made the business one where Chase expected to continue to expand through acquisition and growth of its existing business. Chase said it is the second-largest bank in the credit card business in the country, with nine million accounts and more than $9 billion in credit card receivables outstanding. Citibank is the largest bank in the business, with considerably more than 20 million accounts.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Union Pacific Agrees To Sell Real Estate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The Union Pacific Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell most of the assets of its Union Pacific Realty subsidiary to a California real estate investment firm for about $532 million.
The firm, the Koll Company, will acquire about 15,000 acres and 30 buildings, mostly in the Western United States, that are in various stages of development and leasing. Harvey S. Turner, a Union Pacific spokesman, said the real estate included acreage, industrial parks and buildings in Southern California, Denver, Salt Lake City and Washington state. 
Koll, a private company involved in real estate construction and asset management, said it planned to make the acquisition with an unidentified partner through UBS Securities Inc. in New York.
Union Pacific, the railroad company with headquarters in Bethlehem, Pa., said in April that it would divest itself of its realty company and buy back stock to concentrate on its core railroad and transportation businesses and to help raise its stock price to $100 a share.
The company's stock jumped $3.125 today, to $79.75 a share, in New York Stock Exchange trading.
In May, the company bought back about 11 million shares for $73 each. Union Pacific has already sold more than $125 million in property. It continues to market for sale about 1,000 remaining acres in New Orleans, Denver, Long Beach, Calif., and Las Vegas, Nev. Most of the property had been acquired by Union Pacific for its railroad or for investment.
Koll, based in Newport Beach, Calif., owns more than four million square feet of industrial and retail real estate in the Western United States.
The company said its purchase of Union Pacific's real estate represented its single largest acquisition.
''The portfolio contains a number of real finely located parcels of industrial property as well as existing industrial and office buildings,'' said Chuck Schreiber, Koll's senior vice president of acquisitions.
Mr. Schreiber said that Koll intended to develop much of the land it was acquiring and that it would sell other pieces. While some of the property is in markets that have experienced price declines through recession, he said: ''This is not a fire sale. This is a quality portfolio.'' Union Pacific said only a few small properties had been sold at a loss.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Murdoch Hires Outsider To Run British Papers

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
To hear Rupert Murdoch tell it, the British portion of his publishing and television empire is consuming too much of his time, and Andrew Knight is just the man to do something about it.
Mr. Murdoch announced yesterday that Mr. Knight, who spent the last four years turning the Sunday and daily Telegraph newspapers into money makers, will become executive chairman and chief executive of News International P.L.C., the British subsidiary of the News Corporation. The appointment is effective in March. 
In succeeding Mr. Murdoch in that capacity, Mr. Knight, 50, will be responsible for the publishing operations of News International. Its newspaper holdings include The Times of London, Today, News of the World, and The Sun, a daily tabloid whose circulation of four million makes it Britain's biggest newspaper.
In a short telephone interview from Los Angeles, Mr. Murdoch said he would continue to oversee News International's Sky Television, the fledgling four-channel satellite service that is losing some $3.2 million a week. He also intends to spend more time in the United States, where the News Corporation owns the Fox television stations and programming operations.
''I'm spending 25 percent of my time in Britain,'' said Mr. Murdoch, who will continue to serve as the News Corporation's chief executive. ''I need to cut that down.'' Mr. Knight, whom Mr. Murdoch called ''the most accomplished executive and editor in British publishing,'' was editor of The Economist magazine for 12 years before joining The Daily Telgraph P.L.C. as chief executive and editor in chief. The Telegraph's 1989 profits are expected to total about 40 million ($64.6 million), up from 29 million ($46.8 million) in 1988.
Mr. Knight is credited with modernizing The Telegraph by introducing more features and news analysis and by aggressively marketing the conservative paper.
He also earned a reputation as a tough boss by cutting the Telegraph's staff by more than half. And he recently forced journalists to make concessions aimed at increasing productivity.

HEADLINE: Construction Outlays Up In November

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Construction spending rose 1.5 percent in November, hitting a 10-month high, the Commerce Department reported today.
The department said that government spending rose 7 percent in the month, pushing total outlays to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $421.7 billion, the highest level since $423 billion last January.
David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Corporation, attributed the jump to lower interest rates and to rebuilding after Hurricane Hugo, which hit South Carolina on Sept. 21, and the San Francisco Bay-area earthquake, which struck on Oct. 17. 
 
Response to Lower Rates
''I think a reasonable argument can be made that some of the government spending was disaster related,'' he said.
Mr. Berson noted that the government sector had been growing strongly since July, meaning that not all of the advance should be attributed to the disasters. Government spending totaled $91.4 billion on an annual rate.
Residential spending increased six-tenths of 1 percent, to $194.4 billion, on an annual rate, helped by a 1.5 percent gain in single-family housing and a 4.7 percent jump in apartment building.
''What we're seeing here is a response by builders to lower mortgage rates and increased sales,'' Mr. Berson said. ''We're likely to see that edging up for the next several months, but I don't think we're going to see any surges because builders will remain very cautious.''
The Federal Reserve began letting short-term interest rates fall gradually in June, as inflation moderated and the economy showed signs of sluggishness. The central bank had propped up the rates initially to stem inflationary pressures.
By the end of November, fixed-rate mortgage rates were 9.74 percent, according to a survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. They had peaked at 11.22 percent in March.
Despite lower interest rates, construction of nonresidential buildings was down seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $100.7 billion, on an annual rate. Industrial construction advanced 1.7 percent, to $18.1 billion.
The total construction figure was up 1.5 percent from the level of building a year ago.

HEADLINE: U.S. Economy Stayed In Slump in December

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The economy remained in a slump in December, although production levels rose and exports expanded, the nation's purchasing managers said in a monthly report.
In the report, the National Association of Purchasing Management said that its index of economic activity rose to 48 percent in December from 46.6 percent in November. The index is at its highest level since June 1989. 
A reading below 50 indicates that the manufacturing sector of the economy is in a decline, while a reading above 50 percent indicates an expansion. A reading below 44 indicates a decline in real gross national product.
''The index is up, but not to a level to suggest any serious strength in the economy,'' said Burton Zwick, senior economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company. ''The economy in manufacturing is very slow, and there is a significant risk of a recession. The purchasing managers' index is still meaningfully below 50 percent and has been that way for months now.''
 
Wide Range of Companies
The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because it is compiled from information supplied by managers from a range of industrial companies.
The dollar and stock prices rose in reaction to the report as it suggested the economy might not be so soft as previously thought.
The monthly report indicated that new export orders continued to expand, the report said, although the rate of growth was below that of the previous month. Also, prices declined for the seventh consecutive month, at a slightly higher rate than in November. And vendor deliveries were faster.
Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee, said that although the index was the highest since June 1989, ''the steady declines in both the vendor delivery index and the price index confirms a continued weakness in the underlying economy in this, the eighth year of recovery.''
The new-orders index rose to 50.4 percent in December from 48.1 percent in November, the second month that the index exceeded 50 percent.
 
Production Index Up to 50.6%
After five months of decline, the purchasing managers' group reported that production increased in December. The production index rose to 50.6 percent, from 48.6 percent.
The vendor delivery index was the lowest since May 1982, registering at 42.2 percent, down from 42.5 percent in November. The association said that the number of items in short supply increased to 13 from 10 in November. Among those were bearings, electric motors, hydrogen peroxide, nylon and milk.
The association also said that inventories declined in December, marking a full year of monthly declines. The decline was attributed to manufacturers' reducing their end-of-the-year inventory levels.
Prices declined for the seventh straight month, at a somewhat faster pace than in November, the report said. The price index fell to 41.9 percent, down from 42.7 percent in November and the lowest level since June 1985, when it was 42.4 percent. The report indicated higher prices for a number of products, including hydraulics, benzine, coal, sugar and freon. Lower prices were reported for aluminum, copper, steel, ethylene, orange juice and corn starch.
The report also said manufacturing employment declined for the 11th straight month. The employment index rose to 46.9 percent, up slightly from 46.8 percent in November.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Predicting The Trends Of the 1990's

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
IF the 1980's witnessed the transformation of advertising agencies into diversified marketing/communications conglomerates, the 1990's will mark the continuing evolution in the advertising images that Americans will see and in the companies that will provide them.
Although they differed on who advertising's winners and losers might be through the coming decade, three dozen top advertising and marketing executives concurred in predicting that the top ad news of the 1990's will revolve around technology, geography, creativity and agency structure. The following is a sample of their forecasts:
Media, in new forms and old, will proliferate. ''There will be more choices for consumers in terms of media, and more choices within each medium,'' said Brad R. Moore, division vice president of advertising at Hallmark Cards Inc. ''It will make it more complex for us to reach consumers with advertising, and to make sure we're not neglecting whole groups of consumers who are not watching the typical mass media.'' 
But James C. Reilly, general manager of marketing plans and communications at the International Business Machines Corporation, saw ''a paradox.''
''While new media will be important to reach segmented markets,'' he said, ''at the same time it will lead to more clutter and media choice for the end-user.''
New research technologies will enable advertisers to aim at individual consumers. ''The history of commercially successful media in this country has been tied to an audience-measurement system that advertisers and agencies accept, like Nielsen,'' said William M. Weilbacher, an advertising consultant. ''Single-source data is the big area of growth - you make a lot of different kinds of measurements off an individual. One of the things that will do is provide the measurement capability to permit this media revolution.''
Malcolm MacDougall, the vice chairman of Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, saw this changing the way advertising is judged. ''New technological devices will allow us to track sales almost instantly,'' he said. ''We'll have electronic monitoring of the ads we create. The result of that will be more accountability than we've ever seen.''
The giant ad agencies will collapse. While this belief was universal among executives at smaller agencies, Hank Seiden, chief executive of Ketchum Advertising, New York, cautioned that it might not be a benefit for smaller shops. ''More clients will go toward house agencies,'' he said. ''One of the first breaks was Ron Perelman at Revlon. He found Dick Tarlow, fell in love with him and then bought his agency.''
Many medium and small agencies will disappear. This view was widely held by executives of large agencies and clients. ''They'll have to be part of the global operations, because they can't survive the financial squeezes,'' said Eugene P. Beard, the chief financial officer of the Interpublic Group of Companies. ''And clients will want global agencies. Agencies like Jordan, Bloom and Hill, Holliday, with $200 million or even $500 million in billings - they'll have to join up with the globals.''
Clay S. Timon, head of worldwide advertising for the Colgate-Palmolive Company, agreed. ''I think you'll see a continuing consolidation of major chunks of business with major agency groups,'' he said. ''We have two; Lever has four core agencies.''
Advertisers will rediscover the importance of strategic ideas. ''I see the 1990's as returning to a product-benefit emphasis in advertising,'' said David E.R. Dangoor, vice president of marketing at Philip Morris U.S.A. The reason: ''In the '90's there will be some tightening of economic circumstances, and consumers will buy only what they need. That will make them more skeptical of advertising that doesn't address their needs.''
Slogans and brand imagery will make a comeback. ''From the time we grew up, we look back and remember brand values and symbols and slogans and images,'' said Barrie J. Webster, president of Berenter, Greenhouse & Webster. ''They'll become increasingly important because you'll need something that can travel through many forms of media and remain consistent.''
John Ferrell, executive creative director of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos/New York, forecast ads ''like the old Y.& R. campaign for Frito-Lay - 'Nobody can eat just one.' Ideas like that really make money.''
Japanese ad agencies will make their power felt. ''The Dentsus are going to come alive,'' said Mr. Seiden of Ketchum, echoing a fear held by many ad executives. ''And American agencies will go to the Japanese to sell for top dollar, which will make the Japanese less reluctant to come here.''
Caroline R. Jones, president of the New York agency that bears her name, predicted that the Japanese will have their greatest impact on advertising creativity. ''The Japanese already have had an influence, certainly in a graphic and photographic sense,'' she said. ''They set the standards at the film advertising festivals when they do either demonstration or comparison ads.''

HEADLINE: C.D.'s, Bank Funds Steady

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday.
According to some analysts, the absence of movement in the rates reflects the lack of a clear direction in the economy. In addition, Robert T. Hennes, executive vice president at Dollar Dry Dock Bank, said, ''The credit markets are increasingly addicted to doses of monetary easing, and recent events have suggested that the Fed will ease slower than had been expected.'' 
At the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction of three-month and six-month bills yesterday, interest rates declined sharply. The auction results are considered an influence over what many banks pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposits.
The average rate for a three-month bill dropped 13 basis points, to 7.64 percent, while the rate for a six-month bill fell 12 basis points, to 7.52 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Yields Mixed in New York
The Bank Rate Monitor's weekly survey of New York area banks showed certificate yields at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed.
At commercial banks, the yield on an average money market account declined 3 basis points, to 6.62 percent, while a three-month certificate rose a basis point, to 7.94 percent, and a six-month certificate fell a basis point, to 7.79 percent.
Meanwhile, money market accounts at savings institutions were unchanged, at 6.62 percent. Yields on certificates of deposit were weak, with the average three-month maturity off 4 basis points, to 8.12 percent, and the average six-month certificate down 3 basis points, to 8.16 percent.
Among 20 large banks nationwide, the average yield on money market accounts was unchanged, at 6.44 percent, with six-month certificates down 2 basis points, to 7.81 percent.
Yields offered on certificates and money market accounts held at large credit unions have been mixed for about a month. Money market accounts declined 3 basis points, to 6.74 percent, while six-month and five-year certificates both increased a basis point, to 8.11 percent and 8.24 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Down Slightly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The credit markets opened the new year on a somewhat sour note yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in light trading.
''The stock market has started the year off favorably, but there is very little retail activity in our market,'' said Neil Dubrow, a vice president at Voute, Coats, Stuart & O'Grady, a bond trading firm in Greenwich, Conn. ''The market is missing new buyers, and that is not a good way to start off the year.'' 
Market participants said that yesterday's economic news, which included a slightly higher reading in a monthly index of business conditions compiled by the nation's purchasing managers and another bad 10-day sales report from auto makers, was mixed. And a surprising rise in the dollar was virtually ignored.
Lawrence N. Leuzzi, a managing director at S.G. Warburg Securities Inc., said that ''the purchasing managers report was a mixed bag.''
''The only two numbers that pushed up the overall index were new orders and production,'' he said, ''and they were both impacted by seasonal factors. And the index, which rose to 48 percent, is still below 50, which means the economy is still contracting.''
One government bond trader said, ''The strength of the dollar was the big news, but the market is not focusing on the dollar right now. The pace of activity in December was so slow that it will take time to build some momentum. A lot of people are waiting to see what the employment numbers on Friday show before they make any decisions.''
 
Absence of Tokyo Trading
The absence of trading in Tokyo, where financial markets were closed in continued celebration of the new year, did not help the pace of activity in Treasury issues.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 101 18/32, down 5/ 32, to yield 7.98 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 21/ 32, down 2/32, to yield 7.92 percent. The 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 17/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.85 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 18/32, down 2/32, to yield 7.86 percent.
Treasury bill rates eased at the weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills. At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.64 percent, down from an average rate of 7.77 percent at last week's auction.
Meanwhile, six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 7.52 percent, down from 7.64 percent a week ago.
Elsewhere, activity in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds was very slow, dealers reported. Prices of most issues in both markets were unchanged on the day.
There were no pricings of new debt in either the investment-grade corporate bond market or in the municipal bond market.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Fed Intervenes to Slow Dollar's Rise Against Yen

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply yesterday, forcing the Federal Reserve to intervene by selling dollars several times to stem its rally against the Japanese yen.
The rally is the type of contrary move that the foreign exchange market is known for. Going into 1990, many forecasters said they expected the dollar to continue to decline, especially against the West German mark. In the beginning of 1989, forecasters also expected the dollar to decline, but it went on a nine-month rally, only to finally decline against the mark and other continental currencies. 
Traders said yesterday's rally was prompted by several factors. These included the report of the National Association of Purchasing Management, which showed its index rising to 48 percent in December from 46.6 percent in November. The improvement was greater than anticipated, indicating the economy might not be as weak as believed.
 
A Good Deal
In addition, traders said, the heavy selling of the dollar in December may have gone further than warranted, making the dollar a good buy now.
The dollar was also helped against the yen by new rumors of a political scandal in Japan that if true would hurt the Liberal Democratic Party's prospects in February's parliamentary elections, said James T. McGroarty, senior vice president at Greenwich Capital Markets Inc. in Greenwich, Conn.
Traders noted that the market was thin yesterday because the Tokyo and Zurich markets were still closed for the New Year's holiday.
In late trading in New York, the dollar was up about 2.5 yen, to 146.45 yen, from 143.89 late Friday. Against the mark, the dollar was up more than two pfennigs, to 1.7130 marks, from 1.6910 on Friday.
''When you see the dollar plunge a lot in December, you usually have a pretty good rally in January,'' Mr. McGroarty said.
He added that if Friday's unemployment report for December shows that the economy is a little stronger than expected, the Federal Reserve might delay pushing interest rates lower. The assumption that the Fed will push interest rates lower to prevent a big slowdown has led many forecasters to predict the dollar will decline in the first part of the year.
Mr. McGroarty said he expected the dollar to rise more in January. But he said he would review his view based on the Fed's actions and on developments in Eastern Europe, which at the end of last year led to a significant weakening of the dollar against the mark.

HEADLINE: H. E. Kershner, 98, A Longtime Worker In Children's Causes

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Howard E. Kershner, a businessman and an outspoken conservative about politics and economics who retired 50 years ago to devote himself to relief causes for children, died of a pulmonary ailment on Monday at the Southland Lutheran Home in Norwalk, Calif. He was 98 years old and had lived for several years in La Jolla, Calif.
Mr. Kershner was at various times a newspaper editor and publisher, a real estate operator, builder, manufacturer and author. In 1939 he retired from active business and spent the rest of his life pursuing causes in which he believed. 
Shortly before World War II, he went to Europe for the American Friends Service Committee to provide food for children on both sides of the Spanish Civil War. He later organized a broader Quaker relief effort for European children and was a member of the Committee on Food for the Small Democracies.
After the war, as vice president of the Save the Children Federation, he set up that organization's program of help to schoolchildren in Eastern and Southern Europe. He also raised money for UNICEF and was a founding member of CARE.
In 1950 Mr. Kershner organized the Christian Freedom Foundation, edited its fortnightly journal, Christian Economics, and wrote a column, ''It's Up to You,'' which was printed in 225 daily and 425 weekly newspapers. From 1967-1973 he was a lay preacher for the Congregational Church in Los Angeles. For the next several years he taught economics at the Northwood Institute in Dallas before returning to California.
Mr. Kershner was born in Tescott, Kan., and started work at the age of 12 as a newsboy and carpenter. He graduated from Friends University in Wichita, Kan., and studied economics at Harvard University before he became editor and publisher of The Dodge City (Kan.) Daily Journal.
He was awarded the Order of Leopold by the Belgian Government and the Order of Merit by the International Union for the Protection of Children, and was a member of the French Legion of Honor. He wrote several books, including ''The Menace of Roosevelt and His Policies,'' published in 1936; ''Quaker Service in Modern War'' (1950) and ''God, Gold and Government'' (1956).
Mr. Kershner's first wife, Gertrude, died in 1976. His second wife, Lenore, was killed in an automobile accident in 1981. His third wife, the former Mary DuVall, survives, as do a son, Wendell, of Hacienda Heights, Calif.; two daughters, Margaret Weber of Rochester and Linaford Bassett of South Burlington, Vt.; nine grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Noriega's Surrender: Overview;
NORIEGA GIVES HIMSELF UP TO U.S. MILITARY; IS FLOWN TO FLORIDA TO FACE DRUG CHARGES

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
President Bush announced tonight that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had surrendered to the United States military authorities in Panama, giving the President the final victory he had been seeking in the invasion of Panama.
General Noriega, who had defied American efforts to drive him from power for more than four years, was removed under cover of night from the Vatican Embassy in Panama, where he had taken refuge 10 days ago. He was then flown by United States military helicopter to Howard Air Base in Panama City, where he was arrested by agents of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration.
The general is under indictment in two Federal courts in Florida on drug trafficking charges and Mr. Bush has made bringing him to trial in the United States a major justification for invading Panama on Dec. 20 and an important aspect of his Latin American policy in general.
 
Bush Thanks the Vatican
Mr. Bush appeared in the White House briefing room at about 9:40 P.M., less than an hour after General Noriega surrendered, to announce that the deposed Panamanian strongman was aboard an Air Force C-131 transport plane bound for Homestead Air Force Base in southern Florida. 
Thanking the Vatican for its ''evenhanded, statesmanlike assistance'' in getting General Noriega into American hands, Mr. Bush told reporters at a hurriedly called White House briefing that the general would be arraigned in Federal District Court in Miami on the drug charges filed in Miami in 1988. He was also indicted in Tampa.
An Administration official who asked not to be identified said that the White House had been expecting a breakthrough in the negotiations for several days, but that General Noriega's final surrender came without warning.
 
General Sets 3 Conditions
The general had sought assurances earlier in the week that he would not face the death penalty if he surrendered and had been told that the charges against him did not carry the death penalty, the official said.
Tonight, General Noriega informed the United States through Vatican intermediaries that he was ready to surrender. The official said the general had set three conditions: he wanted the press to be kept away from the Vatican mission when he left, he wanted to be able to contact family and friends by telephone before being flown out of the country and he wanted to be able to wear his uniform when he surrendered.
The United States, acting through the Vatican diplomats, agreed to those conditions, the official said.
General Noriega left the mission at 8:48 P.M. and was aboard the C-131 transport plane by 9:08 P.M. His surrender followed a demonstration by an estimated 20,000 Panamanians who filled five blocks near the Vatican Embassy carrying signs denouncing him, including one that read ''No Mercy'' in six languages.
In an interview on the ABC News program ''Nightline,'' Archbishop Marcos McGrath of Panama said the demonstration might have nudged General Noriega into making his final decision to surrender.
Archbishop McGrath said the Papal Nuncio, Msgr. Sebastian Laboa, had met more and more frequently with General Noriega in recent days seeking to persuade the general to leave the Nunciature, where he had been kept isolated in a room on an upper floor.
In the end, the Archbishop said, General Noriega's choices ''came down to sitting indefinitely in the Nunciature surrounded by a hostile nation and the armed forces of the United States, or turning himself over to one or the other.''
Archbishop McGrath said that the Nuncio was determined not to ''push him out the front door,'' but that it had made it increasingly clear in recent days that the Vatican wanted General Noriega to leave the Embassy building, and that when he finally surrendered, despite his erect bearing, he seemed ''a broken man.''
 
A Turning Point
General Noriega's surrender marked a critical turning point in the largest American military operation since Vietnam.
The general's surrender eliminated a major obstacle to establishing the legal and military authority of the new Panamanian Government and bringing to a conclusion an invasion that had threatened to bog down in the negotiations over his fate. By foiling an attempted coup in October, General Noriega had put intense pressure on Mr. Bush to make good on his often-repeated vow to ''bring Manuel Noriega to justice.''
Administration officials have said they hoped that by capturing General Noriega they could encourage more countries to recognize the new Panamanian Government and eliminate the possibility of prolonged resistance to the invasion.
But Mr. Bush still faces uncertainties in the legal proceedings against General Noriega. The general's lawyers have said they will seek documents detailing his long association with the Central Intelligence Agency, including the period when Mr. Bush was Director of Central Intelligence.
 
Four U.S. Objectives
Mr. Bush said General Noriega had turned himself over to United States authorities ''with the full knowledge'' of the new Panamanian Government that was sworn in at the start of the Dec. 20 invasion.
''On Wednesday, Dec. 20,'' Mr. Bush said, ''I ordered U.S. troops to Panama with four objectives: to safeguard the lives of American citizens; to help restore democracy; to protect the integrity of the Panama Canal treaty, and to bring General Manuel Noriega to justice.''
''All of these objectives have now been achieved,'' he declared.
Mr. Bush said he was ''committed to providing General Noriega a fair trial.''
''Nevertheless,'' he said, ''his apprehension and return to the United States should send a clear signal that the United States is serious in its determination that those charged with promoting the distributing of drugs cannot escape the scrutiny of justice.''
 
'Good News,' Dole Says
Mr. Bush's announcement drew a quick reaction from Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, who called it ''good news for our war on drugs.''
''It proves American won't give up or cave in to anyone, no matter how powerful or corrupt,'' Mr. Dole said. ''Noriega will finally have his day in court, which is more than he gave the people of Panama.''
The surrender of General Noriega marked the culmination of intensive negotiations among officials from the United States, Panama and the Vatican since he took refuge in the Vatican mission on Dec. 24, four days after the invasion by 12,000 American troops who had been sent to Panama to reinforce the 12,000 already stationed in that country.
On Sunday, the United States sent Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State, to Panama on what was ostensibly a mission to discuss economic aid to the new Panamanian Government, whose leaders had claimed victory in May elections that General Noriega later nullified. The announcement of General Noriega's surrender tonight suggested that Mr. Eagleburger's mission may have been crucial in the negotiations.
 
'The Decision Was His'
A senior Administration official said the Papal Nuncio in Panama had informed Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros, the second-in-command of American forces in Panama, at about 6 P.M. that General Noriega was ready to surrender tonight. President Bush was told of the decision by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney at about 6:30, when he returned to the White House after a racquetball game.
At first, Administration officials were cautious, since there had been other promising indications of a solution to the stalemate. ''It could have happened every day,'' the official said. ''The Vatican was trying to talk him into leaving and sometimes we would get rumblings that the Nuncio thought he was ready to do it and it didn't happen.''
Gen. Maxwell R. Thurman, commander of the American troops in Panama, told reporters in Panama City tonight that General Noriega appeared fit when he surrendered, and added, ''The decision was his and his alone.''
General Thurman declined to answer questions about the whereabouts of General Noriega's wife and the rest of his family and also refused to provide any details about how the deal was struck to get the general out of the Vatican Embassy and into American custody.
