HEADLINE: Savings Agency Ordered to Sell Real Estate Fast

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
The new agency created to manage the huge savings and loan bailout was instructed today to sell the real estate it inherited from hundreds of insolvent institutions as quickly as possible. The directive from the Bush Administration raised concerns among bankers that the properties could be ''dumped'' in an already weakened real estate market.
While the mandate to the newly formed Resolution Trust Corporation could mean that billions of dollars in homes, apartment buildings, shopping centers and raw land would be available to investors at bargain prices in 1990, bankers warned that an overzealous sales program could do more harm than good.
''Dumping is an acute political hot button, and if that is mishandled, then the political problems will end up right on George Bush's door,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association.
 
Largest in Nation's History
On Tuesday, the savings agency listed more than 30,000 parcels of commercial and residential property as the first group it will put on the market, making the real estate sale the nation's largest ever. The vast majority of parcels, 26,813, are residential, of which 11,918 are single-family homes. 
The nonresidential properties range from a golf course in South Padre Island, Tex., to a Dairy Queen in Woodland Park, Colo. Also on the list are nursing homes, theaters, marinas and churches.
The heaviest concentration of properties is in the troubled Southwest. Although the trust agency has not disclosed the total value of the real estate, officials put the value of the properties in Texas and Oklahoma alone at $6.4 billion at the end of August.
The instructions on how to sell the assets of the failed savings and loans are part of a ''strategic plan'' released today by the agency's Oversight Board, headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. The plan also spelled out general guidelines for the sale of the hundreds of savings institutions the Government has taken over.
''It is important that the R.T.C. proceed and continue actively to dispose of assets immediately,'' the directive said. ''The R.T.C. should avoid deferring the marketing of properties. Holding properties off the market for an extended period of time may increase the ultimate cost of asset disposition.''
Officials of the Oversight Board contended that the real estate sale would stop short of dumping and serve to accelerate the cleanup of the savings and loan debacle.
But James Chessen, deputy director of economic and policy research at the American Bankers Association, said, ''We are worried that even the perception of dumping of assets is causing trouble.'' Such dumping, or the excessive selling of real estate below market values, the banking officials said, will aggravate a market that is already weak, especially in the Southwest, parts of Florida and the Northeast.
The impact of the real estate sale on the Federal budget will not be fully known for several years. The trust agency has been allotted $50 billion in Government money over three years to clean up the problems. But if it can manage to sell the troubled institutions and their assets at prices more favorable than expected, the budgetary hit will be less.
But few banking experts believe that will happen because of predictions that real estate markets are going to continue to soften and that in the end Resolution Trust, which has so far taken over 318 savings units, will have to take over many more than the 500 institutions initially projected.
 
Troubles Far From Over
In fact, figures released by the nation's chief savings regulators today indicated that the industry's difficulties are far from over.
The Office of Thrift Supervision announced that in October the nation's 2,895 savings and loan associations lost $4.5 billion in deposits, only a moderate improvement from the $5.4 billion loss in September.
The agency said that for the previous 12 months, the industry lost a total of $65 billion in deposits.
The deposits have shrunk for a variety of reasons. Beginning late in 1988, nervousness about the financial condition of the industry, as well as much higher rates offered by money market mutual funds, prompted depositors to withdraw large sums.
 
More Burden on Taxpayers
That caused many financial experts to warn that because the President's bailout plan called for the industry to pay part of the cost through higher deposit insurance premiums, any loss of deposits would reduce that contribution, putting more financial burden on the taxpayer.
The President's plan predicted that deposits would grow at about a 7 percent rate, or $70 billion a year.
But later in the year, when rates began to fall and provisions of the bailout approved by Congress in August became effective, a different dynamic kicked in. The new law called for savings and loan owners to invest higher levels of their own cash in their institutions, or risk losing control. As a result, many institutions that could not raise new money began to sell assets and offer lower interest rates, letting deposits drain off.
Bank board officials said today that that trend continued through October and was not likely to stop.
Playing a key role in overseeing that shrinkage will be the Resolution Trust Corporation, which, along with the Oversight Board, was set up by the bailout plan. The agency is managed on a day-to-day basis by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
 
Four-Volume Listing
The list released by the trust agency on Tuesday detailed the real estate for sale from the assets of 283 troubled institutions seized as of Sept. 30.
Effectively putting for-sale signs on 30,123 properties, the agency sent the listing to Congress and began to make it available to the public.
The agency divides the properties into two books of residential listings, a third book for commercial properties and one for undeveloped land that can be as small as a 2,048-square-foot lot on Frenchmen Street in New Orleans or as large as a 77,626-acre farm in Gilbert, Ariz.
As expected, the largest number of properties are in the Southwest, where the energy collapse early in the 1980's created a major regional depression, causing both banks and savings institutions to fail. Texas has 15,750 properties listed; Oklahoma, 1,575; Louisiana, 2,434, and Arizona, 1,711. Maine, Vermont, West Virginia and North and South Dakota are the only states in which property is not listed.
 
Updates Every 6 Months
The inventory of properties will be updated every six months, with the next one scheduled for June 1.
The guidelines under the Oversight Board's strategic plan said Resolution Trust could provide buyers with short-term options for returning to the Government those assets they find are more troubled than first realized. It also permits the agency to give buyers short-term financing in their purchase of ailing institutions to give them time to come up with longer financing.
The strategic plan also instructs the trust agency to give preferential treatment to minorities in the sale of minority-held institutions. For example, Daniel P. Kearney, president of the Oversight Board, said that if a bid from a minority organization is less costly than a liquidation, ''the R.T.C. is not required to solicit other bids.''
It also set certain guidelines to avoid conflicts of interest in any of transaction, like requiring that ''all communications initiated by senior public officials or their staffs that are intended to influence a case are to be logged and the records made public,'' Mr. Kearney said.
 
Fair Value Mandated
But the Oversight Board officials said they did not expect that their mandate to the trust agency to sell assets quickly would result in dumping. They said that the bailout law, signed on Aug. 9, prohibits the agency from selling any asset at less than 95 percent of its current appraised value.
Moreover, they said their primary concern would be if the trust agency withheld assets from the market in anticipation of an upturn in value; such vast amounts of unsold real estate might keep market prices depressed even longer.
''The real danger is falling prices if you don't sell the real estate,'' said John Ross, an economist with the Oversight Board.
One issue that the strategic plan did not address is the need by the trust corporation for vast amounts of interim borrowings so that it can finance the sales of troubled savings institutions. Although the total cleanup by the agency of about 500 institutions has been estimated to cost $50 billion, the actual amount of cash flow far exceeds that.
Mr. Kearney said he had received estimates from L. William Seidman, chairman of the trust agency, that $50 billion to $100 billion in medium-term borrowings would be needed over the next three years in addition to the original $50 billion. That would eventually be paid back out of the proceeds from the asset sales.
 
Basic Bidding Process
The procedure for buying a troubled institution is primarily through the traditional bidding process set up by the F.D.I.C., in which investors are given basic information about an institution and invited to submit bids.
Purchasing real estate will be done in a number of different ways. Many properties are listed with local real estate agents, while others will be given to local real estate specialists to market to investors. Resolution Trust itself will end up selling probably some of the largest assets to interested buyers.
The listing can be ordered by calling 1-800-431-0600. The four books combined cost $50, the two residential volumes are $15 each and the commercial and land volumes are $10 each. The lists are also being distributed to 1.400 libraries across the country.
Here is the list, by state, of the number of real estate properties for sale by the Resolution Trust Corporation:

HEADLINE: DINKINS WILL DELAY HIRING OF RECRUITS FOR POLICE FORCE

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In his first major act as Mayor of New York, David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would indefinitely delay hiring 1,848 police officers who were to have gone on the payroll on Jan. 16 as recruits at the Police Academy. He said he might also have to delay another class that was scheduled to start in June.
Mr. Dinkins's decision means that the city's Police Department will almost certainly fall below its current strength of 25,971 officers during the year. It will also make it harder for the Mayor to keep his campaign promise to double the number of community patrol officers, who walk neighborhood beats, in his first term. 
Mr. Dinkins said the move would save $4 million a month and help keep the city's budget balanced in the face of deep fiscal uncertainty.
 
'Represents a Hardship'
''I realize that this represents a hardship both for the recruits awaiting induction and for the people of the city, who expect and deserve the protection that these new officers would afford,'' Mr. Dinkins said yesterday. His announcement came unexpectedly in the middle of a news conference called to discuss Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State Message.
State officials have predicted a budget gap for the city of as much as $185 million in the rest of the fiscal year that ends June 30 and a gap of at least several hundred million dollars in the following year.
''As I have said consistently, I will be bound by the requirements of fiscal prudence in making the difficult decisions that affect our city and our people,'' said Mr. Dinkins, whose liberal policies created concern in some quarters during the mayoral campaign that he might overspend. He was also faulted by his opponents as indecisive or unwilling to make unpopular decisions.
 
Discussion With Brown
''I would wish that every announcement I would make would speak of enhancements,'' he said. ''But that's just not the real world.''
Mr. Dinkins had vowed repeatedly during the mayoral campaign and in his inaugural address on Monday to be ''the toughest mayor on crime this city has ever seen.''
The January class was to have had 1,476 recruits for the Police Department, 230 for the transit police and 142 for the housing police. The transit police has about 3,600 officers, while the housing police has about 1,700. During his campaign, Mr. Dinkins had promised to put an officer on every subway car by the end of his first term.
The Mayor said he has explained the hiring delay to his newly named Police Commissioner, Lee P. Brown, who is to take office on Jan. 22. The Mayor said he expected to talk further with Mr. Brown, and to make a decision on how to proceed, by Feb. 15. But he refused to commit himself on when the class would start its five-month training program. ''We'll have a class,'' he said. ''I just cannot now say precisely when.''
While Mr. Dinkins said he hoped to proceed with another class of 1,600 officers in June as planned, he added that it was too early to know whether the city could afford to do so. He also said he did not know whether the Police Academy could accommodate two classes at once.
But Assistant Chief Raymond W. Kelly, head of the department's office of management and planning, said, ''Our position would be that we would find the room to do it.''
 
'Same Power' Against Crime
Mr. Dinkins said he reached his decision on Tuesday after talking with his budget director, Philip R. Michael. Administration officials said the delay in the police class was chosen because it was one of the areas of greatest flexibility. About 75 cents of each dollar in city revenue must go to programs, like social services and welfare payments, that are mandated by either law or court decisions or to keep pace with inflation.
Mayor Edward I. Koch frequently delayed planned police classes to save money, most recently postponing a class of about 1,300 recruits from June to July. Officials said the monthly savings gained by the newly announced delay would obviously accelerate if the delay also resulted in a delay of the class planned for this coming June.
Mr. Dinkins sought yesterday to diminish the blow, saying, ''We have the same power to combat crime today as we had before I made this announcement.''
But because the Police Department loses about 2,000 officers a year through attrition, police officials said the force would begin shrinking almost immediately.
Since last year, the city has had a partial hiring freeze on other agencies, begun by Mr. Koch. Uniformed police officers became exempt from the freeze after other actions kept the budget balanced.
 
'Phantom Cops'
The city's all-time highest police strength was just under 31,000 officers before the fiscal crisis in 1975. The department's strength fell to a low of 21,838 in December 1981, before climbing during the Koch administration to about 28,000 two years ago. In the last two years, the department has begun to shrink again as the city deferred hiring to keep the budget in line.
In the campaign, Mr. Dinkins often criticized Mr. Koch for creating ''phantom cops'' by claiming credit for officers he planned to hire and then failing to hire them. ''The distinction was, I accused the prior administration of counting those persons, when they did not in fact exist,'' Mr. Dinkins said yesterday.
Thomas Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a private group that monitors law enforcement, said he understood Mr. Dinkins's desire for fiscal caution at the beginning of the adminisitration. But he said, ''Given the current level of crime, disorder and drugs in this city, I would hope that maintaining the police force at a reasonable level, at least 26,000, would be among the highest priorities of this administration.''
Herbert E. Berman, who was chosen yesterday as chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, said it would be premature to comment on the delay without discussing it with the administration.
 
Recruits Were Warned
Several of the recruits scheduled to report to the academy in two weeks said they were not completely surprised by Mr. Dinkins's decision, because they have been on Civil Service lists in recruit classes that have already been delayed several times in recent years.
''I'm kind of used to it,'' said Gary Robertson, a 26-year-old Staten Island resident who now works for the Criminal Justice Agency, a private group, where he interviews criminal defendants before arraignment and makes recommendations about whether they should be released on their own recognizance.
''So now I don't get all built up for it,'' Mr. Robertson added. ''I'm hoping, just waiting to see what happens. They do tell you, 'Don't quit your job, because it's never definite.' ''

CORRECTION-DATE: January 6, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about Mayor David N. Dinkins's decision to delay the hiring of 1,848 police officers misstated a campaign promise he made about subway crime. He pledged that by the end of his first term he would put an officer on every train every night, not in every car.

HEADLINE: Dole Winning Applause For Labor Dept. Actions

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
With her help this week in reaching an agreement in the coal miners' strike in Appalachia, Secretary of Labor Elizabeth Dole has taken a step toward ending a bleak period for organized labor in its relations with the Government.
Trade unionists are hardly proclaiming a return to their salad days, but they acknowledge that Mrs. Dole, and by implication President Bush, have made a bow to them in the tone of her office and in modifications of policy that mark at least a modest break from Ronald Reagan's hands-off attitude toward disputes between businesses and unions.
Certainly there is no return to the cozy relationship between labor and Government that characterized the eras of Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy; unionists still seethe over the refusal of Mrs. Dole and the Administration to step into the Eastern Airlines strike. But there is now at least more of the mutual respect that unions experienced with Republican Presidents before Mr. Reagan.
Most important, this week Mrs. Dole acknowledged the value of collective bargaining, organized labor's essential tool in negotiating with management. President Reagan, alone among Presidents since the 1930's, in effect repudiated collective bargaining nine years ago when he refused to talk with 11,500 striking air traffic controllers unless they returned to work. The move broke their union. 
Less noticed in Mrs. Dole's first year, but also important, is the Administration's new emphasis on worker safety. A downward trend in spending at the Occupational Safety and Health Administration was reversed last year, fines for health and safety violations rose and many regulations are being more tightly enforced.
 
'A Lot of Common Ground'
''We're going to have to agree to disagree on some issues, but there's a lot of common ground,'' Mrs. Dole said of her own labor policy. John Duray, spokesman for the United Mine Workers, said of the agreement that the miners union and the Pittston Company announced Monday, ''It's a significant thing that she was willing to take a chance and step out in a different direction than has been the norm of the last 10 years.''
Days before the Pittston announcement, Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L-C.I.O. said he found the Bush Administration ''a little more civilized'' than Mr. Reagan's and ''less intensely ideological.''
''I think we've survived as bad as they could do,'' Mr. Kirkland said of the Reagan era, ''and in pretty good shape.''
After a year of out of the limelight in the Labor Department, Mrs. Dole, a 53-year-old Harvard-educated lawyer, may have begun to live up to the early notices that greeted her appointment.
The Administration's highest-ranking woman, who served in President Reagan's Cabinet as Transportation Secretary, negotiated a compromise with Mr. Kirkland on the President's proposal for the minimum wage increase, from $3.35 currently to $4.25 over two years. And a White House official said she held off an alternative proposal by Vice President Quayle.
''It was Elizabeth who urged the President to state his position and say there was no negotiating,'' said Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas. Mrs. Dole said: ''I planned the strategy. I took it to the President. He agreed with the strategy.''
 
Stepped Aside on Eastern
Early in the Administration when the start of the Eastern strike on March 4 gave her an opportunity to seize the reins of an issue, she balked, or the White House balked for her. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner took it on instead, and a former senior Reagan Administration official said Mr. Skinner did so because the White House wanted to protect Mrs. Dole from trade union brickbats so early in her tenure, when she was just opening her lines to labor.
But Mrs. Dole denies it. ''I went to the President, as did Sam Skinner,'' she said. ''In a situation like that, safety becomes very important, and because of the safety aspects, I told Sam to take it.''
To the extent that deeds and priorities can be measured in money, Mrs. Dole's biggest shift from the Reagan years has less to do with strikes than with workplace safety. Year after year, the last Administration whittled away the budget of the Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration.
But despite the spending constraints on most Government departments, OSHA's budget went up last year for the first time in eight, in part because of $14.9 million Mrs. Dole obtained to hire 179 more officers to enforce the health and and safety laws. And in the President's next budget, Administration officials say, OSHA will have a significant increase, exceeding the rate of inflation.
The fines levied under Mrs. Dole against employers who violate health and safety regulations are often reduced when the employers agree to do more to comply. Even so, her department's fines are running at an annual $60 million, as against $14 million in the Reagan years.
 
Some Issues Still Untouched
OSHA's Administrator, Gerard F. Scannell, says he is studying ways to revise the laws to impose still stiffer fines on industries like construction, and the agency has also been enacting proposals to tighten regulations that had rattled around its bureaucracy, ignored, in the Reagan years.
OSHA aside, Mrs. Dole has left a wide variety of labor-related issues largely or entirely untouched by policy initiatives. Among them are the Reagan precedent of breaking strikes with replacement workers, increasing violations of the child labor and migrant worker laws, and the lively new question of employee incentives like profit sharing.
Even so, in the nine-month Pittston strike in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky, Mrs. Dole showed unequivocal respect for the process of collective bargaining. In her statement announcing the tentative agreement, she said, ''Today's settlement is a victory for the collective bargaining process - a process which over the years has resulted in protection for all workers, stronger businesses and greater cooperation between management and labor.''
Interestingly, in deciding in late October to intervene in the Pittston strike, Mrs. Dole, who began her political career as a Democrat, turned not to her own Administration or her own party but to a proponents of collective bargaining and Government intervention from the past, W. J. Usery Jr., a Democrat who was Labor Secretary under President Ford.
Mrs. Dole helped lubricate the deal in another way. She acknowledged that the most devisive issue in the strike, Pittston's halting of contributions to the health plans of retired miners and interest in negotiating a less costly plan, raised bigger questions than those involved in the strike. Health care costs pose problems for many employers and unions, so she agreed to appoint a commission to examine the issue.
 
Stirring Up a Hot Question
Labor Department officials say she has no intention of adopting the solution sought by some Democrats in Congress, some unions and even some companies: the Government's assumption of some of the health-cost burden. But in even appointing the commission, she is likely to stir the debate over national health insurance, which is anathema to most Republicans Administrations.
In the Pittston strike, Elizabeth Dole (she says she has been trying to shed the nickname ''Liddy'' since college) disclosed a style that both sides said they admired. For months after the strike began on April 5, Richard L. Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers Union, and Paul W. Douglas, chairman of Pittston, has refused to sit in the same room, much less talk.
Upon deciding to intervene, Mrs. Dole called them together to her office and subsequently obtained their endorsement of Mr. Usery. ''People come steaming into her office,'' said Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, who attended Harvard Law School with Mrs. Dole, ''and then she pulls their little steam plugs.''
Labor leaders warn against assuming that the woman from the party of business is changing her stripes, or that even if she did, it would make any difference.
''While her instincts may be good,'' said Victor Gotbaum, retired leader of New York's municipal workers, ''she is inhibited by a President who's much more comfortable with business than he is with labor. Bush is softer than Reagan, but that doesn't mean he's soft.''

HEADLINE: Salvadoran Coffee Boycott Does Harm

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''In response to a consumer group, the Nestle Foods Corporation, maker of a top-selling instant coffee, said yesterday that it was suspending for 30 days the purchase of coffee beans from El Salvador'' (Business Day, Dec. 12).
News media reports such as this show an attempt by a group known as Neighbor to Neighbor to bring pressure on the Government of El Salvador by urging United States coffee manufacturers to cease using Salvadoran coffee in their blends. Obviously, the coffee roasters themselves must decide how to respond to those highhanded tactics. 
Beyond that, however, is the more important question of who would be helped by a boycott of Salvadoran coffee and who would be hurt.
In the last few days, the presidents of five Central American countries have been able to reach a tentative agreement to begin a peace process in the region. Hopefully, the United States will support the peace process. God knows the people of the Central American nations have suffered more than enough.
But public interest groups also bear responsibility in not pursuing efforts that upset the delicate balance. Boycotting coffee from El Salvador will hurt the people who depend on the commodity for their livelihood and appear aimed at further damaging the economy of El Salvador, a nation with a duly elected democratic government that is struggling against the tyranny of fanatical extremists.
The economy of El Salvador was damaged enough by the drastic fall in coffee prices after the collapse of the international coffee agreement. Salvadoran coffee will continue to be in demand for its excellent quality, and United States consumers should be allowed to enjoy it as part of their daily consumption. Let our neighbors help and not hamper the peace process in El Salvador.
Gallant efforts are now being made by the Central American leaders to end the suffering and repression. They should be encouraged and assisted by all people of good will, and not hampered and obstructed by outside forces that are merely seeking to upset democracy where it now exists.
 
MIGUEL A. SALAVERRIA
Ambassador, Republic of El Salvador
 Washington, Dec. 14, 1989

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: The Soviets' Terminal Crisis

BYLINE: By 'Z'

 BODY:
The following article is adapted from the conclusion of a longer historical analysis to be published under the pseudonym ''Z'' in the winter issue of Daedalus, journal of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Daedalus is withholding the author's name from all parties at the author's request. (Although it is not The New York Times's usual practice to withhold an author's identity, it is honoring Daedalus's commitment.)
It is clear that 1989 will enter history as the beginning of Communism's terminal crisis, and not just in Russia but from the Baltic to the China Sea, and from Berlin to Beijing.
It is also clear that perestroika and glasnost, welcome in their intention, have in their application only aggravated the systemic crisis they were intended to alleviate. They have done so because, like all forms of soft Communism, they go against the logic of the system they are trying to save. 
Mikhail Gorbachev has been trying to promote soft Communism through structures and a population programmed for hard Communism. But the latter is the only variety of Sovietism that is the genuine article, for the essence of all varieties of Sovietism is party supremacy. Thus, the instrument of Mr. Gorbachev's reform - the party - is the basic cause of Sovietism's troubles.
The way out of this contradiction? As one Soviet reformer put it after the June Congress: ''The country now stands at a crossroads. From here we either go the Chinese way or the Polish-Hungarian way.'' Although he obviously wished for the latter course, the alternative he posed may well be a Hobson's choice.
The Chinese way since June 1989 means relative, though now declining, market prosperity under a regime of political and military repression. Repression is certainly a possibility in Russia, but market prosperity is out of the question for the indefinite future. Conversely, the Polish-Hungarian way means genuine democracy, but in the midst of economic ruin so severe as to threaten the survival of the new constitutional order.
In Russia, the economic ruin is even worse than in Poland and Hungary, but real democracy, as opposed to mere democratization, is not even on the agenda. Thus, the Russian way could well combine the worst of the Chinese and the Central European scenarios: economic failure in conjunction with an inexpungeable leading role for the party.
Indeed, all paths of Communist reform seem to end in one or another type of impasse. Leninist regimes, when they enter their final decline, seem able only either to implode, as in Poland, Hungary, East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Rumania, or to dig in their heels militarily to stave off implosion, as under Deng Xiaoping in 1989. And this grim impasse at the end of utopia in power is the outcome of the structures that power built. The whole impossible enterprise of Lenin and Stalin was sustainable only as long as the human and material resources on which the system fed retained the vitality to endure the burden of the regime, and as long as some modicum of material success undergirded the party's monopolistic position.
When these conditions ceased to hold, beginning with Deng Xiaoping's marketization of 1979 and Solidarity's revolt of 1980, the Communist parties' will to power began to flag and their people's habit of fear began to fade. For the Soviet party-state's survival, this development soon made necessary the expedients of perestroika and glasnost. But these are only pale substitutes for the market and democracy, halfway measures designed to square the circle of making the vivifying forces of a resurrected civil society compatible with the party's leading role.
But this circle cannot be squared. If marketization and privatization are the economic goals of reform, then party planning becomes superfluous, indeed downright parasitical. If multiple parties, elections and the rule of law are the political goals of reform, then the dual administration of the party-state becomes supernumerary, indeed positively noxious.
There is no third way between Leninism and the market, between Bolshevism and constitutional government. Marketization and democratization lead to the revival of civil society, and such a society requires the rule of law. But civil society under the rule of law is incompatible with the preservation of the lawless leading role of the party.
At some point, therefore, the line will be reached where reform crosses over into the liquidation of the leading role and all the structures it has created. Russia and Central Europe are reaching that critical line. The false problem of how to restructure Leninism is now giving way to the real problem of how to dismantle the system, how to effect at last an exit from Communism. Perestroika is not a solution but a transition to this exit. As Milovan Djilas foresaw early in perestroika, Communism is not reforming itself - it is disintegrating.
So, as we rub our eyes in astonishment at the most stunning Communist implosion of all, the collapse of the Berlin wall, we should not conclude that the structures it shielded for so long can be transformed by a few reform decrees. The revolutionary rapidity of events in 1989 should not breed the illusion that the exit from Communism these events presage will itself be rapid.
And the most difficult case of all will be the Soviet Union. Russia, after all, has had 70, not 45 years of Sovietism. Also, the Soviet party is a national institution, not an alien imposition, with deep roots in the patriotic success of World War II. Finally, this national-imperial party has the military apparatus of a superpower.
Can Mr. Gorbachev succeed? Should we help him? To answer these questions meaningfully, we must first rephrase them. Succeed at what? Help him to do what? If by perestroika's success we mean producing a Communist system that is economically effective and politically democratic, then the answer must be no. The fundamental structures of the Leninist system reached an inextricable impasse at the end of the 1970's, and the mounting contradictions of perestroika indicate that the system cannot be restructured or reformed, but can only either stagnate or be dismantled and replaced by market institutions over a long period of time.
In this case, any aid the West might render to the Soviet state to save or improve the existing system would be futile: On this score, Mr. Gorbachev is beyond our help. Such aid would also work against the real interests of the restive Soviet peoples and thus of international stability. Like Western credits to Poland in the 1970's, aid to the Soviet Government would only prolong the agony.
Yet, if by perestroika's success we mean effecting a transition from a party-state and a command economy to democracy and the market, then the answer, unfortunately, must still be no. First, such a transition is not the aim of perestroika; its aim, rather, is to salvage what can be saved of the system by halfway-house concessions to economic and human reality.
Second, and even more important, such a transition would bring the end of the cardinal leading role and hence would amount to the self-liquidation of Communism, something Mr. Gorbachev clearly does not intend to do.
Still, events are pressing toward the eventual dwindling away of the system, whatever the Soviet leadership's intentions and whoever that leader might be in the future. And here Western help could play a constructive role.
First, reducing the mutual burden of armaments, if carried out with due attention to legitimate security concerns, would ease the severity of the Soviet crisis (though it would not alter its structural causes). And Mr. Gorbachev has clearly indicated his willingness to engage in arms reductions, while taking care that the Soviet Union's international retreat does not turn into a rout.
Second, although Western aid should not go to shoring up Soviet economic institutions in the state sector, it could be usefully applied to the piecemeal development of parallel structures in a private sector operating on market principles so as to promote economic and, eventually, political pluralism. This could take the form, say, of free economic zones operating under International Monetary Fund conditions in such places as the Baltic states, Armenia or the Soviet Far East. In this case, the expectation would be that such a parallel sector, perhaps with its own convertible currency, would eventually spread across the Soviet Union.
Such a policy is, indeed, a modest approximation of the approach that the Government is now inaugurating in Poland. But what Mr. Gorbachev is prepared to accept for his outer empire in Central Europe (where he effectively lost control sometime in 1988) would be much more difficult for him to accept for the inner empire of the Soviet Union itself, since foreign investment would imperil national sovereignty.
So Western investment, in joint or other enterprises in Russia, would have to be handled without triumphalism about capitalism's superiority, and with due sensitivity to Soviet national pride. The West's aim should be to encourage the change of Soviet realities while leaving the old labels intact - in a kind of socialist-emperor-of-Japan arrangement.
Yet, however the Soviet Union edges toward its particular exit from Communism, this uncharted process can only be long and painful. Nor will it be a unilinear or an incremental progress toward integration in some ''common European home.'' Instead, further crises will most likely be necessary to produce further, and more real, reforms. And a last-ditch attempt to stave off ruin by curtailing destabilizing reform altogether could lead to that military reaction so feared by Moscow liberals.
And - who knows - in this scenario Mr. Gorbachev might be agile enough to become his own successor, or if perestroika ends in another 18th of Brumaire, to be his own Bonaparte. Mr. Gorbachev would be hard to replace, because his international reputation is now the Soviet Union's chief capital asset; yet, he could not afford to be a very tough Bonaparte, since he has become the prisoner of his foreign policy successes.
Obviously, none of these prospects is a cheering one, and none would be easy for the West to live alongside. But it is better to look realistically at the genuine options in the East as they have been molded by 70 years of failed utopia than to engage in fantasies about Mr. Gorbachev as a demiurge of instant democracy or about the end of conflict in history. Nor should we forget that Communism, though a disaster in almost every creative domain, has always been supremely successful at one thing: resourcefulness and tenacity in holding onto its monopoly of power.
The Soviet world's transition to normality will be a long time coming. The party, though now dyed with the hues of glasnost and democratization, will cling to the bitter end, like some poisoned tunic of Nessus, around the bodies of nations it has enfolded in its embrace for so many decades.

LENGTH: 1704 words

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Cuomo's Address: 'Journey Toward the Next Millennium'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the text of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State address to the Legislature yesterday:
Today we take the first steps into the last decade between us and the 21st century.
From here, we can see the outlines of a bright and exciting new time of progress -for our state, our nation and the world beyond.
You and I have been working together to prepare for this moment for seven years.
In 1983, the first time I had the privilege of addressing you, the state was still feeling aftershocks of our economic crisis in the 70's. We had to close a potential deficit of nearly $2 billion. 
We knew, despite that, that if we were to make ourselves ready for the challenges and opportunities ahead, we needed to further reduce our state income taxes and to put more people to work. We knew we would have to rebuild roads and bridges, cleanse and preserve our environment, revitalize our schools, reorganize our criminal justice system and adapt our human services to new, rapidly changing realities.
 
Crack and Violent Crime
The challenge was actually even greater.
Unexpectedly, a terrible new drug, crack, appeared on the streets and brought with it a surge of violent crime. Homelessness appeared across the nation on a scale unseen since the Great Depression. The lethal syndrome, AIDS, spread with frightening effect.
And just when we needed its help most, Washington withdrew resources that we required to deal with these problems. These were awesome challenges. But we were not intimidated. Nor did we use the Federal Government's failure to help as an excuse. Instead, you and I went to work. We put aside the unimportant differences between us, and developed a new, vibrant ethic of cooperation - a new sense of family. ...
Together we produced the two largest tax cuts in our history and the lowest income tax rate in 30 years. ...
Our investments in our fight against alcohol and drug abuse and related crime are up 400 percent. We nearly doubled our prison cells and developed the largest drug and alcohol treatment system in the nation, serving 100,000 people a day. ...
We agreed we should lead in protecting the environment. Together we created the first controls on acid rain implemented in the nation; the first energy plan integrated with environmental needs; a huge environmental bond issue; aggressive recycling and landfill-control programs. Thousands of acres of our natural beauty acquired and preserved.
There's more. Governments are often judged by the bricks and mortar they leave behind. By that measure, you - and I -would do especially well. We created a dynamic period of construction - nearly $50 billion worth of bricks and mortar. ...
Washington now admits states have a cluster of extraordinary national problems like drugs and inadequate education. But Washington says it can't help with national resources because they must go to huge Federal income tax cuts that help a lot of people, mostly the richest. Actually, this only shifts the burden on to the states and the real-estate and sales taxes that hurt a lot of people, but the middle class and poor most of all.
 
Large Potential Deficits
That has hurt us. Now the weakness of the national economy is hurting us more.
As a result, much of the Northeast, including New York, today faces large potential deficits.
We will not have the revenues to satisfy all the demands upon us, or even our own desires. ...
The Anti-Drug-Abuse Council headed by the Lieutenant Governor has submitted an excellent, comprehensive report.
In recent days it has taken on new relevance because a number of well-known people have advocated legalizing drugs. . . .
Let me say as clearly as I can: I reject this idea as the abandonment of a whole generation of children, and adults, now caught in addiction - and of generations to come as well. I would not do it to my children. We ought not let the state do it to our children.
Instead of surrendering, I will recommend strengthening every part of our drug effort -law enforcement, education, treatment, prevention. My agenda in 1990 will include an unprecedented expansion of our alcohol and drug treatment capacity: 15,000 new residential treatment beds, and outpatient treatment for 20,000 additional people. We will give special attention to pregnant women and mothers with young children. ...
Despite the immense resources we have committed, our health care system is hurting, and so are some of the people it is meant to serve.
 
Reimbursement Rates
We need new and better ways to deal with reimbursement rates, to ease health personnel shortages, to regulate the system, and to communicate with the men and women who make the system work.
One thing is particularly apparent: adequate primary care in the community - prevention and early intervention - will reduce illness and help limit the overwhelming expense of hospital care.
It's also clear that we must do more for the 2.5 million New Yorkers who are among the 37 million Americans with no health insurance of any kind.
This year, in the third year of the Decade of the Child, I will propose a new program, a unique one, I believe. I call it New York Child, for children's health insurance for lifelong development. It will help cover every uninsured child in this state from birth through age 17, for primary and preventive care, and catastrophic illness. . . .
I will propose as well, a neighborhood-based initiative to improve services for pregnant women, new parents and at-risk children in our most disadvantaged communities. ...
I propose we try a new performance-oriented approach to public education: providing clear goals and effective measurement of student achievement; evaluating schools by improvement in student performance, and not by technical compliance with the words of state mandates. I will offer a program to demonstrate how this can work.
 
Most Vulnerable People
As we journey toward the next millennium, we must continue to serve the needs of our most vulnerable people.
I will ask you for a new supplement to S.S.I. for persons with AIDS who are in special adult care facilities. We will expand prevention efforts for high-risk adolescents, women and young children; increase help for incarcerated or paroled persons with AIDS; and expand support for the community organizations, which serve as our front line of defense.
And we have a solid new program this year, begun jointly by the state and H.E.L.P., Andrew Cuomo's not-for-profit corporation. It is the first public residential health care facility for persons with AIDS in the country. It will provide 66 beds. We will replicate this cost-effective prototype to create hundreds of other beds. ...
As part of our long-term plan to assist the homeless mentally ill, we'll work with New York City to develop additional beds, including new S.R.O. and supported housing units, and we'll expand and improve services for people with disabilities. . . . ...
I have asked our director of economic development, Vincent Tese, to invigorate our promotion of exports - emphasizing high technology and agriculture - and to expand our current international partnership program. Our extensive ''Global New York'' agenda will be a centerpiece of our work in the months ahead. ...
I spoke earlier of all we accomplished in protecting our environment. It's time now for another solid down payment on a better and more beautiful future for the generations to follow us.
We all agree on the importance of these things: helping local governments deal with solid waste; preserving environmentally sensitive lands, maintaining our magnificent parks and historic treasures. To do all these things, I will ask your support for a 21st century environmental bond issue of $1.9 billion. . . .
 
Initiative and Referendum
But let me mention a few more particulars:
* Raising workers' compensation benefits and the minimum wage.
* Extending - this month - the protections for Mitchell-Lama residents, or tens of thousands of people could lose their homes.
* A strong law against bias-related violence. New ways to discourage investment in South Africa. A law banning assault weapons, and a law establishing life imprisonment without parole.
As freedom and democracy are enjoying a rebirth around the world, we should strengthen them here, at the source.
I will ask you to give New Yorkers an important extension of their right to participate in their government, with a limited initiative and referendum. It would require us to vote publicly - one way or the other - on proposals the citizens indicate by petition they believe to be particularly significant. ...
If we only understand this bright new change fully and use it well, historians a hundred years from now will look back and write about the political miracle of the 20th century. ...
Think of it. If we could reaffirm the notion of family and reject, as we always have at our best, the proposition that we can exist and thrive as a house divided - or a world divided, fractionalized - by sex, or nationality, or race, or color, or religion. If we could rouse ourselves from indifference toward the growing gap between our wealthiest and most fortunate citizens, and those who continue to struggle.
If we could wean ourselves from a national addiction that has made our country the prime market for the world's drug trade.
If all those who wound up in treatment centers or prisons were instead working in laboratories or factories or offices, using their gifts productively, helping themselves and the rest of us.
 
Going Forward
Imagine then, what we could do in this state, and in this nation.
Then, someday, not too long from now, another governor could stand here and tell his audience - no, tell her audience - that we, the generations that endured depression and global war and the decades-long threat of nuclear destruction, never lost hope and never stopped going forward.
That we took, always, as our continuing inspiration the words of a great New York poet, Walt Whitman, who beckoned us to come still further, by reminding us that ''the strongest and sweetest songs yet remain to be sung.''
Let us sing them, together.

HEADLINE: Ben Reifel, 83, Dies; Former Congressman

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Jan. 3

 BODY:
Ben Reifel, the first Sioux Indian elected to the United States House of Representatives, died of cancer on Tuesday at Sioux Valley Hospital in Sioux Falls. He was 83 years old. 
A Rosebud Sioux, he worked for the Department of Interior for 23 years, resigning in 1960 as an area administrator for the Bureau of Indian Affairs to win a seat in Congress as a Republican. He stepped down after five two-year terms.
He was instrumental in having the Earth Resources Observation Systems center located in South Dakota and in keeping Ellsworth Air Force Base an active military base in the state.
He was born on a log cabin on a Sioux reservation, which he left to attend South Dakota State College. He received a bachelor's degree there and master's and doctoral degrees in economics and government at Harvard University.
Mr. Reifel served in the Army in Europe in World War II as a lieutenant colonel.
He is survived by his wife, Frances; a daughter and a stepdaughter.

HEADLINE: Tyson Says He Overcame Drinking Habit

BYLINE: By PHIL BERGER

 BODY:
Mike Tyson says he had a drinking habit that intensified after Robin Givens filed for divorce in October 1988, but that he has stopped drinking entirely.
''I guess maybe it was an outlet,'' said Tyson of his alcohol consumption. ''People were telling me drinking doesn't solve anything. But at the time, it solved a lot of problems. When I was sober, I had headaches, my heart was throbbing. A couple of swigs would totally change it around.'' What made him stop drinking ? ''I didn't like my performance against Bruno,'' said Tyson. 
Last February, Tyson knocked out Frank Bruno in five rounds, but was not impressive in doing so.
Tyson said he drank up until he began training in December 1988 for the Bruno fight.
''Drink was a crutch,'' said Tyson. ''No more. Part of why I drank was that the old-time fighters used to. They'd hang out and gallivant.'' Tyson has had an abiding interest in and warm feeling toward the fighters of the early decades of this century.
''I figured,'' said Tyson, ''if I could win on booze, I could do a lot better on the wagon.''
Tyson's promoter, Don King, says he gave up alcohol when Tyson did.
''Years ago,'' said King, ''I'd drink gin and ginger ale, but a reporter I was sitting with one day said to me: 'Who drinks this?' So I went to vodka and ginger ale.
''Anyway, when Mike told me he was stopping, I said I'd stop, too. And I have. We monitor each other. Neither of us wants to give in. Or show weakness.''
 
Optimism on Tyson-Holyfield
Negotiations for a Tyson-Evander Holyfield fight are intensifying.
Holyfield's representatives - Dan Duva, the promoter, and Shelly Finkel, the adviser - were due in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday to meet with King and see if a deal could be closed on a June 18 bout between the heavyweight champion and Holyfield.
Until this week, Finkel had been the designated negotiator for the Holyfield camp, a position that fell to him because it was feared that the deep hostility between Duva and King might stymie progress.
The fact that Duva was set to join the negotiations seemed to signal that the talks were at a critical juncture. Kathy Duva, who handles public relations for her husband, said: ''Dan felt the deal was close enough that it was worth a face-to-face. I know he doesn't go on wild goose chases very often.''
Finkel said that there were still some details to work out, but that he was optimistic the deal would be signed before King and Tyson leave for Tokyo later this month, in advance of the Feb. 11 Tyson-Buster Douglas bout there. A Contract Ache? Rumors persist that the back injury that caused Michael Nunn to postpone his Jan. 27 fight against Marlon Starling was bogus and that the real problem the International Boxing Federation middleweight champion is having is with his manager, Dan Goossen.
According to those rumors, Nunn wants out of his managerial contract so that he can take economic advantage of his new deal with Steve Wynn's Mirage Casino in Las Vegas. Wynn reportedly wants only to recover his site fee and expenses from bouts staged at the Mirage, leaving the rest of the rights revenues to the boxers. Cutting out Goossen would increase Nunn's share even more.
''As far as I know,'' said Goossen, ''It's not true. Nunn hasn't told me that.''
Goossen said his deal with Nunn runs until November of this year and that there had been ''some news about us renegotiating when it's through.''

HEADLINE: The Peabody, Ready or Not, Is Pushed to Go Out on Its Own

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
One of cultural Baltimore's favorite sons is in danger of becoming its fiscal orphan. The Peabody Conservatory, a source of civic pride since 1857, is suffering its biggest crisis since Johns Hopkins University rescued it from extinction 12 years ago.
Johns Hopkins, Peabody's affluent neighbor, has subsidized most of the music school's increasing deficits since 1977 - a sum exceeding $20 million. Now faced with money pressures of its own, Johns Hopkins has tendered a plan that would drastically reduce the university's support and nudge Peabody in the direction of self-sufficiency. One of Maryland's most powerful politicians, however, has other ideas for its future.
Peabody, an affiliate of Johns Hopkins, is ranked close to such elite music schools as Juilliard, Curtis, Eastman, Oberlin, Michigan and Indiana. It has produced graduates like the composers Dominick Argento and Philip Glass; Richard Cassilly, the tenor; the popular singer Roberta Flack; James Morris, an internationally known bass; Hugh Wolff, the conductor; the pianist Andre Watts; the band leader Tommy Newsome, and Virgil Fox, the organist. 
Peabody graduates perform in the Boston, St. Louis, San Francisco and Baltimore Symphonies and play a big part in the symphonic and educational life of Maryland. Peabody has traditionally been known as the music school that attracts talent from the Southeastern states.
 
An Unlikely Ally
But the school, it is generally agreed, has fed for 40 years on its reputation and its previous endowment. Fund-raising has been negligible, principal has been spent to pay annual deficits, and buildings, faculty salaries and morale have deteriorated. Peabody's current endowment is $10 million, a fraction of the reserves held by Juilliard or Curtis.
Peabody has found an unlikely ally in Melvin A. Steinberg, Maryland's Lieutenant Governor. Mr. Steinberg - neither an educator nor an arts figure but a hard-nosed politician - has been heading a state task force to rescue Peabody as a private institution and restore its health.
Filled with enthusiasm and armed with political cunning, Mr. Steinberg has devised a fragile plan that would twist the arms of Johns Hopkins, the Legislature and the private sector with just enough pleasurable pain to get the school through its immediate dangers and raise an endowment of $80 million by the next century.
The Steinberg plan, which needs legislative approval, consists of a series of offers he hopes all parties will accept. Under the plan, the state will put up $15 million and Peabody will put up its art collection as collateral. The collection, mainly American masters in museums around the city, is not to be touched. If Peabody does not live up to its part of Mr. Steinberg's delicate bargain, the school will return the $15 million and get its art back.
 
Recent Signs of Life
Peabody's job is to raise $15 million on its own from the private sector by July 1, a project in which Mr. Steinberg will take an active part. The state will subsidize Peabody to the tune of $5.9 million a year until 1996, at which time Peabody is to begin a campaign to raise enough money to build a self-sustaining endowment of $80 million. Johns Hopkins will continue to address Peabody's deficits for the next few years. The $3 million that Peabody will cost Hopkins this year, if the Steinberg plan is adopted, is far above the $500,000 the university's retrenchment proposal specified. The annual burden for Johns Hopkins, however, will diminish as Peabody's endowment money comes in.
Robert O. Pierce, a former principal horn player in the Baltimore Symphony, became Peabody's director in 1981 and has tried with some success to upgrade the faculty and facilities. Money was found for a new building, now under construction, to house a library, studios and classrooms. Leon Fleischer, the pianist and teacher, has attracted students from around the world; teachers like Berl Senofsky, Sylvia Rosenberg, Earl Carlyss and Stephen Kates have brought in good string players. Some of the school's faculty members commute regularly to Baltimore at Peabody's expense.
 
Problems at Johns Hopkins
Dr. Steven Muller, president of Johns Hopkins since 1972, was both Peabody's savior in 1977 and the formulator of the plan now threatening its future. Dr. Muller has problems of his own. An educator with expansionist ideas, he started programs in the 1970's and 80's that rebuilt the physical plant of the arts and sciences division and branched out as far as Nanjing, China.
Given Johns Hopkins's recent success in raising $610 million, financing all these ventures would seem relatively easy, but Hopkins is not the usual university. Like medieval Italy, it is made up of largely autonomous medical, engineering, public health and other divisions, each entrusted with financing itself and each with a tendency to guard its own assets.
Dr. Muller, who is alternately accused of overambition and praised as a visionary, leaves office in June.
''Over half that money was raised for the medical school,'' he said. ''Ninety-seven percent comes from 2 or 3 percent of all donors, and gifts of $100,000 or more tend to be for specific purposes, to endow a chair for example. The medical school has an enormous capacity to sustain itself -research grants, gifts from grateful patients, gifts from people anticipating being patients in the future.
''Departments like the humanities or music, on the other hand, don't tend to produce affluent alumni.''
 
Borrowing for Peabody
Dr. Muller has persuaded richer divisions to help the financially weaker ones, but money has been borrowed to pay for the arts and sciences expansion and has made Peabody something of a sacrificial lamb.
After 20 years in the Legislature, Mr. Steinberg has weighed his potential supporters and opponents with care. ''I wanted a consultant's report that also talked about quality,'' he said. Joseph Polisi, the head of Juilliard, was enlisted and backed up Peabody's character and potential. He also suggested that enlarging or reducing the school's 430-student enrollment would damage the school scholastically and not improve its finances.
Mr. Steinberg's second marketing point is tradition and history. ''I don't think that any politician now in office wants to have it on his record that Peabody died on his watch,'' he said. ''Maryland has a tight financial situation now, but I'm saying that an economy of a place is based on its environment. Peabody is an important part of our environment and if we lose it, it's gone forever.''
 
The Next Step
Despite a recent $40 million fund-raising drive for the Baltimore Symphony, Mr. Steinberg doesn't think the philanthropic well is dry. Like Jacques Schlenger, the head of Peabody's board, he says he thinks the money is out there and probably resides with the same sources that have been generous in the past. ''Now I can go out and say that the government is behind this,'' Mr. Steinberg said. He indicated that Maryland's Governor, William Donald Schaefer, backs his plan, which will be presented to the Legislature this month and be resolved by early spring.
''If we had known what we were getting into in 1977, I doubt that we would have taken Peabody on,'' Dr. Muller said. In insisting that the acquisition was never intended as decorative or image-making, he admits that Johns Hopkins sometimes labors under its vast but one-note reputation for medicine. ''The question people always get when they say they went to school here is, 'And what kind of doctor are you?'

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lieut. Gov. Melvin A. Steinberg of Maryland listening as students played at the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore. Mr. Steinberg heads a state panel on Peabody's financial rescue. (NYT/Marty Katz)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: Hollywood Registers A Bonanza For 1989

BYLINE: By ALJEAN HARMETZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Americans flocked to the movies in 1989, and spent more money at the box office than ever before. Seven films sold over $100 million worth of tickets each, the first time so many have achieved blockbuster status.
Based on industry estimates, admissions at the nation's movie theaters rose from 1.08 billion in 1988 to 1.12 billion, the highest total in five years. Moviegoers spent more than $5 billion, smashing last year's box-office record of $4.45 billion. 
Nevertheless, as the 1990's begin, Hollywood is shivering with as much dread as anticipation.
The Christmas movie business was a disaster, with ticket sales dropping 23 percent from 1988. Although theaters were thronged over the New Year's weekend, the crowds did not give much of a hint of what January and February would bring.
Next weekend - the all-important post-holiday weekend - will indicate how well the Christmas movies will hold up and whether the box-office expansion that began in June 1986 will be continuing or coming to an end.
 
Three and a Half Years of Growth
Art Murphy, the box-office analyst for the trade paper Variety, said the current three-and-a-half-year expansion was one of the two longest in the last 40 years. Typically, a three-year expansion is followed by a box-office recession.
Among the year's seven blockbusters, the runaway leader was ''Batman,'' with Jack Nicholson as the deadly Joker. Because his contract gives him a share of merchandising revenue and a fat chunk of the film rentals earned by Warner Brothers, Mr. Nicholson may make as much as $40 million for his performance.
According to Variety's figures, ''Batman'' sold more than $251 million worth of tickets, followed by Paramount's ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' with $196 million, and Warner Brothers' ''Lethal Weapon 2,'' starring Mel Gibson as a wild cop, with $147 million.
It only takes a couple of blockbusters to make a year, and ''Batman'' and ''Lethal Weapon'' were enough to lift Warner Brothers into first place among the studios. Universal came in second on the strength of such solid hits as ''Parenthood,'' ''Field of Dreams,'' ''Uncle Buck'' and the sequel to ''Back to the Future.'' Bringing up the rear among the studios were 20th Century-Fox and Orion.
 
Disney Comedy in Fourth Place
The movie in fourth place for the year was a surprise, Disney's ''Honey, I Shrunk the Kids.'' The comedy about four children the size of bread crumbs grossed $130 million. United Artists' ''Rain Man,'' which starred Tom Cruise and Dustin Hoffman as a car salesman and his autistic savant brother, grossed $129 million during 1989. The Academy Award-winning best movie of 1988, ''Rain Man'' has grossed a grand total of $172 million.
The success of Tri-Star's ''Look Who's Talking,'' about a baby who tries to find a husband for his unmarried mother, was another surprise. The movie, which was initially rejected as a dumb idea by some Hollywood studios, has grossed $115 million so far. The movie has also been a windfall for Bruce Willis, who plays the voice of the baby. Mr. Willis took little salary but asked for a share of any profits. His reward will be $10 million.
Columbia's ''Ghostbusters II,'' although tremendously expensive to make at more than $40 million and considered a box-office disappointment, nonetheless grossed $112 million and is in seventh place. Another movie that is likely to make over $100 million is Universal's ''Back to the Future Part II,'' which has topped $95 million already, although the film is showing little of the stamina of its 1985 predecessor.
An interesting trend in 1989 was the success of movies about children, or aimed at an audience of children. Just as the aging of the movie audience began to be reflected in more serious themes and more sophisticated comedies two years ago, last year the nesting habits of the baby boom generation was being portrayed on the screen and filling seats in the neighborhood multiplexes.
 
A Comeback for Animation
In addition to ''Honey, I Shrunk the Kids'' and ''Look Who's Talking,'' Universal's ''Parenthood'' - a comedy about the pitfalls of raising children - was the eighth most successful movie of the year, grossing more than $95 million.
Animated films have made a comeback as part of this trend. Disney's ''Little Mermaid,'' has grossed nearly $50 million, including more than $9 million last weekend, and is well on its way to overtaking last year's ''Oliver and Company'' as the top-grossing animated feature. Despite bad reviews, Don Bluth's ''All Dogs Go to Heaven'' has grossed $21 million. And Orion's low-budget ''Prancer,'' a small, live-action picture about a reindeer who may or may not belong to Santa Claus, has sold a solid $18 million worth of tickets.
Among the movies that have fared poorly are Orion's big Christmas movie ''She-Devil,'' starring Meryl Streep and Roseanne Barr; ''We're No Angels,'' a comedy starring Sean Penn and Robert De Niro, and ''Family Business,'' with the triple star power of Sean Connery, Dustin Hoffman and Matthew Broderick. Others included Clint Eastwood's ''Pink Cadillac''; Sylvester Stallone's ''Lock Up''; Brian DePalma's Vietnam film ''Casualties of War''; Jane Fonda's ''Old Gringo,'' and ''Great Balls of Fire,'' one of the many failures that left Orion in last place.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Post 9.6% Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Sales of new homes surged 9.6 percent in November, the steepest gain in four months, the Government said today in a report that showed sharp gains in every region of the nation except the South.
The Commerce Department said new single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 710,000 units in November after edging up a revised nine-tenths of 1 percent in October. Sales in October were originally reported to be down five-tenths of 1 percent. 
The November gain was the highest since a 14.1 percent advance in July. Sales had fallen 11.2 percent in September.
 
Credit Markets Shaken a Bit
The report rattled the credit markets, where Treasury securities prices closed down as traders viewed the data as another indication that the economy may not be as weak as initially thought, reducing the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates.
Analysts have been looking for a slight improvement in new-home sales as mortgage interest rates decline. Rates were higher earlier this year as a result of Federal Reserve efforts to moderate inflation by tightening credit.
''The market for new homes remains fixed, with both sales of single- family homes and starts of new homes fluctuating from month to month,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. ''The cumulative effect of lower interest rates since their peak early in 1989 suggests that the housing market may rebound somewhat in the coming months.''
Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.74 percent at the end of November, according to a survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. They had peaked at 11.22 percent in March. But despite the lower rates, analysts say the sluggish economy stemming from the Fed action had driven away many prospective buyers.
New-home sales ran up a 29.9 percent gain in the West, the highest rate since advancing 47.7 percent in November 1981. The Mitsubishi Bank's Weekly Economic Indicator Report suggested the November figure would be partly the result of a rebound from abnormally weak sales after the Oct. 10 California earthquake.
Sales in the Midwest registered a 23.6 percent gain, the sharpest since rising 28.3 percent in July, while the Northeast posted an 8.5 percent increase. Sales in the South, however, fell 7.6 percent after a 5.7 percent increase the previous month.
 
Median Price of New Home
The Commerce Department reported that the median price of a new home was $127,000 in November, up 3.3 percent from the revised median price of $123,000 in October. The median is the point at which half the homes sold for more and half for less.
The average price of a home was $155,900, up 5.6 percent from October.
The National Association of Realtors reported last week that sales of existing single-family homes advanced 3.2 percent in November to their highest level of the year.
John A. Tuccillo, the association's chief economist, predicted then that falling mortgage rates would raise home sales in coming months as buyers take advantage of favorable financing terms.
The median price for existing homes sold in November was $93,000, the realtors group said.
New-home sales for the first 11 months of the year were down 3.5 percent from the corresponding period of 1988.
