HEADLINE: Sematech Today: Cash Dispenser

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Sematech, the Government-industry alliance formed two years ago to develop better ways of making computer chips, has been forced to become a financier as well as a coordinator of company research efforts.
Sematech has decided to assume the broader role because so many of the chip-equipment companies taking part in the consortium's research drive are small and in deep financial trouble, often unable to match the spending by Japanese and European rivals. The new role is proving costly for the Sematech alliance, which is financed by the Government and 14 American semiconductor makers.
Sematech believes it has little choice but to begin providing money and expertise to help develop the equipment to meet the standards it sets for chip-making equipment. As a result, Sematech's members now say, meeting the goal of becoming the world leader in this technology by 1993 will require a lot more money than the $224 million budgeted for the next year. 
Moreover, the project could still fail because its innovations might not bear fruit in time to save dozens of American makers of semiconductor manufacturing equipment either from going under or from being acquired by foreign rivals.
When it began, Sematech saw its primary job as pooling American scientific knowledge to design far more sophisticated chip-making equipment, sharing that knowledge with companies that produce chip-making equipment and then testing what those companies produce to insure that it meets high standards.
Many semiconductor and electronics executives warn that Sematech's success is crucial to American industry.
''If we don't do something pretty promptly to shore up that supplier industry, we could find ourselves a generation behind in the technology,'' said Ian M. Ross, president of Bell Laboratories, the research arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, a leading chip producer. ''The other possibility is that it all goes overseas, and we are all dependent on foreign suppliers.''
 
On Track Toward 1993
Despite those obstacles, Sematech members say the alliance is on track to meets its goal for 1993 of substantially improving the process for producing computer chips so that huge numbers of chips with electronic circuits 300 times finer than a human hair can be manufactured without defects. Smaller circuitry is important because more circuits can be packed onto the same number of chips, reducing costs and increasing the speed of the product by shortening the distance that electric signals must travel.
Sematech members also note that Sematech has already helped some American chip makers improve production methods. And it has dramatically changed the attitude of an American industry that had studiously avoided cooperation in the past.
Still, Sematech has its critics. Some say an independent domestic industry is not important because major chip producers like I.B.M. and A.T.&T. are sophisticated enough to improve the chip-making process and the Pentagon could always obtain advanced chips from them if foreign suppliers refused to cooperate. Others argue that the Government should not be participating in industrial projects. And some argue that even if Sematech succeeds in giving American chip makers an edge in manufacturing, the chip industry would falter anyway. They say many chip users around the world would prefer to order chips from Japanese companies with reputations for better quality and service.
 
A $50 Billion Market
The chips that Sematech is developing the tools to make are expected to be the brains of a wide variety of electronic products in the mid-1990's. Global sales for chips alone are expected by some analysts to reach $50 billion by then; for the electronic goods the chips will operate, the estimated market is $750 billion.
Many Government and industry officials warn that without the improvements that stem from an alliance like Sematech, American chip makers and electronic-goods manufacturers will continue to lose ground to Asian and European rivals. That will hurt the United States economy, where electronics is the nation's largest industry, with 2.7 million workers and 1988 sales of $279 billion.
Thousands of military products also rely on advanced chips, and Pentagon officials are concerned that in times of international tension, important foreign suppliers might decide not to sell their most advanced chips to the United States.
 
How Japan Got an Edge
Japanese companies gained their edge on American companies by reducing the time needed to devise new chip-making standards, in part because they pooled much of their production knowledge. Sematech, short for ''semiconductor manufacturing technology,'' was conceived by senior executives at several American chip makers and Pentagon officials as a forum to share that knowledge among American members.
About 220 of Sematech's 550 employees are scientists, technicians and administrators assigned by the 14 member companies, which still pay their salaries and benefits.
The consortium has already produced designs for production of chips with circuit widths of 0.5 micron, or 200 times as narrow as a human hair, and is expected to perfect the manufacturing and testing techniques before the end of 1990. The Japanese are now only slightly ahead of Sematech in this area, said Avtar Oberai, an International Business Machines Corporation executive at Sematech.
Robert N. Noyce, Sematech's chief executive, said that the production process for chip circuits at 0.5 micron should be available in 1991, and that 0.35-micron chips are on schedule for production by 1993.
 
'Working Very Well'
''Sematech is working very well,'' he said. ''Some of the early results are coming easier and faster than we had planned.''
Yet many makers of chip-making equipment and other supplies that are either working on system models and projects with Sematech or are candidates for such work are in serious financial trouble. While many still spend more than 15 percent of their sales revenue to experiment with new equipment and techniques, Japanese companies have invested twice as much on research in recent years, and have advanced their products enough to capture more of the market.
Sematech has responded to these worries with an abrupt change in spending priorities in the last year. More of its money is now going directly into research and development contracts with the cash-short equipment suppliers; this month alone, Sematech awarded five development contracts, the most since May. At the same time, Sematech is investing less to purchase equipment to conduct manufacturing experiments at Sematech's laboratories.
Sematech officials said the higher budget commitments to research grants had not caused a delay in Sematech testing programs for newly developed chip-making tools at the consortium's Austin laboratories.
Still, the officials acknowledged that difficult decisions could loom if a lack of money forced them to choose between research grants and the testing work in Austin.
But despite Sematech's efforts, many companies supplying equipment or materials to chip makers have been forced to widen their search for capital beyond American borders. This raises the prospect that they will be acquired by foreign companies, transferring abroad any gains from Sematech work.
 
'Go the Way of Other Lost Souls'
''We can't allow the bulk of profits from American technology to end up overseas, but if the Japanese or another foreign country buys us, we'll go the way of other lost souls,'' said Andrew K. Lorenz, president of Semi-Gas Systems Inc. of San Jose, Calif., which supplies half the gases and related equipment used by American-based chip makers. Semi-Gas was one of the first suppliers chosen by Sematech in the spring.
Companies in Japan, West Germany and Britain are among foreign bidders for Semi-Gas, which Hercules Inc. of Wilmington, Del., has said it plans to sell.
In the last three years, 28 domestic companies supplying equipment or materials to American chip makers have been bought by companies in Japan and Europe; 30 were acquired by American companies, and 4 closed their doors. Sematech does not work with foreign-owned suppliers, and the number of domestic companies eligible to compete for Sematech contracts is down to 130. Of that group, more than 100 have annual sales of $25 million or less.
Most of those companies have little cash to pour into costly research. Yet the next generation of chip-making technology will require a collective investment of at least $2.5 billion in the United States before any chips are sold, according to VLSI Research, a research firm in San Jose.
 
U.S. Share Dropping
American companies held half of the $8.2 billion in global sales for chip-making equipment in 1988, compared with three-quarters of a $2.1 billion market in 1980. The Japanese increased their share to 39 percent from 24 percent in that period, and are expected to take the lead in a few years, VLSI Research said.
''America cannot let that happen,'' said Robert W. Galvin, chairman of Motorola Inc., a large chip maker. ''If Sematech starts producing results, there is a rational chance that it will reinvigorate elements of the industry. We are enthusiastic.'' Last month, a panel of Government officials and industry executives urged Congress, the White House and the domestic chip makers to increase Sematech's annual budget so that the consortium could pump more money into financially fragile suppliers.
Dr. Ross of Bell Laboratories and Mr. Galvin of Motorola, both members of the panel, the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors, said in interviews that they would soon campaign for Congress to approve more money for Sematech.
 
Government Contributions
The Government has contributed $100 million in each of the last two years; the member companies will exceed that by $24 million in 1990. They surpassed that by more than $75 million in 1989. The panel wants industry and Government to add a total of $100 million now, and $800 million over the next three years.
Still, officials in the chip-making business and the Pentagon acknowledge that money alone cannot insure that the American suppliers benefiting from Sematech research will remain in American hands in coming years. Problems beyond Sematech's influence include the rapidly growing chip markets in Asia, where trade barriers have made it difficult for American companies to compete; the higher cost of raising money in the United States, and lagging numbers of scientists and well-trained production workers in the United States.
Even as Sematech struggles to complete its mission, it has produced some tangible benefits for American chip companies. For example, the National Semiconductor Corporation, in Santa Clara, Calif., said it had built several wafer-fabrication lines in the last 18 months using documents prepared at Sematech, said Jim Owens, head of wafer production at the company. ''That definitely saved us time and money,'' he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 22, 1990, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption in Business Day on Jan. 4 about Sematech, the Government-industry alliance formed to improve ways of making computer chips, referred imprecisely to Semi-Gas Systems Inc. Despite the juxtaposition with a reference to other companies' troubles, Semi-Gas is profitable and currently has no long-term debt. The adjoining article also described part of Semi-Gas's business incorrectly. The company is the largest supplier of equipment for handling special gases used in semiconductor production; its customers include semiconductor manufacturers in many major industrial nations.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
It's Slow Going In Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By Robert J. Cole

 BODY:
THE Samsonite Corporation, the world's biggest luggage producer, has been working on a deal for six months to make luggage in Hungary for sale in Western Europe. Production is already under way, even though details of a joint venture with a Government cooperative are far from complete.
If the experience of Western experts who work closely with Eastern European officials is any guide, the details could take considerable time to work out.
Peter Rona, president and chief executive of the IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company, an adviser to American subsidiaries of foreign companies, discussed the complexities of Eastern European deals in a recent interview in downtown Manhattan. One client, Asea Brown Boveri A.B., the Swedish electrical giant, invested less than $10 million last year in a Hungarian transformer plant, Mr. Rona recalled, and the deal took nearly a year. 
''A year's amount of time and effort is very hard to justify in light of the size of the deal,'' he commented. ''And, technically, it's still not done.''
There are no legal approvals, permits or licenses and no accounting niceties of the Western world, he said, nor are there procedures to protect proprietary knowledge or even dismiss people in a system where, until now, workers were guaranteed employment for life.
Raising a problem facing all companies doing business with the Eastern bloc, Mr. Rona, a Hungarian-born American lawyer and a specialist on trade with the Eastern bloc, said, ''There is no legal system to make you feel comfortable that the agreement and understandings are legally enforceable, and until last year there was no market to reflect the value of corporate assets because all businesses were Government-owned.''
Despite the difficulties, Western business people are excited about the possibilities opening up in Eastern Europe. Mr. Rona ticked off a few deals in the works:
* General Electric is trying to buy 50 percent of Tungsram, the Hungarian light bulb maker, which has 8 percent of the West European market.
* Guardian Industries, a Detroit plate glass manufacturer, is committing $100 million to make glass in Hungary for export and local consumption.
* Barbara Piasecka Johnson, the Polish-born widow of J. Seward Johnson, son of the founder of the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical company, has declared her readiness to spend as much as $100 million in Poland to revitalize the Gdansk shipyards.
* Karl Kassbohrer Fahrzengwerke G.m.b.H., a West German bus maker, is negotating with Ikarus, a Hungarian bus maker, to make buses for sale in Western Europe.
* Volkswagen of West Germany is negotiating with Warburg, producer of East Germany's Trabant car, to make cars for sale in East Germany.
* Citibank, which opened its only East European branch in Hungary four years ago, is helping employees buy Hungary's state-owned stationery business, Apisz.
A big part of the incentive, of course, is that in two years the European Community will not only eliminate internal tariff barriers but also promote economic development in Eastern Europe by cutting tariffs.
''You have a highly educated work force working for very low wages'' in Eastern Europe, Mr. Rona said, ''and you're betting that with proper technological transfer and industrial organization, they will be highly productive.'' The savings on labor costs would offset any remaining duties, he added.
IBJ Schroder, which is becoming increasingly active in Eastern European deals, represents such big-name clients as Electrolux A. B., the Swedish appliance maker; Hoechst G.m.b.H., the West German chemicals producer, and YKK, the Japanese zipper manufacturer. Based in New York, it is 98.3 percent owned by the Industrial Bank of Japan. The rest is owned by the parent company of the British merchant bank of J. Henry Schroder Wagg & Company Ltd.
In view of the uncertainties, is it really worth the trouble?
''Absolutely,'' said Steven J. Green, chairman and chief executive of Samsonite, which also buys luggage from manufacturers in South Korea and Taiwan. ''We think the quality will be better and more controllable because it's our factory.''
Discussing the red tape, Mr. Green noted in a telephone interview that while Eastern Europe was angling for Western deals, ''Theirs was not an entrepreneurial system, and the system is creating a lot of bottlenecks.'' Even so, he forecast ''a tremendous benefit to Samsonite down the road,'' and raised the possibility of expanding the Hungarian operation.
''What he figured out,'' Mr. Rona said, ''is that he can get the same productivity and quality in Hungary as in Korea or Taiwan - and he doesn't have to pay the shipping cost'' to Europe. That means more profit, Mr. Rona said.
As a first step, Eastern European experts will meet Jan. 8-12 in Indianapolis to map a program to help Hungary. It will be sponsored by the Hudson Institute of Indianapolis and the East-West Forum of Washington, two research groups specializing in Eastern Europe, Indiana University and independent Hungarian institutions.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President Appointed By Pacific Exchange

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher

 BODY:
The Pacific Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had appointed Leopold Korins president, effective Jan. 22. Mr. Korins, who is currently managing director of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, is also expected to be named chief executive officer by the exchange's board of governors on Jan. 25.
Mr. Korins, who is 56 years old, succeeds Herbert Kawahara as president and will replace Dr. Maurice Mann as chief executive. Mr. Kawahara resigned in June. Mr. Mann, who is 60, will continue as chairman and as a consultant until May 1. He has not indicated his plans. 
The Pacific Exchange has had financial difficulties in recent years, but it had its most profitable year in 1989. Dr. Mann is given credit for making significant changes in the exchange's structure since his appointment in early 1987. The exchange is now debating opening a third trading floor in Hawaii to complement its floors in San Francisco and Los Angeles.
''I think that the opportunity to play a key role in the development of these markets in the next three to five years offers something I've been pointing to all my career,'' Mr. Korins said. ''I think the exchange is in a unique position to take advantage of some time frames in the trading day which have not been exploited,'' he said. ''It is the only exchange which has the potential to fill a time frame after the New York Stock Exchange is closed and prior to the opening of the Japan exchange.''
Although a number of West Coast brokerage firms have closed or been merged, Mr. Korins said he sees ''the whole West Coast as a tremendously fertile territory for the development of new broker dealers.''
He said he would work to strengthen the rapport between brokers and the regional exchange. ''There is tremendous potential to get people to fully utilize this asset in their own community, both in Los Angeles and San Francisco,'' he said.
After receiving his B.S. in economics from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania in 1954, Mr. Korins served in the Army and began his career at Merrill Lynch as an account executive in 1957. He held various positions including floor broker, managing director of the equity trading group, regional manager for New York institutional sales and director of marketing and sales for unit trusts.
Mr. Korins and his wife, who live in New Jersey and have one grown son, plan to move to San Francisco, where the Pacific Exchange is based.

HEADLINE: Study Says the Military Hurts Competitiveness

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Although Pentagon contracts provide ''safe havens'' for American high-technology companies, the military's emphasis on low-volume, high-cost products has put those companies at a commercial disadvantage, especially in competition with Japanese manufacturers, a study sponsored by the Ford Foundation contends.
''The characteristics of the defense procurement system are completely antithetical to what you need to be successful in the commercial sector,'' said the author of the study, Prof. Susan W. Sanderson of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's School of Management.
By contrast, Professor Sanderson's report said, Japanese high-technology companies have generally had to rely on high-volume, fast-turnaround consumer markets to spur growth. The Japanese Government encouraged them to become more competitive, developing sophisticated designs and manufacturing techniques for rapidly changing, highly competitive environments, the report said. 
 
Military Cuts Will Help
American high-technology companies stand to grow more competitive and to prosper if American military spending is cut, as expected, as East-West relations improve, Professor Sanderson said in an interview today.
A number of economists and analysts have speculated about the effect of sharply reduced military spending, both on military contractors and more broadly on American manufacturing. The Senate Budget Committee has scheduled hearings later this month on ''the question of how to handle the military build-down,'' Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the committee, said in an interview. One subject will be ways to enhance the commercial competitiveness of military contractors, he said.
''The Pentagon procurement system has serious flaws with regard to developing a cost-efficient approach that will allow a firm to be competitive on the open market,'' he added.
Asked to comment on the report, Robert C. Costello, former Under Secretary of Defense for acquisition, said, ''Under the present conditions, with all the rules, regulations and standards, much of what it says is right.'' He added, ''The conditions are now in the process of being modified'' to overcome problems highlighted in the report.
 
Cutbacks Called a 'Blessing'
Professor Sanderson, an expert on the manufacture and design of products, who was the sole author of the study, maintained that Pentagon cutbacks would be a ''blessing.''
She added: ''The question is, How are we going to get our companies to be able to make the transition from defense production to commercial production? It's absolutely essential that we make the transition. We're going to have to put corporate and Government resources together.''
The report noted that American companies had gradually decided to pull out of consumer electronics manufacturing at the same time that foreign companies were making a long-term commitment to improving their design and production. Supported by Government industrial policies, companies in Japan, South Korea, Europe and elsewhere applied sophisticated manufacturing technologies and revamped their corporate organizations to produce advanced products ever more quickly, the report said.
 
Time-Consuming Process
The non-competitiveness of American companies is worsened by the Pentagon's time-consuming approval process for all products used in production, Professor Sanderson said. ''In the long run, they end up in a situation in which they aren't using state-of-the-art products,'' she said.
Professor Sanderson cited the General Electric Company, which was once ''going great guns in the consumer electronics industry'' as a company that could ultimately benefit from the ''peace dividend.''
J. Richard Iverson, president of the American Electronics Association, said the Pentagon spent about $40 billion a year on electronics equipment, little of it the most advanced. ''You don't have any modern products in any weapons systems,'' Mr. Iverson said. ''It takes too long to get there.''
The Sanderson report noted that in the last 20 years the United States had gone from being the world's leading producer of electrical and electronic goods to a major consumer of such products made elsewhere.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were up sharply for the week ended yesterday.
Analysts at Donoghue's said the yields had risen because of seasonal pressures, like the absence of Japanese investors, and should stay at current levels for a week or two before falling. They also noted that stronger-than-expected economic reports were also a factor behind higher short-term interest rates during the holiday period. The employment report for December, which is due tomorrow, may give more clues to the direction of interest rates, they said. 
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market mutual fund increased 20 basis points, to 8.39 percent, while the 30-day yield increased 4 basis points, to 8.26 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Assets of taxable funds fell $3.6 billion, to $356.6 billion. IBC/Donoghue's analysts said much of the decline had come from consumer funds, whose assets fell by $2.3 billion, to $240.9 billion.
The average number of days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios declined by 2 days, to 39 days, as managers took advantage of higher short-term rates.
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that are surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, the Alger Money Market Portfolio, distributed by Fred Alger & Company of Jersey City, had the best return on a yield of 9.16 percent, about 77 basis points better than the average yield in the week.
Tax-exempt assets declined $1.5 billion, to $69.9 billion, as the average seven-day compounded yield increased 19 basis points, to 6.07 percent. The taxable equivalent would be 8.43 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 9.05 percent for those in a 33 percent bracket. Portfolio managers reduced the average days to maturity of portfolio securities to 52 from 53.
The top-performing fund in the week was the Calvert Tax Free Reserves Money Market Fund, distributed by the Calvert Group in Washington, D.C. The fund posted a return of 6.78 percent, or about 71 points better than the average.
By contrast, bank money market accounts, which did not succumb to year-end pressures, remained unchanged at 6.35 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, while the average yield for a six-month C.D. dropped one basis point, to 7.92 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Are Down While Crude Oil Prices Rise

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Precious metal prices continued to fall yesterday, largely on the firmness of the dollar and the belief that the Federal Reserve will not reduce interest rates because of recent signs of economic improvement.
Prices of crude oil continued to soar on the willingness of many refiners to pay more despite production problems at several Southern refineries. Much of the buying reflected strong prices for heating oil and the unusually tight gasoline supply for the season. 
''The precious metals market, led by gold, again ignored the rising energy prices and their impact on inflation and focused instead on the recent firmness of the dollar and indications that the economy was not as weak as had been thought,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, a precious metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities.
Among the recent bullish economic signs, she said, is the upturn in sales of new homes and construction starts in real estate. The strong equities market has also prompted many investment fund managers to switch out of gold mining shares.
All this comes at a time when the precious metals markets are unusually thin, Ms. Raptopoulos said, ''because many of the important participants, particularly those in Asia and Europe, have closed shop for the Christmas and New Year's holidays.''
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the spot January gold delivery settled at $394 an ounce, down $5.60 on the day. The closing gold price was the lowest since mid-November. The spot Comex silver contract settled at $5.151 an ounce, down 3.2 cents. It was the lowest spot silver price since mid-October.
The spot January platinum delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange settled at $469.80 an ounce, off $4.40. That was the lowest level since last September.
Peter C. Beutel, an energy analyst at Elders Futures Inc., said ''that despite refinery production problems, much of related to the uncommonly cold weather along the Gulf and other parts of the South, refiners continue to be the big buyers of crude.''
The refiners have sharply increased their buying of crude because of the soaring demand and prices of heating oil, as well as unleaded gasoline, Mr. Beutel said, adding that ''some of the refinery problems have been in the plants that produce gasoline.''
At the close of the New York Merc, the spot February crude oil delivery settled at another contract high of $23.68 a barrel, up 79 cents on the day. The spot February unleaded gasoline contract climbed 1.54 cents a gallon, to 67.23 cents, and the spot February heating oil delivery rose 0.81 cent a gallon, to 78.20 cents.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Mark Trading But Declines Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday against the primary foreign currencies, falling more than a yen against the Japanese currency and rising against the West German mark.
Traders said the dollar fell against the yen partly in response to reported efforts by the Bank of Japan to drive it down by selling dollars in Singapore and London. The Tokyo market was closed for an extended New Year's holiday. 
Earl I. Johnson, a trader at Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said technical factors were responsible for the dollar's movements. But he said trading remained thin as many dealers extended their holiday.
The market was beginning to focus on tomorrow's release of unemployment data for December to get a better picture on the outlook for the American economy, Mr. Johnson said. He said some of the dealers felt the data would show strength in the number of non-farm jobs, which could support the dollar.
But he said he did not think that was sustainable. The fundamental argument, he said, is for a weaker United States economy and softer interest rates.
The dollar was also depressed by reports that Japan's central bank had intervened several times in Europe and in Singapore to support the faltering yen, the dealers said.
The yen has been under pressure recently because of Japan's relatively low interest rates and as rumors of another stock scandal begin to appear.
In New York, the dollar stood at 145.25 yen, down from 146.45 yen on Tuesday. Earlier, in London, the dollar was quoted at 145.70 yen, up from Tuesday's 144.09 yen.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound. Sterling dropped to $1.6080 an ounce in London, from $1.6115 late on Tuesday, and rose to $1.6115 an ounce, from $1.6085 in New York.
Against the West German currency, the dollar rose in the United States to 1.7208 marks, from 1.7128.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with those late on Tuesday, included: 1.5785 Swiss francs, down from 1.5815; 5.8765 French francs, up from 5.8510; 1,289.00 Italian lire, up from 1,284.00, and 1.15985 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16005.

HEADLINE: NORIEGA'S SURRENDER: CHRONOLOGY;
Vatican Issues an Ultimatum And a General Takes a Walk

BYLINE: This article was reported by Andrew Rosenthal, Elaine Sciolino and David E. Pitt, and was written by Mr. Rosenthal., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
After 10 days of trying to persuade Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to give himself up, the Vatican's envoy to Panama on Wednesday entered the spartan quarters that served as the deposed Panamanian dictator's temporary sanctuary and delivered an ultimatum: His refuge in the Vatican Embassy would expire at noon today.
Within hours, the once-feared general walked out of the embassy compound with the cleric, Msgr. Jose Sebastian Laboa, and surrendered to American soldiers in the presence of the general who commanded the 24,000 United States troops who had seized Panama 16 days earlier.
 
Monsignor's Diplomacy
Monsignor Laboa's terse warning, recounted today by a senior Administration official, was the culmination of an extraordinary personal effort by Monsignor Laboa, the Papal Nuncio, to get General Noriega out of the Vatican Embassy without appearing to be kicking him out the door in violation of the church's ancient promise of sanctuary.
A reconstruction of the events leading to General Noriega's surrender, pieced together today from accounts by Administration officials and others involved in the Panama crisis, indicated that it was the personal diplomacy and tenacity of Monsignor Laboa that ultimately forced General Noriega from the Vatican Embassy. 
But the officials said the turning point in the diplomatic stalemate over the general's fate came Saturday, when the Vatican, under pressure from the United States and the Panamanian clergy, decided to drop its refusal to turn General Noriega over to the United States and made it clear that it would not allow him to go to a third country.
That cut off General Noriega's favored route of escape and enabled Monsignor Laboa, an outgoing Spaniard who has often said he was a priest before he was a diplomat, to begin the psychological and emotional assault that persuaded General Noriega he had two choices: turn himself over to the American military and be tried in the United States on drug charges that could put him in prison for life or surrender to his own people, thousands of whom were in the streets outside the embassy demonstrating against the general on Wednesday, the day he made his decision.
Although thousands of protesters were waving American flags, Administration officials said today that the United States did not orchestrate the protest.
 
Wearing His Uniform
General Noriega, a former head of military intelligence and student of psychological warfare, decided to walk out of the embassy, wearing his uniform to maintain the appearance of military dignity, and take his chances in an American court, where he might be able to beat the charges against him or at least embarrass his adversary, President Bush. The Stalemate Begins From Frustration To Actions The President's announcement that General Noriega was in custody and headed for trial in the United States, after two and a half years in which the Panamanian leader thumbed his nose at American threats and cajoling, was a satisfying conclusion for the President to an operation that had at first been frustrated, at least in part.
As thousands of American troops stormed Panama City on Dec. 20, smashing the Panamanian Defense Forces and installing a new Government that had been elected in May but prevented from taking office by General Noriega, the Panamanian leader eluded the American authorities. For four days, he hid in Panama City, moving from one hideout to another, sometimes just steps ahead of his pursuers.
Then, on Christmas Eve, he surfaced in the Spanish-style nunciature in the heart of Panama City, and the Vatican announced that it would not turn him over to the United States, which it considered an invading power. The Administration began a diplomatic blitzkrieg to convince the Vatican that General Noriega had no legal right to the church's protection.
On Christmas morning, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d telephoned Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, the Vatican Secretary of State, from Houston with a strong message: that the ousted Panamanian leader was a fugitive from justice, not a political refugee, and that he should be delivered immediately to the United States for trial. Thomas Miledy, the American Ambassador to the Vatican, repeated the message a day later to Vatican officials.
Although Mr. Bush, who was personally directing the key aspects of the Panama invasion, relishes any opportunity to exercise his skill at personal diplomacy, he avoided direct involvement in the diplomatic play over General Noriega's fate. White House officials said they reasoned that if Mr. Bush stepped in personally, telephoning Pope John Paul II or making some other dramatic gesture, it might appear that the United States was trying to strong-arm the Roman Catholic Church.
Mr. Bush called the Pope today, the White House announced, to thank him for the Vatican's help in resolving the crisis.
Still, Vatican officials bristled at the Americans' sharp words, insisting that its nunciature, like any other embassy, was empowered to deal only with the host country and would violate international law by handing over the general directly to the United States authorities. The General's Isolation A Simple Room And a Broken TV After taking sanctuary inside the nunciature, General Noriega was left with little to do except contemplate his fate. But for Vatican officials, the first task, one that they later described as one of the most difficult of the entire crisis, was disarming the general. He had arrived at the mission armed.
First, the clerics persuaded General Noriega to give up a pistol that he carried with him when he arrived at the nunciature on Christmas Eve. Later, they discovered a knife in his possession and persuaded him to give it up.
Monsignor Laboa said today that General Noriega also found, and hid under his bed, an automatic rifle that apparently had been left in the nunciature by one of three Noriega associates who had earlier taken refuge there. He said Eliezer Gaitan, a former bodyguard for the general, helped persuade him to surrender the weapon and then played a key role in the negotiations, acting as an intermediary for the general with the monsignor and top American officers.
The surrender of Luis del Cid, a top officer in the Noriega forces, further isolated the general and ''had a tremendous impact'' in lowering his morale, Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros, the second-in-command of American forces in Panama, said today.
In contrast to the opulence of his island bunker overlooking the Pacific entrance to the Panama Canal, the toppled ruler was largely confined to a simple white room with a crucifix, a broken television set and a few pieces of furniture. There was no air-conditioning to cut the tropical Panamanian heat, and he could not see out the opaque windows.
''Spartan in their simplicity,'' is how one former occupant of the room described the quarters, which were earlier used by prominent Panamanian opposition figures when they fled General Noriega's Defense Forces and were given refuge by Monsignor Laboa.
Deprived of the racks of French-tailored uniforms that hung in the closets of his former quarters, General Noriega was dressed in simple civilian clothes, according to diplomats in Panama who are friends of Monsignor Laboa. A vegetarian, he was forced to eat the food served to other embassy residents. Limited to one wing of the house, largely shunned by Vatican officials and workers, unable to receive visitors or make more than a few limited phone calls, separated from his mistress, his wife and three daughters, who sought refuge inside the Cuban Embassy, he found himself increasingly isolated.
''He kept pretty much to himself and was downcast and a bit moody,'' Archbishop Marcos McGrath, Panama's senior churchman, told NBC's ''Today'' program today.
The only time General Noriega socialized with other guests and residents at the Vatican Embassy was on Christmas Day and New Year's Eve, when the papal envoy served special communal meals. But one of Monsignor Laboa's aides was so distressed at General Noriega's presence that he would not sit down at the same table with him.
After dinner on New Year's Eve, the group went to Mass. The general sat by himself in the last pew.
Outside, American troops tried to wear him down by blasting the heavy metal sounds of rock groups like Twisted Sister and radio news reports about his fate at ear-splitting levels. Helicopters hovered overhead and tanks rumbled up and down the street.
For diplomats in Washington, the approach adopted by the Papal Nuncio was a masterpiece of psychological persuasion. ''He closed all the doors one by one, until Noriega himself concluded that his only alternative was to surrender to the United States,'' a diplomat said today.
A friend of Monsignor Laboa said, ''Every time General Noriega accepted that one solution was no longer possible, Monsignor Laboa would move on to the next point, wearing away at Noriega's resistance until he was convinced that that route too was now closed.''
By character and training, Monsignor Laboa was ideally equipped for such a task. In the two-and-a-half-year struggle to oust General Noriega, the Vatican envoy maintained an official neutrality while privately doing everything he could to encourage the anti-Noriega forces.
The nuncio also had to consider the safety of his own people. When Gen. Maxwell Thurman, the commanding officer of the American troops in Panama, reportedly urged him to at least evacuate nuns from the Vatican mission out of fear that the general and the Panamanian military officers accompanying him would take the clergyman and the staff hostage, he sent a letter to American officials authorizing General Thurman to send American troops into the mission if a hostage crisis arose, according to officials close to the papal envoy. The Political Quandary Moral High Ground And Waiting Game The diplomatic atmosphere outside the nunciature was delicate.
Archbishop McGrath said the church thought it had done the right thing by granting the general's request for sanctuary. But he said, ''We were so up against the wall about what would be the next step.''
Church officials reasoned that if they allowed General Noriega to stay in their protection, they ran the risk of going against public opinion in the United States and Panama. But turning him over to the United States could violate the sanctity of the church and international law, they said.
In Washington, Administration officials had assigned a high priority to seizing General Noriega, but the United States was not eager to become embroiled in a bitter fight with the Vatican.
''We decided to take the moral high ground,'' an official said. ''We figured it was probably a waiting game, that the Vatican did not have the political or religious authority or the desire to hang on to Noriega and that they were as anxious as we were to come off in a good light.''
Both sides began looking for ways to move gracefully from the positions they had taken at the start of the negotiations.
Officials of the papal mission here and Panamanian officials said the idea of declaring the papal mission no longer diplomatically immune was one of several possibilities mentioned in the course of negotiations with General Noriega in efforts to force his exit from the building.
Ricardo Arias Calderon, First Vice President in the new Government, said, ''My understanding was that the Vatican was heading in that direction.''
Mr. Arias Calderon said Monsignor Laboa discussed the possibility with General Noriega that the mission would simply lower its flag and declare itself no longer the embassy if he persisted in his determination to remain in the mission.
The Rev. Javier Villanueva, a spokesman for the papal mission, said, ''Had Noriega not surrendered to the United States and the Papal Nuncio, there were other alternatives possible.''
''One of the alternatives,'' he said, ''was to give Noriega to the Panamanian Government, but they never requested him.''
The Rev. Villanueva said that ''struggles in the Government leadership'' over whether they wanted to take General Noriega into custody had effectively eliminated the possibility of the papal mission unilaterally ending its diplomatic immunity.
But Mr. Arias Calderon and the spokesman for the Papal Nuncio stressed that that option was seriously considered, at least for a time. The Negotiations The Church And the Army Much of the direct negotiating between the Vatican and the United States was done by Monsignor Laboa, General Thurman and General Cisneros.
Michael G. Kozak, a deputy assistant secretary of state and a lawyer who helped negotiate the Panama Canal Treaties and had negotiated face to face with General Noriega when the Reagan Administration tried to get him to step down from power, also was a key negotiator.
Vatican officials tried to find a country that might be willing to give asylum to General Noriega. But Administration officials said they insisted the general must come to the United States to stand trial.
To help persuade the Vatican and General Noriega to take that course, the United States assured Vatican officials that the charges against him did not carry the death penalty. ''We thought that it would make a substantial difference in their willingness,'' the senior official said.
Throughout, Administration officials said they walked a thin line between pushing the Vatican toward the American position and avoiding the appearance that they were strong-arming the Roman Catholic Church.
''We emphasized that this was not a traditional request for political asylum since he had been indicted on charges that went beyond U.S. borders,'' an official said.
Then, the United States got help from Panamanian clerics. Archbishop McGrath said he and other bishops in the country wrote the Pope and ''repeated our longstanding accusations against Noriega for his violation of human rights.''
That, he said, prompted the Vatican to announce on Saturday that General Noriega ''was not considered to be in diplomatic or political asylum but a person in refuge against whom there were criminal charges.''
Over the next few days, Monsignor Laboa, encouraged by the United States, stepped up his campaign to break down General Noriega's resistance.
Administration officials said the United States never directly negotiated with General Noriega. They also said they made ''no deals'' with him, offering only assurances that he would be given a fair trial and would not face the death penalty. The General's Surrender The Time Runs Out For the Dictator On Tuesday, Monsignor Laboa told American negotiators that he would take another day to try to ''talk some sense into the general,'' said a State Department official. On Wednesday afternoon, Monsignor Laboa delivered the final blow, telling General Noriega that at noon today, his sanctuary would run out. The man who had survived coups and intense economic and diplomatic pressure surrendered.
The Vatican immediately told the United States Southern Command that General Noriega would probably leave that evening, and the President was given the news about 6:30 P.M. The Papal Nuncio also called the new Government of President Guillermo Endara. At 7:30, another call came to the United States authorities, this time saying the general would leave the nunciature in about an hour.
At the general's request, his uniform, dark brown pants and a tan shirt with military emblems, was taken to him. He reportedly talked to his wife, Felicidad, who was in the Cuban Embassy, and with his mistress, Vickie Amado.
At 8:48, in pitch blackness, General Noriega made the 20-yard walk to Avenida Balboa, where United States soldiers waited to handcuff him.
''I will pray for you everyday,'' the Rev. Javier Villanueva, one of the priests, said he told the ousted dictator.
''Thank you,'' replied the general.

HEADLINE: With Official Permission, Change Stirs Mongolia

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Less dramatically than in Berlin and less bloodily than in Bucharest, the winds of Communist change have swept across the Gobi Desert to stir up political life in the sparsely populated nation of Mongolia.
Sandwiched between China and the Soviet Union, Mongolia is twice the size of Texas but is home to only two million people, many of them nomadic herdsman. Mongolia has attracted little attention in the West since the 13th century, when its warriors conquered most of Asia and swept as far west as Eastern Europe.
In 1921, Mongolia became the second country in the world - after the Soviet Union - to turn to Communism, and for most of this century life has been governed by a rigid Stalinist order. That has been changing recently, and in the last month the pace has accelerated. 
Temperatures in the capital, Ulan Bator, often reach 15 degrees below zero at this time of year, but inside their homes and traditional felt tents, known as yurts, some Mongolians are talking animatedly about politics and demanding unprecedented changes, according to reports in the Mongolian press and by two diplomats reached by telephone from Beijing.
 
Rallies Are Permitted
The Government has responded favorably, the diplomats said, and twice last month rallies were held in Ulan Bator, with official permission, to encourage further change. Rallies have also been held in at least three other cities, the diplomats said, but information is sketchy on those gatherings.
''Democracy is our goal'' and ''Solidarity for human rights'' were among the banners unfurled at the rallies in Ulan Bator. Some of the banners were in English, reflecting the current national enthusiasm for learning English, the diplomats said.
Some of the protesters also called for a reappraisal of Genghis Khan, the 13th century Mongol conqueror who terrorized Europe and Asia. Partly out of respect for Soviet sensibilities, since Genghis Khan is a dark figure in Russian history, he was almost entirely ignored for decades here. Now a hotel is being named for him, and a movie is being made of his life, but the rehabilitation is not rapid enough to suit many Mongolians.
Diplomats said the unrest was inspired partly by news of the events in Eastern Europe. While there are very few foreigners in Mongolia to spread the news - the few tourists who go to Mongolia mostly just rumble through the desert and grassland while on the trans-Siberian railroad between Beijing and Moscow - there have been accounts in the Mongolian press, and some Mongolians are avid listeners of Voice of America and British Broadcasting Corporation news bulletins.
Estimates of the number of people who attended each rally range from 250 to more than 1,000. The rallies were organized by an unofficial organization calling itself the Mongolian Democratic Association.
 
Free Elections Demanded
The association has prepared a formal charter and has asked to be officially recognized by the Government. Among its demands are free elections to choose national leaders, national referendums on major issues, a more market-oriented economy and an end to the privileges of officials.
The demonstrators have pledged to work within the system, and the diplomats interviewed said they did not expect the kind of mass unrest or rebellion seen recently in Eastern Europe. They also said there was much less hostility to the Soviet Union in Mongolia than in Eastern Europe. Many Mongolians regard the Soviet Union as a protector and counterbalance against China, the diplomats said.
''It's not an unhappy marriage with the Soviet Union,'' a diplomat said. ''This is not an anti-Soviet movement.'' Mongolia's press and broadcasting gave extensive coverage to the demonstrations, and the national labor union newspaper carried a supportive editorial. Three members of the Mongolian Democratic Association were even invited to join a television debate last week against a representative of the ruling Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party.
Newspapers have been increasingly daring in reporting discontent and in criticizing the policies of Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal, who headed the ruling party for 26 years until he was ousted in 1984.
 
Official Calls for Change
''The genuine human rights upheld in all major laws of the country were violated during the period of personality cult and thousands of innocent people became victims of unlawfulness and repression,'' the national newspaper Unen said in an editorial last month.
Under the current party leader, Jambyn Batmonh, some of the calls for change have been coming from within the leadership. The national radio service reported after a Central Committee meeting a few weeks ago that people favored ''sweeping changes in the society.'' And the new Deputy Prime Minister was quoted as saying, ''We must change our notion about socialism and the way we are building a socialist society.''
While the focus of the recent unrest has been political change, some Mongolians are reported to have been driven to action by a perceived slight by Garry Kasparov, the young Soviet citizen who is world chess champion. Mr. Kasparov proposed, in the end of a long interview with Playboy magazine, that Mongolia might be sold to China to raise money for the Soviet Union.
The Soviet spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said this week that the chess champion's ''fantastic idea'' had resulted in a deluge of protest letters and petitions arriving at Soviet diplomatic missions in Mongolia, The Associated Press reported from Moscow.
According to the A.P., Mr. Gerasimov said Mr. Kasparov's proposal had nothing in common with Soviet policy.

HEADLINE: NORIEGA'S SURRENDER: PANAMA;
'Criminal Is Gone,' but Joy Is Fleeting in Land He Ruled

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Jan. 4

 BODY:
With Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in American custody and out of the country, relieved Panamanians turned their attention today to the arduous process of repairing the damage he inflicted on the political, social and economic fabric of this nation of 2.3 million people during his six-year rule.
At Government offices, businesses and banks, Panamanians reported to work still aglow with delight from the street celebrations that exploded here when General Noriega's departure was announced Wednesday night. But that joy has been tempered by awareness that the country still faces serious problems that will not be easy to resolve.
''The criminal is gone, and we are happy to be rid of him,'' said Ligia Cornejo, a middle-aged office worker. ''But I am still here, and my children and I are the ones who will have to live with the consequences of all the evil deeds the dictatorship committed when it pillaged and intimidated this country.'' 
The new civilian Government that took power after the American military invasion on Dec. 20 took no time to savor its victory. While ordinary Panamanians were dancing in the streets, President Guillermo Endara summoned his Cabinet for an unusual midnight meeting, part of a continuing effort to revise or abolish the many institutions that General Noriega and his associates subverted or corrupted. #90% Support Seen for Endara ''This is a golden opportunity to restructure this country in a much more modern light,'' a prominent Panamanian political figure said. ''We need to repeal the political and judiciary systems, cleanse the bureaucracy and get rid of practices that only create corruption.''
A senior Panamanian Government official said today that the resignation of Col. Roberto Armijo, appointed on Dec. 23 as head of Panama's new Public Security Force, came after evidence of his corruption surfaced in a Government investigation. The official said he could not rule out the possibility that Colonel Armijo, a member of General Noriega's inner circle, would be prosecuted on the corruption charges.
Action against other remnants of the Noriega Government continued today. It was announced that Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, the much-despised head of the secret police, is now in United States custody on a military base here.
For the moment, Mr. Endara is the principal beneficiary of the vacuum left by the collapse of the Noriega Government. Archbishop Marcos McGrath, the country's highest-ranking Roman Catholic, estimated today that ''at least 90 percent of the population'' supports the Endara Government and would vote for it if a plebiscite were held immediately.
 
Discord in Panama Government
But many Panamanian and foreign analysts said they believed it would be difficult for the new Government to maintain that consensus for very long. Members of Mr. Endara's Authentic Panamanian Party and First Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon's Christian Democrats have already begun sniping at each other in private.
''So long as Noriega was around, he could be the focal point of the entire nation's hatred and frustration,'' an Latin American diplomat said. ''But now, things will inevitably start to splinter because this is, after all, going to be a democracy.''
The most immediate problem, however, is rebuilding the shattered economy that once gave Panama the highest standard of living in Central America and the Caribbean. As a result of the political turmoil of the last two and a half years and the American economic sanctions imposed last year, the economy has shrunk by at least 25 percent and unemployment has doubled, to a quarter of the working population.
Those difficulties were compounded by the Dec. 20 American invasion, which Panamanian economists and bankers estimate inflicted at least $500 million in damage and looting. They argue that the economy needs an immediate and large injection of credit if the downward spiral is to be reversed.
 
Urgent Calls for U.S. Aid
''The most urgent thing is to replenish commercial activity now, in January and February,'' said former President Nicolas Ardito Barletta, an American-educated economist. ''If that does not happen, then unemployment will rise and the hopeful note struck by getting Noriega out will be reduced.''
Since the Endara Government inherited a national treasury that was virtually empty, Panamanian officials are looking for outside assistance, particularly from Washington. But at a news conference here just hours before General Noriega's surrender, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger and other members of an American economic reconstruction mission made no specific offers or promises of assistance, saying they need more time to assess the situation.
Several Panamanian economists and businessmen said they thought the Eagleburger mission had failed to understand the urgency of the situation. They emphasized that it is in the long-term interest of the United States to support Mr. Endara's Government and other democratic elements that are seeking to replace the Panamanian military as the country's dominant institution.
''The new Government now has to really take hold and project its image,'' said Mr. Ardito Barletta, who was forced by General Noriega to step down just months after he was elected in a 1984 presidential election marred by widespread accusations of fraud. ''Also, the United States Government must, at the highest level, announce that it supports the recovery of Panama. That has to be done dramatically, by President Bush at the White House.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Panel Calls for Delays In Offshore Drilling for Oil

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Recommending choices to appease both environmentalists and the oil industry, a panel headed by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. says more study is needed before oil companies drill off the coasts of California and Florida.
New measures are needed to protect the environment before the Government leases offshore areas for drilling, the panel said in a report sent to the White House today.
The report, dated Jan. 1 and made available by Federal officials, listed a number of options for President Bush but none that called for a permanent drilling ban.
All called for a delay of at least three years for lease sales off Florida and a delay of at least a year for those off California. 
 
President Has Many Options
President Bush may choose from among the options or choose another course entirely. Government officials have said a decision could be announced by the President in the State of the Union Message this month, but a White House spokesman said that was speculation.
Federal efforts to develop the nation's offshore oil and natural gas reserves have been debated, contested and often effectively blocked for nearly a decade.
The coastal states and environmentalists contend that they pose an unacceptable risk to the marine and coastal ecology and threaten fishing and other economic activities, including tourism.
The oil industry and the Federal Government, pressing for development of offshore oil, say that would promote economic growth and protect the nation from dependence on foreign sources of energy.
The panel, which includes representatives from the Interior, Energy and Commerce Departments, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Office of Management and Budget, concluded that more study is needed on the environmental, economic and social effects of the drilling.
 
No Option Is Pushed
The options for the Florida coast called for the cancellation of lease sales for at least the duration of the Interior Department's current five-year plan for developing the oil resources of the outer continental shelf, which expires at the end of 1992.
The options for two California areas called for a deferral of lease sales for at least a year while additional data about the effects of oil activity are collected.
The report did not recommend which option the President should choose. It concluded that the risk of a major offshore oil spill was small but warned that if such a spill occurred ''the environmental effect could be significant.''
''Many of the environmental effects of oil and gas activities, taken individually, are acceptable,'' the preliminary report said. But it added, ''Collectively, environmental effects of oil and gas activities could result in unacceptable changes to the local environments.''
Among the measures proposed were prohibiting the discharge of fluids used in drilling in ecologically sensitive areas, improving the ability of communities to respond to oil spills, and requiring that oil from the outer continental shelf be transported by pipeline rather than in tankers, which are considered more prone to accidents.
 
White House Declines Comment
A White House spokesman, Stephen Hart, said the President would consider the document in deciding what to do about pending lease sales. The leases involve 1.1 acres of ocean off Southern California, 6.7 million acres off Northern California and 14 million acres off South Florida in the Gulf of Mexico.
In 1981, Interior Secretary James G. Watt announced plans to make the entire billion-acre outer continental shelf available to industry for exploration and development.
His action touched off an outcry from coastal states and environmental groups who said that such leasing would cause severe degradation of the coastal environment. They charged that the plan violated the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act Amendments of 1978, which requirs that the Government balance the need for oil with the need to protect ecological systems.
Shortly after taking office last year, President Bush postponed the three lease sales scheduled for last year and formed the panel headed by Mr. Lujan.
A statement issued by the American Petroleum Institute, a trade association that includes the nation's biggest oil companies, said: ''We urge the President to choose the option to move ahead expeditiously. A long delay would hurt our nation.''
Lisa Speer,a staff member of the Natural Resources Defense Council who is an expert on offshore oil drilling, said the report appeared to be flawed because it included no option for the permanent cancellation of the lease sales. She also said the Administration was ''trying to suppress open debate on the issue'' by keeping the report secret.

HEADLINE: The Boat People and the Commonwealth

 BODY:
The sad story of Hong Kong's Vietnamese boat people gets sadder by the day. News that the refugees are now willing to risk violence to avoid repatriation only increases the urgency for a more humane global response.
Just before Christmas, 51 boat people, mostly women and children, were taken by the British from camps in Hong Kong and deported to Hanoi. The deed was done secretly, at 3 A.M., to avoid unpleasant photographs. Now 40,000 more who face deportation are making homemade weapons and plotting resistance. Guards and prisoners have already been wounded in clashes; the next attempt at repatriation could lead to bloodier violence. 
No doubt this is deeply troubling to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her flustered civil servants. They wish the boat people would understand that nobody relishes this dirty business. They patiently explain that boat people fleeing Vietnam are merely economic migrants, unprotected by refugee law. And yet anyone with a grain of spirit will rejoice at the refusal of these outcasts to go gently in the middle of the night.
Unless Mrs. Thatcher wishes to be remembered for dealing abominably with the helpless, she would be wise to put forced repatriation on indefinite hold. Yet her critics also need to think again. While Washington condemns forcible repatriation as ''odious,'' it resists more than token resettlement of boat people in the U.S. It also vetoes aid to Hanoi, whose problems caused the migrants to flee in the first place. And as British newspapers have noted, little help has come from the former British dominions that constitute the Commonwealth.
Here is a worthy challenge for an international group given to high-minded lecturing on human rights. The Commonwealth's 49 sovereign members include Canada, Australia and New Zealand. If these and others opened their wide gates, the 40,000 boat people could be swiftly distributed.
If the Commonwealth does nothing for the boat people, it will share ignobly in Britain's shame.

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
Moscow's New Deal Economics

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein

 BODY:
Thinking about economic restructuring on the grand Soviet scale is a thrill for any economist. So it was with special eagerness that I approached a recent meeting with Abel Aganbegyan, the Soviet guru of perestroika.
In his writing as in person, Mr. Aganbegyan lucidly diagnoses current ills. A sclerotic bureaucracy ineptly manages the economy and sabotages reform. The answer is to replace centralized planning with market forces. 
Yet Mr. Aganbegyan's idea of markets is jarring. He calls for price reform - but most prices would stay regulated. He calls for a free capital market - but selling shares of enterprises would be prohibited. His markets don't act much like markets, at least not in the Western sense. Government control remains dominant.
As I listened to him, I found myself reflecting upon a different set of reformers: the economists who advised Franklin Roosevelt in the 1930's. From the perspective of the 1990's, their advice seems confused and contradictory. The National Industrial Recovery Act, for example, probably hindered recovery from the Depression. Their mistakes seem baffling, until one recalls the skimpy state of macroeconomic concepts before Keynesian theories took hold after World War II. Policy contradictions went unrecognized because there was no simple macroeconomic framework to sort them out.
Mr. Aganbegyan seems similarly confused. His generation of Soviet economists is accustomed to directing capital with the aid of complex computer models. He seems palpably uncomfortable with markets in which resources flow at the whim of individual investors.
Can the Soviets design an economic path to private property and markets? A recent report by Mikhail Gorbachev's chief economic adviser, Leonid Abalkin, is modestly encouraging. Mr. Abalkin recognizes the subtle interaction between markets for goods, labor, foreign trade and capital. He understands that all these markets must be reformed at once for any one to work well.
Mr. Aganbegyan's enduring contribution was to prove that markets are needed. But it will take the increasing sophistication of Mr. Abalkin and his followers to execute the transition. Herbert Levine of the University of Pennsylvania thinks the Abalkin report presents ''a glimmer of hope'' that perestroika will succeed. Perhaps economic collapse in the Soviet Union has educated a new generation of economists just as economic collapse in the 1930's did in the U.S.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Truths Of the Pariahs

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
One day it may become respectable again, maybe even fashionable, to speak plain truths about some of the world's more important political realities.
Take, for instance, what has been happening in two countries in whose futures the United States has found itself very much involved - the Soviet Union and Panama.
Truth one about the Soviet Union is that while Communism collapses as an economic system in his country, Mikhail Gorbachev fights hard to save the Communist political apparatus.
Truth two is that he will fail. He cannot have both the freedoms demanded for economic survival and the monopoly power necessary to maintain the stultifying Communist political system. 
Truth three is that the United States' present naive, euphoric support for Mr. Gorbachev will make the elimination of the monopoly take longer and cause more pain to the Soviet people; eventually it will come, with or without him.
But respectability looms. The pariah band of those of us who talk and write that way broadens a little. Soon we may be legalized. The new issue of Daedalus, the journal of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, carries a long, well-reasoned piece on the Soviet crisis - well-reasoned meaning I agree with it.
But it is a pity the author hid behind anonymity and that his editors agreed. For a newspaper or a magazine to use anonymous pieces is an invitation to mugging.
The author did not have the courage of Winston Lord, former Ambassador to China. In a Washington Post Op-Ed article, he attacked the decision to double-cross Chinese freedom fighters by sending that high-level mission to Beijing.
That means he can give up any lingering hope of getting another diplo-matic post, to which his talent and experience clearly entitle him. But he can reside in the embassy of his own self-respect.
How ironic that the Daedalus author chose anonymity to criticize the Soviet Union in the United States. Tens of thousands of men and women who were the victims of the Soviet system went to jail for telling similar truths in their own names, in their own country.
That takes us to Panama. We who insist on facing the truth about the Soviet Union can practice what we preach by spelling out truths about the American action in Panama.
There, truth one is that the United States had paid and embraced Manuel Antonio Noriega for years and armed his thugs.
We have done that before. We installed or propped up the dictators Batista and Somoza in Cuba and Nicaragua, and that fellow Stroessner who used to run Paraguay.
The result in Cuba and Nicaragua was justified rebellion that turned into dictatorship of the left - our very own bastard child.
Panama truth two is that President Bush correctly felt at last that it was in the best interests of the United States to stop our old pal. The grounds seem reasonable to me -General Noriega's statement that a state of war existed between Panama and the United States.
Leaders of the other American states denounced us, a longstanding defense of dictatorships firmly rooted in history, self-interest and hypocrisy.
But let's not pretend there are not strong legal arguments against one country sending in troops to throw out the government of another.
Still, my personal truth is I am glad that Mr. Bush made the decision not to be a good lawyer and to move against General Noriega at last, and that the operation was a success.
Panama truth three is that the United States will have a difficult time keeping him in an American jail. Judges will have to decide on the legality of the seizure and transport of General Noriega and the way evidence and witnesses were rounded up.
He should hope his lawyers are not too good. If they get him off he will have to face the Panamanian people, the very sight and sound of whom drove him into the arms of the American military.
The United States helped strengthen the same forces that became his strong, brutal arm. Attention: Now we are signing up many of the same Panamanians and giving them guns in the name of law and order. They march about, proclaiming their new devotion to democracy. Americans may believe them, but not Panamanian civilians who may be beaten again by these guardians of freedom.
That point brings us straight to the final Panamanian truth: American expediency got us into the mess, and if we don't keep an eye on reality, expediency may get us in again.

HEADLINE: NORIEGA'S SURRENDER;
Panama in Disorder: The 1980's

 BODY:

 
March 1982: After the death in 1981 of the armed forces chief, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, three senior officers - Col. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Col. Ruben Darlo Paredes and Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera - cut a deal to resolve ja power struggle. Paredes is promoted to general, takes over as armed forces chief and agrees to retire in August 1983, leaving Noriega to take over, with Diaz Herrera as second-in-command. Noriega promises jto deliver 1984 presidential election to Paredes. 
 
August 1983: Noriega, now a general, takes over as commander of the armed forces. The Panamanian legislature passes a law creating the Panamanian Defense Forces with control over National Guard, other Panamanian military and police forces, canal matters and functions such as immigration control and regulation of civilian aircraft. Noriega reneges on Paredes deal and installs his own President in 1984 election.
 
June 1987: Diaz Herrera, retiring as second-in-command, accuses Noriega of drug-related activities, rigging 1984 election and murdering Hugo Spadafora, former Vice Minister of Health who accused Noriega of drug trafficking. Protest movement demands investigation into Diaz Herrera allegations and return to democracy. Street protests are brutally crushed.
 
February 1988: Federal grand jury in Miami indicts Noriega on drug-running charges. Grand jury in Tampa returns similar indictment. President Eric Arturo Delvalle, who was put in place by Noriega, announces that he has dismissed his patron. Noriega-dominated National Assembly ousts Delvalle, who goes into hiding.
 
PUB-DATE: March 11, 1988:
 
PUB-DATE: March 16, 1988:
 
April 1988: United States increases economic sanctions. Some $56 million in Panamanaian funds in American banks are frozen.
 
May 7-9, 1989: Presidential election pits Noriega candidate against the opposition candidate Guillermo Endara. Noriega forces claim victory, but protesters and international observers say voting was rigged. Former President Jimmy Carter, an observer, says Noriega stole the election.
 
PUB-DATE: May 10, 1989:
 
Oct. 3, 1989: Attempted coup against Noriega fails. American forces stationed in Panama take some steps to block pro-Noriega reinforcements from attacking the rebels; President Bush is widely criticized for not doing more.
 
Dec. 15, 1989: Panamanian legislature declares Panama in a ''state of war'' with the United States and appoints Noriega chief executive officer to respond.
 
Dec. 16, 1989: Panamanian soldiers kill a U.S. Marine lieutenant, saying he and three others drove a car past checkpoints, then fired at Noriega's military headquarters building, wounding two civilians and a soldier. Unites States says the four were unarmed and got lost near the headquarters.
 
Dec. 20, 1989: Bush orders American troops into combat in Panama. White House says the mission is to seize Noriega, to protect American lives, restore democracy and preserve the integrity of Panama Canal. ARmed resistance is quickly reduced, but Noriega eludes manhunt.
 
Dec. 24, 1989: Noriega seeks refuge at Vatican Embassy. Bush Administration demands he be turned over to face drug charges.
 
Jan. 3, 1990: Noriega leaves the Vatican Embassy and turns himself over the U.S. authorities.
 
Jan. 4, 1990: Noriega is arraigned in Miami.
 
Source: Associated Press
