HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Quiet Community Stirs When Feast Turns Violent

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: NAUGATUCK, Conn.

 BODY:
For 40 years, the Portuguese community in Naugatuck has celebrated St. Paio, a patron saint, and the celebration has evolved into the biggest social event of the year for the 6,000 Portuguese and Portuguese-Americans who make up 20 percent of the town's population.
St. Paio is the patron saint of the northern seacoast town of Torreira in Portugal, where most of the Portuguese in Naugatuck came from, and the transplanted festival, which occurs every year around Labor Day, is normally three days of dancing, drinking and general celebration for the Portuguese, tourists and townspeople alike.
But last fall's love feast turned to trouble. ''The whole incident was regrettable,'' said Mayor John Letts. 
''It awakened a sleeping giant,'' said Joseph Fonseca, the Vice Consul in the Portuguese Consulate in Waterbury, who is a resident of Naugatuck and sort of an unofficial mayor of the Portuguese community.
What happened was that the celebrants, about 2,000 or so, spilled out of the Club Uniao Portuguesa, the Portuguese Union Club, into the streets. A fight started between two young men, only one of them Portuguese, and he from out of town, and the police were called. Two officers responded.
The police officers - ''young officers,'' said the Mayor; ''rookies,'' said Mr. Fonseca - found themselves in a hostile crowd, insults were exchanged, and the officers called for reinforcements.
Other officers responded to the ''officer in trouble'' call, and the incident escalated. The state police were called. They closed the festival, and several Portuguese, organizers of the festival, were arrested.
''That galvanized the whole community,'' said Duarte Alves, an accountant who works for the state and came to Naugatuck from Portugal 10 years ago.
Mr. Alves is the secretary of a newly formed political action group, the Portuguese-American Polical Action Committee. It is the first such group in the state, and perhaps the first in the nation dedicated solely to representing the interests of Portuguese and Portugese-Americans. It formed as a result of the incident at the Portuguese Union Club.
''Our goal is that the Portuguese community will be recognized as a social, economic and political entity,'' Mr. Alves said.
''There was a group of us all along who felt that we needed better representation,'' said Frank Rodrigues, the president of the newly formed group. ''But we never got anything started.
''But this time, people felt there was a terrible police overreaction,'' he said. ''We decided to stop talking and start doing.''
Traditionally, said Mr. Fonseca, who holds dual Portuguese and American citizenship, the Portugese in America have been hard-working and non-complaining, in large measure because there was little tradition for democratic protest in Portugal, and as a result they were regarded with a kind of paternal noblesse oblige.
''They always say we are peaceful, hardworking and law abiding, and you can eat off the floors of our houses,'' he said. ''It's true and I think that is the way they want it.''
But indeed, concedes Mr. Fonseca and others in the Portuguese community here and perhaps elsewhere, there has been a reluctance to confront authority - indeed, even to swim to the mainstream.
''That Portuguese don't want to become involved is a fact,'' he said.
Indeed, in Naugatuck, about half the residents of Portuguese extraction are not citizens, and a large number speak English poorly, or in some cases not at all.
''We are 20 percent of a population of 30,000, and half are not citizens,'' Mr. Alves said. ''One of our objectives is to conduct a census and determine just how many are not citizens.''
Once such a census is carried out, organizers say, the group will work with the schools and city hall to create classes to help people become citizens.
''We are going to promote classes to naturalize our noncitizens,'' said Mr. Fonseca. ''Once they are citizens, they will become voters, and once they are voters they can become a political organization.''
At the moment, he said, the movement is local, but organizers hope it will expand statewide to involve the about 70,000 Portuguese and Portuguse-Americans who now, partly by choice, have little political voice For his part, Mayor Letts says he is delighted by the prospect, though he says he is not prepared to make any public apology for the incident at the festival of St. Paio.
''We will just work to make it much more successful next year,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Fills Operations and Economic Posts

BYLINE: By LEONARD BUDER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins filled two more major positions in his administration yesterday, selecting as his director of operations a New York City school official whom he credited with helping to reduce the bureaucracy at the Board of Education. The Mayor also named an investment banker to head the city's economic-development effort.
The school official, Harvey Robins, said he intended to spend about 14 hours a day trying to ''wring'' the excess from the city government bureauracy. 
For the last 18 months, Mr. Robins, 42 years old, has been the Deputy Schools Chancellor for Financial Affairs. He previously served as the deputy administrator in the city's Human Resources Administration, where, the Mayor said, he helped improve the delivery of social services. His new title will be Director of the Mayor's Office of Operations.
 
A 'Deal Maker'
Mr. Dinkins, on his fourth day in office, also named Leressa R. Crockett, a 38-year-old investment banker, as Commissioner of the Financial Services Corporation, a not-for-profit city corporation that promotes economic development by offering below-market-rate loans and other assistance.
Observing that Ms. Crockett, a vice president at Salomon Brothers, had spent nearly a decade as a ''deal maker'' who put together ''business proposals worth hundreds of millions of dollars,'' Mr. Dinkins said, ''We need creative, experienced financial decision makers working hard to keep business in the city.''
Both Mr. Robins and Ms. Crockett will take office by next month, Mr. Dinkins said. Each will receive an annual salary of $110,000. Mr. Robins said that is about the same as his present salary, but Ms. Crockett said she will be taking an unspecified cut in pay.
 
Critical Jobs Unfilled
But a number of critical city positions remain to be filled, among them human resources administrator, health commissioner, labor relations director, and head of the City Planning Commission.
Introducing the two appointees at a City Hall news conference, Mr. Dinkins said Mr. Robins had overseen a 20 percent reduction in the central Board of Education staff and had redirected more than $60 million from headquarters functions to new educational and support services.
A Board of Education spokesman, Robert H. Terte, said that since 1988, the headquarters staff had been reduced, in two phases, to 5,224 from 6,447. The reduction of 1,223 employees was achieved through transfers to jobs outside headquarters, attrition, and the elimination of unfilled positions, Mr. Terte said.
Responding to reporters' questions, Mr. Robins said that there were still too many people working at board headquarters, and that he has been working on additional reductions that the new Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, would announce later this month.
Asked whether he saw ''a bloated bureaucracy in city government,'' Mr. Robins replied, ''Absolutely.'''
He noted at another point that he had played a role in Mr. Fernandez's decision to take away city cars from 14 top-level Board of Education officials. Asked if he would try to do the same at City Hall, Mr. Robins paused, and then, amid considerable laughter from reporters and others, said, ''I'll defer to the First Deputy Mayor on that.''
The Mayor provoked more laughter when he asked, ''Will you try to see to it that I keep mine?''

Woman, 31, Dies From Severe Beating

DATELINE: MANHATTAN

 BODY:
A 31-year-old woman was found severely beaten in her apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan on Wednesday and died that night, the police said yesterday. There have been no arrests. 
The woman, Julie Farrell, was found lying on the living room floor of her apartment at 47 West 75th Street at 3 P.M. Wednesday by her boyfriend, the police said. She was taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where she died at 11:55 P.M.
Sgt. Nick Vreeland said yesterday that there was no evidence of a break-in, adding, ''The boyfriend has cooperated fully and is not a suspect at this time.''
Ms. Farrell was unemployed. The police said she took dance lessons at the Steps Dance School at 2121 Broadway.

HEADLINE: THE LAW;
For the Record

 BODY:

Ambiguity of the Law
The following excerpt is from ''American Lawyers'' by Richard L. Abel (Oxford University Press, 1989). Mr. Abel is a professor of law at the University of California at Los Angeles.
All law is inescapably two-faced. It reproduces and justifies existing inequalities and injustices; yet it also embodies ideals and offers mechanisms through which they can be pursued. Lawyers display the same moral ambiguity. The legal profession has constructed and defended an elaborate constellation of economic, social and political privileges. It propounds an ideology that allows lawyers to escape difficult moral choices by invoking their technical expertise. 
Most lawyers persist in seeing their daily work as morally neutral and apolitical. Yet many are attracted to the profession precisely because they embrace law as a ''transformative vocation'' (to use Roberto Unger's eloquent phrase) and wish to dedicate themselves to ''struggle against the defects or the limits of existing society.'' A few remain committed to that ideal throught their legal career.
 
Debut for Dershowitz
The following was excerpted from an article that first appeared in the Harvard Crimson last fall and subsequently was reprinted in the Harvard Law Record.
A veteran of 25 years at HLS [Harvard Law School] and both the Geraldo Rivera and Morton Downey Jr. shows, Prof. Alan Dershowitz will return to the airwaves as a special consultant to People's Court Judge Joseph Wapner. During five shows tentatively scheduled for this week, Wapner occasionally mentions legal discussions with Dershowitz. In one, the civil libertarian is introduced in the audience.
Although Dershowitz has argued in higher courts, statistics suggest that his appearance on the courtroom show will be a greater boost for his fame. According to a recent survey, 54 percent of Americans can recognize and name Wapner, while only 9 percent can identify U.S. Supreme Court Justice William Rehnquist.
''Well, Judge Wapner's a better judge than Rehnquist,'' Dershowitz said.

The Economy
Real estate investors and prospective home buyers are jamming the phone lines of the Government agency that this week began selling billions of dollars' worth of properties owned by failed savings institutions. Charles H. Keating Jr., testifying in a crowded Washington courtroom, denied any wrongdoing in connection with his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, which was taken over by Federal regulators last April. During an hour of mild questioning by Government attorneys, Mr. Keating was unshaken and calm, joking at times with District Judge Stanley Sporkin. [D1.]
American auto makers had badly depressed sales for both late December and last year, and voiced little confidence that the current sales incentives are enough to solve their problem despite a late surge in light-truck sales. HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Surge in Oil Prices Falters As Gradual Decline Is Seen

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 4

 BODY:
After surging this week to one of its highest trading levels in four years, oil prices are likely to decline gradually before reaching a low point sometime in the spring, industry analysts said today.
Another cold snap or a display of unity by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to limit production could keep the price of the American benchmark crude, West Texas Intermediate, from falling below $20 a barrel by the middle of March. But most of the analysts said they would be surprised by either development. 
In trading today on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the spot price for February contracts of West Texas Intermediate fell by 19 cents a barrel, to $23.49. The final price on Wednesday, $23.68, was the highest closing price for the oil futures contract in four years, except for a one-day surge of more than $2 a barrel last April 20, to a peak of $24.65.
Philip K. Verleger Jr., a specialist in global oil markets at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, predicted the price for West Texas Intermediate would fall to $18 or $19 a barrel by mid-March. ''If we get an economic slowdown and oil demand drops, we may not see today's price level again for a couple of years,'' he said.
He and other analysts noted that daily production by the 13 members of OPEC rose to nearly 24 million barrels in recent weeks, or by two million barrels above the ceiling set by the organization at its November meeting in Vienna.
Few analysts expect OPEC members to follow the new production limits, which took effect on Monday.
Several unusual factors contributed to soaring prices in recent weeks, including temperatures that averaged 10 degrees below normal, disruptions in producing fields and temporary shutdowns at many Gulf Coast refineries. Over all, oil demand in the United States was eight million barrels above normal from Nov. 28 to Dec. 30.
''If OPEC misreads this as being a fundamental shift in demand, prices could get very weak,'' said Lawrence Goldstein, the executive vice president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. If demand in the United States returns to normal levels and OPEC production remains high throughout the winter, he noted, prices will also decline.
But even if oil prices do tumble in the spot markets, homeowners in the Northeast, where prices for home-heating oil soared by nearly 50 percent, to $1.30 a gallon, during last month's cold period, will not get much relief from higher prices before winter ends.
Many oil distributors are beginning to pass along to consumers the higher prices they paid for oil deliveries in December, and they will not cut retail prices in tandem with declines that are expected for the crude oil spot markets, Mr. Verleger said.
Other problems loom that could make global oil markets tight and send prices higher than expected. The Soviet Union, the world's largest oil-producing nation, has deepening production problems. Some reports have placed Soviet daily production a million barrels below its average 1988 output of 12.2 million barrels a day for oil and for liquefied natural gas.
This decline could force Soviet officials to limit oil exports to Europe, and put a further squeeze on oil supplies there. Rumania has also cut oil exports to Western Europe, where demand was unusually high during a November cold wave. Also, output in the North Sea has faltered after several explosions involving production platforms and pipelines last year.

LENGTH: 1177 words

HEADLINE: Real Estate Sales Lure Investors

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
Attracted by the hope of bargains, real estate investors and prospective home buyers are jamming the phone lines of the Government agency that this week began selling billions of dollars' worth of properties owned by failed savings institutions.
But it is questionable whether the program, which promises to be the largest real estate sale in the nation's history, will result in as many bargains as buyers might hope, real estate experts and Government officials said yesterday. The program will bring thousands of houses, condominium apartments, office buildings, shopping centers and other properties onto the national market, perhaps further depressing prices in already glutted markets like the Southwest.
But Government officials say they are determined to make sales in an orderly manner. And they note that they must sell each property for at least 95 percent of its appraised value, as the bailout bill requires. 
 
Where Opportunities Are
''There are going to be opportunities, but they aren't going to be in buying at a deep discount,'' said Stan Ross, the co-managing partner of Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a real estate consulting firm in Los Angeles. ''The opportunities are going to be in the ability of buyers to sort through and identify properties that they can work on and create more value.''
Real estate executives said, however, that many properties would prove unattractive to potential buyers, particularly apartment complexes and small office buildings, and that the Government may be unrealistic in believing that it can command full price for them.
 
'Aren't All Cats and Dogs'
''The properties aren't all cats and dogs,'' said David W. Gleeson, the president of the Lincoln Asset Management Company, one of the largest real estate concerns in Dallas. ''But it is going to be difficult to find investors. It will be a rude awakening for the Government to find that they have to lower prices.''
Under the program, the Resolution Trust Corporation is offering for sale residential and commercial buildings and undeveloped land owned by hundreds of insolvent savings and loan associations that have been seized by the Government. The properties are available for sale to anyone interested, from individual home buyers to huge real estate companies.
Most of the residential properties will be listed by local realtors, which will handle them just as if they were privately owned. The commercial properties will generally be sold through regional offices of the Government agency, through the savings institutions themselves or through brokers hired by the trust agency.
On Tuesday, the trust agency published an inventory of the more than 30,000 properties it had taken control of through Sept. 30. Since then the agency has been besieged with phone calls - 8,000 on Wednesday alone, with 200 callers on hold at any one time - as people scrambled for information on what many perceived as a fire sale.
Texas has by far the greatest number of properties for sale - 15,750. Its neighbors in the oil patch also had high totals, with 1,575 in Oklahoma and 2,434 in Louisiana. The only other states with more than 1,000 properties on the lists are Florida, with 1,288, and Arizona, with 1,711.
In contrast, New York had only 12, New Jersey, 11; Connecticut and Delaware, 2 each, and New Hampshire, 1, while several states had none -Maine, North Dakota, South Dakota, Vermont and West Virginia.
 
Desire for a Bargain
''There's a lot of desire out there to get a bargain,'' said Stephen Katsanos, a spokesman for Resolution Trust. ''There's a feeling that if they don't get in there now, they may miss an opportunity. But people may be disappointed when we don't accept an outlandishly low offer.''
The residential properties on the list encompass everything from a $4 million mansion in Malibu, Calif., to a 500-square-foot house in poor condition in Louisiana. The commercial properties include office buildings, shopping centers, hotels, stables and even boat slips.
Mr. Katsanos said the Government's inventory of properties was continuing to swell as more institutions were taken over by regulators. He said the properties on the current list were probably less than half of what the Government would ultimately possess.
The inventory list published this week has only skeletal information about the properties offered for sale, including a brief description of size and location. Asking prices are included for some properties, although the values have yet to be set for many of them. Most listings include the name and phone number of someone to call about purchasing the property. The others include information about which savings institution had the property and how to reach that institution.
 
Toll-Free Number
To take orders for the inventory list, the trust agency has set up a toll-free telephone number: (800) 431-0600. The complete inventory of 26,813 residential properties, 2,516 commercial properties and 794 land parcels is available for a charge of $50. The volumes containing the commercial and land properties can be purchased separately for $10 each, and separate sections listing just single-family or multifamily housing are $15 each.
In addition to selling properties through local realtors and brokers and consultants who specialize in distressed property sales, the trust agency is also considering a number of unconventional approaches, including displaying some of the properties on cable television programs and working with a company that sets up international auctions by satellite.
Residential properties listed by local realtors will not be distinguished from other homes and condominiums. ''In a lot of cases the buyer may not even know this is a Government property they're dealing with,'' Mr. Katsanos said. Some real estate experts are skeptical of the Government's ability to manage such a huge undertaking efficiently. ''The first piece of advice I'd give to investors is that they should go into the process with a lot of patience,'' said James W. Field, a liquidation expert at Coldwell Banker, the real estate company. ''It's going to take a lot of time and you're going to have to learn to deal with the foibles of the bureaucracy.''
 
Volume Seen Causing Chaos
Perhaps more important, some real estate professionals said that the Government will never be able to develop a firm grasp on the value of the properties it is selling, and that the sheer volume of the properties it puts up for sale will inevitably cause chaos in the marketplace and drive prices down in some areas.
Almost by definition, the greatest concentration of properties the Government is now trying to peddle are in those regions hardest hit by economic downturns and falling real estate prices. As a result, finding buyers for a greater number of properties without pushing prices down may be impossible, some experts said.
For those who are interested in the properties but do not want to buy the books, the lists are also being distributed to 1,400 libraries across the country.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Business Cycle's New Stability

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IS the business cycle dead? The United States economy has now completed seven straight years of expansion, the longest in its peacetime history. Most economists foresee no recession in 1990 or 1991, and 1992 will be another Presidential election year, when the odds tip strongly against recession. Japan, West Germany and most of the other capitalist countries of Europe and Asia are also on a long upward roll, with no end in sight. It is time to consider whether the capitalist system has experienced a fundamental change in its stability, as important in its own way as the decay of the Communist system.
To be sure, plenty of people worry that the long spell of stable growth may still end with a bang, conceivably this year. Ravi Batra's latest best seller is called ''Surviving the Great Depression of 1990.'' But the crash of October 1987, and the market plunge of Friday, Oct. 13, 1989, have come and gone without stopping the expansion of the real economy. 
Those economists who have been warning for years that the United States is bound to suffer a ''hard landing'' actually demonstrate how resilient the American economy is. In saying just that, Lawrence Summers of Harvard, who was Michael S. Dukakis's chief economic adviser in the 1988 campaign, warns that the wolf could still come. Writing in The Financial Times this week, Professor Summers said: ''In the end, the wolf ate the boy. It would be a mistake to bet too strongly on the American economy in general or the dollar in particular over the next few years.''
This is not a partisan position. Speaking at a news conference in Atlanta last week, Michael J. Boskin, President Bush's chief economic adviser, foresaw moderate growth in 1990 but warned that the United States faces the danger ''not of a heart attack, but cancer'' - a gradual wearing away of its economic strength from inadequate savings and continuous dependence on foreign savings to finance domestic budget deficits, trade deficits and private investment.
Nevertheless, why has the danger of an economic ''heart attack'' ebbed? And why have those economists who expected a collapse of the real economy erred, year after year, despite the instability of financial markets and the dollar?
One source of error, common since the development of national income accounts and the heavy focus on the national economy, has been to see the United States economy as ''closed.'' In this view, the principal determinants of national income are domestic consumption, private domestic investment and government spending - with net exports a small tail incapable of wagging a very big dog.
In the postwar years the United States has increasingly become an ''open economy,'' as international flows of goods and services - and, far more important, capital - have grown to shape the national economy, thus far toward greater real stability.
The shortage of private domestic savings, aggravated by the Federal budget deficit, has been covered by capital inflow from abroad, thereby sustaining business investment and keeping the American economy growing. Of course, this has meant the transfer of United States assets to foreign hands. That disturbs many nationalists, but the immediate consequences for American growth in output, income and employment have been positive. Cutting off that foreign capital inflow now would drive United States interest rates through the roof.
A team of economists at Salomon Brothers, headed by David G. Shulman, contends that the liberalization of financial markets has, paradoxically, increased the volatility of securities and currency markets but has improved the stability of the real economy. The Salomon team concludes that this trend will continue and that the economic climate in the coming decade will still favor financial assets over real assets or cash.
Deregulation, according to this analysis, has enhanced United States growth prospects, ''even though it has not repealed the business cycle.'' Financial market liberalization acts as a ''shock absorber'' for the real economy, with price substituting for quantity in rationing credits. And deregulation means greater labor and capital mobility, attracting resources from weak sectors or regions to strong or growing sectors.
Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve holds to a cautious policy, accepting modest growth in exchange for lower inflation. The Salomon economists predict that disinflation will pave the way for lower interest rates, aided by lower Federal deficits resulting from the scaling back of military spending.
Similarly, Thomas W. Synnott 3d of U.S. Trust predicts that with a smaller Federal deficit relative to G.N.P. and lower inflation, long-term real interest rates on Treasury securities ''could easily move down from the current 3 1/2 to 4 percent range to 1 1/2 to 2 percent, their historic norm.''
Such a cut in the cost of capital would spur the industrial and public investment so urgently needed to enhance United States international competitiveness - a major goal for the 1990's.

HEADLINE: Car Sales Off 20.2% at End Of December

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
Despite a late surge in light-truck sales, American auto makers ended December and last year with total sales badly depressed and little confidence that the current salesroom incentives are enough to solve the problem.
Late December car sales by domestic manufacturers were down 20.2 percent from the period in 1988, a slightly smaller rate of decline than earlier in the month. Light-truck sales by domestic manufacturers were up 1 percent. There were eight selling days during the last selling period of the year, compared with nine a year earlier. 
The late surge in the light-truck market was helped by a 16.1 percent increase at the Ford Motor Company and a 19.8 percent gain at the Chrysler Corporation, which for the first time offered incentives on its popular mini-vans. The vans are counted as light trucks.
 
'Not a Disaster'
For the year, the United States auto industry sold nearly 14.6 million vehicles - 9.8 million cars and 4.8 million light trucks, domestically produced and imported - the fifth-largest total ever, said Joel Pitcoff, an analyst for Ford. In 1988, the industry sold 15.8 million vehicles. ''It wasn't a strong year and not a disaster,'' Mr. Pitcoff said. ''We had less than excellent results at high cost.''
One sign of the times: A Japanese car model, the Honda Accord, was for the first time the best-selling car in the United States. The Honda Motor Company sold 362,707 accords, 60 percent of which were produced in Marysville, Ohio. The car's closest rival, the Ford Taurus, sold 348,061 units. Last year's leader, the Ford Escort, dropped to No. 3.
The American auto market in 1989 was characterized by the rising influence of the transplants - the United States-based assembly plants operated by Japanese auto makers. The growing production at these plants allowed all major Japanese auto makers to gain market share at the expense of the industry's leader, The General Motors Corporation, and Chrysler.
G.M.'s market share, including domestic and imported cars, dropped to 34.8 percent in 1989 from 36 percent a year earlier. Chrysler's market share fell to 10.3 percent from 13.7 percent a year earlier. Ford managed a slight gain, to 22 percent from 21.6 percent in the period.
Honda remained the top seller in the United States among Japanese auto makers, with a 7.9 percent share of the market, up from 7.3 percent in 1988. The Toyota Motor Corporation increased its share to 7.2 percent from 6.5 percent. The Nissan Motor Corporation raised its share to 5.6 percent from 4.5 percent, while the Mazda Motor Corporation went to 2.7 percent from 2.4 percent and the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation to 1.2 percent from seven-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Incentives a Major Factor
For most of the year, the Detroit producers were able to sell their cars by offering big rebates and subsidized low-interest loans, which cut deeply into profits. But toward the end of the year even rebates and attractive loans could not keep sales from falling.
In December, sales of domestically produced cars fell 23 percent, to 455,686, from 614,860 a year earlier. There were 25 sales days in December, compared with 26 sales days in 1988. The seasonally adjusted rate for the month was 6.5 million units, down from 8.4 million a year earlier.
Sales of imported cars in December dropped 22.5 percent, to 194,543, compared with 261,082 a year earlier. Sales of domestically produced light trucks in December dropped 6 percent, to 299,170, from 331,030 in the 1988 period.
Detroit executives attributed the depressed sales to everything from consumer confusion over rebate programs to bad weather. But several acknowledged that with interest rates, inflation and unemployment all comparatively low, they were puzzled by the weak market.
 
Upturn Foreseen
''We don't have an answer, and none of the speculations satisfy my logic,'' said Alex J. Trotman, executive vice president of Ford's automotive operations in North America. But he said showroom traffic had improved since Christmas and added that he had a ''gut feel'' that the slight improvement in the last 10-day period of December presaged generally better sales.
John Middlebrook, vice president of General Motors and head of the Pontiac division, said, ''Consumers may be confused on incentives, believing that they will get better,'' and thus delaying purchases.
Robert L. Rewey, a Ford vice president, noted that cars bought with five-year loans in 1985, a strong sales year, would be paid off soon, ''creating a substantial reservoir of potential replacement demand during 1990.''

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Rules On Emissions

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency proposed regulations today to reduce hydrocarbon releases from cars and trucks when gasoline evaporates.
The proposal would change how vehicle emission tests are to be run and would require auto makers to modify vehicle emission control equipment such that atmospheric hydrocarbon levels would fall about 5 percent, the agency said. 
The modifications are said to be minor and should add only about $10 to the cost of a car, an amount that would be more than offset by better fuel economy, the agency said.
Hydrocarbons from motor vehicles react with the sun to form ozone. When the are combined with particulates in the air, the result is smog.
The proposal would require emissions testing to be changed to assure that hydrocarbon releases from the normal evaporation of gasoline are better controlled.

HEADLINE: Retailers Say Sales Rose In December

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Many of the nation's big retailers yesterday reported that sales were moderately higher in December, bolstered by a buying pickup in the final days before Christmas.
General merchandise chains, department stores and discount operations posted December results that mostly met their expectations for the holiday season. Analysts said the industry was saved from a lackluster sales performance by price discounts, aggressive advertising and special promotions.
''Santa came late, but he did come,'' said Jeffrey Feiner, retail analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. 
 
Pre-Christmas Sales
Retailers' sales are considered an important indicator of consumer spending, which accounts for a big portion of the nation's economic activity. In the recent holiday shopping season, performances differed depending on the type of retailer. Various regional factors, like the weather, also had an effect.
The holidays are a crucial time for retailers because half or more of their profits are made between Thanksgiving and Christmas. Worried about softness in consumer spending, retailers increased promotions, with many offering big pre-Christmas sales.
''If the retailer hadn't had the hook out, he wouldn't have had any customers in the stores,'' said Walter Loeb of Morgan Stanley & Company. He estimated that sales grew about 5 percent in December from a year earlier, down from a 7.5 percent increase in December 1988.
 
Sears Up 3.6%
The nation's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Company, had a mediocre showing, as the low-pricing policy it adopted last March continued to hurt results.
Sears said its sales rose 3.6 percent in the five weeks ended Dec. 30, to $4.696 billion, from $4.53 billion in the similar period last year. But Sears posted only a 1.6 percent gain at stores open at least a year. These comparable, or same-store, sales are considered a better indicator of a retailer's performance than data that include newly opened stores. New stores often benefit from retailing momentum because of their novelty.
 
Woolworth Sales Strong
Among the chains turning in strong holiday performances was the Woolworth Corporation, which had an 11.2 percent increase in domestic sales. ''Benefiting from strong sales gains in all divisions during Christmas week, our December results were in line with our expectations,'' said Harold E. Sells, the company's chairman and chief executive.
Even more pleased was Kenneth A. Macke, the chairman and chief executive of the Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson Corporation, who said solid gains at all divisions were ''more encouraging because they came on top of a strong December'' in 1988. Dayton Hudson, the owner of department stores and the Target discount chain, reported an overall increase of 15.1 percent.
Analysts said Dayton Hudson probably had a more profitable season than many other retailers who relied heavily on markdowns to attract customers. In general, they said, price cutting will probably not hurt earnings too much because of tight inventory systems and other cost controls, as well as fairly low inflation.
 
Apparel Sales
Stores catering to clothing shoppers fared better than mass merchandisers, much of whose business is devoted to expensive durable goods, like stereos, televisions or home appliances.
The Limited Inc., the specialty apparel retailer based in Columbus, Ohio, reported a fairly robust 11 percent gain in December sales. But not counting stores opened in the past year, the Limited's sales rose a more moderate 5 percent.
Another apparel chain, the Gap Inc., also turned in an above-average performance. The San Bruno, Calif., company's total sales rose 22 percent, while its same-store sales went up 14 percent.
Following is a list of the domestic sales reported yesterday by large general retailers for the five weeks ended Dec. 30, compared with the similar period in 1988:
 
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.: Sales rose 3.5 percent, to $531.4 million.
Dayton Hudson Corp.: Sales rose 15.1 percent, to $2.41 billion.

Limited Inc.: Sales rose 11 percent, to $815.9 million.
May Department Stores Co.: Sales rose 8.7 percent, to $1.80 billion.
Melville Corp.: Sales rose 7.8 percent, to $1.27 billion.

TJX Cos.: Sales rose 7.5 percent, to $305.1 million.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc.: Sales rose 22 percent, to $3.63 billion, for the month.
Woolworth Corp.: Sales rose 11.2 percent, to $879 million.Penney, J. C.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 13.65 Points, To 2,796.08

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices fell broadly yesterday, depressed by caution before the Government's report today of employment data for December. The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 13.65 points to close at 2,796.08, just below the important 2,800 technical level.
The average had pierced that level decisively on Monday with a 56.95-point surge to a record close of 2,810.15. Traders said yesterday that the dollar's tumble on foreign-exchange markets and several rounds of program selling contributed to the market's malaise. 
Volume on the Big Board contracted to 177 million shares, from 192.3 million shares on Wednesday.
 
Seesaw Activity
A spurt of program selling hit the market about noon, pushing down the Dow by nearly 20 points before it began to bounce back about a half-hour later. Another round of early afternoon selling sent the Dow about 37 points lower before buying programs brought the indicator back over the last two hours of trading.
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2, with 924 issues falling in price and 645 rising.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell by 3.09 points, to 355.67, while the New York Stock Exchange's composite index moved down by 1.51 points, to 196.29.
In the currency markets, the dollar plunged by almost two yen against the Japanese currency and by four and a half pfennigs against the West German mark.
The dollar's debacle proved a boon to gold stocks, which rebounded after faltering on Wednesday, when gold fell below the $400-an-ounce level.
 
ASA Gains $1.625
ASA Ltd. rose 1 5/8, to 56; Hecla Mining 1/4, to 14 1/4; Homestake Mining 1/2, to 19 3/8; Placer Dome 3/8, to 18 5/8; Echo Bay Mines 1/2, to 18 3/4, and Giant Yellow Knife Mines 3/8, to 9 7/8.
The Labor Department data for December, eagerly awaited all week, have kept many investors on the sidelines. Most economists expect the non-farm payroll employment figure to increase by 150,000 to 220,000 jobs.
The active blue-chip issues included Philip Morris, off 1 1/2, to 41 7/8; American Telephone and Telegraph, down 3/4, to 45 3/8; Chrysler, off 1/8, to 19 5/8; Union Carbide, down 1/2, to 49, and General Electric, off 3/8, 66 1/4.
Moderate strength in technology and metals issues helped ameliorate the stock market's drop. In the high-tech group, I.B.M. rose 1 1/8, to 100; Digital 7/8, to 86 3/4; Motorola 1/4, to 62 3/4, and Compaq Computer 1 3/8, to 86 1/8. But Hewlett-Packard slipped 1/2, to 48.
In the metals sector, USX rose 7/8, to 36 5/8; Alcoa 1/8, to 76 7/8; Bethlehem Steel 1/8, to 18 1/2; Inland Steel 1/4, to 36, and Allegheny Ludlum 1/2, to 41.
 
Teledyne Up on Rumors
Among other individual issues, Teledyne rose 7 7/8, to 360 1/8, on rumors that the company, based in Los Angeles, had received a favorable tax ruling on a proposed spinoff of an insurance unit, the traders said.
Helen of Troy, a hair-care maker with headquarters in El Paso, dropped 2 5/8, to 17 7/8, after reporting lower-than-expected earnings for its third quarter.
Hanson P.L.C. rose 1/4, to 19 1/4, on a consolidated volume of 29.1 million shares, 20 million of which were on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange. Today is the record date for the London-based company's dividend of 62 cents per American depository receipt, to be paid on Feb. 9.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index slipped by 0.26, to 382.16, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index fell by 1.51 points, to 459.39.
In over-the-counter trading, MCI dropped 1 3/4, to 41 3/8. The Washington-based company said it had signed an agreement with Telefonos de Mexico S.A., or Telemex, to provide direct voice and other telecommunications services between the United States and Mexico.A.T.& T.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Security Prices Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended narrowly mixed in fairly light trading yesterday, as market participants largely shrugged off developments in the foreign exchange, energy and equity markets.
The crosscurrents that buffeted traders included a sharp drop in the dollar and more modest declines in stock and oil prices. In addition, traders received a report on initial unemployment claims, which rose by 77,000 in the week ended Dec. 23, and 10-day automobile sales data for late December that were a little stronger than anticipated.
''The Street is a little confused,'' one government bond trader said. ''It doesn't know whether to watch the dollar, oil or stocks. But the bottom line is that everybody is waiting for the employment number on Friday.'' 
Most analysts are expecting the employment report to show that non-farm payroll employment rose by about 220,000 in December, a figure that includes 60,000 Boeing Company employees returning after the aircraft company's long strike.
Yesterday's big drop in the dollar, caused in large part by concerted intervention by major central banks, was mostly ignored in the credit markets. But analysts said it could well have longer-term implications for the bond market, particularly by reducing the possibility that the Federal Reserve will move soon to push down interest rates.
 
Effects of Dollar Weakness
''Though the chances of near-term easing by the Federal Reserve were remote at best, the weakness of the dollar should be the nail in the coffin of a January easing,'' analysts at MMS International, an economic information and forecasting company, noted in their daily market commentary.
Charles Lieberman, a managing director at the Manufacturers Hanover Securities Corporation, said, ''At some point the bond market will start to care about the dollar. But right now it is too soon for global investors to react to changing conditions.''
Mr. Lieberman said the dollar selling by central banks was ''a very clear message'' that monetary authorities do not want the dollar to rally further. But he suggested the bond market may not become attuned to the dollar's movements for several more weeks.
''The Treasury's refunding auctions in February will be an interesting test,'' he said. ''At that point we will see if the Japanese step up to buy the 30 to 40 percent of the issues that they typically purchase.''
Despite the potential long-term implications, market participants left Treasury prices pretty much as they found them at the start of the session.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 101 2/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.03 percent.
Among note issues, the seven-year notes to be auctioned next Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.98 percent, unchanged from Wednesday. And the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 11/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.89 percent.
 
Drop in Treasury Bill Rates
Treasury bill rates fell. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.55 percent, down five basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates fell six basis points, to a late rate of 7.45 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.28 percent, down two basis points.
Elsewhere, two investor groups placed bids on a total of $394 million worth of State of California veterans bonds.
A group led by the investment banking subsidiary of BankAmerica won the largest part of the issue, $343 million worth of bonds that are subject to alternative minimum tax provisions.
This part of the issue consists of serials and term bonds. The serial bonds carry coupons from 6 percent in 1994 to 7.20 percent in 2006. A term bond that matures in 2010 carries a coupon of 7.30 percent. Another term bond, which matures in 2019, carries a coupon of 7 3/8 percent.
An investor group led by Shearson Lehman Hutton won the $51 million tax-exempt portion of the issue. Coupons on the serial bonds sold in this portion range from 5.80 percent on bonds maturing in 1994 to 6.80 percent on bonds maturing in 2007.
Both portions of the issue are rated AAA by Moody's Investors Services and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds was light yesterday, dealers said.
Corporate dealers said that prices of most investment-grade issues were unchanged on the day. Most municipal bond prices, meanwhile, dipped by about an eighth of a point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Dec. 25.
The money supply report had no effect on prices in the credit markets, though the figures were the latest in a string of strong increases.
''At this point I am not going to get concerned,'' said Wayne Smith, an economist at Ried Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn. ''But if we don't get a reversal in the next couple of weeks, particularly in M-2 growth, that could be a source of concern.'' American Expressd (Shearson Lehman)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Sharply lower As Bundesbank Intervenes

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar dropped precipitously yesterday as a result of unexpected intervention in the foreign exchange market by the West German central bank.
The Bundesbank's dollar selling in Europe raised fears that there might be a surprising new effort by the United States and its allies to drive the dollar lower. Traders said this fear sent the dollar down by more than 4 pfennigs against the West German mark and by almost 2 yen. The dollar also fell sharply against other major currencies except the Canadian dollar. 
Several traders said, however, that they did not think the Bundesbank move signaled a new policy for the Group of Seven, which consists of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. But they said the possibility spooked the market. These traders contend that the Bundesbank was just trying to slow the rapid rise of the dollar on the first two trading days of the year, which pushed the dollar as high as 1.7350 marks from 1.6910.
The fear of a new policy was reinforced when the Swiss central bank also sold dollars. And in New York, when there were rumors that the Federal Reserve was checking foreign exchange rates - a step that often precedes intervention - the dollar fell even further.
 
'A Very Sensitive Market'
''It is a very sensitive market that can be easily spooked,'' said Richard E. Witten, vice president for foreign exchange at Goldman, Sachs & Company. He does not believe the Bundesbank's move signals a new dollar policy, he said, but added, ''The thought has to go through your mind; you have to give it some credence.''
Nicholas Sargen, director of international bond market research at Salomon Brothers, agreed. ''These guys are just saying, 'Let's not get crazy here and send the dollar back to 1.75 marks,' '' he said. He added that the Bundesbank did not want the mark to weaken against the dollar because it would increase inflationary pressures, by making imports more expensive, in an economy that Germans already see as threatened with overheating.
But these and other traders acknowledged that they would not have a clear indication of the Group of Seven's motives until they saw what the Bundesbank and other central banks would do if the dollar began to rise again.
In late New York trading, the dollar was at 1.6785 marks, down 4.39 pfennigs from 1.7224 on Wednesday and 5.65 pfennigs from 1.7350, the high in Japan and Europe for the day. Against the yen, the dollar was down 1.87 yen, to 143.38, from 145.25 on Wednesday.
Traders and economists believe that the Group of Seven, in an effort to maintain stability in the foreign exchange markets, has set a range for the dollar of 1.70 to 1.90 marks and 120 to 140 yen. Yet the Bundesbank moved to drive the dollar lower when it was at 1.7320 marks, near the bottom of the range. Because it is now below the range against the mark some speculated that a new range, possibly of 1.60 to 1.80, had been set. But some traders said it was too early for such a conclusion.
Before the Bundesbank surprise, the Bank of Japan tried to push the dollar lower against the yen with dollar selling in Tokyo totaling about $750 million, traders said. The Bank of England then sold dollars for yen in London at the request of the Bank of Japan, traders said. The dollar did not fall in Tokyo, but it did when trading in Europe opened.

HEADLINE: Creation of Jobs Is Only Sluggish In Latest Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
New jobs were created at a markedly slower rate in December, but the nation's unemployment rate remained unchanged at 5.3 percent, completing a year of exceptional stability, the Labor Department reported today.
The department's survey of business payrolls showed a weak increase in the number of jobs, by 142,000, and the number of factory jobs declined for the ninth straight month. But the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood, noted that the overall economy continued to expand, although at a very slow pace. ''There is still growth going on,'' Dr. Norwood told reporters. ''We're certainly not anywhere near a downturn.'' 
Other analysts have been more pessimistic, and today's figures included only scattered signs of encouragement. ''We're going into 1990 with very little momentum,'' observed Robert H. Chandross, chief economist for Lloyds Bank North America, who said the gross national product probably posted a small decline in the fourth quarter of 1989.
 
Poorest Quarter Since '86
The number of jobs rose by an average of only 145,000 a month in the fourth quarter of 1989, the poorest quarter since 1986. In contrast, the average monthly rise in the first quarter of 1989 was 265,000.
In all, 119,588,000 Americans held civilian or military jobs last month and 6,658,000 were unemployed, for an unemployment rate of 5.3 percent. The jobless rate excluding military personnel was also 5.3 percent, unchanged from the revised level for November.
Most analysts maintained that while the new labor-market data would increase pressure on the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates another notch, this probably would not occur for at least a week. Next Friday, the Government is to report on producer prices and retail sales for December.
The central bank is eager to avoid a surge of inflation and could not have taken any comfort from data in today's employment report showing that average hourly earnings of private production workers climbed six-tenths of 1 percent last month after being essentially unchanged in November.
Another factor that was likely to prevent the Federal Reserve from acting immediately to reduce interest rates was a separate report released today on factory orders. After two straight declines, those orders climbed a hefty 2.4 percent in November to the second-highest level of the year.
 
Drop in Jersey Unemployment
Among the 11 biggest states, New Jersey showed a sizable 1.5-point decline in its jobless rate last month, down to 3.6 percent from 5.1 percent. But analysts cautioned that while this improvement was statistically significant, it might be overstated. State samples are far smaller than national ones, and therefore less reliable.
The New York increase of four-tenths of a point, to 5.6 percent, and Texas's decline of six-tenths of a point, to 6.6 percent, were considered marginally significant.
Nationally, the increase of 142,000 jobs last month was not only one of the smallest of the year, but took into account 55,000 Nynex workers who returned from a strike. In all, jobs in the service sector climbed by 206,000, but this rise was partly offset by a decline of 64,000 goods-producing jobs. The drop in production jobs was considerably worse than in November, which after a small revision now shows a gain of 4,000 jobs instead of a 3,000 decline.
Health service jobs, which continued to rise sharply last month, grew by 525,000 jobs for the year. Employment in wholesale trade and in finance, insurance and real estate also rose in December. Jobs in retailing showed little change as department stores did less hiring than usual, and automotive-related job losses offset gains in food stores, restaurants and bars.
About two-thirds of the decline in goods-producing jobs was in construction, which suffered from especially harsh winter weather. Factory jobs fell by 25,000, bringing the total decline since March to 195,000. Nearly 15,000 of the December decline was in computers and other electrical equipment.
''The manufacturing component continues its steady downward slide,'' said Michael W. Keran, chief economist at the Prudential Insurance Company. But over all, Mr. Keran said, the economy did not seem to be stumbling as fast as he had expected and he estimated today that the chance of a recession in the near term had been cut to 40 percent, from about 50 percent. #48,000 New Jobs As measured by the department's survey of households, the economy generated a very modest 48,000 new jobs last month. Nonetheless, this was nearly enough to match a similarly modest 54,000 increase in the size of the labor force. The ranks of the unemployed thus edged up 6,000, to 6,658,000.
The unemployment rate was 5.3 percent for both January and December of last year, and moved outside the range of 5.1 percent to 5.3 percent only in March, when it touched 5 percent, according to a table of revised figures published today. The rates for March, August and September were one-tenth of a point higher than initially reported, while January's was one-tenth lower.

HEADLINE: Why Milk Prices Are Soaring

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Elsie the Cow, meet Adam Smith.
Behind the surge in milk prices, both at the farm gate and on many grocery shelves across the nation, lies a simple but largely overlooked fact: The United States dairy market today is far more susceptible to free-market forces than it was a few years ago.
Once plagued by a chronic glut that produced huge Government stockpiles of milk, butter and cheese, the market now finds itself facing shortages, with its stockpiles largely depleted. A Federal initiative to ease regulations, reduce dairy herds and lower the prices guaranteed to farmers - in tandem with changing consumer tastes here and abroad - is reshaping the dairy industry.
These changes mean that milk prices, once fairly predictable, are likely to become far more volatile in the years ahead. That, in turn, will mean less certainty for consumers and farmers and considerably more risk for everyone else along the milk delivery route: The big dairy processors like Borden's and Dean Foods, the highly competitive food chains like Giant and Safeway, and the Wall Street investors who finance them. 
''It's a new ball game,'' said Ed Coughlin of the National Milk Producers Federation in Washington. ''Milk producers are learning their way in a supply-demand driven market. We have never done that before.''
 
A Rising Benchmark
 To be sure, there is still a panoply of state and local rules that govern the retail milk industry, causing local prices to vary considerably. And the Federal Government, while playing a smaller role than before the Reagan Administration's deregulatory drive, still puts a floor under the prices that producers receive and restricts imports of some dairy products. These will continue to influence the price swings for some time.
But the evidence of increased price volatility is clear. The benchmark price of raw milk has soared more than 34 percent in the last nine months, to a record $14.90 a hundredweight for December, according to figures released this week by the Department of Agriculture. The price, based on the key Minnesota and Wisconsin markets, is the benchmark gauge for 100 pounds of fluid milk, or roughly 11.6 gallons.
 
A Soggy Summer
 ''This is the largest single seasonal price increase in raw milk in the history of the milk program,'' said William Tinklepaugh, vice president of the Milk Industry Foundation in Washington. The previous record, however, was barely a year old: prices climbed about 18 percent in 1988, from $10.43 in March to $12.22 in December. At the store, many consumers did not see prices climb sharply until this fall because many supermarkets were not able to pass the full increase on to shoppers for fear of losing business to rival stores.
No one predicted that 1989 milk prices would climb so far so fast. In fact, the changes in the diary market are so profound that Mr. Tinklepaugh, one of the most widely cited analysts of milk-price trends, says he has simply given up forecasting prices for this year. ''I've been so far off on price forecasts that I've stopped doing it,'' he said. ''I thought it would peak at no more than $14 a hundredweight, and it's way past that now.''
The Wall Street analysts who monitor the giant dairy companies like Borden Inc. and Dean Foods are more fearless in their predictions, but their track record is no better. Nevertheless, many estimates of 1990 earnings are based on the assumption that today's sky-high prices, which raise the dairy industry's raw material costs and squeeze profit margins, will disappear with the spring thaw.
Of course, weather is to blame for some of the recent climb in milk prices. Two years of heat and drought in the Southeast and Midwest reduced pasturage and put dairy cows off their feed; a soggy summer had similar effects in the Northeast. Rain, in sufficient but not excessive amounts, will no doubt ease some shortages in the spring and summer, stabilizing prices in some regions and pulling them down in others.
But beyond the seasonal forces that have always affected milk prices, there are new structural factors at work in the market today, the long-term effects of which are not entirely understood, even by the industry.
 
Fewer Milking Barns
 One important structural change is the reduction in the number of dairy farmers, thanks to a Government herd buyout program begun in April 1986. The program pared roughly 1.5 million cows from the nation's milking barns, roughly 13 percent of the total, in less than two years. Moreover, the program's rules require the farmers who sold out, some of whom might be tempted to return to meet current demand, to remain out of the business for five years.
Some Western farmers can add to their stock quickly and with little capital investment, dairy economists said. But other sections of the country, where farms are smaller or where weather is more inclement, are not so adaptable.
''In the Northeast, production will not be able to pick up promptly,'' said John Malcolm, a dairy farmer in Pawlet, Vt. ''It takes a lot of skill to keep 100 head of cattle healthy, and there just isn't the skilled labor available.''
A growing population had already made milk supplies tight in the Southeast, said Daniel Shaw of the Dairymen Inc., a cooperative in Louisville, Ky., and the herd buyout program has exacerbated the shortages there.
 
Competition From Cheese
 In addition to these changes in supply, consumer preferences are changing in dramatic, unpredictable ways. Milk drinkers are increasingly choosing skim milk over whole milk - adding to Government stockpiles of surplus butter. But cheese, which is high in fat, has become increasingly popular. Prices are climbing, and cheese processors are competing fiercely with milk bottlers for the farmers' scarce supply.
Meanwhile, the once-mountainous Government inventories of cheese and, more important, of nonfat dry milk have disappeared, thanks to shrinking supply and rising prices. ''I cannot tell you what a sharp contrast that is with just a few years ago,'' said Andrew Novakovic, an associate professor of agricultural economics at Cornell University.
''As recently as 1983, three out of four pounds of nonfat dry milk in this country were sold to the Government,'' he said. ''The commercial nonfat dry milk market was a basket case. But since July 1988, there have been zero sales to the Government under the price-support program.''
The world market for powdered milk - the most transportable form of the product - has undergone dramatic changes as well.
 
Common Market Quotas
 Traditionally, Europe's dairy surpluses were sold into the world market in the form of powdered milk at subsidized prices that United States farmers had no incentive to beat, since the price offered to them by their own Government was higher. ''Before 1989, you virtually could not give the stuff away,'' said Allen Rosenfeld, director of agricultral policy for Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, a Washington consumer organization.
But as new production quotas in the European Community began to have an effect, the Europeans virtually withdrew from the nonfat dry milk market. The result was just as Adam Smith would have predicted: with supply reduced, the world price for nonfat dry milk rose. Suddenly, United States powdered milk looked like a good deal.
With no clue that a serious shortage was brewing, the United States entered the world dry milk market in 1989 for the first time. And, in the sort of chain reaction that is likely to become routine in the future, surplus milk usually available to ease winter shortages elsewhere in the nation was not available. That helped push fluid prices up, as one region competed with another for scarce supplies.
At the supermarket level, milk prices were slow to rise but are beginning to catch up, said Mr. Rosenfeld at Public Voice. Whether they will be equally slow to fall in the spring, when farm prices are expected to soften, is ''something we will be watching closely,'' he added.
 
Nothing but Headaches
 In towns without competing supermarkets, prices may stay higher longer, several economists noted. But given the drag in passing producer prices along to consumers in the politically sensitive milk market, increasingly volatile milk prices will be nothing but headaches both for food-store executives and analysts.
For dairy industry executives, the recent price increases pose new worries. Borden's, the leading producer of fluid milk in the country, announced a plan earlier this fall to sell many of its less-profitable dairies. Increased uncertainty about milk price patterns in the future may worry potential buyers and reduce the amount Borden's can clear from the sale.
While Dean Foods, the second big domestic player in fluid milk, has diversified into a variety of snack foods and condiments, it still depends heavily on its dairy operations, where profit margins in its current fiscal year have fallen to an estimated 4.5 percent of sales from 6.8 percent in the 1986 fiscal year.
Although the existing milk price-support program is still a factor in the market, prices will have to fall substantially before today's lower subsidy levels kick in, said Mr. Novakovic at Cornell. In the meantime, the effect of all these shifts in production and consumption has been to make the United States industry, already one of the world's lowest-cost producers, far more sensitive to international forces.
''International marketing has been the buzzword for so many years, but the dairy industry has not been a part of that market,'' he said. ''They've got a lot of learning to do.''

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Push Transportation Charges Up

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The recent explosion in petroleum prices, especially diesel fuel, is raising transportation prices in a way not seen for a decade, economists and industry executives say. Airlines and trucking companies are imposing fuel surcharges or indexing their rates to fuel costs.
The increases, brought on by unusual cold in December, will reverse themselves if normal weather holds, experts predict. But the current practice of linking airplane ticket prices and motor freight rates to fluctuating oil prices may foreshadow the situation in the mid-1990's, when oil prices are widely expected to be higher. 
''This was a dress rehearsal, but I don't think it's the main event,'' said Charles T. Maxwell, vice chairman of C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Greenfell Inc. In the short term, he said, oil prices will fall because the unusually high demand will end, ''and a slow economy will reassert itself next spring.''
The record cold in December raised demand for heating oil about 35 percent above normal, pushing prices from 89 cents at the beginning of the heating season to nearly $1.40 now. Diesel fuel, which is the same substance as heating oil, began December at about $1.15 a gallon and jumped to about $1.43. So steep and unusual was the rise that Platt's Week, an industry newsletter, labeled an article on the subject ''Fuel oil meets Rip van Winkle.''
As a result of the increases, Continental Airlines said it would raise domestic fares by 4 percent on Jan. 10 to cover fuel costs that have risen by 46.5 cents a gallon in the last month. Pan American World Airways and Delta Air Lines Inc. also announced 4 percent fare increases on domestic fares. Trans World Airlines said it would add a surcharge of $5 on flights under 500 miles and $10 on longer flights, but it also said it would match fare cuts by Eastern Airlines.
Many trucking companies also began indexing freight rates to fuel costs. Donald A. Lucchesi, group vice president of planning and marketing, for Landstar System Inc., which describes itself as the nation's largest group of full-truckload companies -those that accept only full loads for shipment - said he had not seen indexing of that kind since the first oil shock, nearly 20 years ago.
Landstar, based in Stamford, Conn., which runs 7,000 trucks and 10,000 trailers, said on Thursday that it would raise its rates by 5 to 8 percent to recover the increased costs. It said it would peg its rates to the Interstate Commerce Commission's weekly survey of diesel fuel prices. Frozen Food Express Industries of Dallas, said it would adjust prices each week, beginning with increases of 4 to 5 percent.
 
Highly Competitive Business
 The full-truckload business is highly competitive, and analysts believe that rates will fall as soon as fuel prices do. The portion of the trucking business that accepts partial loads for shipment is less competitive, however, and some of its increases may linger.
''It's a spike,'' said Dr. Marion B. Stewart, an energy consultant at National Economic Research Associates of White Plains. Natural gas prices, driven higher by the same weather, have already begun to decline, he said, ''and heating oil prices will surely do the same thing. We'll be likely to see heating oil prices go down as quickly as they came up.'' Because the trucking industry is competitive, he said, trucking rates would then decline.
Philip K. Verleger Jr. of Charles River Associates, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., said, ''It won't have a long-term effect, but we'll see a very sharp increase in the Consumer Price Index in February.'' The increase due to fuel oil could be 1 percent, he said, and will show up when January's numbers are reported.
''But assuming that there is no other major cold weather, the effect will start wearing off,'' he said. ''When the weather is warmer than average, people start riding their bicycles and say, 'We don't need extra heating oil.' ''
 
Higher Oil Prices Seen
 But many economists who specialize in energy believe that oil prices will drift higher in the 1990's, as world demand increases, eroding the surplus production capacity that has held prices down since the mid-1980's. The trend is expected to become more pronouced because of an expected 5 percent decline in American oil production, as well as declines in Britain and the Soviet Union. Analysts say the market would tighten more quickly with an economic revival in Eastern Europe, or continued strong growth in the Pacific Rim.
And long-term increases in oil prices will be felt throughout the economy on a more permanent basis, as was the oil price collapse of 1986, experts say.
''All during the 80's, one of the important elements of economic growth was the OPEC tax cut,'' said Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates of Cambridge, Mass. First the cost of oil was eroded by inflation, and then the dollar price fell in 1986, he said, sustaining economic growth.

HEADLINE: For New York Area, 20 Lessons in Real Estate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
There will not be any Greenwich mansions at Levittown prices in the Government's sale of 30,000 properties taken over from failed savings institutions. But a look yesterday at some of the 20 residential properties offered in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut showed housing for every pocketbook and life style and, maybe, a chance to save a few thousand dollars.
Among the offerings are: seven rent-controlled or rent-stabilized apartments, with tenants, in a New York City cooperative building on West 75th Street, priced as a group at $425,000 to $450,000; four fire-damaged apartments in Sicklerville, N.J., at $45,000 to $50,000 each, and an unfinished luxury home on two wooded acres in Redding, Conn., at $519,000.
But bargains, like beauty, are in the eye of the beholder, and in a weak market some think prices will get still weaker.
For example, Jacquelyn Wilcox, who spent the better part of November searching for a one-bedroom cooperative apartment in Manhattan, decided to wait. ''The first thing everybody would say after telling you the price was, 'but that's negotiable,' '' she recalled. 
While the New York region's economy has not suffered the hardships of, for example, Texas, where the Government is offering 15,000 properties for sale, real estate prices have been weakening for many months in the metropolitan area, encouraging prospective buyers to delay.
Now some buyers hope that the Government-sponsored sale will depress the market further. With only 20 properties involved, that would not seem likely for this region, but the rise of mortgage delinquencies makes it probable that there will be more failures among savings institutions and more properties for sale by the Government.
The Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency in charge of selling the properties, plans to set prices equal to at least 95 percent of appraised value. Of course, appraised values can fall rapidly, especially when sales are slow. The Government is using regular real estate brokers for many of the residential sales, and the agency is relying on appraisals and estimates of market values in quoting prices.
The largest offering in the New York area is the group of seven tenant-occupied apartments at 240 West 75th Street in Manhattan, according to a four-volume listing published by Resolution Trust.
While the handsome building with a limestone facade is well maintained, any potential buyer of the apartments might want to visit Ms. Stella, the fortune teller who operates on the same block. She, or perhaps an actuary, could offer guidance about how long it might be before the tenants, ranging in age from their 50's to their 80's, will vacate the units, allowing the buyer to occupy an empty apartment or sell it at a profit.
The apartments were taken over by the Metropolitan Federal Savings and Loan Association of Denville, N.J., which foreclosed on loans it made to the sponsors of the cooperative, a defunct partnership known as 240 Venture Associates.
 
Changing Tax Laws
 ''Investments in occupied apartments were all the rage before the Tax Reform Act of 1986, but the change in tax laws really killed the investors,'' said John P. Almeida, managing agent for the Resolution Trust Corporation now working at Metropolitan.
At one time, investors were buying occupied apartments for half their market value. On West 75th, the market price of one-bedroom apartments went as high as $180,000, while two-bedroom units were nearly $300,000. Prices have fallen almost 20 percent for comparable units in the neighborhood since their peak.
Under the old tax law, investors could claim as losses for tax purposes rapid depreciation of the apartments, as well as the difference between the amount they received in rent and the higher amount they paid in maintenance fees to the cooperative. The tax losses could be used to offset ordinary income.
But now such tax losses are largely denied; they are termed passive and can be taken only against passive income by wealthy investors. So, demand for occupied apartments has fallen sharply.
''They are virtually unmarketable, unless you are buying a large number of apartments where you can count on a few of them becoming vacant every year,'' said one real estate agent on the West Side of Manhattan who asked not to be identified.
 
Rents Are Kept Low
 Because New York law does not allow the eviction of a tenant by an owner who wants to sell an apartment, and because rent-control laws have kept many rents low, the buyer of the seven apartments will have to pay more in monthly maintenance fees to the cooperative building than will be received in rents. James M. Levison, president of the cooperative board at 240 West 75th, put the difference at ''a few hundred dollars'' each month for each apartment.
Emil Wiehl, a retired factory manager and a tenant at 240 West 75th for more than 20 years, declined to buy his one-bedroom rent-controlled apartment five years ago, when the asking price was $50,000. ''It was much cheaper to rent,'' he said. ''A year ago I was offered $30,000 to move. But if I sell, where should I go? What could I afford to buy?'' Given this situation, many investors are unwilling to make monthly payments on a property they may not possess for years. As a result, Metropolitan has already re-evaluated the price it is setting on the seven apartments. Mr. Almeida said the $589,995 total listed in documents published earlier this week has been reduced by about 25 percent to $425,000 to $450,000 ''based on new appraisals.''
 
A Tenant's Opinion
 Lee Cohen, a tenant at 240 West 75th for the last 25 years, said that despite the low income Metropolitan receives from the rent-controlled two-bedroom apartment she shares with her husband, Samuel, ''They have been very nice to us, and our apartment is as well maintained as those that are in the cooperative.''
Each property on the Government's list has its own set of circumstances. In Sicklerville, N.J., four condominium apartments are being rebuilt after being heavily damaged by a fire in October 1988.
Robert C. Reich, a loan officer at Liberty Bell Savings, Beaver Falls, Pa., now Reeves Bank, said other units in the same development had sold quickly. ''It's a strong market there, and we expect no problem selling them at $45,000 to $50,000,'' he said.
The properties, in which Liberty has an 11.1 percent share, came to the institution as a result of the 1985 collapse of EPIC Holdings Inc., a mortgage investment company that defaulted on 20,000 properties around the country worth more than $1 billion.
The episode, which caused one of the nation's largest mortgage insurers to go out of business and threatened to disrupt the entire mortgage market, resulted from over-estimations of the market value of properties that were bought by EPIC and then sold to other investors. The main lender on the properties is the Home Federal Savings Bank of Washington, which is handling the sale.
In Connecticut, an unfinished seven-room, three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath, 3,300-square-foot contemporary-style home on two wooded acres came to be owned by the Columbia Savings Bank of Westport, after the bankruptcy of the builder, the D. L. M. Corporation of Brookfield, Conn. The custom-built home is about 75 percent finished and has been appraised at $500,000 pending its completion. Columbia has set an asking price of $519,000.
Information about all 20 of the properties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut is available in a listing published earlier this week by the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is to be updated every six months. The complete four-part listing costs $50, though the two volumes of residential properties may be bought for $15 each. Volumes may be ordered by calling 1-800-431-0600.
The Government agency plans to employ many methods of selling the properties, including the use of real estate brokers or auctions conducted by the savings institutions. Sale prices for many properties have not yet been published, and all prices may be changed depending on market conditions.
