HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Weighing The Differences Among Heaters

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Another fad is taking hold in the business of keeping warm: ceramic electric heaters. Like the portable kerosene burners and quartz electric heaters that preceded them, ceramic heaters have a few advantages over older models. But they are also the subject of advertising and sales promotions that sometimes promise too much.
They come with names like ''Disc Furnace'' and ''The Heat Machine'' and appear in advertisements that tout a high-tech product with such phrases as ''A scientific breakthrough . . . an engineering marvel!'' and ''At last, a safe, economical source of portable heat.'' 
The suggestion, especially appealing during the recent spell of bitter cold, is that the costly high-tech models provide a less expensive source of warmth. And that is the information you are likely to get at your local hardware or discount store.
But the first truth about electric heaters, as even the manufacturers of ceramic models acknowledge, is that the standard 1,500-watt model provides 5,200 British thermal units an hour. Translation: for a given quantity of electricity, all electric heaters deliver the same amount of heat, whether they use ceramic components or plain old metal coils.
The ceramic models cost much more: the Pelonis Disc Furnance, the first and best-selling ceramic, retails for about $125, about triple the cost of a metal-coil model. The difference in price is enough to run a 1,500-watt heater at full blast for eight hours a day for nearly three months, based on the national average cost for electricity (about 8 cents a kilowatt-hour).
A corollary is that all standard heaters deliver the same amount of heat regardless of size. Some conventional heaters are quite small, while others are built to resemble steam radiators. If small size is an advantage, the ceramic heaters are among the smallest.
The ceramic heaters also claim a safety advantage, because the hottest part of a ceramic heater is a great deal cooler than the hottest part of a conventional electric heater. Jeffrey Mahlstedt, the marketing director of the Del-Rain Corporation of Niagara Falls, N.Y., which makes the Pelonis, said: ''A conventional resistance heater has temperatures in excess of 1,000 degrees Fahrenheit, but ours is 390 degrees, which is well below the combustion point of paper. Even if the curtains blow into it, they will not ignite. If it is tipped over, it could not ignite the carpet, the floorboards or anything else.''
That is true, but all electric heaters, including the Pelonis, have a switch that automatically cuts off the power if they tip.
Fire experts do not keep statistics that differentiate between types of electric heaters, but as a group they are by far the safest form of heating, apart from central heating. According to the National Fire Protection Association, in 1987, the most recent year for which figures are available, space heaters caused 130,000 house fires, with 680 deaths. But only 3,200 of those fires and 103 deaths were linked to portable electric heaters. Space heaters fueled by natural gas, wood stoves and portable kerosene heaters caused the rest of the fires and deaths.
''As a general rule, portable electric heaters come off much better than other devices, when you compare loss rates to the number of units in use,'' said Dr. John Hall, a statistician at the association.
The makers of ceramic heaters also say that their models have more sophisticated temperature-control mechanisms. But Consumer Reports, on the basis of its own laboratory tests, said last November that as a group the ceramics perform poorly in distributing their heat.
Among electric heaters, the ceramics are gaining ground rapidly. According to HFD, a weekly trade publication that reports on home furnishings, manufacturers shipped at least five million space heaters in 1988. Of those, HFD said, probably more than a million were ceramic heaters, first sold in 1986.
 
Coils, Quartz and Kerosene
 The leading type is the heater with resistance coils. The other major type is the quartz heater, designed to radiate its heat to objects, not air. Kerosene heaters, long popular in Europe, are essentially small furnaces without chimneys. They are popular in garages and other semi-enclosed indoor spaces, but they have fallen out of favor for home use because they pollute the indoor air and are banned in some localities.
While electricity is by far the most popular way to heat an individual room, consumers should be wary of cost claims in national advertisements, which often assume a price of electricity of 7 cents per kilowatt-hour. Costs in New York City are nearly double that, and prices in many other major cities are substantially above 7 cents.
The cost factor aside, electric heaters have important uses. They can warm a room that the furnace does not heat well under any circumstances, or on the chilly days of spring or fall, they can warm a summer house that does not have central heat. But in a year-round house, insulation or weatherstripping is often a better solution than a portable heater.
 

 
CAN A HEATER SAVE MONEY?
 Can homeowners save money by turning down the thermostat that controls the furnace and using a portable electric heater to keep a room warm? The answer is: ''It depends.''
Turning the thermostat to 60 degrees and using an electric heater to raise the temperature in one room to a toasty 70 can save fuel that would otherwise be burned in the furnace. But whether the homeowner comes out ahead depends on the price of electricity and the cost of the fuel the furnace uses. Heat from electricity is often three times as expensive as heat from a furnace running on oil or natural gas.
Another consideration is the size of the house. Using an electric heater in only the master bedroom of a drafty Victorian mansion may make more sense than in a snug four-room Cape Cod with heavy insulation.

GRAPHIC: For a given quantity of electricity, all electric heaters deliver the same amount of heat, whether they use ceramic components or plain old metal coils. But the ceramic models, top and bottom, are more compact than the familiar metal-coil type, center. (NYT/Jim Estrin)

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Are the Insurers Fiscally Strong?

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
The Pacific Standard Life Insurance Company, a carrier with $7 billion of insurance in force that had invested heavily in ''junk bonds'' and ''junk mortgages,'' was declared insolvent by the California Department of Insurance at the end of November. In the weeks since then, many financial advisers have asked whether the insolvency is an isolated event or whether other insurers are also at risk.
The question is an important one to consumers. Not only do people buy life insurance to protect their families, but in recent years many people have also bought annuities and other insurance products with investment components. 
Furthermore, pension plans invest with insurers. And some 65 percent of the assets in 401(k) retirement savings plans - $150 billion - are in guaranteed investment contracts, or G.I.C.'s, which are fixed-income investments offered by insurance companies.
''However, contrary to popular belief, the only guarantee is the full faith and credit of the insurance company issuing the contract,'' said J. Ben Vernazza, chairman of the investment policy committee of IMS/CPA's & Associates, in Aptos, Calif., a firm that advises other certified public accountants who do fee-only financial planning.
Still, there is no simple answer to the risk question. If there is an expert consensus, it is that consumers should take care in selecting insurance carriers, looking at the company's financial stability, not simply at premium cost of the yield it pays on an annuity, for example.
''I would be very concerned about the insurance companies,'' said Gerald Morlitz, a lawyer and director of Arthur Andersen & Company's personal financial planning group in New York. ''I think it's the savings and loans five years deferred without any bailout. Make sure it's a healthy company or get out.'' Among the companies he views as healthy are Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance, Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance, Guardian Life Insurance and New England Life.
''There is definitely a place for insurance,'' Mr. Vernazza said, ''but we tend to use it specifically for what it is - protection against risk, not as an investment vehicle.'' He added that ''problems are just starting to surface with the insurance companies'' and he would avoid certain companies, including some large ones because of their junk bond holdings and shaky real estate. ''Junk bonds were accurately named from the start,'' he said.
Brian Ternoey, an actuary who is head of the investment services practice of Foster Higgins, a benefits consulting firm, is far more sanguine. He sees no real credit risk among insurers and cautions against overreaction.
''Some carriers are heavily invested in junk bonds and junk real estate, but they are not at the breaking point yet,'' he said. ''The heaviest can survive for several years with no real default problems.'' Even Executive Life, a company often cited for its junk bond portfolio, also has a lot of United States Treasuries, he noted.
Terence Lennon, chief examiner for life insurance at the New York Insurance Department, agreed. ''There is no immediate danger with the companies pension plans are likely to deal with,'' he said. But, he added that ''the environment in which life insurance companies operate has changed dramatically in the last 15 years.'' Where the greatest risk in the past was mortality, it is now investment risk, he said.
Insurers invest primarily in corporate and government bonds, commercial and residential mortgages, real estate and common stock. The industry's asset quality is high relative to other financial institutions, Moody's Investment Service says, but over the years some insurers have made more risky investments in junk bonds and mortgages as competition for yields has increased. Indeed, insurance companies own 30 percent of the junk bonds outstanding and pension funds own 15 percent.
It is in assessing the degree of risk that financial professionals differ. A number of factors must be considered, including the diversification of a portfolio, economic and market outlook, a company's underwriting standards and accounting standards used in reporting assets and liabilities.
In the case of Pacific Standard, which is owned by the Southmark Corporation of Dallas, California regulators, using conservative accounting standards, disallowed millions of dollars in assets claimed by the insurer. Most were in stock, mortgages and real estate, not in its junk bonds, although the state wants the company to move into less risky investments. Southmark itself has filed for bankruptcy protection.
The company is continuing to pay death benefits and annuity payments but has imposed a six-month moratorium to prevent policy holders from cashing out their policies.
''Don't panic,'' Mr. Ternoey advised investors in general. Pension plans are administered by employers, he noted, but employees can approach 401(k) plans with something other than benign neglect because most plans offer employees a choice of investments.
Most people should put more of their 401(k) funds in stocks and less in fixed-income investments, both Mr. Ternoey and Mr. Morlitz said, because historically, over the longer term, stocks have outperformed other assets.

HEADLINE: Italy Devalues Lira by 3%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: ROME, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The Italian lira was devalued by 3 percent against other major European currencies late today, while its trading band within the European Monetary System was narrowed.
A spokesman for the European Commission said the changes had been agreed by the community's finance ministers and central bank chiefs at night. Speculation of a lira devaluation had swirled through the currency markets all day, but the announcement did not take place until a few minutes before midnight.
In New York trading before the announcement was made the lira was quoted at 754.60 to the West German mark, compared with 751.00 Thursday. Since early December the mark has appreciated by about 2 percent against the lira.
The lira's move to a narrower trading band of 2.25 percent from 6 percent previously is an essential step toward the wider objective of European monetary union. Italy has taken great strides in tackling inflation and achieving sustained economic growth in recent years, and the Bank of Italy is now confident of its ability to hold the lira within a narrower band.
The sweeping changes taking place in Eastern Europe have pushed the mark sharply higher against other currencies.
Pressure has been building in the markets for an upward adjustment of the mark, but this has been strongly resisted by France's Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy.

HEADLINE: Stocks Drop Broadly, With Dow Off 22.83

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks retreated broadly yesterday in continued moderate trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.83 points, to 2,773.25.
The drop, when combined with the decline of the preceding two days, erased more than half of Tuesday's 56.95-point rise. The key indicator finished with a 20.05-point advance for the holiday-shortened week. 
Initially, equities were pushed down by a smaller-than-expected gain in non-farm jobs in the nation and the announcement of the cancellation of political meetings in January by President Mikhail A. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union so he can focus on domestic events. Traders said that sell programs also kicked in late to depress prices further.
On the economic front, the Labor Department reported that non-farm payrolls in December rose by only 142,000 jobs. Most economists expected an increase of 150,000 to 220,000 jobs.
 
Bellwether Bond Up to 8.06%
 The data cheered the bond market initially, but by late in the day the bellwether 30-year Treasury issue had fallen 11/32, to 100 24/32, to yield 8.06 percent, up from 8.03 percent on Thursday and 7.97 percent a week ago.
''We've noted a reversal in the first week of activity from the fourth quarter last year,'' said Brian Luedtke, a vice president at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. ''The 'January effect' - when smaller-capitalized stocks that were depressed late in the year return to favor - was most evident in technology and select economic-sensitive groups.''
Volume shrank to 158.5 million shares, from 177 million on Thursday. Only 591 issues gained ground while 931 fell.
More encompassing indexes than the Dow also faltered, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropping 3.47 points, to 352.20, and the Big Board composite index falling 1.65 points, to 194.64.
 
Philip Morris Most Active
Philip Morris led the most-active list, rising 1/4, to 42 1/8, on a volume of 3.1 million shares. Other busily traded issues included I.B.M., off 1/4, to 99 3/4; A.T.&T. 3/4, to 44 5/8, and General Electric 5/8, to 65 5/8.
Pan Am jumped 1/2, to 3 1/4. An article in Business Week's Jan. 15 issue said that AMR was interested in buying some or all of Pan Am's operations. Traders said that the magazine also reported a rumor that Carl C. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines, was looking at Pan Am as a merger candidate for T.W.A.
Tandy fell 7/8, to 39 3/8. The company said it expected second-quarter earnings to be slightly lower than last year's because of actual and planned patent settlements and because December sales were below projections.
Campbell Soup slipped 1 5/8, to 51 5/8. Leonard Teitelbaum, a Merrill Lynch analyst, said he lowered his rating on the food company to ''neutral'' from ''buy,'' asserting that the takeover interest that has lifted the price of the stock might fade.
Gold stocks gained for a second day as the price of bullion shot up.ASA rose 1 3/8, to 57 3/8; Homestake Mining 7/8, to 20 1/4; Placer Dome 1/2, to 19 1/8, and Echo Bay Mines 1/2, to 19 1/4.
In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.17 points, to 458.22, but the market-value index on the American Stock Exchange edged up 0.29, to 382.45.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Late U.S. Rally; Gold Prices Post Sharp Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar staged a turnaround yesterday, closing mostly higher in domestic dealings after taking a sharp hit in overseas markets that were focusing on events in Eastern Europe.
Gold prices soared by as much as $9 an ounce. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery jumped $7.70 to settle at $406.30 an ounce. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $406.25 an ounce, up $7.50 from Thursday's late bid. 
Reports from the Soviet Union that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had canceled January appointments with foreign officials so he could deal with domestic problems led to the jump in gold prices. But the reports sent stock prices declining and frightened currency markets worldwide.
''So much depends on him keeping peace in the Eastern bloc to give enough room for progress to continue,'' said Jack Barbanel, managing director of First Global Managers in Princeton, N.J.
While foreign markets focused on Mr. Gorbachev's political health, domestic traders concentrated on a Labor Department report that showed the unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent last month. The addition of 142,000 non-farm jobs was weaker than expected.
''The dollar dropped off rather sharply on the weak number,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
The report seemed to support the argument that the United States economy is slowing and that the Federal Reserve might move to lower interest rates. The foreign appetite for dollars is dampened when the yields on American securities decline.
Traders also said the Federal Reserve entered the market to sell dollars for yen, pushing the dollar lower against the Japanese currency.
A lower dollar will help insure ''we have some advantage in continuing the level of exports'' to Japan, which in turn aids in improving the trade deficit, Mr. Barbanel noted.
Despite the news that depressed the dollar early in the day, technical factors pushed it higher at the close of trading.
''The volume was high, and trading was somewhat chaotic,'' Mr. Flanagan said.
In New York, the dollar finished at 144.50 yen, up from 143.38 on Thursday. Earlier, the dollar fell in Tokyo to 144.15 yen, from 145.20 on Thursday. And in London, it fell to 143.75.
In London, the pound rose to $1.6375, from $1.6290 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.6350 to buy a pound, unchanged fom Thursday.
Against the West German currency, the dollar rose to 1.6895 marks from 1.6800.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.5445 Swiss francs, up from 1.5395; 5.5778 French francs, down from 5.7450; 1,276.25 Italian lire, up from 1,263.00, and 1.1608 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1607.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $404.50 an ounce, from $395 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold's closing bid was $405.50, up from $395.70 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: The Noriega Case: Statement;
Transcript of Bush News Conference on Noriega and Panama

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Well, this morning I met with the Attorney General, Dick Thornburgh, to discuss the legal process related to the prosecution of General Noriega. We are committed to a fair trial and to providing all the protections guaranteed by the United States Constitution and laws. The Attorney General assures me that our case is strong, our resolve is firm and our legal representations are sound. Our Government is not seeking a deal with Noriega. Our policy remains that we have brought him to this country for prosecution.
I will be ever mindful of this legal process in the days ahead and will not comment on any aspect of this prosecution or any matters that could even inadvertently affect the outcome of this case. And I'm going to ask others in this Administration to do the same. 
 
Lifting of Sanctions
Deputy Secretary of State Eagleburger and Deputy Secretary of Treasury Robson have just given me a report on the economic reconstruction efforts in Panama. The first action that the United States took after General Noriega was removed from power was to release some $400 million in money that was withheld by virtue of our economic sanctions, sanctions which are now being lifted -$140 million, I believe, is already in Panama.
The revitalization of the Panamanian economy is a major priority in the months ahead, as our - as are our efforts for humanitarian assistance. And I would say here I've been very grateful for the medical supplies that have gone to Panama.
I can report today that considerable progress has been made so far in returning Panama to a normal state of affairs. The new Government is taking charge, and President Endara is working tirelessly to meet the needs of his people. Both Under Secretary Robson and Eagleburger were very high in their praise of Mr. Calderon and Mr. Ford, and, of course President Endara. They are discussing housing programs, business development, bank loans that will help spur economic growth. We are committed to be a part of that process.
 
U.S. as Friendly Neighbor
I want to assure all of the countries of Latin America that United States policy remains one of a friendly, supportive and respectful neighbor. We have worked hard and intensively to consult bilaterally and multilaterally with Latin America, and we will continue to do that. I personally will be involved in that. At the Latin American summit in Costa Rica I pledged that we would work with the countries of this hemisphere to build a better life for its citizens. Our policy of cooperation is firm.
Yesterday I had a lengthy discussion with Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, who is so well-respected - in this hemisphere as well - and I share his deep personal interest in seeing that the countries of this hemisphere pull together on behalf of democracy and economic freedom. I know the yearnings of my fellow leaders in this hemisphere, leaders in Latin America, and I believe they will support the new Government of Panama, and they will support the United States as we work together in this hemisphere.
I've asked the Vice President, Dan Quayle, to visit a number of these Latin American countries within the next several weeks, to personally deliver this message. I view this as very, very important diplomacy and I am determined not to neglect the democracies in this hemisphere. Some have felt that we were so infatuated with the change in Eastern Europe that we were in a process of neglecting this hemisphere and that is not the case. And the Quayle trip, in my view, will help.
I have been undertaking consultations directly with leaders since I've been President. I will resume that, as I said, and the Vice President will be in a position to explain very clearly not only U.S. policy but our aspirations for - for Panama and indeed for this entire hemisphere.
So that's where we are, and I'll be glad to take a few questions. Is it Helen first?
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Possible Deal on Charges
Q. You said that the Government is not seeking any kind of a deal --
A. Yeah.
Q. -- concerning Noriega. Does that mean that you are irrevocably ruling out any reducing of charges, increasing of charges? And also since the indictment runs from '81 to '86 and you had many contacts, apparently, with Panama during that period, were you ever aware of any drug activities on the part of Noriega?
A. On the first part of the question, there's no such plan. The man's entitled to do whatever is, is granted him under our law. So there isn't any such plan.
Secondly, I have made some statements along, in reply to your second question, so punch it in the computer and I'll have nothing more to say about it because I do not want, even inadvertently, to prejudice this case. But my actions are in my view totally unrelated. Yeah, Tom.
 
U.S. Peacekeeping Force
Q. Mr. President, with General Noriega out of Panama and safely in custody in this country, it seems like you might have a difficult choice in deciding how to maintain order in Panama. Do you envision keeping a U.S. military peacekeeping force there beyond the usual contingent of 12,000 troops or would you like to see the Panamanian Defense Forces reconstituted?
A. One, I'd like to see their police forces, whatever emerges, reconstituted. Two, we will get our forces that went in out as soon as possible. Three - I will just say this because your question obviously understand this, but to those listeners out there - Southcom has had a force there and that force, under the treaty, will remain there. But the answer is we want go get those additional, augmented, forces out as soon as possible. And we will.
 
Secrecy on Missions to China
Q. Mr. President, I'd like to try to follow up a question. Mr. President, of all the questions you were asked when you were here last about secrecy, and the two missions by General Scowcroft to China; as I'm sure you may be aware, Secretary of State Baker was asked about what we thought was the first China mission on one of the weekend talk shows. He indicated that it was indeed, it turned out to be the second.
You have since acknowledged quite openly that his answer was false, and that he felt constrained to give that answer to protect the secrecy of the mission. I wondered, first, Sir, whether you felt this was worth it for him to have to do that and second, whether that sort of thing is acceptable in your Administration?
A. Well, let me simply say that some things will be conducted in secrecy and I know you don't like it. Your business is to get everything out in the open, and my business is to conduct the foreign affairs of this country in the way I think I was elected to, and for the most part that will be in the open.
But this move into Panama was held in secrecy and I think the American people understand that. My move to send people to China was controversial. Some think that the best way to make change for human rights in China is isolation. Don't talk to them. Try to punish them by excommunication. I don't feel that way. And so I asked these people to go forward and I don't think Jim Baker would ever deliberately mislead somebody and so I will stand with him.
Q. Sir, I believe he indicated that he felt he had to do that and that he knew what he was doing, that he had to do it. I wondered how you --
A. Ask him about it. I had to support my Secretary of State. Yeah, Lesley?
 
Prejudicing the Noriega Case
Q. You talk about your concern about prejudicing the case, but as you well know, you have called Noriega a thug, and other people in the Administration have gone further; you said he's poisoning our children; haven't you already done that and --
A. Well, I think I've heard all kind of characterizations of him in the press, columnists, even commentators. Presidents, members of the United States Congress. He is not in custody. Time for rhetoric is over. Time for answering hypothetical questions that might prejudice the trial is over. Now I would go back, Lesley, to help you on that to Watergate, where there were hearings. Hearings held. Charges made. Over and over again. Editorials written and voiced, and yet the people received a fair trial. So I am convinced that our system of justice is so fair that the person will get a fair trial. But I can tell you from my standpoint, I am going to bend over backwards and not answer hypothetical questions or not do anything that might prejudice that. Yeah?
Q. I have a follow-up. I want to actually follow up on Helen.
A. No, that's a separate question.
 
Noriega's Trial Rights
Q. Reducing our charges. Are you saying that if he wants to go for that, if he wants to try to go for reducing of charges, that we will entertain --
A. No, I'm not saying that. I'm saying he has a right to do what he wants, and then let the legal process determine how that should work out.
Q. You're not ruling it out?
A. Well, I'm not ruling it in. I'm just saying he's got his rights, and we ought not to stand up here and try to define narrowly what they are. Yes, and then John, and then we'll start moving into the back.
 
Relations With Latin America
Q. Mr. President, based on your opening remarks, and your comments about the Vice President's trip, it would indicate that you're concerned about relations with Latin America. Has the actions we've taken set it back?
A. To some degree I am concerned, because I am well aware of how our friends south of our border, including my friend President Salinas, look at the use of American force anywhere. So I'm concerned about it. I think it's something that's correctable, because I think they know that I have tried a lot of consultation, that we have exhausted the remedies in this particular case of multilateral diplomacy. But given the history of the use of U.S. force, I would be remiss if I didn't face up to the problem that we must go forward diplomatically now to explain how this President looks at the protection of American life; that we acted, in our view, well within our rights, but that we will continue a consultation - but look, I felt strongly about the protection of American life. So we've got to get them to understand that this isn't a shift away from what some had termed excessively timid diplomacy.
Q. But, Mr. President, wouldn't that indicate that actually you're - that we're continuing old American policies that have upset the people of Latin America?
A. Well, to the degree, if there is that perception, then it's up to me and the Secretary. And in this instance, the Vice President's trip takes on enormous importance to convince the people of the truth, and that is that we are not reverting to just, you know, a willful -what's the word I'm groping for here - the use of force that has no rationale. But when it comes to the protection of American life, please, our friends south of the border, understand this President is going to protect it.
I'll tell you one thing that's helped on this, to the degree there is a problem at all, and that is the way the Panamanian democracy is now starting to move forward, the certification of the three people who had been deprived of their right to hold office by the previous regime. That's been of enormous help. And then I think the other thing is the reception, the public reception in Panama for our action. It has been overwhelming, overwhelming.
 
Political Reactions on Panama
Q. On that, Sir, Lee Atwater, the chairman of the R.N.C., says Panama is a political jackpot for you and it will wipe out the disenchantment, for example, with the way you handled China. Without saying that's why you went into Panama [unintelligible], it is a political jackpot.
A. Well, Jesse Jackson doesn't think so. He talked to my wife. And so, you know, there's differences of opinions on that. But this isn't, I didn't do something for a political reason. That's not the reason I do that. I did it to protect American life. A President's called on to take certain action. We're not going in to try to furbish a political image. That's ridiculous.
Q. I haven't said that, though. Have you now neutralized the Democrats on foreign policy? Is this the last time George Mitchell can ever accuse you of having a timid foreign policy?
A. Knowing George, he'll find a reason; he'll find a way. And that's his job. I mean, look, we're going into an election year. But this, this - I want to try if I can to separate - the response has been - he's been supportive of this. Let's give the man credit. But I don't think it's laid to rest or put off bounds any criticism of the President by a Democratic opposition, if that's the question. No. Absolutely not. Yeah, Frank. And then back there. And then you're third.
 
Disposition of U.S. Troops
Q. Mr. President, do you anticipate that the combat troops, the bulk of the additional combat troops sent into Panama will indeed be out by the end of this month, as some Administration officials have said? And secondly, and more broadly, do you now see an expanded role for the American military in small regional issues like this one or in more particularly in the war against drugs since there was a strong drug connection to this operation?
A. No, I see no - well - I see no parallel between the situation here, where American lives were at stake and you had an indicted person who'd usurped power and declared war against the United States, I don't think you can draw a parallel between that unique situation and then other countries. And what was the other part of it?
Q. The bit about when you see America, these additional combat troops, able to come home, all of them?
A. Soon as possible and I have made clear to the Secretary of Defense, to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, who is down in Panama right now, I believe that this is what we should do. This is what they themselves want to do. Some U.S. forces that went in are already out. So I would look for an early return.
Q. General time frame?
A. Can't help you, but soon as General Powell gets back we'll have a more - Dave?
Q. What about the international --
A. Your name Dave? Go ahead.
Q. What about the international law implications, isn't this something that you are also going to talk to the Latin American countries about?
A. Absolutely.
Q. Mr. President, what is the explanation behind it?
A. The right to protect American lives granted under the U.N. Charter, and we will - we will protect lives of citizens, and we will go forward with that. The State Department, as I understand it, has already spelled that out. But I think you raise a good point: yes, we should make very clear why we acted and under what authority we acted as we did. David?
 
Future Deployment of Military
Q. Mr. President, you just described Panama as a unique case, and I'd just like to ask you a sort of a philosophical question. If the criteria you listed here - protecting American lives, having exhausting all the other diplomatic options - presented themselves again, should we look in a Bush Presidency for more such deployments of military force if your criteria were met?
A. Well, yes, if you can spell out what the criteria is, and then if you - if you can look to the future to see the situation surrounding it. I can't visualize another situation quite this unique, but let me just say, when American life is threatened we - we were concerned in El Salvador, for example; a civilian hotel could well have been occupied by a guerrilla force that would have threatened the American use of - threatened American life. That concerned me, and indeed we - we moved forces. Not in some macho way, but to try to protect the lives of American citizens. But I think most people understood that.
But I don't see, David, I don't see another real parallel here looming on the horizon at all.
 
Results on Missions to China
Q. Mr. President, back to the issue of China, your decision to send emissaries to China carried some costs for you. Have you seen any payoff? Have you had any response from the regime there that is productive or encouraging for you?
A. Well, it does carry some. And I think some who were familiar with the situation have been quite supportive - and some quite critical, I will admit that. As I indicated, some favor isolation: Don't talk and let them come to us. HEADLINE: Peru's Inflation Is Owed To Lack of Restraints

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your report that Peru will resume some International Monetary Fund debt payments (Business Day, Dec. 7) calls President Alan Garcia's debt policy ''disastrous.'' For Peru, 1988 and 1989 have indeed been disastrous years, but in the first two full years of the policy, 1986 and 1987, Peru enjoyed real growth rates of 8.6 percent and 6.9 percent, respectively, with its lowest inflation since 1982, indicating that the debt policy did not cause the disaster. 
Peru's economic problems originate in President Garcia's domestic policies. The hyperinflation reflects absence of monetary and fiscal restraint, marked by an increase in the government deficit from 3 percent of gross domestic product in 1985 to 8.4 percent in 1987. Meanwhile, price controls and generous wage increases made consumption and imports rise, draining Peru's foreign reserves. The economic contraction results largely from the foreign exchange shortage, which prevents vital imports.
President Garcia's debt policy made available foreign exchange that would otherwise have gone abroad in debt payments. Had it been invested, rather than squandered, we would probably be hailing his courage and foresight, and pointing to Peru as a model for other heavily indebted countries.
 
ANTHONY MARCUS
 
JEFFREY FRANKS
 Princeton, N.J., Dec. 19, 1989
 
The writers are students at, respectively, Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School and Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School.

HEADLINE: COLOMBIANS BALK AT A CRUCIAL PART OF U.S. DRUG PLANS

BYLINE: By BERNARD E. TRAINOR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's plan to step up military involvement in the war on drugs in Latin America was dealt a setback this week when Colombia balked at a crucial element, the stationing of United States vessels off its coast, Administration officials say.
The officials also say the Pentagon intends to put ground-based radar units in the mountains of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, to be run by Americans and officers of those nations. This element of the plan, already approved by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, would be the first use of American forces in other countries for surveillance of planes believed to be carrying drugs.
The broad outlines of the military's plans were revealed Dec. 28 when the White House press spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, told reporters that the Administration had ''decided to take certain actions'' to help Latin American countries fight the flow of drugs into the United States. Mr. Fitzwater did not provide specifics, but other officials have said the Defense Department has completed plans to send an aircraft carrier battle group to international waters off Colombia and to use surveillance planes in the region.
 
Ships Leave Home Port
The battle group, consisting of the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and support ships, left its home port in Norfolk, Va., on Friday for the Caribbean. But the group will not take position off the Colombian coast until the Pentagon's overall anti-drug plan is formally announced. 
That announcement is now scheduled for the week of Jan. 15. Officials had planned to announce the details of the plan earlier. But the Colombian authorities refused this past week to meet with an American team that had been sent to explain the Navy plan. Administration officials said, however, that they are confident that President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia will cooperate with the American plan.
An Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the American intervention in Panama to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as the Panamanian leader unsettled the Colombians. The official said the Colombians feared that the United States might use its Panama operation as a precedent to enter other countries in pursuit of people wanted on American drug trafficking charges. The official also said that earlier reports about the dispatch of a naval force to Colombia had been misinterpreted by the Colombians as suggesting the United States planned a blockade.
 
General Support for Plan
Venezuela, the only other country that would be directly affected by the naval proposal, did receive the briefing team. Peru and Bolivia have been generally agreeable to the overall military plan, which includes establishing radar sites in their countries.
In his press conference on Friday, President Bush acknowledged the need to allay concerns among Latin American nations over the American intervention in Panama. He said he would send Vice President Dan Quayle to meet with several Latin American leaders in Honduras on Jan. 27.
No cost estimates for the expanded drug program are available yet, but it is likely to be a multibillion-dollar effort. The United States has already supplied Colombia with $65 million in emergency military aid and President Bush has pledged $2 billion in economic aid to Colombia, Bolivia and Peru over the next four years.
Pentagon officials are uncertain how effective the new effort will be in combating drug traffic, but expect it to discourage drug traffickers and say it will give a psychological boost to Latin countries by showing American support for their war against drugs.
The program may at least make drug smuggling more difficult and dangerous for those who see it as simply a business, a Drug Enforcement Administration official said. ''When private pilots doing contract work for the cartels find they are being tracked and may be shot down, they may not want to stay in the game,'' the official said.
In September, Mr. Cheney ordered the military to put together plans for an expanded role in the battle against drugs. The detailed strategy was developed on the basis of recommendations submitted by senior military commanders to the Joint Chiefs of Staff in mid-October.
 
No U.S. Combat Role Planned
Those plans call for the radar units in the Andes to be part of an extensive intelligence and electronic surveillance network that would monitor air traffic in the Caribbean and the Andean region of South America, Administration officials said. These officials stressed that the American technicians who will be operating the radar units are not expected to play a combat role or the make decisions about the shooting down of aircraft suspected of carrying drugs or the raiding of landing sites. The officials said such decisions would be made by Colombian, Peruvian and Bolivian authorities using their own forces.
It is not known how many radar sites will be involved or how much danger the radar technicians would face in the mountainous areas where they would be set up. But military officials rate the danger as minimal.
There are currently about 14 Army special forces troops in Bolivia and a similar number in Peru. There are also 60 to 100 American military specialists and technicians in noncombat roles at an equipment center in Colombia to help in that country's battle against drug dealers.
The Kennedy, once in place off the Colombian coast, would use E-2C Hawkeye planes, radar-equipped aircraft, to monitor air traffic over Colombia. In addition, the plans call for Air Force Awacs surveillance aircraft to monitor air traffic in the region.
As part of the new program, the military plans to establish communications systems to transmit information picked up by the radars and electronic eavesdropping equipment to the authorities within the three countries.
 
Ship Off Colombian Coast
At a later date, Administration officials said, an amphibious helicopter ship will be stationed off Colombia to provide a secure sea base to support Colombian drug interdiction efforts. Among other functions, the ship will serve as a training and equipment maintenance site and provide backup communications and electronics intelligence support for systems already established ashore.
The ship could also provide a temporary safe haven for endangered Colombian officials like judges and intelligence agents, an Administration official said. Some United States advisers could also be on the ship, keeping down the number of Americans ashore in Colombia. The United States has already used a similar sea-based system off El Salvador.
Small twin-engine private planes are used widely to transport coca paste from Peru and Bolivia to Colombia for refinement into cocaine powder. Much of the finished product is then smuggled into the United States by air. Officials concede that distinguishing between illegal drug and legitimate business flights will pose a major problem.
There are thousands of primitive air strips in the region and many businessmen, like cattle ranchers in remote areas of Colombia and Peru, use airplanes for routine transportation.
A Pentagon official said: ''This will not be an overnight process. The first job is to get everything in place and build up a data base on air traffic in the region and identify the landing strips and flight patterns of suspected drug flights.''
 
Security for Operations
Another problem involves security for operations. Anti-narcotics efforts throughout the Andean region have been hampered by government corruption and reluctance to move aggressively against drug traffickers. Many drug raids are conducted half-heartedly and in many instances those involved with illegal drugs are tipped off to impending military and police action against them.
To achieve secrecy for sensitive missions, a Pentagon officer said Colombian anti-drug authorities could probably plan sensitive missions aboard the off-shore amphibious ship scheduled to sail to the region in a few months.
A small number of United States special forces, equipment technicians, helicopter mechanics and intelligence experts are already scattered throughout the Andean region. Although the number of Americans will increase as the surveillance and intelligence network grows, Pentagon officials insist that the American military presence will be kept to a minimum.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Japan;
Tokyo Broadens Plan to Aid A New Poland and Hungary

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 6

 BODY:
In a signal of Japan's eagerness to take part in the emerging new order in Europe, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu plans next week to announce a package of more than $1 billion in loans and guarantees for Poland and Hungary, Japanese officials said today.
The officials said Mr. Kaifu would present the new assistance package, which is several times larger than anything discussed publicly up to now, during a 10-day visit to Europe that begins on Monday.
Most of Tokyo's plan consists of low-interest loans to Poland and Hungary for the import of machinery and capital goods from Japan and other countries. Japan and the other exporting nations stand to benefit from Mr. Kaifu's package. 
Like the aid packages being assembled in the United States and Western Europe, the Japanese plan would be contingent on efforts by Poland and Hungary to open up their economies to market forces and to negotiate debt rescheduling.
Mr. Kaifu's trip is to include stops in most major Western European capitals, as well as visits to Warsaw and Budapest. His stop in the Hungarian capital will be the first by a Japanese Prime Minister.
 
Aid Is Conditional
The officials said Prime Minister Kaifu wanted to convey the willingness of Japanese companies to make major investments in Eastern Europe provided that Poland, Hungary and other countries overhaul their economies.
''We have always thought that the important thing for Eastern Europe is not government assistance, but for those countries to make the transition to a market economy,'' a Japanese official said.
He said similar aid and investment packages could be assembled for Czechoslovakia, Rumania, East Germany and other countries. But for the moment, he said, Poland and Hungary are the only Eastern European countries that have made a commitment to liberalizing their economies.
Mr. Kaifu's trip was planned at least in part to improve his political standing in Japan before parliamentary elections in February. Japanese officials said the visit was also aimed at allaying Western European suspicions about the Japanese, worries that are growing as economic competition intensifies.
 
A Role in World Politics
Japanese officials said Mr. Kaifu wanted to send a message that Tokyo is determined to take part in the unfolding of a new Europe, and to insure that Japanese automobiles, electronics goods and other exports are not shut out of this new economic order.
''We believe we have now come to the stage where Japan has to be a major player in world politics,'' the official said. ''Not just in the economic sense, but in maintaining and shaping the future world order. We want Europeans to understand that basically we share the same values.''
But businessmen and officials here emphasize that major Japanese private investment in Poland and Hungary will not be forthcoming unless Western European nations show that they are willing to consider importing the end products.
Officials said that the automaker Daihatsu discussed the possibility of building an automobile factory in Poland, and that Suzuki held similar talks about a car factory in Hungary.
 
Finding West European Markets
Those ventures are unlikely to succeed unless the factories export cars to Western Europe, which has been unreceptive to Japanese automobile imports. Officials said that Mr. Kaifu would test West European attitudes on these and other investments next week.
Executives here acknowledge that Japanese investment in Eastern Europe might be viewed as an attempt by Tokyo to secure a foothold on the Continent as Europe moves toward economic and political integration.
''Europe is becoming more united and more integrated than before, which we welcome,'' said a Japanese official. ''But there's always a possibility that Europe will then become more concerned with itself rather than relations with the outside world.''
Officials said that the team accompanying Mr. Kaifu has not determined the exact sum of its aid and loan package, but that it appeared to be in the range of $1.5 billion, and perhaps as high as $1.95 billion.
 
As Much as $1.95 Billion
The figure of $1.95 billion was cited today by the Asahi newspaper, but it appears that a good portion of that amount is ''soft money,'' like guarantees of compensation to Japanese exporters should Poland or Hungary default on payments.
Two months ago, Mr. Kaifu's Government announced that Japan would provide $150 million to Poland to help the country stabilize its currency and restructure its economy.
This proposal remains the centerpiece of Japan's package, but the sum has grown to include $50 million in food aid for Poland and technical assistance for Poland and Hungary, officials said.
Officials said Japan was also ready to provide perhaps $400 million to $500 million each to Poland and Hungary to finance the imports of capital goods and machinery needed to revitalize their industrial base.
Poland and Hungary could also each receive another several hundred million dollars in the form of guarantees to Japanese exporters that would ship goods to those countries. In the tradition of much Japanese aid, those sums would help Japanese businesses as well as the recipients.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: China;
In Reaction to Rumania, A Hardening in Beijing

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Shocked at the upheavals in Rumania, the Chinese Government is reacting by taking an even harder line politically and adopting a tougher posture diplomatically, Chinese officials and foreign diplomats say.
Police and army units have been put on alert, and plans to lift martial law have been canceled, the officials and diplomats said. They say the Chinese leadership has been deeply traumatized by the toppling of the Rumanian Government.
''The entire picture has changed because of Rumania,'' said a university professor who backed the democracy movement last spring. ''Things were getting better for a time, but now they seem to be worsening again.'' 
The hardening of policy is the opposite of the conciliatory signals that President Bush apparently anticipated when he sent Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, on an official visit to Beijing in early December.
 
Relaxing Economic Controls
But while political control tightens, Chinese officials say that the Government is relaxing some economic controls to avoid the threat of unrest from disgruntled workers. Most importantly, a central party document has called for salaries of employees at state-owned companies to be raised before Chinese New Year late this month. In addition, special efforts are being made to assure plentiful supplies for the holiday, and the authorities are trying to win support by easing monetary policy and restrictions on rural enterprises, Chinese officials said.
While almost everyone interviewed describes the Government these days as tense and anxious, few expect large demonstrations in Beijing soon.
''I tend to think of the population in terms of sullenness rather than explosiveness,'' said a Western diplomat.
A university student said: ''We were so happy about Rumania. But who dares to go out on the streets, with martial law still in effect? We can't show our pleasure.''
 
Banners and Quiet Gatherings
Yet some students and intellectuals have been surprisingly bold, putting up posters and banners and holding quiet gatherings at a half-dozen universities and other institutions.
Residents of the capital are also talking - some with an air of wonderment - of the small group of students that demonstrated last month in front of the Government television offices. Seven to 10 of the students were arrested, but their action is widely hailed as a sign that the people of Beijing have not been entirely cowed.
An aspect of the Rumanian rebellion that is believed to have most shocked the Chinese leadership was the army's role in overthrowing President Nicolae Ceausescu. Since that happened, there has been a stream of meetings reported in the People's Liberation Army Daily in which the Chinese leaders have stressed that the army must always obey the Communist Party.
''The easiest way to capture the fortress is from within,'' cautioned the People's Daily in reporting the discussions at political study classes for the army. The newspaper said that the chief of the general staff, Chi Haotian, had ''rushed'' back from the provinces to join the classes, which, it said, stressed that ''the party must exercise absolute control over the army.''
 
Tough Statement on Dissident
There have been two important statements on significant foreign policy matters since the Rumanian unrest that have suggested a harder line is emerging, diplomats say. The first was China's unexpectedly harsh criticism on Dec. 30 of a British plan to allow 225,000 Hong Kong residents who hold British passports to take up residence in Britain after the colony is turned over to China in 1997.
The second was the Government's tough statement on Wednesday about Fang Lizhi, the dissident astrophysicist who has taken refuge in the American Embassy. Mr. Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, who is also a leading dissident, fled to the American Embassy during the Government crackdown last June. The statement, which was much harsher than comments about the couple by the Communist Party leader Jiang Zemin on Dec. 21, said the ''only way out'' for Mr. Fang was to plead guilty immediately.
While there was never an announcement that martial law would end, some knowledgeable Chinese say that the Politburo had agreed to lift it, possibly on Dec. 24. But they say that this decision was revoked in a series of emergency meetings that began on Dec. 22, as the Rumanian rebellion unfolded.

HEADLINE: Cocaine Ring's Latest Campaign: Kidnapping Wealthy Colombians

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Shifting tactics from bombing and killing, Colombia's cocaine traffickers have kidnapped about 20 members of wealthy families in recent days, the police say.
Pablo Escobar Gaviria, declared Colombia's most wanted criminal by law-enforcement authorities, is believed to be orchestrating the kidnapping campaign in Medellin, Colombia's second-largest city and the headquarters of his trafficking ring.
''You could describe one as a Colombian Vanderbilt, another as the owner of the fastest growing group of chain stores,'' the managing editor of a news organization here said of the prominent captives.
The drug traffickers have also seized the son of President Virgilio Barco Vargas's closest adviser, German Montoya. 
 
Message From Kidnapping Ring
On Friday, newspapers published a communique from the Extraditables, a terrorist group set up by the traffickers. Using leftist language, the group said the kidnapping campaign was designed to raise money for ''contruction of popular housing'' and for ''the war declared against the political oligarchy.''
''We have ordered leaders of poor neighborhoods to take hostage members of the traditional oligarchy,'' said the group, which acts on behalf of multimillionaire cocaine dealers who fear extradition to the United States.
Analysts here give a mixture of political and economic explanations for the kidnapping campaign. ''I think the situation in Medellin is changing,'' said an aide to President Barco. ''The city is starting to turn against the traffickers. The kidnappings neutralize the important local families.''
 
Appeals to Populist Sentiment
Mr. Escobar has long used appeals to populist sentiment. In the mid-1980's, Mr. Escobar paid for a low-income housing project in Medellin.
Oddly enough, in recent years Mr. Escobar has also sponsored a clandestine group, Death to Kidnappers, that killed left-wing guerrillas.
''He is trying to reach out, with a populist appeal,'' said the magazine editor. ''But by kidnapping, I think, he will make more enemies than friends.''
Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez, the head of Colombia's federal intelligence police, argued that the Government's five-month war on the traffickers has disrupted their business to the extent that they are short of cash. ''Escobar is kidnapping because he has a liquidity problem,'' the general said.
Mr. Escobar's personal fortune is estimated at $2 billion, but in recent months the authorities have seized many of his ranches and airplanes and have frozen many of his bank accounts.
 
Death of Rodriguez Gacha
General Maza argued that the death on Dec. 15 of Jose Rodriguez Gacha, a major trafficker, in a shootout with security forces had deprived Mr. Escobar of key military and logistical support. Mr. Rodriguez Gacha, who appeared on wanted posters here with Mr. Escobar, is believed to have controlled much of the chain of supply for cocaine shipped to the United States.
Mr. Rodriguez Gacha is believed to have orchestrated a bombing campaign for the Extraditables last fall. The police say the traffickers exploded 203 bombs, killing 261 people and wounding 1,238.
The pace of the bombings has declined drastically in the three weeks since Mr. Rodriguez Gacha's death. Last week, the police in Bogota raided a bomb factory containing over three tons of dynamite. This week, police in Medellin seized 275 pounds of dynamite in a raid.
Indeed, the only major explosion in recent days took place on Thursday at a cocaine laboratory in Medellin. Five people were killed when the illicit laboratory blew up.
Assassinations have not ceased, however. A land reform adviser to President Barco was shot to death on Friday night in Medellin, the police said today. The adviser, Roberto Lozano Suarez, was shot by a man at a motorcycle as he sat in his car at a stoplight.
Mr. Escobar is believed to be hiding in Medellin, and on Friday the local army commander distributed wanted posters in the city offering a $450,000 bounty for information leading to his capture.
''Yesterday it was Rodriguez Gacha,'' the posters say. ''Now it will be Pablo Escobar.''

HEADLINE: HEALTHY ECONOMY IS SEEN FOR FARMS

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 5

 BODY:
A healthy farm economy for New York State this year and the rest of the 1990's was forecast this week by agricultural experts at Cornell University in Ithaca and the State Department of Agriculture and Markets here.
''Agriculture will be in a strong position in 1990, better than in 1989, depending on the weather,'' said Richard T. McGuire, the State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.
He said farm production had been cut by two successive years of bad weather, a drought in 1988 and excesssive rainfall in 1989. If the weather is good in 1990, Mr. McGuire said, he expected production of almost all crops and farm income to increase. 
 
'Continued Improvement'
Speaking at a farm outlook conference in Ithaca, Bernard F. Staunton, professor of agricultural economics at the State College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at Cornell, said that farmers generally were entering the 1990's facing a much healthier agricultural economy.
''The debt crisis and inflated land values of the early 1980's are behind us,'' he said. ''Net farm income is up in 1989 compared to 1988 and expectations for the first half of 1990 are for continued improvement.''
Although official figures are not yet in, he estimated that net farm income in New York in 1989 rose about 12 percent above 1988, from $571 million to $640 million. New York has about 37,000 farms, according to the latest United States Census of Agriculture, with a gross farm income of $2.6 billion.
 
Dairy Farms Are Healthier
The major reason for the optimistic view was an improvement in the financial picture for New York's dairy farms, the largest economic segment of the state's agriculture.
New York, which is the third-leading dairy state in the nation behind Wisconsin and California, has about 13,000 dairy farms, with 800,000 cows. Last year, they produced about 11.25 billion pounds of milk, down 1.5 percent from the year before, which they sold for about $1.5 billion.
Milk production dropped, dairy experts said, because of poor forage caused by bad weather, a consequent drop in production per cow and a decrease in the number of cows.
With production decreasing in other states, too, a national shortage of milk followed, producing a sharp price rise.
Farm milk prices rose to a record level in 1989 and are expected to remain high in early 1990, the Cornell dairy experts said. In November, farmers in southern New York and northern New Jersey received $15.28 for each 100 pounds of milk (about 45 quarts) that they produced.
As a result, the retail milk price increased. In the New York metropolitan area the price of a gallon of milk rose to an all-time high of $2.53 in December, an increase of 20 cents since August.
 
More Milk Is Expected
The rise in prices, both at the farm and at retail, should end sometime early this year because of an anticipated increased supply of milk, the milk experts said.
''For 1990, a recovery in milk production is expected by everyone, but there is disagreement about when it will start and how big it will be,'' the Cornell farm economists said.
They estimated that production might rise by 1.5 percent, because of some increase in cow numbers and gains in production per cow, assuming a more normal growing season and a better supply of feed for the cows.
Mr. McGuire and the Cornell experts also agreed that 1990 would be a good year, weather permitting, for the state's apple and vegetable growers, for egg producers and for nursery operators growing bedding plants, potted plants and flowers.

HEADLINE: Fashion;
Resort Wear: Beyond the Beach

BYLINE: By BERNADINE MORRIS

 BODY:
Although automobile sales and other parts of the economy are sluggish, fashion retailers are cheered by the response to resort fashions that began arriving in the stores last month.
''Selling is surprisingly strong,'' said Kalman Ruttenstein, senior vice president for fashion direction at Bloomingdale's. ''The clothes that are being bought will set the direction for fashion in the next six months.'' The emphasis is on designer names. ''Donna Karan is a phenomenon,'' said Andrew Basile, vice president and fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman. ''The customers come looking for her clothes, and the minute we get a delivery the styles are sold out. Our Michael Kors stock is depleted, and we've reordered. Chanel is sensational, and Isaac Mizrahi is hitting his stride.'' 
Helen O'Hagan, vice president and corporate public relations director of Saks Fifth Avenue, agreed. ''Designer sportswear is doing fabulously well, and the action everywhere is on better priced merchandise,'' she said.
 
Linen Is Back
Linen, which has not been spectacularly successful in the last few years, is back in favor among customers.
''People were turned off for a while because it wrinkles,'' Miss O'Hagan said, ''but they have come back to it because it is, after all, the coolest and most comfortable fabric for warm weather.''
Linen is an important fabric in the dresses that have captured shoppers' fancy in many stores. Every retailer has easy, short dresses in soft or bright colors that rank among the best sellers.
An even more dynamic fashion is shorts, ranging from brief to Bermuda-length and either sleekly fitted or cut with gentle fullness.
''Shorts are our strongest-selling category,'' Mr. Ruttenstein said. ''They include stretch styles like the ones bicycle messengers wear and graceful styles that are worn like suits.''
Mr. Basile reports that best-selling shorts at Bergdorf Goodman have carried diverse designer labels, including those of Ralph Lauren, Gianfranco Ferre, Michael Kors and Chanel.
During a recent selling trip to Saks Fifth Avenue's store at Bal Harbour, Fla., Isaac Mizrahi found that his best seller was a black crepe double-breasted shorts suit with satin revers. Women were buying it as a swingy evening outfit.
Suits are an important part of the resort selling picture at Bergdorf.
''Resort is not just beach and evening clothes any more,'' Mr. Basile explained. ''Some women spend a considerable length of time in the South, while others combine trips with business appointments so they need fairly formal lunch clothes.''
Accessories are selling well at Saks Fifth Avenue, especially gold metallic styles, including hats, belts, bags, and flat mesh or stripping sandals by Donna Karan.
 
A Jump on Spring Shopping
Not all the resort clothes and accessories are purchased to wear in the South. Many customers like to shop when the stores are less frenetic than they will be in warmer weather, while others want to be prepared for the first warm days. Still others plan to wear some styles, like crepe dresses, under their winter coats.
''I always buy my own summer clothes from the resort collections,'' Miss O'Hagan said. ''I never face a weekend from Memorial Day on without a new swimsuit.''
Among her first purchases this season are a striped navy T-shirt by Adrienne Vittadini at $35 and a navy and black striped pullover by Ralph Lauren at $65. She plans to wear the striped top tied around her neck like a scarf when she is not wearing it as a sweater.

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Do Songs About The World's Ills Do Any Good?

BYLINE: By Stephen Holden

 BODY:
Anyone who follows pop music's ongoing hit parade must have noticed the unprecedented convergence on the charts of hit singles with lyrics bearing social messages, about topics from homelessness to race relations to child abuse. In the national top 30 singles at year's end, no fewer than six songs took note of the world's ills.
The current rash of these songs is part of a movement that began five years ago with the all-star charity singles ''Do They Know It's Christmas'' and ''We Are the World'' and found its most eloquent personal expression last year in Tracy Chapman's ''Fast Car.'' If today's hits aren't actually raising money for worthy causes, many of them are created with the same good intentions. Yet there is something disquieting about a process that reduces human problems into neat little sound bites that cast a moral glow upon their creators. 
During the final weeks of 1989, America's No. 1 hit was Phil Collins's mournful, chiming ballad, ''Another Day in Paradise,'' which offers snapshots of homeless people pleading to pedestrians for attention and being ignored.
Mr. Collins's hit supplanted Billy Joel's semi-serious novelty, ''We Didn't Start the Fire,'' at the top of the chart. ''We Didn't Start the Fire,'' the Long Island rocker's first No. 1 hit in six years, is a clever pop-rap fusion that offers a chronological montage of names and historical buzzwords, beginning in 1949 with Harry S Truman and ending with this year's uprising in China and with the phenomenon Mr. Joel calls ''Rock and Roller Cola Wars.'' While the time span of the song implies that current events come out of historical processes, Mr. Joel offers no analysis or editorializing other than to throw up his hands at the sheer volume of it all.
The two hits have both yielded snappy music videos. In Mr. Collins's, alarming statistics about homelessness and poverty around the world are flashed onto the screen in bright white letters as the singer casts dark, meaningful glances into the camera. Mr. Joel's music video juxtaposes images of the singer in front of a raging fire with re-creations of an ''I Love Lucy''-style sitcom.
However clever they are, both leave one with unsettling intimations about the effects on people's lives of the sheer barrage of modern media. Contemporary pop and video are now so skillful at delivering information that induces a visceral response that the passive reception of the news is in danger of being confused with active involvement in social causes.
Of course, involvement begins with awareness, and these songs are nothing if not news-savvy. But, inevitably, the songs that call attention to these problems are part of a tidal wave of horrifying images that make the mere act of receiving them feel like an act of courage in itself. Could it be that socially conscious songs and music videos that call attention to problems might actually reinforce acquiescence to crises that seem too numerous and serious to be solved?
At the end of the year, the single most likely to wrest the No. 1 spot away from Mr. Collins was Janet Jackson's fast-climbing ''Rhythm Nation.'' A militantly utopian dance-floor exhortation, written by Ms. Jackson with her producers Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis, the song calls for racial harmony and cooperative struggle to create a better, stronger world.
New Kids on the Block's ''This One's for the Children'' echoed ''We Are the World'' in expressing a generalized concern for the world's hungry children. The Rolling Stones' ''Rock and a Hard Place'' ticked off a whole list of issues, among them pollution, world hunger and human rights. Without naming names, it also offered a veiled protest to United States involvement in Central American affairs. Aerosmith's lurid hard-rock ballad, ''Janie's Got a Gun'' tells of a girl who shoots her father to death after suffering through years of incestuous abuse.
Among the six singles, Mr. Collins's and Mr. Joel's hits are both the catchiest and the most revealing in their reflection of America's social mood at the end of the decade. Mr. Collins's hit describes the increasingly common experience of being approached on the street by a homeless person, studiously ignoring the plea for help and the attendant embarrassment. In the chorus, Mr. Collins comments: ''Oh think twice, it's another day for you and me in paradise.'' It conveys a complicated sequence of emotions: empathy, defensiveness, shame and and finally impotence.
But because Mr. Collins is one of pop music's Mr. Nice Guys, there is almost something reassuring about the record. The only advice the song offers to the listener who might be approached by a homeless person on the street is to ''think twice'' (in other words have a compassionate thought), and to count one's blessings.
Mr. Joel's hit evokes much the same feelings of detached interest and helplessness. The song is the aural equivalent of a video montage flashing the historical events in the lifetime of a prototypical baby boomer. In the breathless little merry-go-round chorus that punctuates the chronology, the singers insist that there's nothing they can do to change the course of events. ''We didn't start the fire/ It was always burning/ Since the world's been turning,'' they protest. ''We didn't start the fire/ No we didn't light it/ But we tried to fight it.''
Ultimately, both songs' points of view are essentially the same as that expressed in 1986 by Bruce Hornsby & the Range in ''The Way It Is,'' the last No. 1 hit with a strong social message. In that song, Mr. Hornsby lamented racial discrimination and the economic deprivation of African-Americans and commented: ''That's just the way it is/ Some things will never change/ That's just the way it is/ But don't you believe them.'' In the context of the record, the plea, ''but don't you believe them'' comes only as a wistful utopian afterthought.
While these hits suggest that the social consciousness of American pop is deepening, there are also signs that the mainstream pop audience will only embrace messages that don't demand a deep, personal involvement in social causes. In several cuts on his newest album, ''Freedom,'' Neil Young addresses homelessness and drug addiction. But instead of singing from the point of view of a concerned middle-class urbanite, he imagines himself inside the skins of disenfranchised street people, and his tone is scarily cantankerous.
Jackson Browne's recent album ''World in Motion,'' contains some of the most stirring music of his career, but it makes no bones about the fact that the only way things can change is by people getting involved in political and social action programs. A number of the songs are impassioned sermons intended to prick the conscience.
Neither ''Freedom,'' which has reaped more critical acclaim than any of Mr. Young's albums in a decade, nor ''World in Motion'' has been welcomed by the kind of mass audience that made ''Another Day in Paradise'' and ''We Didn't Start the Fire'' instant successes. They demand depth of identification and a commitment to work for social change that may be just too upsetting for most people to want to consider.
