HEADLINE: For Airlines, a Heated Push Into the Pacific Rim

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
A few years ago, Jerry Connelly, a fashion executive in New York who flies regularly to the Far East, booked his flights to cities like Hong Kong a just few days ahead of time. But no more. ''Now you need at least a week or two's notice,'' he said. ''Sometimes I can't even get a seat then.''
Mr. Connelly's frustration is a sign of the airline industry's Asian bonanza. Spurred by the blossoming economies and relaxed travel policies in countries like Japan, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore, air travel to and from Asia is booming and airlines are clamoring to grab a chunk of the fastest-growing market in the world. ''United States carriers are gaga about the Asian market,'' said John Ash, managing director of Global Aviation, a consulting firm in Washington. ''Everybody wants a piece of it.'' But it won't come easily. Certain Asian countries like Japan do not have open-sky policies and therefore prohibit carriers from flying into their airports at will. And airports are already congested, especially in travel-crazed Japan. While new long-range jets could help alleviate overcrowding by bypassing current stopovers, production of these planes has been hamstrung by labor strikes. What is more, Asian airlines, with their lower labor costs and reputation for attentive service, are proving to be tough competitors. 
And rivalries in the Far East among American carriers are also expected to heat up. Until recently, Asia was the domain of two United States lines: Northwest Airlines and United Air Lines. But others, like American, Delta and Continental, have gained a toehold in the region in recent years. Northwest now commands only 42 percent, and United 29 percent, of the travel in the Pacific handled by American carriers.
The newcomers, dividing the remaining 29 percent of that travel, are primed to expand. ''The American carriers are chafing at the bit, wishing they could fly from, say, Chicago to Tokyo,'' said Mary Hunt, editor of Business Traveler International.
 
New Routes Ahead
 An agreement signed in November by the United States and Japan could enable more of them to establish routes into Tokyo, the gateway to the Pacific rim.
 Last Thursday, Washington formally opened bidding for six routes provided for under the accord, which could increase air service between the two nations by 30 percent. Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner called the pact ''the most dramatic expansion of air services to Japan since the original bilateral agreement was signed in 1952.''
But Northwest and United are the least likely of the American carriers to win rights to the new routes. To stimulate competition, the Transportation Department said it is more inclined to award those routes to carriers that currently have less of a Pacific presence.
The two carriers still rely heavily on that traffic. Pacific flights now account for more than half of Northwest's revenues, and for 30 percent of United's. While United's domestic traffic has dropped slightly, its Pacific traffic soared nearly 24 percent over the last year.
United made its big push into the Pacific in 1985 with its $750 million purchase of Pan American World Airways's extensive Pacific routes - one of the largest acquisitions of such a network in the industry and, in retrospect, one of the shrewdest. ''At least initially, there will be enough room for everybody,'' said Raymond Neidl, an analyst with Dillon, Reed. ''But the competition will begin to erode their market share.''
The Pacific routes are rich with business travelers and, until recently, relatively competition-free. In general, long flights are more profitable for airlines than short hops, since they do not require as many employees on the ground. And in the Pacific, airlines need not discount as many seats as they do on European flights.
Indeed, keeping planes filled is hardly a problem. Traffic between North America and Asia is expected to grow at about 10 percent annually for at least the next decade, about twice as fast as the rate within the United States. And cargo traffic there is also on the rise. ''It's the growth market for the 1990's,'' said Kevin Murphy, an analyst with Morgan Stanley.
The Japanese, riding a strong yen, are leading the boom. In 1986, 5.5 million Japanese traveled abroad. In 1989, it was 10 million.
The Koreans and Taiwanese are also traveling more. Last year Korea relaxed age restrictions on travel for its citizens, who previously had to be 50 years or older to travel freely. The threshold age was lowered to 30 in 1987 and the restriction was lifted altogether last year. As a result, the number of Koreans traveling abroad is expected to double this year. Likewise, the number of Taiwanese travelers is expected to double to four million people by the decade's end. ''Suddenly there's a new lode of people who can afford air travel,'' said Michael Hewitt, secretary general of the Orient Airlines Association in Manila.
The one Asian country where the airlines are not deploying more airplanes is mainland China. Since the Tiananmen Square uprising in May, Northwest has cut its flights from Osaka to Shanghai to one a week, from two.
But the surge in travel has clogged the Pacific airways and even caused shortages of hotel rooms in certain cities like Bangkok. Load factors, or the percentage of seats filled, on Pacific routes now average 70 percent or better, compared with 64 percent in the United States. And Asia, as an archipelago, has no land-transportation alternatives linking its countries to offer relief.
 
Clogged Airports
 The International Air Transport Association has flagged airports in Hong Kong, Tokyo, Bombay and Sydney as the region's most congested. ''The capacity of airports is being stretched to the limits,'' said Ken Chamberlain, executive vice president of the Pacific Asia Travel Association. ''Travel is an increasingly difficult experience.''
''Flights for the last year were chock-a-block,'' said Richard Chao, owner of Taiwan Travel, a travel agency in Taipei. ''The public isn't happy with the airline situation here. There isn't much flexibility.''
To relieve congestion, Hong Kong is building a new $5 billion airport to replace Kai Tak International, which, with its single runway surrounded by mountains, is dreaded by pilots and passengers. Meanwhile, Japan is building a new airport near Osaka on a man-made island - well clear of communities that have insisted on an 8:30 P.M. curfew at the current airport.
But the biggest bottleneck in Asia is Tokyo's Narita Airport. With only one runway, it is already operating 40 percent over its capacity of 13 million passengers a year. An attempt to build more runways has run headlong into fierce opposition from local farmers and other landowners.
 
Alternative Gateways
 Given this congestion, airlines are looking for alternatives gateways to the Pacific. Both United and Northwest, for instance, are developing Seoul as a ''mini hub'' for the region.
 And many carriers have placed orders for a new, extra-long-range jumbo jet, the Boeing 747-400, that could enable them to fly nonstop from the United States to Seoul or Bangkok with a full passenger load. United, for one, has 15 747-400's on order, all of which will be deployed on the Pacific routes.
The trouble is, a backlog of orders and an eight-week strike at Boeing has stalled delivery of the jets to many airlines and forced them to delay their expansion plans. Japan Airlines has delayed its expansion until 1991 as it awaits delivery of 15 Boeing jumbo jets, a company spokesman said.
Unlike the American and European air-travel markets, where battles are fought with super-saver fares and bonus mileage, the contest for the Pacific market is being waged with fine china and after-dinner drinks. Asian carriers like Singapore Airlines and Cathay Pacific have a reputation for pampering their passengers to extremes unheard of in the United States. ''There's no way a Western carrier can compete with an Asian one on service,'' said Mr. Starkman, the analyst.
But American carriers are trying. At a cost of $45 million, United is revamping the business-class sections on its 747's and DC-10's, adding wider seats and more flight attendants. On occasion, it also dispatches an employee to fly on a rival's flight to report on the quality of service. ''These are among the best airlines in the world'' said William C. Speicher, senior vice president of Pacific marketing for United. ''Its tough competition. There's no doubt about it.''
Northwest, under its new owner, hotelier Alfred Checchi, is attempting to shift its image as a discount airline. It recently began an advertising campaign in America that reminds potential passengers that telephones are pink in Hong Kong and that one shouldn't slurp noodles in Taiwan. And the airline, which has been flying the Pacific routes for 42 years, now offers such ammenities as concierge service at the airport and in-flight ice cream sundaes. ''We could never do something like this between Minneapolis and Chicago,'' said Robert Gibbons, a company spokesman. ''When you have passengers for 8 to 14 hours, you can pamper them.''
The airlines are emphasizing service on their Asian flights because of the high percentage of business travelers, who generally pay more for their tickets and are most likely to bring repeat business.
For instance, the 747's that Japan Air Line flies between New York and Tokyo are outfitted with 196 first-class and business-class seats and only 60 coach. Pacific flights are popular with business executives in part because some employers prohibit business-class travel across the Atlantic but permit it for the longer transPacific flights.
In assimilating to Asian culture, American airlines have made some blunders. When United began its concierge service in Tokyo, it identified its employees by having them wear white carnations. In Japan, the color symbolizes death and mourning. United switched to red.
And American carriers may not have bargained for such tough competition. Asian carriers bring more than their sparkling service. They bring impressive bankrolls. Japan Airlines, which was privatized in 1987, is investing $6.1 billion in new planes, maintenance facilities and computer reservation equipment. All Nippon Airlines, Japan's largest domestic airline, has begun to fly to Los Angeles and Washington, and is gearing up for a major expansion into the United States.
To compete for American passengers looking to fly to the Far East, Asian carriers are also beginning to match the Americans' most potent marketing tool - frequent-flier programs. For instance, passengers on Philippine airlines can earn a free trip after racking up 30,000 miles - only three round trips to the United States. American carriers require more than double that travel for a free trip.
To woo travel agents, the Asians pay a handsome 26 percent commission on flights to and from the Far East - a move that United and Northwest have followed. Travel agents earn about 10 percent on American business.
Of course, American airlines still have one critical advantage with consumers: their strong domestic feeder systems. Foreign airlines are prohibitted from flying between two American cities.
The coming battle for the Asian and American carriers is for control of the computer reservation systems being developed in the Far East. About two-thirds of the airline tickets sold for transPacific flights are purchased in Asia. But fewer travel agencies use computer reservations systems there than in the United States. The airlines that succeed in linking up with the new systems will go a long way toward determining the long-term survivors. ''The computer systems are up for grabs,'' Mr. Speicher said. ''There aren't real strong alliances in one camp or another.''
For now, thought, attention is focused on the new flights between Tokyo and America, which are scheduled to begin in October. The six new routes could mean 125 more flights a week. Virtually every major American carrier has applied for the right to fly one of the routes. Officials in cities like Houston, Denver, Phoenix and Miami have also aggressively lobbied Washington for airline service from their communities to Asia.
Regardless of who wins the new routes, however, one thing is unlikely to change. In terms of air travel, the United States will continue to have a trade surplus with Japan. ''This is a wonderful aberration in the U.S. and Japan trade picture,'' said Jeffrey Shane the Transportation Department official who was the architect of the recent agreement with Japan.

HEADLINE: Prospects;
Housing Bounces Back

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
Sales of new homes rose by 9.6 percent in November, the biggest jump in four months, according to the Commerce Department last week. The Northeast and Middle West posted the strongest gains. After months of soft prices and slow sales, do the November figures signal an end to the housing slump? Four experts give their views.
 
Ara K. Hovnanian
President, K. Hovnanian Enterprises Inc., Red Bank, N.J.
 There seems to be a little more activity in the housing market because seller prices are coming into line and developers' prices are too. I think we have probably hit bottom. I don't know if we can say the market is on its way up yet, but buyers are beginning to realize there are real deals out there. 
For the first half of this year we expect the current situation to remain without much change. However, we believe that when the market does begin to recover, particularly in the Northeast and California, there will be a steady upward ratcheting of prices. I don't know if the recovery will happen in 6, 2, or 12 months. But once it happens, it will turn rapidly and we will see a real strong market. Real estate is cyclical. When people start selling, they also start buying and then the market accelerates.
 
Lyle E. Gramley
Chief economist, Mortgage Bankers Association, Washington.
 It would be a mistake to make too much out of this number. The November figures are in part a consequence of the earthquake in California. But even so, the picture for new-home sales is improving modestly.
Those stories about an impending collapse of the residential real estate market were overblown. An impending collapse was wrong and that's what this upturn tells us. No one doubts that the housing market is different from what it was a decade ago. Prices are not rising as fast, the demographics are different, rental space was overbuilt and housing is now responding differently to lower interest rates.
If interest rates continue to move down, as I think they will, then there will be further improvement. But the current 710,000 annual rate for new-home sales is higher than can be sustained.
 
David F. Seiders
Chief economist, National Association of Homebuilders, Washington.
 We are looking for a flat period in all of single-family housing through the middle of this year and then a gradual improvement. Those new-home sales figures do jog around a bit. But all of the single housing numbers for November were solid.
The one place where the numbers signal something really fundamental is the Northeast. We have been forecasting a bottoming out in that market and a resurgence in the Northeast in housing starts, new sales and sales of existing homes. We see confirmation now that it has bottomed out and we're looking for a gradual upturn throughout the year and into 1991 in that market.
 
Francis Schott
Chief economist, Equitable Life Assurance Society.
 This upturn in housing has been part of my forecast and it's why I don't think we'll have a recession. A decline in mortgage rates has happened - so you can get a fixed-rate mortgage below 10 percent - and it created the turnaround. Housing starts looked poor before the Fed eased. There was pent-up demand as people adjusted to higher rates and the lower rates now are making a difference.
I am convinced that interest rates will go down further until mid-1990. I think the signs are clear that new home starts will be at the 1.5 million rate, seasonably adjusted, for most of 1990 with a possibility of going even higher. In the fourth quarter of 1989, we had the bottoming out of new-home sales.
The downward adjustment with rising interest rates has ended. The market won't be buoyant, but it will have stability with a little updrift through 1990.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Turn to the Hard Sell

BYLINE: By STUART MIEHER; Stuart Mieher writes about finance from Boston, where he is a student at the Harvard Business School.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Time was when the managers of the Janus Capital mutual fund group paid scant attention to their customers. Cash-flow multiples and moving averages concerned them far more. But faced with persistent redemptions, Janus concluded in 1987 that performance alone wasn't enough. The marketing specialists came in, the advertising budget went up, and in 1989 the company's accounts doubled.
In the vicious competition for investor dollars, managers of the nation's 350-odd mutual fund companies are learning to be salesman. The companies are designing funds for every taste and installing banks of telephones and computers to improve customer service. Many are spending lavishly on advertising. ''In this commodity environment, it becomes important to let people do business the way they want, not the way you want,'' said Michael J. Hines, vice president of marketing at Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest fund operator.
Hype is nothing new to an industry that is the intermediary between Wall Street and 20 million United States households. An industry catch phrase holds that funds are sold, not bought. But increasingly, fund companies are adopting strategies much like those of packaged-goods marketers. The weapons in this new struggle are market research and product positioning instead of hot trading strategies. Investors should benefit from better service, lower costs and a smorgasbord of new funds. Large fund companies stand to gain if smaller competitors can't make the investments required. 
But some attack the increased emphasis on marketing. ''This is gimmickry,'' said Tyler Jenks, research director at the Boston brokerage of Kanon Bloch Carre & Company. Mr. Jenks worries that investors are increasingly selecting funds based on marketing flair and the cheerfulness of telephone clerks rather than on safety and long-term returns. Increasing volatility in financial markets and these ''revved-up marketing teams,'' he said, are ''setting the industry and investors up for a big fall.''
The march toward marketing is not universal; some companies would rather minimize operating costs. And improving mutual fund sales amid a reviving stock market may postpone the need for change.
Yet strategies driven by marketing are taking root in unlikely places. Consider Janus Capital, a small Denver-based fund group with $1.7 billion in assets. When it was founded in 1969, Janus was dominated by numbers specialists. ''The firm had a philosophy,'' said Jack Thompson, executive vice president, ''that all you needed to sell fund shares was a set of good performance numbers.''
But service problems and redemptions caught up with Janus, so that by 1987 the company began an overhaul. It added experts in public relations. It beefed up service by firing the outside firm that handled its back-office needs and bringing these functions in-house. It started programs for small investors and began to advertise consistently.
Even the financial pros became marketers. Last Oct. 13, when the Dow plunged 191 points, James Craig, manager of two of Janus's four fund portfolios, took to the phone to calm investors' fears. Helped by top performance ratings for several of its funds, sales of fund shares, net of redemptions, totaled about $360 million last year, up from a deficit of $60 million in 1988.
Few companies felt they needed nimble marketing during the bull market of the mid-1980's. Assets under management grew an average of 25 percent annually, from $241 billion at the beginning of 1982 to $848 billion at the market's peak in August of 1987.
Sales net of redemptions hit a torrid $190 billion in 1986. Virtually all the growth occurred in stocks and long-term bond funds, whose fees average two to three times those of the money market funds.
The boom ended with the stock market's collapse in October 1987. Since then, the industry's assets have grown at a mere 13 percent annually, and net sales slowed to $7 billion in 1988. Stock and bond funds have grown even more slowly. Through the first 11 months of 1989, the industry's sales recovered to $119 billion, but 77 percent went into money market accounts.
The boom may yet revive. Buoyed by a healthy stock market, sales of stock and bond funds in November reached $5.1 billion, a post-crash record, though still below the levels of 1987. But fund operators have discovered they can't rely too much on performance to draw investors.
''The traditional method of selling product has been to say, 'We can provide higher returns than the next guy,' '' said Louis Harvey, president of Dalbar Financial Services, a Boston research company. ''But no one is on top all the time.'' Fidelity has been the industry's marketing pioneer since the early 1970's. It advertises with abandon. For money market accounts, it was the first to let people write checks. Fidelity added innovations like automated telephone ordering, round-the-clock phone service and investor centers, 55 retail outlets that each combine the solid look of a bank branch with the theatricality of a trading floor.
On big days for the market, people would stare at the electronic ticker in the front window of the Investor Center near Fidelity's downtown Boston headquarters, clustering so thickly that they spilled onto the street. Interest in the ticker has waned, but Fidelity has prospered. Its assets now stand at $110 billion, up from $85 billion before the 1987 crash.
These days, more fund groups act like Fidelity. A recent survey found that mutual funds spent 50 percent more on advertising in the first six months of 1989 than in the comparable period in 1988 - but less than in 1987, when higher sales could finance heavier advertising.
The Dreyfus Service Corporation this year increased advertising by $15 million, to $40 million. Many of the ads say little about performance but focus instead on investor needs, like saving for the children's college education.
Fund companies are also offering scores of new products, including many that some critics say the public could do without. The industry began 1989 with 2,718 funds, and added another 280 by the end of November. ''Two out of three of the funds that are out there shouldn't be,'' said Mr. Jenks of Kanon Bloch.
Some companies are following the lead of packaged-goods marketers by building products around types of investors - like those receiving lump-sum distributions from pension plans - rather than types of investments. Many fund marketers scoff at such tactics. ''If you roll out a fund for every group, it reaches a point where it's just too cumbersome and expensive,'' said Fidelity's Mr. Hines. Yet Fidelity itself has 144 funds. Even tiny Janus is adding two funds.
The goal: Keep investors within the family of funds. As Mr. Hines said: ''Investors want to simplify who they do business with. If you're a large company, you're more likely to have the fund the investor's interested in.'' Fidelity now is taking the approach a step further, selling other companies' funds and including them on monthly statements.
Not all marketing moves are so sophisticated. Fidelity and Dreyfus have resorted to old-fashioned price cutting, like a couple of corner gasoline stations. Last year, both opened money-market funds with reduced management fees and therefore higher yields. Fidelity's Spartan Fund brought in $5.4 billion in assets by December, while Dreyfus's Worldwide Dollar Fund had $4.3 billion.
Both companies figure most of the cash will stay within the family even after fees go up. It is an expensive bet: Thomas Ackerman, an analyst at Advest Inc., said absorbing the fees on Worldwide Dollar is draining Dreyfus's earnings at an annual rate of 75 cents a share.
Companies are also competing in service. American Capital Management and Research Inc. of Houston saw its sales lag in the mid-1980's amid a snarl of back-office problems. Don McMullen, a veteran of Pittsburgh's Mellon Bank, was hired in November 1987 to revamp marketing and service. ''I run both marketing and service because, when it's all said and done, the quality of your service has a lot to say in how well your product sells,'' Mr. McMullen said. The improvements - new training for telephone clerks, an automated telephone order system and computer equipment for clerks to call up customers' records quickly - cost about $1 million for equipment alone.
Nor has Fidelity been sitting still. It spent the last two years increasing telephone capacity and improving its automated services. During last October's market slide, customers seldom got the busy signal, and redemptions ran at less than a third the level of the 1987 crash. Last fall Fidelity announced plans to offer customers a package to handle mutual fund transactions over Nintendo video game systems.
Such investments in marketing have increased the benefits of bigness. Advertising, sophisticated back-office systems and expanding fund families all offer significant economies of scale. Price cutting as practiced by Dreyfus and Fidelity requires big cash reserves. Finally, a downturn in the stock and bond markets could crimp sales of mutual funds and push less-efficient companies into the red.
A logical result would be consolidation. But the market's recovery since 1987 has helped keep most fund operators profitable and independent. And many, including Fidelity, remain private.
A few mergers, like the Transamerica Corporation's purchase of the Criterion Group for $95 million, have been offset by spinoffs, like the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's sale of its Federated Investors unit to its managers for $345 million.
According to Strategic Insight, a mutual fund research and consulting company, the top 10 companies in 1989 held 48.6 percent of the industry's assets, just a tenth of a point above their share four years earlier.
Even so, today's new marketing environment ''could pose problems down the road for small operators,'' as Mr. Thompson put it.
Janus already has a parent with deep pockets. In 1984, its founders sold 80 percent of the firm to Kansas City Southern Industries Inc., a railroad holding company. Those deep pockets may come in handy. Mr. Thompson said, ''A company our size can't do everything Fidelity does, but we've had to stay in the same ball park.''

LENGTH: 3598 words

HEADLINE: To the Brink and Back in Real Estate

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

DATELINE: IRVING, Tex.

 BODY:
Back in the late 1960's, most people saw nothing more than cattle and horses rambling over the rolling prairie northwest of Dallas. Ben Carpenter saw the community of the future. So, in 1969, he set about building it.
He envisioned transforming his cattle ranch into one of the most coveted planned developments in the country, a place that oozed quality with granite curbs and harmonious architecture set amid pristine landscape. In the downtown, he imagined an elevated people mover and a canal system with mahogany water taxis plowing through the currents.
Before too long, office buildings and houses began sprouting up. People moved in, some of them into breathtaking homes costing $3 million. The water taxis came. Organizations like the Boy Scouts of America relocated their national headquarters there and others like Allstate Insurance, Caltex, Southwestern Bell, Neiman-Marcus and two dozen Japanese companies took space. Sure enough, Las Colinas, as the development was called, became just about the hottest corporate relocation destination in the country. The place was nifty enough that TV's ''Dallas'' even liked to shoot some of its footage there. 
Then the sun went away. The crash of the Dallas real estate market in 1986 caught Las Colinas suffocating in debt. As late as the middle of last year, it looked as if Ben Carpenter's dream, less than half finished, was ready to implode. In many respects, the tribulations of Las Colinas were all too symptomatic of the haywire, borrow-and-build-anything real estate market of the Southwest.
But Las Colinas got lucky. Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, a big insurer in New York, and JMB Realty, a Chicago-based real estate operation, rode in to restructure much of the debt. Just in the last year, the GTE Corporation agreed to put the headquarters for its regional phone companies in Las Colinas. And in late October, in the biggest boost yet, the Exxon Corporation consented to buy 132 acres of land crowded with mesquite trees where it will move its corporate headquarters from New York City.
The comeback of Las Colinas is a tribute to the continuing appeal of Mr. Carpenter's dream. In a larger sense, the revival perhaps signifies a turning point in the protracted Texas slump. But the rise and fall and rise again of Las Colinas is also a story - albeit a vastly more complex one than most - of what it takes to rescue a foundering project once the buyers of land go away and the creditors are pounding on the door.
When he was young, life was pretty sugary for Ben Carpenter. His family, involved in the cattle business since 1877, was prospering in ranching, insurance and real estate. Back in 1928, Ben Carpenter's father acquired about 200 acres in Irving in the middle of what is now Las Colinas and named it Hackberry Creek Ranch, and this became the family home. He was then an executive of the Texas Power and Light Company and later became chairman of the Southland Life Insurance Company.
When his father died in 1959, Ben Carpenter followed him as Southland's chairman. The younger Carpenter, along with his brother-in-law, Dan Williams, began adding acreage to the Hackberry ranch. At the same time, Mr. Carpenter was dabbling in real estate development through a family business eventually known as the Southland Financial Company (unrelated to the Southland Corporation that runs the 7-11 stores). In time, it would merge with the insurance company and go public in 1971.
By the late 1960's, land values and taxes had risen so sharply that the ranch was struggling to meet the higher assessments. But then opportunity came knocking in the loudest possible way. It was announced that property was being assembled within a few miles of the ranch for a huge new airport, the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, which would open in 1973. With streams of planes setting down just miles away, the ranchland would be ideal for both commercial and residential development.
''I couldn't afford to keep running it as a cattle ranch,'' said Mr. Carpenter, a slight, chipper man with a homespun demeanor. ''I had to either sell it or develop it. When I thought about it, I realized, here was an opportunity from scratch to plan the best possible use of a piece of property on a large scale. Very few opportunities like this arise. Why let it go?''
 
Enter the Raiders
 So, as simple as that, Ben Carpenter decided to get the bulldozers going. As Las Colinas (which means ''the hills'') began taking shape, however, the development's parent company started to attract some rather unwelcome interest.
In the mid-1970's, for example, Saul Steinberg, the flamboyant financier, bought a stake of close to 5 percent in Southland, and after some give and take, the company bought the stock back at a profit for Mr. Steinberg. Fretting more and more about possible raiders, Mr. Carpenter eventually attempted to take the company private in late 1984.
However, Ivan Boesky - the notorious arbitrager jailed for securities violations unrelated to Southland - began snapping up Southland stock. Craig Hall, a Dallas real estate investor, got his wallet out, too. The purchases shoved the price up so much that Mr. Carpenter scrapped his plan. Southland wound up buying back the stake Mr. Hall acquired (Mr. Boesky clung to his) to solidify the Carpenter family's control.
Meanwhile, the company was spending pretty heavily. It bought 1,280 acres of land to add to Las Colinas in 1985 and 1986 at peak prices, thus tacking on $210 million of debt.
It was hard not to spend. Bankers and investors were throwing money at developers as if it stung if they held it themselves. Don't worry, the investors would more or less say. Pay it back when you can.
Two major ''junk bond'' financings, handled by Michael Milken's famous junk bond department at Drexel Burnham, were issued in 1985 and 1986 to pay for the land and to gain working capital. One was a private offering of $150 million, in which the two largest investors were the now troubled Southmark Corporation, a real estate and financial services concern, and the First Executive Corporation, an insurance company. The other was a public debt issue of $200 million, in which the Kemper Investors Life Insurance Company had a sizable stake.
Heavy debt - who was to worry? Though there were some signs that the Dallas economy was beginning to sputter, land sales at Las Colinas remained strong, growing to a peak of $127 million in 1984 and finishing at a healthy $96 million in 1985.
 
The Bottom Falls Out
 But once 1986 rolled around, it was obvious that Dallas was in pitiful shape. The office vacancy rate shot up to more than 30 percent, and some entire buildings were occupied only by insects and mice. Substantial financing, of course, had come from savings and loan institutions, which emerged as major players in commercial lending in 1984 and 1985, though no significant savings-and-loan financings were done at Las Colinas.
With scads of space around, prices tumbled. The raw land market almost stopped dead. For Las Colinas, land sales in 1986 collapsed to just $22.4 million. (They would be $39 million in 1987 and $29 million in 1988.) Southland had upward of $500 million in debt strapped to raw land, most of it short term. At this point, Southland had sold off its insurance unit, and was dependent on the dwindling land sales for most of its cash flow.
By late 1986, Ben Carpenter's health began to falter (he had had seven heart-bypass operations by then), and he stepped down to allow his son, John, to take over as chief executive. Wishing to put his affairs in order, Ben Carpenter tried to sell the company, 40 percent of which was owned by the Carpenter family. But there were no takers.
A suffocating depression hung over the company. The debt was like a time bomb. ''This was the point when Texas was getting the spigot turned off on it,'' said John Carpenter. ''Nobody wanted to touch Texas.''
The Carpenters decided to speak to Teachers. It made some sense. After all, Teachers had financed several Las Colinas properties and knew the land; besides, Teachers had been conservative in its investments at a time when others were out on limbs hanging by their teeth. It hadn't been battered and bruised by the Southwest, but was sniffing around for big opportunities.
Thus, in the summer of 1987, the Carpenters approached Teachers with one question on their minds: Was there something Teachers could do?
Sympathetic as it was, the insurance company was dubious. This was an atypical request for Teachers. For one thing, to go around and ask lenders to accept less favorable refinancing was not something it felt comfortable doing. After all, its role in life was to be a lender. Alice Connell, a mortgage officer at Teachers, summed up the company's feeling by telling the Carpenters: ''We don't know if we could get out of the blocks on this one.''
Returning to Texas, Southland managed to conclude a deal in the fall of 1987 with the Lincoln Property Company, a national development organization. Lincoln agreed to supply Southland with $50 million and try to restructure its debt in return for a 20 percent stake in Las Colinas. But the existing creditors hated the deal, and it soon collapsed.
 
A Second Chance
The Carpenters cultivated others, including a few Japanese investors. Interest was dim. Finally, at the urging of Peter Gevalt, the managing director of Wells Hill Partners, a New York investment banker and broker that was trying to help the Carpenters solve their problems, they called Teachers once again. At this juncture, with Southland in flames, Teachers seemed the only alternative to bankruptcy.
In December 1987, a luncheon meeting between the Carpenters and some Teachers executives was held near Teachers' Manhattan headquarters. This time the importunings of the Carpenters worked.
At length, Teachers said it would attempt a restructuring under which the shareholders and many of the creditors would in effect be bought out and Southland would be replaced by a partnership. It was reckoned that Teachers would need to chip in something on the order of $250 million. It would then be in partnership with the Carpenters. But it wanted a third party involved, especially since Teachers knew nothing about buying up junk debt, and recruited JMB Realty, which knew a lot about junk debt and was one of the largest players in the real estate business. H. Patrick Hackett, JMB's senior vice president, became its representative in the deal.
In the early part of 1988, agreement was reached among the partners, under which the Carpenters would own 60 percent of what had been Southland, Teachers would have 22 percent and JMB would hold 18 percent. Policy would be set by a small executive committee: John and Ben Carpenter, Ms. Connell and Mr. Hackett, who got two votes.
Stockholders, whose shares tumbled as low as 50 cents from nearly $40, would ultimately get $2 a share (except for the Carpenters, who got notes that became part of the partnership's capital). The whole transaction was referred to by the partners as something highly unusual, a management-led leveraged buyout of a virtually bankrupt company.
For it to succeed, a horde of creditors had to accept less money than they had contracted to get. The partnership wanted to pay on the order of 50 cents to nearly 90 cents on the dollar, depending on the particular debt, and to get there it figured it would have to do a lot of horse trading. There were a half-dozen creditor groups for the raw land and more than 30 for income-producing properties.
When Alice Connell outlined the proposal to the board of Teachers, she mentioned that her best guess on the likelihood of the deal succeeding was 20 percent. Pat Hackett was more optimistic; he gave it a 25 percent shot.
 
The Moment of Truth
 Imagine the scene. Galloping in as the white knight was not some vulture fund but one of the most conservative of real estate lenders. Pitted against it was a motley group that included some extremely cantankerous creditors. As Ms. Connell once put it: ''This was the sort of situation where everything was fine as long as the music played. If the record skipped, however, you saw the dark side of securitized real estate. You got to see people who didn't know if it was Irving or Irvine or Norman, Texas. You were not talking with people who knew the business.''
On June 28, 1988, at the Sheraton Hotel in downtown Dallas, a so-called tent meeting was held with all the creditors to announce the plans. Some of the creditors were extremely irritated; their blood pressure was not helped by the fact that many hadn't got a single interest payment in more than a year.
Nevertheless, Teachers and the Carpenters figured the creditor talks just might pay off after a few months at the most. After all, there were some promising signs. For instance, Pat Hackett discovered that the chief negotiator for the Royal Bank of Canada, one of the creditors for the land, was his best friend from high school.
But once the talks started in earnest, the hard truth sank in. They might take an eternity. For instance, Pat Hackett's best friend proved to be a crafty bargainer.
''We thought because of the desperate shape of the Dallas real estate market, the creditors would welcome Teachers,'' Ms. Connell said. ''Nothing could have been further from the truth. I mean, some of the creditors had honed the act of brinkmanship to a fine art.''
A regular and rather irritating backdrop to the negotiations was the periodic posting of foreclosure notices by one or another of the creditors. The first arrived in November 1988. In Texas, foreclosure notices must be posted on the first Tuesday of a month; every time the first Tuesday approached, the members of the partnership began to get a sick feeling in their stomach.
Some talks proceeded with pleasing enough civility, but in meetings with the more obstreperous creditors, tempers ran short. ''I can't convey the embattled nature of these discussions,'' Ms. Connell would say later. ''It was night and day and 100 crises.''
The creditors holding the $150 million in notes from the private placement turned out to be perhaps the most worrisome group. This group, which came to be known as the 150's, was vital to the restructuring, since it held delectable collateral: 700 acres of prime land. The group posted a foreclosure notice early in the going, and in the ensuing months frequently renewed its intention to foreclose. Although the partnership and the 150's came to basic terms fairly early in the going, the deal had a time limit to it, and when other creditor negotiations failed to be completed by the deadline, a whole new round of bargaining was triggered.
''I think the deal we settled on we could have had a year and a half earlier,'' said Keenan Woolens, who did some of the negotiating for the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, one of the investors in the notes. ''A lot of creditors had hard heads and it took a while for them to realize this was the best we could do.''
During one tempestuous session, when the two sides were $10 million apart, a creditor representative outlined a plan under which, among other things, Wells Hill would forgo some money, Teachers would put up a bit more, the Carpenters would sacrifice a little equity and, voila, the creditors would get an extra $10 million. After listening to the proposal with her temperature rising beyond measurement, Alice Connell announced, ''If I found $10 million lying on the street, I wouldn't push it across to you.''
It was O.K. to get miffed, but the Carpenters felt they could not let the group carry out the foreclosure. If it seemed they were seriously going to, Southland aimed to file for bankruptcy first, thus forestalling the creditors from taking possession of the land.
On several occasions, the courthouse steps in Dallas became roosting places for Southland lawyers and lawyers from the 150 group. Hugging walkie-talkies or cellular car phones, they were poised to sprint to their respective filing places as soon as they heard word of an irreparable breakdown in the talks. The whole matter, at these moments, seemed to boil down to which side had the fleetest short-distance runners.
In any event, by May 1989 Teachers had agreed to invest $290 million in the deal. Then, as Ms. Connell put it, ''We took our hands out of our pockets and said no more.''
But still more was wanted. And on the first Monday evening of May, hours before foreclosure day, the 150's seemed like they had had it. As Rob Goodman, head of a consulting group called the Goodtab Corporation, who did much of the bargaining for First Executive, remembered, ''We were literally within 15 minutes of foreclosing.''
A call went to Rob Goodman's home late that evening from Alice Connell. Things looked dismal. At about 6 the next morning Peter Gevalt from Wells Hill called Mr. Goodman, trying to stave off the foreclosure action. After some haggling, matters looked brighter and a conference call was commenced, with people connected from cities all across the country. There were so many people plugged into the call that quite a burble of voices built up. Some callers would drop off for a while and then patch back in. The call continued for upward of six hours.
At one point, when the creditors presumably lost track of the Carpenter people and thought they were off the line, one of the creditors, figuring things were hopeless, began preparing one of the others for a race to the courthouse. ''Now you better get in your car and be ready to go to the courthouse,'' he told the man. ''You haven't had any drinks at lunch today, have you?''
The discussion then centered on the restless 150's wanting some penalty imposed if the deal failed to close by a specific date. Wells Hill ultimately agreed to pay $41,800 a day every day after June 1 that the deal didn't close (the bulk of which would be reimbursed by Southland employees). ''We gulped when we signed that,'' Mr. Gevalt said. With that resolved, and with 15 minutes to go before the foreclosure window closed, the parties came to terms.
After several more crises, like the First National Bank of Boston foreclosing on a Las Colinas shopping center, and after nearly a month of payments to the 150's being racked up, the deal that looked like it would never get done in fact closed on June 29. There was relief, exaltation, exhaustion. ''By the end, everyone had left some blood on the table,'' said Mr. Gevalt.
 
Back in the Saddle
 On a breezy, sun-drenched afternoon, people stream in and out of the elevated people mover, getting to their jobs in the downtown towers of Las Colinas. Some tourists are shelling out the $1 to take a water taxi. A few cars trumpet their horns. Foursomes are already clambering into their golf carts to attack the course at the Four Seasons resort.
Las Colinas has certainly reached palmier times. When Exxon looked all over the country for a fit spot to plant its headquarters and settled on Las Colinas, that act alone boosted everyone's spirits to heights not known in years.
Still, much remains to happen. In terms of land to be sold and buildings to be erected, the game is still less than half over. The hope in Dallas is that the bottom of the real estate market has been reached. For its part, the Las Colinas partnership thinks it can do $45 million in land sales this year. Whatever happens, the partnership is content to wait patiently. ''It's no get-rich-quick scheme,'' said Ms. Connell. ''It's a 25-year project. We want to develop the place in an orderly fashion.''
Up in his office, Ben Carpenter leaned back in the soft leather sofa. The coffee table in front of the sofa seemed big enough to land a plane on. ''I see no reason why it won't develop just as I thought way back when,'' he said. ''It's just been a little wilder and it will take a little longer. Sometimes, that's the way it goes.''
 
LATE-NIGHT PHONE CALLS
During the arduous skirmishing to restructure the pile of Las Colinas debt, the various sides in the bargaining lived a life of unending pressure in which they learned to employ quite a bag of tricks.
''We always thought we had only another week before everything would go up in smoke,'' said Alice Connell of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, a partner in the restructuring. ''You checked yourself at the beginning of each week to see if you had any lethal bullet wounds,'' she added. ''If you didn't, you went on for another week.''
Some creditor representatives got so annoyed by stalled progress that they refused to come to meetings or accept phone calls from members of the partnership.
The partnership thus resorted to alternative tactics. Once, Pat Hackett of JMB Realty waited, eyes fixated on asphalt, in a representative's driveway for several hours on a Saturday afternoon until the man drove up. It was talk or go back to the mall.
A number of times, phone calls were placed to bargainers' homes at hours when odds were extremely favorable that they were there: for instance, somewhere between 2 and 5 in the morning.
''I wouldn't say they were pleased to hear from us,'' said Mr. Hackett. ''But, you know, it was a good way to get to talk.'' Throughout the months of negotiations, no one was ever off duty. Ms. Connell, for example, did one bargaining session from a phone in Disney World, while her impatient son whimpered.
''I also got faxed while on vacation on the QE2,'' she said.

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1880 words

HEADLINE: Bad Times, Bold Plans for Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
Fernando Collor de Mello, Brazil's 40-year-old President-elect, has some ambitious plans for his troubled nation.
The need for them is plain, for as Finance Minister Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega has pointed out, the 1980's were ''a lost decade'' for Latin America's largest nation. ''Per capita income stagnated, inflation beat all records, investment declined, public finances went into virtual collapse, and the foreign debt crisis prematurely transformed Brazil into an exporter of capital,'' he wrote recently in a remarkably blunt assessment in the Jornal do Brasil.
Determined to mend things, Mr. Collor has put together a somewhat Thatcheresque package of goals and means that includes:
* Cutting Brazil's inflation rate, which ran at a record 1,765 percent in 1989, by catching tax cheats, cutting the number of ministries in half and selling money-losing state companies.
* Reducing the burden of Brazil's $110 billion foreign debt, the largest in the third world, by encouraging foreign creditors to swap their debt titles for shares in Brazilian companies and to renegotiate debt so that service payments are capped at $5 billion a year. 
* Restoring growth after a decade of stagnation, by encouraging foreign investment, lowering trade barriers and promoting greater integration with the developed world. To this end, he is to travel to the United States, Europe and Japan before starting his five-year term on March 15.
Even the foreseeable obstacles to this grand plan for the 1990's, however, are formidable.
On the political side, implementation of most of Mr. Collor's changes depend on approval from a powerful Congress. Mr. Collor does not control that Congress now and further problems for him could develop in October, when congressional elections will take place, at a time when the country may be in what Mr. Collor expects to be ''a small recession.''
In the 1980's, Brazil was overtaken by the Pacific rim nations as the third world's hot growth area. Now, the fear here is that Eastern Europe will draw away foreign capital. ''Eastern Europe is the new competitor of Latin America,'' read a recent newspaper headline here.
Running against the trends of the last 30 years of Brazilian economic thinking, Mr. Collor has proposed foreign investment in such traditionally state-dominated areas as road building and energy generation.
But Mr. Collor and his colleagues realize that to attract foreign capital they must also improve Brazil's economic environment to reverse the outflow of Brazilian flight capital - $1 billion a month last year, according to the American Embassy.
The Dec. 17 presidential election, which Mr. Collor won 53 percent to 47 percent, left him facing a strengthened, radicalized left.
''Now the working class will have the opportunity to watch him kissing the hands of the businessmen, kissing the hands of the military, kissing the hands of the International Monetary Fund,'' said Luis Inacio da Silva, Mr. Collor's left-wing adversary, at a postelection news conference.
Indeed, despite the national self-examination that took place during the six-month presidential campaign, it is unclear whether Mr. Collor has a popular mandate for his free-market program.
Losing most of the major cities, Mr. Collor won on the shoulders of Brazil's poorest, least educated and mostly rural voters. During the campaign, Mr. Collor, who speaks five languages, reportedly joked that his voters thought ''risk capital'' referred to crime in Brasilia and that ''tax incentives'' referred to bribes paid to tax collectors.
Today, the President-elect's strategy for winning support appears to be to let Brazil's present government flounder into what economists call hyperinflation, a rate of 50 percent or more a month. The December rate was 53 percent, and estimates for January are for 70 percent.
Mr. Collor has ruled out ''co-governing'' with Brazil's outgoing president, Jose Sarney, and has barred his economic advisers from meeting with Mr. Sarney's. His own travels will keep him mostly out of the country into February.
''Collor's no dope - he wants the bomb to explode in Sarney's hands,'' said one Brazilian businessman.
Some Brazilians believe that a plunge into severe hyperinflation might scare Brazil's Congress into supporting Mr. Collor's program - much the way inflation and sackings of food stores in Argentina last June gave that nation's President-elect, Carlos Menem, bipartisan congressional support for economic reform.
But, as Roberto Campos, a Brazilian Senator and conservative economist, said in an interview, ''Argentina went through a disaster. Brazil has only gone into a half-disaster.'' Indeed, Brazil may prove resistant to hyperinflation's effects. Sheer size tends to keep the economy rolling, and there's a lot more size than immediately meets the eye. Economists say as much as 40 percent of the country's economic activity goes unrecorded, mostly because of tax evasion. And, of course, people do adjust to dealing with explosive numbers.
There is also a system of monthly adjustments of wages, rents and savings rates that helps offset price explosion. Known as indexation, the system kept Brazil's economy functioning during the 1980's, when prices increased by 39,043,765 percent. (Folha de Sao Paulo, the newspaper that calculated that mind-stretching inflation rate, compared it to 85 percent in the United States.) ''Hyperinflation is not a monthly inflation rate - it is a state of disorganization,'' Finance Minister Nobrega argued last month. ''In hyperinflation, people lose faith in contracts and in institutions and there are shortages.'' Considerable disorganization is indeed apparent. Contracts are rarely made in cruzados, the local currency, but rather in dollars or in terms of a national treasury bond that serves as a unit of measure, corrected for inflation.
In shops, where there are daily recalculations, pricing in cruzados (which have replaced cruzeiras) is breaking down. Last week, a new Chevette cost the same as 42 silk brassieres. The same bottle of wine cost 50 cruzados at one supermarket and 17 cruzados at another.
In the rush to convert shrinking cruzados into solid goods, Brazilians seem to ignore such anomalies. Last month, for example, the Paes Mendonca supermarket chain opened a store here with 121 checkout counters - 17,000 shoppers crowd in daily.
Most of Rio's restaurants and hotels stopped accepting credit cards last month because a 20-day billing period eroded the value of payments. Many factories have shortened the payment time of stores to 10 days from 20, and many employers are moving from a monthly payment system to a weekly system.
In the absence of political support from Mr. Collor, the outgoing government is following three policies that Brazilian economists say will prove to be costly to the new government. Public utility rates are being kept low, exacerbating deficits of state utility companies. An artificially high official exchange rate is depressing exports. And high interest rates are swelling the internal debt.
To tame inflation, Mr. Collor, a former karate champion, plans to raise government receipts by initiating ''catch thief'' - a program to enforce Brazil's widely ignored tax code. On the expenditure side, he has said he wants to raise $18 billion by selling state companies and to save billions more by dramatically slashing subsidies and bureaucracy.
''Our economic program is based on the fact that the state cannot remain with the power of interference that it has today in the Brazilian economy,'' Mr. Collor said recently in a nationally-televised news conference. ''The state is inefficient, the state is corrupt, the state is incompetent and the state is gigantic.''
But many subsidy systems - such as the duty-free industrial zone of Manaus - are guaranteed by the Constitution. Mr. Collor may cut the number of ministries to 12 from 23, but many federal employees have virtually lifetime employment. ''The Brazilian political class is basically state-ist, it believes that the state is the solution of all problems,'' Finance Minister Nobrega said recently.
An early reaction - one that may become typical - came last week to Mr. Collor's proposal to abolish the National Information Service, Brazil's foreign and domestic security agency. ''If he wants to abolish the service, let him send a bill to Congress,'' said Gen. Ivan Mendes, head of the service.
To restore growth, Mr. Collor plans to limit annual debt service payments to $5 billion - about half the 1988 level. Last July, Brazil stopped servicing its commercial debt, and the President-elect will inherit arrears of about $5 billion. Brazil's reserves are currently $7.2 billion, and the trade surplus for 1989 was about $16 billion - down from $19 billion in 1988, but still third largest in the world after Japan and West Germany.
No foreign banker interviewed here predicted that Brazil will pay significant amounts on its debt in 1990. Over the last six months, the value on the secondary market of a dollar of Brazilian debt has dropped to about 23 cents, from 34 cents.
During the campaign, candidates concentrated nationalist ire on the foreign debt. ''International bankers have Collor by the tail,'' said literature from the leftist Mr. da Silva, ''and he is going to continue paying the foreign debt.'' Among the pieces of legislation working their way through Congress are bills that would reject floating interest rates, put a 6 percent ceiling on rates and remove debt talks from the ''hostile environment'' of New York City.
In the campaign, Mr. Collor proposed withdrawing central bank guarantees covering about 80 percent of Brazil's $60 billion commercial debt. Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the President-elect's principal economic adviser, argues that this would free debtors to engage in individual renegotiations. But the representative of one large American bank here objected: ''They can't unilaterally withdraw the guarantee. It's written in almost all the loan contracts.''
To exert pressure, some banks have started cutting back on short-term credit for Brazil, virtually the only kind of commercial credit still available. In a more conventional debt-cutting approach, Mr. Collor is expected to seek relief under a plan put forward recently by the United States and to accelerate debt-for-equity swaps. Highly popular with creditors, the swaps cut Brazil's debt by about $9 billion until they were suspended in 1988 on the ground that they were ''inflationary.'' Surviving in a limited form, the swaps cut another $4 billion off the debt in 1989.
The debt swaps are to be part of a campaign to make Brazil, Latin America's largest market, attractive once again for foreign investment.
''We have to do away with this inferiority complex, especially strong in the Brazilian left, that the presence of foreign investment in the economy means the presence of the colonizer oppressing the colonized,'' Mr. Collor said in a campaign interview. ''I want Brazil to be once again a land of opportunity, above all for the younger generation. In the last two years, 200,000 young people abandoned the country. They didn't leave for travel, tourism or education - they literally gave up on Brazil.''

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
A Giant Sale By Uncle Sam

BYLINE: By STEVE DODSON

 BODY:
The biggest real estate sale in American history is under way as the Federal Government acts on Administration orders to move quickly to dispose of properties taken over from failed savings and loan institutions. Last week the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency handling the dispositions, listed about 30,000 properties it had acquired since Sept. 30. The list includes mansions, small houses, office buildings, hotels, shopping centers and tracts of land. The agency was swamped with calls from bargain hunters, but officials said the Government was determined to get at least 95 percent of the appraised value. Some experts were expressing concern that the assets, many of them in the Southwest, would be ''dumped'' in real estate markets that are already depressed. The supply of such properties will grow; only 318 of a projected 500 institutions have been taken over, and many analysts say the projection is low. 
 
*
 New-home sales jumped 9.6 percent in November, their steepest gain in four months. The October data were revised to show a gain of nine-tenths of a percent, rather than the decline of five-tenths originally reported. Another sign of strength came from factory orders: they rose 2.4 percent in November to their second-highest level ever. Construction spending was up 1.5 percent in November, reaching its highest level since January 1989. The first data for December showed the unemployment rate was unchanged at 5.3 percent. But only 142,000 jobs were created last month, and that figure reflected the return to work of 55,000 striking telephone workers. For the year, 1.7 million jobs were created, down from 2.3 million in 1988.
 
*
 Retailers got what they expected from the Christmas season, a moderate gain in sales. Much of the buying came late, and merchants had to offer deep discounts and advertise heavily. Sears, Roebuck said its sales were up 3.5 percent. Gains at other chains were generally from about 8 to about 15 percent. Toys ''R'' Us posted a 22.7 percent gain in the eight-week Christmas season.
Car sales remained depressed late last month, with domestic manufacturers showing a decline of 20.2 percent from the period in 1988. But light-trucks, including mini-vans, registered gains. For the year, sales totaled 14.6 million vehicles, the fifth- largest ever but a decline from 15.8 million in 1988. Last year also saw an industry first: a Japanese model, the Honda Accord, became the best seller in the American market. Honda sold 363,707 Accords, many of them made at a plant in Ohio. Ford Taurus was second, with sales of 348,061.
 
*
 Stocks had a rousing start to 1990, with the Dow Jones industrial average soaring 56.95 on Tuesday, the year's first trading day. That put the Dow at a record 2,810.15, its first close above 2,800. But prices backed off after that, and the Dow ended the week up only 20.05 points, at 2,773.25. Bond prices were lower as traders concluded that the economy was not so weak as once thought and the inflation-wary Federal Reserve might not be willing to lower rates. A possible inflation worry came from oil prices, which went to four-year highs, with West Texas Intermediate reaching $23.68. But there were widespread predictions that prices would ease, and OPEC production was said to be running about three million barrels a day above the quota of 20.5 million. The dollar was volatile, up strongly against the yen but then down after central banks intervened.
 
*
 Eastern Airlines lowered fares as much as 45 percent below the industry's deepest discounts in an effort to regain passengers after its strike and bankruptcy turmoil. Some other carriers matched the move on competing routes, but there was a general trend to raise fares by 4 to 5 percent to cover recent spurts in fuel costs.
 
*
 Robert Campeau gave up a 20 percent holding in his company when he handed $100 million worth of its stock to a Canadian bank after defaulting on a loan to two of his private investment companies. The move reduces his holding in the Campeau Corporation to less than 50 percent. But Mr. Campeau did get a two-week reprieve from other banks on their threat to declare a default on $2.34 billion of loans. Those loans were to the company's Allied and Federated department store units. The prize of that retail collection, the 17-store Bloomingdale's chain, is now up for sale.
 
*
 Miscellanea. Merrill Lynch is selling its Canadian retail brokerage business to Wood Gundy, a leading Canadian securities firm . . . A Federal judge approved a $6 million settlement of a suit filed against CBS by an investor who held 12 shares and said the company was mismanaged from 1983 to 1986. CBS did not admit any wrongdoing but agreed to put aside $4.5 million to benefit stockholders in general. The plaintiff will get $15,000 and his lawyer $1.5 million . . . Asahi Breweries, Japan's third-largest beer maker, said it would build a $70 million brewery near Denver to produce its ''Super Dry'' beer.

HEADLINE: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER;
Forecasting Tools for the Novice

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
Every business depends on forecasting, whether its executives know it or not. How many new franchise stores should we open in 1990? Will we have enough cash on hand in November to pay expenses? Will our current staff be adequate to meet manufacturing demand in 1992? When do we need to reorder widgets? Forecasts are intended to answer those questions.
Until recently, forecasting was the domain of specialists in the dark science of statistical analysis and mathematical modeling. These people pore over the historical numbers generated by a company - monthly sales figures, for example - and then put them in motion, trying to find patterns and models that can be used to predict what might happen a month, a year or a decade ahead. 
For especially complex forecasting jobs, like predicting how much the West German economy will benefit from changes in Eastern Europe, it still makes sense to hire a specialist. But many executives are discovering that today's powerful personal computers can handle all but the most complex forecasting chores.
Business Forecast Systems Inc., of Belmont, Mass., (617) 484-5050, has created three programs for personal computers made by the International Business Machines Corporation and compatible machines that allow experts and novices to forecast with exceptional ease. The most sophisticated product, Forecast Master Plus ($695), is aimed at the niche of executives who understand such concepts as multivariate state space and variable parametric regressions and thus do not need much hand-holding.
Lost already? Me too. For those of us who dozed through Statistics 101, the company offers Forecast Pro ($495), a forecasting tool that has a built-in expert system to guide the user. If Forecast Master Plus is thought of as a high-powered telescope, Forecast Pro is a pair of binoculars. And for those who only need a good pair of glasses to sharpen their vision a bit, there is Forecalc, a $149 program that allows users of the Lotus 1-2-3 (up to version 2.2) and Symphony spreadsheets to enter the forecasting field relatively painlessly.
The less expensive programs use fewer analytical tools. And they6 are not meant to create presentation-quality reports. Their relatively crude graphics are a weakness, and executives would do well to take these forecasts and plug them into a leading graphic program like Harvard Graphics before making a presentation.
Expert systems are becoming increasingly important business applications, especially in esoteric areas like statistics. In essence, the programmers have imbued Forecast Pro and Forecalc with a crude form of ''artificial intelligence'' that captures the collective wisdom of experts in the field - in this case the developers themselves, Robert L. Goodrich and Eric A. Stellwagen. Their expertise can then be applied to the user's problems.
For example, the user might define the problem and enter all the raw data needed for the analysis. But that is only a small part of the exercise: choosing the right model from among more than a dozen different forecasting techniques for extrapolating that data can greatly increase the user's confidence in the results.
A small retail business whose sales depend largely on certain holidays would need a smoothing technique, for example, that would take into account seasonality. Forecast Pro will automatically analyze the problem and recommend the optimal forecast model, and experienced users at the Coca-Cola Company and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, among others, have reported that the program seems to pick the right one most of the time.
Many businesses test forecasting packages by feeding in historical data and turning the software loose on a problem whose outcome is already known - the effect of last year's interest rates on sales, for example. Employing different models would presumably yield results of varying accuracy. The expert system in Forecast Pro will even explain why it chooses one method over another.
Both Forecast Pro and Forecalc are intended for users who do not have a background in statistics. Forecalc is a sort of ''one-button'' forecasting machine that works from within a Lotus 1-2-3 or Symphony spreadsheet. Forecast Pro is also relatively easy to use, making extensive use of pull-down menus, but it is not for the cowardly. For those who understand such things, the principal statistical methods employed by Forecast Pro are exponential smoothing, Box-Jenkins and dynamic regression. Forecalc sticks with exponential smoothing.
At this point, we should note that some people will find it most helpful to read the Forecast Pro manual back-to-front. The third and last part of the manual is a statistical reference written by the developers, describing the basic principles in relatively simple English.
The authors favor exponential smoothing as the most general approach for most problems, since it requires less data and since it is easiest to fit to a particular model. Five types of smoothing, in the so-called Holt Winters family, are included in Pro and Forecalc. Pro also includes Box-Jenkins models (''an implementation of the univariate autoregressive integrated moving average procedure described by Box and Jenkins''), which are preferred in cases where there are more data and when the data are relatively stable, and a more complex family of models called dynamic regression.
Executives who decide to work with Forecast Pro or Forecalc should remember that no forecast is ever 100 percent accurate. No manipulation of fusty old numbers can account for the unexpected introduction of a competing product or a change in public taste, say, to orange widgets from green ones.
That's where the most important ''expert system'' of them all -the user - comes into play. An executive can overlay his or her insight, or even gut instincts, atop the computer-generated equations to refine predictions. At the same time, ''there is an advantage in the objective results that these programs produce,'' said Mr. Goodrich in an interview.
''The statistical methods are subject to biases.'' he said. ''We separate desires and goals, the subjective factors, from the forecasting process, making the results more reliable. The result is that decision-making is much better, and simpler.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In the Deep South Of the Soviet Fold, Complaints Rise In Many Tongues

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
EVERY time a new protest group announces itself along one of the mountainous turnings of the Soviet border, a vast frontier of disparate passions, Kremlinologists rush to their gazetteers the way they used to study the hierarchal lineup atop Lenin's tomb for hints of impending upheaval.
Nakhichevan? The Nakhichevan Popular Front put itself on the map last week, reportedly marshaling thousands of protesters along miles of the far southern border with Iran. According to Moscow's complaint about fresh ''extremist'' lawlessness, they showed up with tents and bullhorns, demanding an open frontier, shouting, ''Down with the Russian empire,'' and destroying extensive stretches of guard posts and border fencing.
Nakhichevan is a separate Islamic piece of the Azerbaijan republic whose kinship with the neighboring Azerbaijan province of northern Iran is an indisputable part of ancient and modern history. Stalin pursued expansionist intrigue across this border quite brazenly four decades ago, but eventually pulled back a puppet government from Iranian Azerbaijan when the Western powers complained. 
But now in the Gorbachev era, it is the Azerbaijani people themselves on the Soviet side of the frontier who are exercising their increasing freedom of self-expression, in order to complain that they long have been denied open access to Iranian kin and culture.
Westerners are forbidden to go to this frontier, but still the scraps of available information prove tantalizing, particularly after the wave of upheaval that has swept Eastern Europe right up to the Soviet border. A Harbinger? Might this largely Shiite Muslim republic be the spark for the long rumored, never realized ''pan-Islamic'' rising against Soviet masters?
Beyond the novelty of scattered group protest, is a common strategic denominator possible among the scattered separatist fervors that stretch far to the north, to the Baltic republics?
Or with the cross-border ties, far to the west, of the proud Moldavians lately inspired by their Rumanian kin?
Or closer, with the Abkhazian minority's yearning for a more independent status in Georgia, an issue that saw Soviet troops use excessive force last April and leave the Kremlin more wary of ethnic confrontations?
Far more locally, how might Nakhichevan be related to the deadly Azerbaijani-Armenian enmity of the last two years over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh enclave, 30 miles north of the Iranian border? In that communal violence, more than 100 people have been killed and scores of thousands turned into refugees.
Even such a Kremlinologist as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev does not pretend to have answers to such polyglot riddles. He has expressed a kind of pained wonderment at the mix of ethnic grievances and ancient vendettas that the Communists inherited from the czars and that Stalin often compounded.
It is a mix of pressures now being expressed as separatist yearnings in the first flush of unsuppressed outspokenness.
In a way, their separate roots in ancient time and geography, endlessly complicated as they are, seem to insulate the Soviet leader from having to confront a single wave of separatist grievance.
Instead, there is more the feel of a wave of undifferentiated anxiety to the assorted yearnings and occasional violence crackling lately along the Soviet frontier.
 
WILDFIRES IN THE MUSLIM REPUBLICS
In the six predominantly Muslim Soviet republics that stretch from the Caucasus Mountains to the Central Asian steppes, opposition movements, ethnic conflict and economic grievances have challenged Moscow's control to one degree or another. But the popular fronts take pains to avoid identification with religion, asserting that the threat of Islamic fundamentalism is a myth the Soviets use to keep their subjects in check. Here is a look at the Soviet Union's southern flank.
* Azerbaijan has the most organized opposition movement in the Muslim-dominated republics. Unlike the Islamic populations in the other five republics, which are largely Sunni, the Azerbaijanis are Shiite. But the leaders of the Azerbaijani Popular Front say they identify not with Islamic Iran, but with secular Turkey. Last week, crowds in the region of Nakhichevan tore up fences along the Soviet-Iranian border, unrest that local leaders said was largely the result of a desire for farmland across the border. In addition, the Azerbaijanis are warring with neighboring Armenia, the only Christian republic in the southern tier, over custody of Nagorno-Karabakh, a region of Azerbaijan that is predominantly Armenian. The dispute has encouraged the Popular Front, which is also angry about what it says is the transfer of the republic's oil wealth to Moscow.
* In Kazakhstan, which has more than 100 ethnic groups, anger about the presence and privileges of migrant workers and alarm about contamination from a vast nuclear-weapons testing range have become focal points for opposition. Three years ago, nationalists rioted after the naming of a non-Kazakh Communist Party chief. The republic is also warring with neighbors; it wants to reclaim a region that is now part of Uzbekistan and Turkmenia.
* Though Soviet authorities have often cited the need to counter Iran's propaganda in Turkmenia, Tehran and Moscow signed an agreement last year for a new rail link between the republic and Iran.
* In Uzbekistan, a popular front called Birlik, or Unity, has been fueled by the rural poverty and environmental degradation of its vast cotton fields. Last year, there were protests that not enough Muslims were on the election ballot. Also, Uzbek mobs have rampaged against the republic's Meskhetian minority, which is relatively better off.
* The people of Tadzhikistan are of Persian origin and speak an Iranian dialect. (The Muslims in other Central Asia republics are Turkic.) But unlike the Iranian Muslims, the Tadzhik Muslims are mostly Sunni. Still, Soviet authorities have said the republic is fertile ground for Teheran's propaganda, and several years ago the press reported a crackdown on fundamentalist mullahs. The Tadzhiks and Uzbeks have claims on each others' land.
