HEADLINE: Baseball Notebook;
Yanks Champs! In 80's Payroll, That Is

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
If there ever was any doubt that George Steinbrenner is the biggest spender in baseball, doubt it no longer. The Yankees' owner spent so much more money on players in the 1980's than anyone else that the Players Association should erect a monument to him at Yankee Stadium in the form of a giant, 24-carat gold dollar sign.
The Yankees' player payroll in the 1980's totaled $137,883,665, nearly $21.5 million more than the next highest payroll, belonging to the California Angels, and three times the lowest payroll, possession of the Seattle Mariners.
The difference between the payrolls of the Yankees and the Angels is the largest, by more than $5 million, of any difference among the 26 clubs from one level to the next. Furthermore, the average salaries of 13 teams - half of the teams in the major leagues - fall within the same dropoff from the Angels' average salary as exists between the average salaries of the Yankees and the Angels - $78,492. 
For all of their heavy spending, the Yankees won only two division championships and one pennant in the 1980's, none since 1981, making them one of the least cost-efficient teams.
The most cost-efficient were the St. Louis Cardinals and the Los Angeles Dodgers. The Cardinals, with a payroll of $92,550,286, won three division titles, three pennants (most in the decade) and one World Series. The Dodgers had a payroll of $108,032,998 and won the most division titles, four, and the most World Series, two, in the 1980's. Oakland and Kansas City were not far behind those two teams in making their player expenditures worthwhile.
The compilation of the 1980's payrolls, however, also shows that it does pay to pay. The Cleveland Indians, the Texas Rangers and the Mariners were the last three teams in the payroll standing and they were three of the five teams that did not win division titles in the 10-year period. The Pittsburgh Pirates and the Cincinnati Reds were the other two failures and they joined the others in being five of the seven lowest-paying teams.
The moral of the economic story, then, would seem to be you have to pay to win, though you don't necessarily have to overpay like the Yankees.
The Yankees, whose payroll was 18.5 percent higher than the Angels' total, were one of eight teams with payrolls that exceeded the $100 million plateau. The other six were the Mets, the Dodgers, Boston, Houston, Philadelphia and Atlanta. At $46,189,730, the Mariners were the only team under $50 million. The average payroll was $90 million.
The average player salary for the period from 1980-89 was $332,090. Average salaries were also compiled because the teams, during the 10 years, had different total numbers of players, depending on how many players were on the disabled list Aug. 31 each season. That is the date used by the Players Association and the Player Relations Committee in determing average salaries each year.
The Yankees' average salary was $485,506, the Angels' $407,014. No one else reached $400,000.
Except for the first two years of the 1980's, the Yankees had payrolls of more than $12 million, reaching a high of $19.4 million in 1988. The Mets and the Dodgers each exceeded that total last year.
The Indians and the Mariners were the only teams whose payroll never reached $10 million in any of the seasons. Those teams also had the smallest increases from the first year of the period to the last, Seattle's payroll rising $5.6 million, Cleveland's $6 million.
The Mets had the largest increase, $17.7 million, followed by Oakland $15.9 million and Los Angeles $15.6 million.
 
Mattingly, the Booster
Whatever the Yankees think of Don Mattingly, it's not enough. Given the team's inability to win a division title in his first seven seasons and the seemingly bleak outlook for the immediate future, Mattingly could conceivably go through his career without playing on a division champion. Yet he maintains, at least publicly, a positive view of the team and speaks of the future optimistically.
Asked if he has been discouraged by developments, Mattingly said: ''No, not really. Basically our organization is trying to win. It gets out of whack a little or something happens, but in my heart I know we're trying. We'll do some things. I know they went after Langston heavy. You can't get everybody. At least I know George is making the effort to get somebody like that. To me, that's encouraging.''
Looking ahead to next season, he added: ''I think we can contend. There's no doubt about that. We have good defense up the middle with Espinoza, Sax and Kelly, and Geren came on and is a solid catcher defensively. I'm encouraged in a way. I like our young pitchers. Cadaret, Plunk, Cary and Parker show promise. I don't think we're a club that has to make wholesale changes. You talk about good teams with solid defense up the middle and we had that. I didn't see us as a horrible club. We never got together and we didn't have that much confidence in ourselves. We could do some things.''
Spoken like a veteran public relations man. The Yankees need all the good public relations they can get.
 
Trading Out of Necessity
Mark Langston, Bryn Smith and Pascual Perez for Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, Joaquin Andujar and Dave Schmidt: would any general manager make that trade?
The Montreal Expos would not have, but in practice, they have, out of necessity. The Expos lost the first three pitchers as free agents, then signed the other three as free agents. They can't expect the same production from the new trio, but they had to start somewhere.
Boyd, an erratic personality, has been plagued the last three seasons by shoulder ailments and blood clots. He started only 10 games last season. Andujar, another hyper individual, hasn't pitched in the major leagues since 1988; the Expos signed him out of the Florida seniors' league.
Schmidt, normal, gave the Baltimore Orioles two solid seasons as a reliever and spot starter, pitching effectively when he moved into the rotation late in the season. But the Orioles made him a regular starter last season and discovered he was out of his element. If the Expos revert to his 1987-88 use, he could be the best of their three newcomers.
Dennis Martinez and Kevin Gross are the Expos' only remaining starting pitchers. If Boyd is healthy, he should be in the rotation, too. Mark Gardner and one of two right-handers who pitched in Class AA this year, Mel Rojas or Howard Farmer are also possibilities. Gardner was the American Association pitcher of the year and had an 0-3 record in four starts and three relief appearances near the end of the season for Montreal.
The Expos, however, will spend the first two months of the season focusing on fields far from Montreal. Because they lost the three pitchers, plus Hubie Brooks, as free agents, they have loads of compensation coming to them in the form of draft choices.
Counting their own choices, the Expos will get 10 of the first 52 picks in the June amateur draft: two in the first round, four in the special-compensation round, between rounds one and two, and four in the first half of the second round.
The Expos will receive California's first-round selection (for Langston); picks between the first and second rounds for Langston, Perez and Brooks, who were Type A free agents, plus one because they didn't sign their first-round choice last year, and the second-round choices of the Yankees (Perez), Los Angeles (Brooks) and St. Louis (Smith). The four lost free agents will thus bring the Expos seven extra draft choices.
''Gary Hughes and his scouting staff will have an interesting time,'' Dave Dombrowski, the Expos' general manager, said. ''Our guys have done a very good job of drafting in recent years so we're looking forward to it.''
 
Closing Information Bank
A few years ago, the Player Relations Committee established an information bank to gather and disseminate information on offers made to free agents. When the Players Association discovered the bank's existence, it asked the arbitrator to order the P.R.C. to terminate it. The arbitrator said the bank would be an issue to be decided with the rest of the collusion case, but told the P.R.C. to share the information with the union.
When the free-agent season approached last fall, the P.R.C. decided to abolish the bank. Barry Rona, then the P.R.C. executive director, always contended that the bank actually enhanced offers to free agents, but Donald Fehr, head of the union, now says the abolishment of the bank was greatly responsible for the lucrative developments in the free-agent market.
''I am satisfied that what we saw this year demonstrates that the information bank had an anticompetitive effect, like we said,'' Fehr remarked when asked about the bank's impact. ''What the information bank does is make it far less likely that pre-emptive bids will be made, and if there is going to be any competition, it will be done at the lowest possible level, which is a mutual goal of the clubs.
''Having 26 teams all interested in the same player but having it be at 10 percent of what he's worth is not something we care for. It has not escaped our notice that the differences in the market this year occurred as soon as the information bank was pulled down.''

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 14th for Newark;
New Airport Hotel

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Hampton Inns of Memphis is building a 154-room hotel near Newark International Airport, the 14th to serve the terminal's immediate area. The $5 million facility on Route 1-9 in Elizabeth, N.J., facing an entrance to the airport, is expected to be finished in about a year. Airport officials attributed part of a major increase in hotel business around the terminal to the growing practice among business executives of flying in, attending meetings overnight in conference rooms and returning home the next day.
The architect of the five-story structure is John Granville Taylor of Memphis and the builder is Controlled Construction of Wayne, N.J. The 80,000-square-foot building is being constructed of concrete plank on block bearing walls.
Hampton Inn is a rapidly expanding subsidiary of Holiday Corporation, which is also based in Memphis. The subsidiary expects to have 250 hotels and motels in operation by the end of this year. The chain seeks to attract an economy-minded clientele by offering prices 20 to 40 percent below those of its sister company, Holiday Inns.

LENGTH: 2354 words

HEADLINE: Whose Broker Is It, Anyway? Albany Offers An Answer

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
SUPPOSE a house-hunting couple wants to make a bid on a house. They aren't sure how much under the asking price to offer, so they ask the broker. The broker says, ''Well, the house has been on the market for six months, you saw how old the furnace is, so why don't you try this number?''
The scenario is a familiar one to many home buyers who have come to regard ''their'' real estate salesman as an adviser on the final deal.
But it is also unethical under the rules of of the National Association of Realtors, and it would become illegal, along with a host of other daily customs and practices in the real estate business, under new rules being proposed by New York's Secretary of State, Gail Shaffer, whose office regulates the real estate industry in the state. 
What Ms. Shaffer is proposing, in a 40-page draft now circulating in Albany and among the state's real estate brokerages, is to codify the distinction between a broker's client and his customers and, some industry leaders complain, undo some basic elements of today's housing market.
In the case of a broker advising a buyer, the new law would underscore the long-standing rule that if a broker accepts a listing to sell a house, the seller is the broker's client and is thus owed full loyalty. That includes the obligation to obtain the highest possible price for the property and precludes advising a buyer how to save some money at the seller's expense, a practice known as representing adverse interests.
Among some of the more far-reaching proposals in the draft laws are these:
* To make it illegal for a broker to let agents and brokers not licensed directly to him to market one of his listings, a measure that could, Ms. Shaffer concedes, doom the use of multiple listing services.
* To make brokers get house-buyers to sign a document acknowledging that the broker represents the seller, not the buyers.
* To forbid the common practice of brokers buying properties listed with them.
* To require that all advertisements for a residential property include an accurate description of the property's geographical location.
THESE rules, some of them new, others restatements of scattered agency regulations, legal precedents and state laws, are needed, Ms. Shaffer said in an interview, because the modern real estate market has tended to blur the opposing interests of buyer and seller in favor of the middleman, the broker.
''I regard this as a consumer protection issue of the largest proportions because real estate is probably the biggest transaction the consumer is going to make in his lifetime,'' she said. ''Yet many people probably do more research about buying a toaster than about a transaction costing tens of thousands, or hundreds of thousands of dollars.''
The problem is compounded, Ms. Shaffer went on, when buyers forget who the broker is working for.
''Many people think the friendly guy in the mustard-colored jacket is going to represent them and stick up for their best interests,'' she said. ''They may not realize that, by law, he has to do everything he can to get the highest price and the best terms for the seller.''
A 1983 Federal Trade Commission survey, she noted, found that 71 percent of buyers believed the broker represented them. Two examples of this that Ms. Shaffer provided illustrate the point. In one instance, the Harvey Heino Realty Corporation of Brooklyn was fined $1,000 last February - the maximum penalty allowed short of revocation of a broker's license - for forging a buyer's name to an offer on a home. Despite the fact that the buyer had agreed to the offer, Roger Schneier, the administrative law judge, ruled that the false signature amounted to fraudulent behavior.
The case of Ferris Real Estate of Cortland, N.Y., last March demonstrates what can happen to a broker who does not warn buyers of the broker's first duty to the seller. The firm was brought before Judge Schneier on charges by a seller that the firm had understated the amount of an offer, a charge the judge dismissed as illogical - a lower offer would reduce the broker's commission - and unfounded.
But in the course of the proceeding it became clear that the buyer had not been given sufficient notice that Ferris Real Estate worked for the seller, and the firm was fined $1,000.
The Department of State's two law judges hear about 100 license violation complaints a year, and have handed down 35 revocations and 37 suspensions in the past three years, officials said.
Some brokers have anticipated a greater awareness of buyers' rights in the real estate business by creating buyers-only brokerages, in which brokers and agents represent only buyers. The practice has been a long-standing one in the commercial real estate field, and Susan Bird of S. W. Bird & Company pioneered the approach in Manhattan, with her agents splitting the sales commissions with the seller's broker, just as a co-broker would do in a conventional real estate deal.
The distinction can be hard to make, however, since brokers for buyers get their fees from the seller just as the sales brokers do, and common law ordinarily assumes that an agent is working for the one who pays him. Nor do the financial interests of buyer-brokers and their buying clients always mesh, since the brokers profit from higher sales prices and the buyers, which are against the interests of the buyer.
The Bird Company has to some extent blurred the distinction between brokering purchases and sales by creating a sales brokerage division in the same office. Dale Emily LaPointe, the general manager for sales, said that the two divisions operate independent of each other, however.
Codifying the rules under the regulations of the Department of State's Division of Licensing Services, which administers and enforces the state real estate law, will require approval by the Legislature, Ms. Shaffer said. Public hearings on the proposed rules will probably be scheduled in the spring.
Considering the sweeping nature of some of the rules, the response among real estate professionals so far has been surprisingly mild. Charles M. Staro, executive director of the New York State Association of Realtors, said that his members were studying the proposals and would not comment in detail until the deadline Ms. Shaffer set for their response, on Jan. 26.
''A cursory review says we can live with some of the regulations,'' said Mr. Staro, ''but we also anticipate that we will have some concern about other ones.''
Jack Hill, a staff member of the Real Estate Board of New York, a city trade organization, said the board has been meeting with Ms. Shaffer to discuss her draft for the past several months.
''I would think that Gail Shaffer might be the first to admit that we work in a very sophisticated environment in New York City,'' he said. ''The buyer and the seller or lessee are all very knowledgeable, so things are done in a way that are for the most part honorable.''
But William D. North, executive vice president of the National Association of Realtors and the trade group's spokesman on legal and regulatory matters, was more direct, particularly about proposed rules on ''subagency,'' the assignment of brokerage rights on a property to other brokerages, as is done through a multiple listing service.
''On the face of it, several things strike me as enormously destructive of the consumer interest here,'' he said. ''Historically, we have been through the marketplace that she would create, where each listing is tightly held, where a buyer goes from broker to broker to broker to see what is available, where when you buy a house, you don't really know what the alternatives are, you don't know what the comparable prices are and it is an absolute horror. All you have to do is go to France or Germany, where these subagency rules are in place, and you can see what the implications of these proposals are.''
But subagency agreements violate the fiduciary responsibility of a broker to his client, the seller, Ms. Shaffer said. Hence the key language of the proposed rule, which says that a broker may offer subagency only to licensed associate brokers or sales people who are employed by the real estate broker himself.
Not, in other words, to the dozens of other brokerages who use the blanket offer of subagency implied in a listing in a multiple listing service, or M.L.S.
''A fiduciary responsibility means that you are undertaking to maximize the profitability of that property, and you are also acting to minimize the risks inherent in marketing it,'' Ms. Shaffer said. ''When an agent contracts with a subagent or the M.L.S., the seller has no agreement with that universe of people who are now suddenly authorized by the broker to market his property. The subagents could be incompetent, they could engage in unethical or illegal practices, and the seller could suddenly find himself liable for them.''
EXAMPLES of illegal dealings by subagents that could implicate a seller include acts of racial discrimination, where the subagents deceive a minority home-seeker, or, the failure of a subagent to promptly deliver an offer on a property, hoping for a higher one, or a subagent's failure to disclose a material defect in the property.
''My feeling is that the seller could have recourse through the Department of State against the subagent and the agent if there is wrongdoing,'' said Mr. Staro of the state association.
Mr. North, of the National Association of Realtors, said the state's proposed solution outmatched the problem.
''From a national perspective, we have just not seen that liability,'' he went on. ''Sure, there is a theoretical liability, and you can protect against it with insurance, or arbitration. But as a practical matter we just have not seen it.''
In the section on self-dealing, the new rules' proposed ban on brokers buying their own listings will fly in the face of a common practice, brokers said. But Ms. Shaffer insisted that a broker buying from a client is a bare-faced violation of his responsibility to obtain the highest possible price for the property, and the proposed law would require a broker to resign a listing before making an offer on a property he represents.
''The fiduciary responsibility requires that the agent put the client first, and if the agent's self-interest comes into play, you can no longer do that,'' the Secretary of State declared.
''If you are a potential buyer, you can no longer be in that relationship, so you will have to say, 'Look, I can't represent you any longer because I have an interest in this property, and you can be better served by another broker.' ''
As it is, Ms. Shaffer said, brokers are routinely buying their own listings, often after having set the price in an appraisal as well.
''And they are actually collecting the commission, on top of getting the property,'' she added. ''That is unconscionable and untenable.''
Mr. North made two points in response - that sellers are fully aware of how markets work, and are able to protect themselves from charlatans and that there is ample legal recourse for sellers who believe they had been cheated.
''If that happens, I can only tell you that the remedies that are available, and the damages and other consequences are so horrendous that a real estate broker who engages in that type of practice will get everything he deserves.''
The rules would outlaw another common sales technique, Mr. North added, the guaranteed sale, in which a broker promises to buy a property that does not sell as an agreed-upon price in a certain period of time. The offer is usually contingent on the seller's having made a commitment to buy another home.
A New Jersey broker, who wished not to be quoted, made an additional point:
''If I buy any house in the whole multiple listing service I would be self-dealing under that rule, because I'm a subagent for every listing in the M.L.S.,'' he said.
The proposed new rules also contain strict enforcement powers against blockbusting, the illegal practice of inducing homeowners to sell by spreading fear that a neighborhood is changing, racially or economically. Ms. Shaffer has already scheduled 11 hearings between next Thursday and March 22 in Queens, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Nassau County on her plans to issue nonsolicitation orders in areas where blockbusting is suspected. The orders forbid real estate brokers or their agents to solicit listings in the areas where blockbusting is suspected.
THE state had been issuing such orders for 18 years until they were struck down last February by the Court of Appeals on the ground that the Department of State lacked statutory authority to issue them. The Legislature then passed enabling legislation for that authority, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed it into law, during the last session. The hearings thus mark a return to the practice despite the stiff objections of the real estate industry.
For all the disagreements that are likely to arise when the full public discussion of the proposed new rules gets under way, some measures appeared unobjectionable to real estate industry leaders. One would require the chief broker of each real estate agency to list his or her full name, plus the legend ''Licensed Real Estate Broker'' on each ''For Sale'' sign, calling card and advertisement. Another would require that listing contracts contain language defining the different kinds of listings available to a seller, including the seller's right to reserve the right to sell the house alone without paying a commission.
The real estate officials also agreed with the Secretary of State's proposed ban on ''net listings,'' in which the broker gets to keep any sales money over an agreed-upon figure.
While reserving formal comment until later, several brokers who were interviewed said they did not particularly mind having buyers sign a document spelling out that the broker's first duty is to the seller, or a rule that would require the name of the broker-of-record - every brokerage must have one - on each ''for sale'' sign the firm plants on front lawns.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: The 10-Year Housing Plan;
Issues for the 90's: Management and Costs

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IN housing, New York City has changed horses in midstream. Mayor David N. Dinkins has come into office at about the halfway mark of the expensive, long-term municipal housing program begun by former Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1985.
The new administration faces two key challenges. One is to sustain the production effort at reasonable cost, which is becoming all the more difficult as the buildings still to be planned become more scattered and smaller than those already in the development pipeline.
The second issue is how to effectively sustain the buildings for 20 to 30 years once they are occupied. 
Will tenants' incomes and the rents they pay rise sufficiently to cover rising operating costs? Will reserve funds be sufficient to meet unexpected contingencies and unwanted inflation in costs? Will nonprofit management corporations that own debt-free housing make periodic demands on city government for more operating money? Will neighborhood problems overwhelm housing managers?
The production volume itself has built up impressively. In the last two fiscal years, which ended last June 30, starts were achieved on 13,260 apartments in gut-rehabilitated buildings. These are mainly in vacant, tax-foreclosed, city-owned properties. Recycling is the central element in the production program. In the current fiscal year, the plan is to start construction on 7,300 more.
Moreover, construction of new city-assisted houses, for one or two families, is also moving apace. There were 4,290 starts in the last two fiscal years, and prospectively 4,100 more this year.
City dollars are flowing. The pace reached $1.3 billion in new capital-budget commitments for the three fiscal years that ended last June. In the 10-year plan, former Mayor Koch undertook to spend $5.1 billion for housing. Moderate amounts of Federal and, particularly, state assistance also are provided.
The city's housing officials express confidence that once rehabilitated and occupied, the buildings will sustain themelves. ''We believe the budgets are hefty enough to secure the buildings,'' said Felice Michetti, deputy commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
Yet many new buildings have a preponderance of extremely low-income tenants. In some cases all of them get their rent money from the welfare system - $312 a month for a family of four, unindexed for inflation. To the extent that welfare rents pay substantial portions of buildings' incomes, many buildings will long be at risk unless they have substantial reserves.
In most buildings, care has been taken to provide for reserves.
''YOU go into a project knowing you will need a big reserve fund,'' said Catherine Herman, associate director of the housing office of the Brooklyn Catholic Charities, an experienced nonprofit housing manager. ''In the early years the rents will pay the freight. But if rents are rising only 1 or 2 percent a year, you've got to provide the building almost with an endowment to pay for future repairs if the property is going to be maintained for 20 years or more.''
Brooklyn Catholic Charities is managing three buildings with 55 apartments in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn that have been rehabilitated under the auspices of the Enterprise Foundation, whose investors use the Federal low-income tax-credit program. The requirements of this program, when mortgages are insured by the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, cause almost half the private investors' equity contribution to be used for the reserve fund. This came to $300,000 in a 30-unit Brooklyn Catholic Charities building in Williamsburg.
But in buildings that are entirely city-financed, some managers say there may be a need for further subsidies eventually, even though low-income tenants have gotten apartments without mortgages, so that rents cover only operating expenses.
Carol Lamberg, executive director of the Settlement Housing Fund, a major nonprofit housing manager and developer, said she believed that certain buildings would need the security of assured Federal housing vouchers to supplement tenants' rents over time.
''The shelter allowance is too low,'' she said. ''If a big crisis like the one in 1974 comes, anything can happen.''
''Debt-free low-income buildings will be O.K. for a short time,'' said the Rev. Louis Gigante, president of the nonprofit Sebco Development Company in the South Bronx. ''But after that they are finished unless housing vouchers go to the welfare people.''
VOUCHERS are used to inject Federal funds into existing low-income housing. But critics question whether tenants who are in effect getting free apartments should also benefit from vouchers to offset future repair costs. If incomes are too low, it is necessary, the managers say.
In 1974, the price of oil surged and thousands of privately owned, rent-controlled apartments were dropped to mortgagees, and ultimately to the city. That housing disaster remains the principal cause of the current low-income housing shortage.
The immediate cost issue involves the prices paid for city-financed gut rehabilitations. Those that have been contracted out in large clusters to major construction-management companies are costing far more than anticipated in Harlem and the Bronx.
In Harlem alone it is costing at least $72.7 million to rehabilitate 720 apartments to Public Housing Authority standards. That is at least $30 million more than the Koch administration predicted. And the costs keep rising. Two months ago, bids came in so high in the third round of bidding for gut rehabilitations under this phase of the city's program that all were rejected. The lowest came to $115,000 a unit.
Now the city is seeking out smaller builders for the same work, divided into smaller building clusters. Working with badly rundown walk-ups being redone as elevator buildings, officials are seeking to pay under $70,000 a unit for gut rehabilitations.
The bigger long-term problem is the scattered small buildings. How will those 15,000 units get rehabilitated, and at what cost and for whom?
There are believed to be about 1,700 such buildings, with 5 to 20 apartments each. In the past, the city has attempted to sell them to small private developers for rehabilitation and resale as condominiums. There has not been much success. The Citizens Housing and Planning Council, in a 41-page report last month on the city's housing programs and how to improve them, singled out the small-building rehabilitation and sales program as the one most in need of overhaul.
''MANY of the buildings slated for this program do not make sense as sales housing,'' said the council. It urged the city to turn to very small builders and contractors, simplified paperwork procedure and either looser income-eligibility requirements for occupancy or ''turnkey'' back to public ownership for low-income occupancy.
Of the 253,000 housing units specified in the 10-year program, 169,000 had tenants when the program began, housing officials say. The assistance the buildings get comes mainly as low-interest moderate-rehabilitation loans to private owners.
The heavy costs and risks come in new construction and gut rehabilitations, which can be considered additions to the housing supply. New construction includes private homes on city-owned land, mainly for moderate- to middle-income people. The subsidy per unit is relatively modest - up to $25,000. Prospectively, there may be more multifamily city-assisted new construction. The overall goal is about 37,000 new homes or apartments over 10 years.
In gut rehabilitations, the Koch administration's goal was about 47,000 of the 53,000 vacant apartments in the tax-foreclosed stock, Abraham Biderman, the housing commissioner in the final years of the Koch administration, said in an interview.
The largest vacant-building recycling program has also been done at least cost. A total of 18,000 housing units are to be put into development by small builders, using private construction financing and permanent private mortgages with a city subsidy in the form of a nominal-interest second mortgage of $12,000 to $15,000 an apartment.
The costs are higher whenever the city itself has managed the construction, intending to turn over buildings with very low incomes - between 30 percent and 60 percent of areawide median - to nonprofit managers. To house that population in fully rehabilitated buildings that are successfully maintained as decent housingover time may be the biggest challenge on the low-income housing front in the 90's.

HEADLINE: TALKING: Mortgages;
V.A. Loans Regaining Acceptance

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
AN unexpected byproduct of the weaker real estate market has been the return of the Veterans Administration mortgage as a popular financing tool, one that developers and sellers appear keener to honor than in the mid-80's, when sales were booming and any loan subject to possible bureaucratic delay was scorned.
Gone are the days, for example, when couples like John and Ikuko Doyle of Weehawken, N.J., would go shopping for a home and, Mr. Doyle says, ''nobody would accept V.A. loans.''
''So we couldn't buy because we weren't in a position to use anything else,'' Mr. Doyle said, referring to the V.A. loan feature that requires no down payment.
Today, any option that will broaden the marketplace and produce a willing and able buyer is being welcomed. ''You don't mind waiting a few more weeks for the approval if you know you have finally found a buyer,'' said Nancy Gordon, assistant vice president at the Hackensack, N.J., headquarters of Globe Mortgage, where V.A. applications are on the rise. 
Lumberman's Mortgage Corporation of N.J., for example, wrote 138 V.A. mortgages in the first 11 months of 1989 compared to 92 in 1988, a 50 percent increase, even though loan originations at Lumberman's rose by only 10 percent.
The Veterans Administration home mortgage program dates to 1944, when it was used to help returning World War II veterans buy a home. It is actually a loan guarantee program. The loan itself is made through a local lender, although the terms are set by the Department of Veterans Affairs. Today it is available to anyone who has served at least 90 days in the military (reserve duty normally does not count). The individual needs only a certificate of eligibility from the local Office of Veterans Affairs.
In Connecticut that office is in Hartford at 450 Main Street, in New Jersey it is in Newark at 20 West Place, and in downstate New York it is in Manhattan at 252 Seventh Avenue.
From time to time, terms and conditions change. Thus another reason V.A. mortgages are enjoying new popularity is that they offer an unusually good interest rate - a fixed rate of 9.5 percent. This is about one-fourth to one-half point lower than most fixed-rate mortgages available through the conventional market, according to the most recent surveys by HSH Associates of Butler, N.J., a mortgage monitoring service.
It is also possible to use a V.A. mortgage again and again. This feature was introduced in 1970 and has been encouraging veterans to use the mortgage on an ongoing basis rather than just for a first home - especially useful if the borrower has been divorced and there is no equity to pass along to a new home.
In addition, V.A. loans tend to be more flexible on how much debt a borrower can carry in relation to income. Total debt, including all consumer borrowing, can reach 41 percent of income, compared with 36 percent for most conventional mortgages.
And - and perhaps most important - a V.A. loan is one of the few remaining ways to borrow 100 percent of the cost of a home. The only restriction, a $144,000 ceiling, is about to be raised, according to officials at the Department of Veterans Affairs in Washington, although the amount is not yet available.
So why does the V.A. loan have a reputation of being difficult to use? One is the amount of paperwork and delay involved in getting an approval. But experts who have worked with V.A. loans for many years say that the reputation is no longer valid, and that there are ways to avoid even a minor delay.
MS. GORDON, for example, has found that V.A. loan approval takes four to five weeks, compared to two to three for conventional loan clearance. Most of this added delay, said Louis R. Ciullo, regional vice president at Lumberman's and branch manager of its Toms River, N.J., office, comes from prudent lending practices - the more stringent verifications needed to provide someone with a loan that carries no down payment.
If those verifications can be obtained easily, approval can come quickly. For instance, Elaine and William Rutledge - she is a financial adviser and he is an electrical contractor - closed this month on a two-bedroom town house condominium in Lakewood, N.J., for $117,900 for which they were able to get V.A. loan approval in 30 days, Mrs. Rutledge said.
But to get it that fast two factors must be in place. The lender should have a V.A.-approved staff underwriter. This eliminates the need for the paperwork to be sent to a V.A. office for clearance - a cause of many of the legendary delays. Second, if the purchase is a new home, or a substantially rehabiliated home like a condominium conversion project, the project itself needs prior V.A. approval, which can take two months or more. So it is usually easier to buy a new home that already has such clearance. This should not be a problem as more and more developers are getting those approvals early, aware that it can stimulate sales.
Such approval also can be requested by the borrower. The Doyles did that, ending up with the $98,000, two-bedroom condominium in Weehawken they had decided was exactly for them, even though they knew they might face several months of delay waiting for the approval.
The second myth is that the appraisal and inspection of the property by a V.A. representative is so stringent that there is a great risk of rejection. Not so, says Nicholas De Serio of Bricktown, N.J., a former V.A. appraisal supervisor who now handles V.A. appraisals for his own account. Three years ago, he said, a new appraisal form was introduced that requires simply a market-value analysis. It is no more onerous, he insisted, than those used by conventional lenders.
The final strike against the V.A. loan was always the requirement that the seller pay most of the points. But brokers have found that this can usually be traded for a lesser reduction in the asking price. Tom Meyer of Seapoint Realty in Point Pleasant, N.J., who has handled such negotiations for 20 years, said that both buyer and seller must be willing to compromise.
He gave as an example a home with an asking price of $100,000. Instead of a reduction to $98,000, the buyer agrees to accept the $100,000 price in exchange for the seller's paying two points, or $2,000, of the three-point loan inititation charge. The buyer is required to pay one point. Thus, requirements are met, and though the buyer pays a bit more, that is offset by the better terms of the V.A. loan.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Orleans, Mass.;
Cape's Sales Continue Slide

BYLINE: By SETH KING

 BODY:
LAST January, Donald Fulcher and his wife, Susan, year-round residents on Cape Cod, put their modest two-bedroom, one-bath house in South Yarmouth on the market for $119,000. Nothing happened.
Three months later they lowered the price to $115,000 and, after another three months, lowered it to $112,000. 
Finally, late in October, they found a buyer who could qualify for a mortgage and they accepted his offer of $108,000.
Last month, the Fulchers paid $180,000 for a four-bedroom, two-bath house near Barnstable Village, five minutes from Barnstable Harbor's beaches and docks. Although it had been on the market only a month, the Fulchers paid $15,000 less than the asking price of $195,000.
Their experience is typical of Cape Cod's current real estate market. Despite another painfully slow year, a modest number of houses and condominiums are selling.
But most have been on the market unusually long and virtually all sell well below the original asking price.
''There's no question that the big adjustment that started more than a year ago is continuing,'' said Walter F. Brown, an Orleans real estate appraiser who was involved in the Fulcher transactions.
Sellers, Mr. Brown said, are having to lower their acceptance prices periodically to compete in a market that now has a record number of houses and condominiums listed.
They also have to adjust to mortgage interest rates that still hover around 10 percent and to the fact that there are now far fewer prospects who can qualify for home loans, he added.
Mr. Brown is supported by the latest count of residential sales made through the multiple listing service of the Cape Cod and Islands Board of Realtors, which also handles Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard.
During October, there was a 5 percent drop both in the number of residential properties sold through multiple listing - to 180 - and in their total value, which came to $29.9 million.
In the first 10 months of 1989, a total of 1,693 properties, virtually all of them houses and condominiums, were sold through multiple listing, a drop of 8.9 percent. And at the end of November, the Board of Realtors was listing 6,083 properties for sale, 700 more than a year ago.
This trend, according to other Cape real estate brokers and bankers, has reshaped the profile of this year's buyers. Many more now intend to live in the houses they buy, and fewer are buying homes and condominiums as investments.
And those who intend to buy, the brokers say, are doing so very slowly, apparently waiting for prices to drop more.

HEADLINE: Defense Cuts Top Delegation's Agenda

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
WEATHERING cuts in defense spending, reducing pollution in Long Island Sound and passing child care legislation for working families top the state's Congressional agenda for 1990.
Some Connecticut lawmakers, including two who are running for governor, will have to find time between campaign stops to conduct their legislative business. The rest will be in the same boat as most members of Congress: trying to pass legislation at a time when the Government has no money.
The 1990 gubernatorial election is expected to dominate the state's political news in the next 10 months and much of the attention will focus on Washington as United States Representatives John G. Rowland, Republican of Waterbury, and Bruce A. Morrison, Democrat of New Haven, begin campaigns for the state's top office. The delegation could get even busier if Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, Democrat of Hartford, contest. 
How will they find time to legislate in Washington and run for governor?
 
'Working Twice as Hard'
''By working twice as hard,'' Mr. Morrison said. ''I will continue to do my job. It will aid me in my race for governor that I will continue to be effective in my specific responsibilities in Washington.''
Mr. Rowland says he faces less of a problem because in his view ''we have a unique advantage of having the nomination pretty much sewed up.''
While Mr. Morrison is hustling to muster convention support and votes for the primary, Mr. Rowland said, he will be concentrating on his job in Washington and preparing for the final election.
Mr. Rowland and Mr. Morrison, along with virtually the entire eight-member Connecticut delegation in Washington, mentioned the impending cuts in the defense budget as a major local priority for Connecticut.
''Connecticut very definitely needs both the Federal and state government to get heavily involved in planning for reduced military expenditures,'' Mr. Morrison said. ''We've got to make sure that Connecticut's peace dividend is not unemployed workers.''
 
Two Strategies
Mr. Rowland, a member of the House Armed Services Committee, said he has two strategies: to make sure Connecticut does not take an unfair share of the cuts and to create policies that will encourage businesses to convert to nonmilitary production and to hire unemployed defense workers.
Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Bozrah, whose district includes the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics, where nuclear submarines are built, has been a leader in the push to diversify the state economy and plans to continue working toward that goal.
The state's two Senators, Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman, both Democrats, will be the only members of the delegation not facing some kind of election in 1990. But their agendas appear full for the coming year.
Senator Dodd has been running up a hefty long-distance telephone bill maintaining contacts in Central America amid the tumultuous developments there. A top priority for Mr. Dodd will be monitoring the Nicaraguan elections next month.
 
Child Care Legislation
Domestically, the top item on Senator Dodd's list - and also a key issue for Representative Kennelly - is child care legislation, which has come close to passing two years in a row. ''I'm hopeful, based on the statements made by the majority leader and others that they consider it a top priority,'' Mr. Dodd said.
Mr. Lieberman, who ends his freshman year in the Senate, said that he would continue to push his environmental agenda. Among the first bills to be taken up this year by the Senate is the Clean Air Act, a revision that includes acid rain legislation important to Connecticut.
Senator Lieberman said he would also focus on the continuing study of pollution in Long Island Sound. And he is seeking to establish Connecticut's first national park, at the Weir farm in Ridgefield. He said he does not plan to back down from his support of a capital gains tax cut, a position that drew some criticism last year in Democratic circles.
Representative Christopher J. Shays, Republican of Stamford, counts himself among those who follow former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill's slogan that ''all politics are local.'' He listed the Federal budget deficit as his ''first, second and third'' local priorities.
''Nothing is more important than that,'' Mr. Shays said. He also lists commuter rail service to New York and the cleanup of Long Island Sound as two other important measures.
Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of New Britain, sounds somewhat un-Republican when she lists child care, affordable housing, the Clean Air Act and a solution to the problem of trying to provide health care for the uninsured as her priorities for 1990. She heads a Republican panel looking into ways the Federal Government can help the uninsured without breaking the bank.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT OPINION;
Our Suburban Children Could Learn Much From the Immigrants Among Us

BYLINE: By Robert Liftig; Robert Liftig lives in Westport.

 BODY:
THIS new year is the 100th since the last of my ancestors left Eastern Europe to settle in Connecticut. 1990 is therefore a coming of age for my family, and I've been thinking how fitting it is that our anniversary falls during one the largest periods of immigration in recent American history. These days, however, the immigrants often come from other directions: South America, the Caribbean and Asia. And it's anybody's guess whether these contemporary immigrants are more unwelcomed than my Eastern European ancestors were a century ago.
Lately, radio talk show hosts have taken to spouting off about the Third Worldism they claim is ruining the United States. And they don't mean to be taken figuratively. They object to the immigration of these peoples, claiming that the United States has lost its place as No. 1 in everything except the number of immigrants - legal and otherwise. 
The images these critics stir up are designed to be disturbing: from thousands of shiftless illegals selling drugs to formerly wholesome American children, to unscrupulous sweat shop and agricultural laborers working on the cheap, intent on stealing jobs from all the law-abiding real Americans. No wonder our country is going downhill, they try to convince us; look what we're dealing with.
There is a dramatic shift in American demographics under way, and it does speak volumes about what is happening to our native population. But I believe our country will be only the better for this. Pulling into a gas station anywhere on the Post Road, for example, can be inspiring: they all seem to be operated by Arabs, Caribbean Islanders and Indians. And it's much the same on Interstate 95, and on the Merritt Parkway, where almost every pump is manned by South Americans. And so it goes in fast food shops, in emergency rooms and behind the counters of shopping malls throughout the nation.
''At least there's some people left who work for a living,'' a friend of mine said when we discussed the issue. ''You wouldn't find my neighbor's kid being bothered. He's always stoned or drunk. Or even my neighbor, for that matter. He had a big lawsuit against his company and retired on disability when he was 40, and that must have been 20 years ago.''
It's odd that the same observations that depress our immigration worriers so much, make me so optimistic. They may choose to misinterpret sluggish or surly service as further evidence of imminent national catastrophe, but I try to look at the larger picture. For in these days of lifelong unemployment, golden parachutes and six-month rehabilitation programs, I thank our 50 stars that at least the newcomers to our country are out there working.
Our immigration naysayers might reconsider their opinions if they postponed their Winnebago wanderings long enough to see what happens in America's parking lots when the work shift changes. Then they'd see how often employer vans gather up our new arrivals and truck them 50 miles or more to their homes in our urban ghettos, and the next morning bring them back to their jobs to serve natives who are evidently free to travel, eat and spend as much time over coffee as they want while others work - for $4 or so an hour and for the privilege of being accused of stealing great jobs from the suburban children of real Americans.
Yes, the average American citizen is not what he used to be just a few years ago, but it's us who have changed for the worse, not the immigrants who still come here, as my great-grandparents did, for a shot at the top. Today, our drugged-out, sotted-down, welfare-sated, pensioned and disabled native populations seems most definitely down for the count - a secret that is no secret at all to our competition. (Asked their impression of Americans in a recent survey, 67 percent of Japanese respondents who have worked in the United States said we were lazy, a diagnosis that comes as a surprise only to those most seriously afflicted.) The immigration worriers would take us back to what they imagine was a happier, more homogeneous generation, one that in fact was neither if they would read American history. The United States has always been an ethnically diverse experiment; consider the Walloons who settled New Amsterdam or the Huguenots who settled near them or the Africans or the native Americans. American homogeneity, in other words, is a myth. This great country, as my friend likes to say, has always been a ''land of broken toys,'' and it is high time we were getting used to it. We're still the country that has taken in more of the huddled masses than any other, and the fact that we continue to do so is a symbol of our strength, not weakness.
In fact, our crazy population pump has kept our blood lines so much in flux, that in three and a half centuries we have not yet produced a face that can be recognized around the world as distinctively American.
Similarly, it may be true that our social traditions are neither as ancient nor exhalted as the European, African and Asian. There is most certainly another side to this: our history does not reek of religious massacres or Holocausts or Inquisitions, which more established societies have produced for the world in obscene variety and great profusion.
So if our drugged-out, burnt-out and pensioned-off native population is really in danger of being replaced by hordes of immigrants, then I may be in favor of it.
It could be that the next Americans will be more sober and industrious, and even optimistic.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Flashback: A Video Tour Of the 80's

BYLINE: By Susan Resnick; Susan Resnick lives in Old Bethpage and is editor of a television channel at Cablevision.

 BODY:
INSERT videotape ''Flashback of the 1980's'' into the skull, between the eyes and the brain. Press play.
1980. Tight designer jeans are hot. President Jimmy Carter requests that American athletes don't attend Moscow Summer Olympics. Mount St. Helens erupts in Washington. In the other Washington, Ronald Reagan is elected the 40th President of the United States. Former Beatle John Lennon is fatally shot outside his New York apartment. Pause. 
1981. Play. 52 American hostages freed from Iran, after being held for 444 days. Space shuttle Columbia goes into space. President Reagan gets shot by a would-be assassin. Federal air-traffic controllers go on strike, and are fired by Reagan. Sandra Day O'Connor appointed first woman Justice on the Supreme Court. Henry Fonda gets an Oscar for ''On Golden Pond.''
1982. Stop. Play. The film ''Gandhi'' sweeps the Oscars. The Equal Rights Amendment is defeated. Barney Clark receives the first permanent artificial heart. Unemployment reaches 10.4 percent. Fast forward rest of the year.
1983. Stop. Play. The world buys millions of copies of Michael Jackson's thriller album, thanks greatly to the gaining popularity of Music Television. OPEC drops its oil prices. Sally Ride is the first woman to travel in space. Every kid had to have a Cabbage Patch doll. The Soviet Union shoots down a Korean airliner, killing all 269 people aboard. A total of 214 marines are killed in Lebanon when a suicidal terrorist blows up their headquarters in Beirut. Hit pause to reflect on these two senseless acts of terrorism. Play. The United States invades Grenada.
1984. Bittersweet year for women. Vanessa Williams crowned first black to become Miss America; she's dethroned after sexually explicit photos of her appear in Penthouse magazine. Democratic candidate Walter Mondale chooses Geraldine Ferraro as his Vice Presidential candidate; there's no female Veep that election, though, as Reagan and Bush win another term. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India assassinated by her own bodyguards. Tina Turner returns to the rock scene and wins the Best Grammy of the Year for her antiromantic ballad ''What's Love Have to Do With It?''
1985. War between Iran and Iraq escalates. Yuppies hit the Pause button to remember your friends at E. F. Hutton, who were fined $2 million for manipulating checking accounts. Play. Live Aid raises $70 million for Africa's poor. Reagan and Russian leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet at a summit.
1986. Space shuttle Challenger explodes, killing six astronauts and Christa McAuliffe, a teacher, aboard. Chernobyl nuclear power plant accident kills 23 in the USSR. AIDS cases are expected to increase tenfold in the five years. Hit Pause. How far have we really gone in science in the 80's? Hit Play. United States officially observes Martin Luther King Day. Securities trader Ivan Boesky is fined $100 million.
1987. Condom ads promote the catch phrase ''Safe Sex.'' Glasnost opens freedom to the Soviet People. ''Baby M'' case awards biological father William Stern all parental rights. The televangelist Jim Bakker resigns as head of the PTL after it is disclosed he has been paying hush money to a former Long Island church secretary, Jessica Hahn. Senator Gary Hart drops out of the Presidential race after he receives some extraspecial ''political support'' from a model, Donna Rice. Wall Street crashes on Black Monday. Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises'' is auctioned for $53 million.
1988. George Bush is elected 41st President of the United States. Unemployment reaches an eight-year low. Radon gas is linked to 13,000 deaths. AIDS reported to be a great threat to heterosexuals. The Rev. Jimmy Swaggert is defrocked by the Assemblies of God Church because of a ''moral failure.'' Reagan and Gorbachev hold a summit in Moscow. Two million South African Blacks strike over a proposed labor law. Mickey Mouse turns 60.
1989. Hurricane Hugo hits the Carolinas and Puerto Rico. A 6.9 earthquake rocks San Francisco. It is the 20th anniversary of Woodstock, man's landing on the moon and Sesame Street. The '60's are revisited with Batman fever, the Rolling Stones tour and peace sign/tie-dye clothes. Beijing student uprising in China. the Webster abortion ruling. The much-loved redhead Lucille Ball dies. Pete Rose makes baseball the new bettor's sport of choice. The Exxon Valdez oil spill despoils the Gulf of Alaska. Tabloid television rules the airwaves.
Click. End of tape.
Stop. rewind. Stop.
Eject.
Insert blank tape.
Welcome to the '90's.

LENGTH: 1532 words

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: JOEL J. FLAX;
When Push Comes to Shove: Dealing With Runaway Youth

BYLINE: By STEVE VIUKER

 BODY:
SINCE April 1979, Joel J. Flax of Freeport has been executive director of the Runaway Youth Coordinating Council, a tax-exempt, nonprofit organization supported by the Nassau County Youth Board, the State Division for Youth and the United States Department of Health and Human Services.
Before, Mr. Flax was executive director of the Middle Earth Crisis Counseling and Referral Center, a full-service, Nassau County-based volunteer organization.
Mr. Flax, who was born in Brooklyn on Nov. 10, 1948, attended Nassau Community College from 1967 through 1968.
Q. What is the usual reason a youngster will come to you?
A. Maltreatment represents about 80 percent of the reasons. Lack of communication within the family and school problems are other reasons for kids to run away and ultimately seek our help. 
Q. What forms do maltreatment take?
A. Being locked up with no food, denied access to the outside world, physically and/or sexually abused, neglected and, in some cases, verbally abused.
Q. What about reports of teen drug and alcohol use on the rise?
A. I read a report that said it was down, but statistics are almost irrelevant. The problem does exist, and it really doesn't matter to me if it's more or less usage. In fact, most kids who come to us don't have that problem. Many times, it is the parents who have a drug or alcohol problem.
Q. What percentage of calls are from potential suicides?
A. Not very many. Over the years, I would say that only a handful could be identified as suicidal crisis calls. That doesn't mean that the person hasn't contemplated suicide in the past or that the situation, if it were to continue, might lead to suicide. The suicide rate for runaways is extremely high.
Q. There has been an increase in runaway youth of 400 percent over the past decade. Why?
A. The economic situation in the country has put an increasing strain on families, and that has led to a greater number of homeless and runaway people. Not all the homeless are mentally ill or alcoholics. Many are single mothers or children.
Q. How was your organization founded?
A. It was founded by people associated with the Nassau County Youth Board, Middle Earth and Walkabout, a shelter for boys. Our staff totals four, including two social workers, and we operate on a yearly budget of about $250,000. Our funding is supplemented by private donations.
Q. Did the Reagan budget cuts hurt your organization?
A. Our funding has actually increased over the last eight years. But the total budget for runaways in this country is only $25 million, and that figure easily slips through the bureaucracy. In fact, Nassau County cut off funding by $100,000 in 1988 and we recouped $20,000 of that from the Federal Government. We weren't sure of our survival for a while.
Q. Is the runaway problem different in the suburbs?
A. The degree of danger is greater in urban areas, but not the fact of that danger. A runaway is subject to more danger in urban areas. It used to be that runaways could sleep in railroad stations, but the stations are now being locked at night. Airports have become popular because they operate 24 hours a day, and you always have people around.
Q. DO you take the side of the child in a dispute? How are they involved in a dispute?
A. No. All we have to start with is an allegation. To assume that a person is guilty because of an allegation is just unfair. It isn't that the child is lying, but he or she is telling us the problem from one perspective. The parents have their side.
In many instances, one or both parents were themselves victims of an abusive cycle and are now responding in the only way they know how. If we tell the parents they are wrong, they won't want to have anything to do with us and we have not done our job.
We listen to both sides and offer to mediate, arbitrate or just open new lines of communication.
Q. Does abuse by a teacher or counselor surprise you?
A. Not at all. That has been going on for a long time. There is a raised consciousness among the press to publish those cases. But if you wanted to abuse children, you would go where children are.
You wouldn't be ugly and disgusting. You would be personable, friendly and have adults trust you. But most abuse that occurs is from people the child knows.
Q. Do Nassau and Suffolk Counties differ in caring for runaways?
A. Nassau has three components of its runaway system. One is a runaway 'hot line,' another is an emergency shelter called Nassau Haven and then there is our program. We primarily do counseling and family work services for troubled youths 10 to 21 years old.
In Suffolk, each town provides its own runaway program, and that program is funded by the county, state and Federal governments.
Q. What is the demographic makeup of your client base?
A. Kids from every type of family situation, and from all parts of Long Island, come to us. Runaways come out of families, and rich and poor people are families. Nearly 40 percent of our clients are Afro-American, 5 percent are of Hispanic background and a small percentge are Asian.
Q. Are many of these runaways out of school and pumping gas?
A. The vast majority of runaways are underachievers. If they are in school, they are usually having problems, but in most instances they are not pumping gas for a living. In many cases, these kids don't have a job.
For a county like Nassau, where education is supposed to be important, there is a large percentage of kids who have not finished high school or even junior high.
Q. Since the Island has a reputation for a high quality of life, why are there so many problems?
A. First of all, you must define quality of life. One survey put Nassau at fifth in the nation, but another had it 15th and still another had the county in the 30's. Although the income level on Long Island is high and there are numerous educational opportunities available, Nassau and Suffolk also have very high per capita taxes.
It is very hard for a young person to make a start on the Island. A study pointed out that 75 percent of the kids who leave Nassau County to attend college do not return to continue their adult lives. That is a startling and frightening statistic.
The two counties also have a poor public transportation system, and that fact makes a car a necessity. There are service jobs available, but what about a job where a kid can earn a living wage? A wage that would allow a young person to buy a house and have a life.
Schools are beginning to recognize this, and some have instituted experimental programs to train kids for the real world.
Q. Are you seeing more runaways with crack habits and AIDS?
A. Crack may be used as a quick way to make money, but drugs are not a major problem with the kids we see. As for AIDS, we may see an increase in another five years or so.
Q. Have you ever had to deal with a hopeless case?
A. I've never felt that you can't solve a problem. There are times when you must work within limitations and you wish that the outcome could have been better.
But you try to find something in every case that can be a positive. If nothing else, a youth-crisis organization can be a support system that the kid can turn to.
Q. Did you ever run away from home as a child?
A. Yes, but only for a couple of hours at a time. But I wasn't aware of terms like child abuse back then. But I did have family problems that still exist, and I suppose that is one reason why I am involved in this field.
Q. Are you better able to advise because of your upbringing?
A. Not always. I don't always see the runaways' problem as being my problem.
Q. What is your organization's success rate in regard to reuniting a runaway with his or her family?
A. We don't define returning a child to his or her family as necessarily a success. It may be that the child has no other option but to return home. Success is defined as whether we met the needs of the child and the family, whatever they were.
Q. Can you define a throwaway case?
A. A throwaway is someone who has such an intolerable situation at home that he or she must leave. It can also be a case where the parents literally push a kid out the door and say that things are tough.
Q. Can the isolation of suburbia hurt a youngster?
A. There are people who grew up on Long Island and have never been to New York City. There are people who grew up in suburban Philadelphia and never made it to the city. The cities are big, scary places. Many kids run away, but most stay within two miles of their home.
Q. Were you surprised that the recent mass murders in Montreal were committed by an abused male?
A. Not at all. The Public Broadcasting System did a show in which mass murderers were interviewed. All had been abused as children.
Q. Is it tougher growing up now than it was 20 years ago?
A. I don't know. In the 1960's, we had to worry about airplane glue, heroin and whether we would be wiped out by a nuclear holocaust. I've always felt that each era is different and that you can't compare them.
But many kids today do feel that they may not have a future. There is a feeling of hopelessness and helplessness.

LENGTH: 928 words

HEADLINE: $500 Million Budget Question Waits in the Wings for Florio

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
ON Jan. 16, James J. Florio will take the oath of office as New Jersey's 49th governor, lead a parade in the state capital and celebrate at an inaugural ball. It could be the last chance for Mr. Florio to smile for several months.
Within weeks of taking office, Mr. Florio will deliver his first budget to the Legislature and could face the task of dealing with a projected deficit of $500 million in the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
The exact size of the fiscal problem has not been outlined. State officials are awaiting the sales-tax collections from the holiday shopping season, hoping for a shot in the arm that could ease a yearlong slump in tax revenues. 
New Jersey is not facing as serious a problem as other states in the Northeast, and the departing Governor, Thomas H. Kean, is sticking to his prediction that the current fiscal year will close on June 30 with a reserve of $250 million on hand.
The looming problem stems from the fact the budget contains built-in escalators for items like state aid to education. If revenue continues to drop below expectations, it will not be possible to meet the constitutional mandate for a balanced budget without raising taxes or cutting services.
In his election campaign, Mr. Florio, a Democrat, said he saw no reason to raise taxes, and he will be pressed to exhaust all possible economies before looking at increased revenues.
Mr. Kean, a Republican, said any increase in the income tax would hurt the state's ability to attract businesses and hold on to ones already here. He said it would be possible to increase the so-called sin taxes on alcoholic beverages and tobacco and on activities like interstate telephone service and still remain competitive with surrounding states that have higher taxes on those businesses.
Richard Roper, executive director of the Council for New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University, said, ''It seems to me Florio will face a real tough first year, given what has been reported thus far about a budget shortage.''
''Expectations that he would come into office with some new policy initiatives are clearly not going to be realized,'' he continued. ''And not only is it unlikely that he will find funds for new programs, he will have to spend most of his time finding the money to shore up efforts that have been put in place over the last eight years.''
The beginning of Mr. Florio's administration is remarkably similar to Mr. Kean's first few months in office in 1982. Mr. Kean found a $600 million deficit awating him, and with the recession that arrived that year, the shortfall approached $1 billion. The state's Economic Policy Council said last month that New Jersey stands a better chance of slipping into a recession this year than the country as a whole.
Mr. Kean and the Democratic-controlled Legislature enacted increases in the income and sales taxes to close the gap in 1982 and meet a State Supreme Court mandate for increased state spending on public schools.
When the economy turned around, these higher tax rates produced a windfall that enabled the state to assume about $1 billion in program costs passed along to the state by Reagan Administration policies and to pay for a growth in spending that saw the state budget double, to $12 billion, in Mr. Kean's eight years in office.
Mr. Florio becomes the state's new chief executive with a promise to solve some of the state's pressing problems, including high automobile-insurance premiums and environmental pollution. He has a panel working on the insurance problem and plans to appoint an environmental prosecutor to crack down on polluters.
The one requirement, members of the transition team said, for any new initiative is that it not entail increased state spending, at least until the current crisis passes.
Mr. Florio said that he still intended to go ahead with his promised outside audit of the state government, but that he did not expect it to be completed before the end of the year. He said, however, he hoped it would point the way to possible economies before it is completed.
There is a freeze on hiring and on such items as leasing or buying state cars and awarding contracts. In addition, Mr. Florio has postponed anticipated pay increases for himself, members of his cabinet and the judiciary until next year and said that if the state's economy is still in trouble, the raises might be delayed again.
The incoming Governor's plan to centralize decision making in a new governor's office of his own design and to coordinate the efforts of various departments in focusing on problem solving has been upstaged by the fiscal problems.
Mr. Florio's staff says he is emphasizing a horizontal rather than a vertical view of state government. Instead of agencies' operating independently of one another, Mr. Florio would like to work on issues with teams of high officials' crossing departmental lines. But when he announced his first six cabinet appointees at three news conferences, the questions by reporters always focused more on the economy and the budget than on the new cabinet members.
Last week Mr. Florio announced a few additional cabinet appointees, accomplishing this by circulating press releases and avoiding any contacts with reporters. Beyond saying that the frequent briefings by the Kean administration on the state's economy had been sobering and that he would not have the necessary information to strike his budget much before next month's deadline, the new Governor has kept his own counsel on what he might propose to meet the fiscal squeeze.

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 4, Column 6; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 832 words

HEADLINE: Kean Reflects On Era

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
GOV. THOMAS H. KEAN became New Jersey's most familiar chief executive during his eight years in office.
His easy manner was made for television, much to the chagrin of his political opponents, and on Tuesday at 10 P.M., the New Jersey Network will broadcast a taped hourlong interview with the departing 48th Governor that enabled him to talk about how the job looked from his vantage point.
Mr. Kean said a chief executive could easily lose touch with reality, what with state troopers driving him everywhere, a helicopter waiting for him, people standing up when he enters a room and someone always on hand to do his bidding. 
The person who could be counted on to bring him back to earth, the Governor said, is his wife, Debby. ''She'll tell me to take out the garbage,'' he said, adding that when he asked her recently to obtain a telephone number, ''she said, 'I'm not your secretary.' ''
It was Mrs. Kean who attended all the school plays, soccer games and recitals for their three children when he could not be there.
When they were younger, the children had trouble understanding that their father could not attend all their school functions, Mr. Kean said, even though he wanted to.
 
'I Had a Funny Job'
''I told them I had a funny job,'' he said. ''And if they wanted me to attend, they had to tell me what was going to happen two or three months in advance.''
Because he wanted to spend as much time as possible with his family, Mr. Kean called his decision to live at home in Livingston and forgo the governor's mansion, Drumthwacket in Princeton Township, ''the best decision I ever made as governor.''
Mr. Kean entered office in the midst of one economic downturn and will leave on Jan. 16 in another. In the program, ''A Conversation With Governor Kean,'' Kent Manahan, the anchor for the nightly news program on the public-television network, touches on the major issues, the gains and the failures of Mr. Kean's two terms.
Much of the interview was used in an earlier program, ''The State House Years,'' in which Mr. Kean's critics and supporters also gave their views of the man and his career.
 
Familiar Criticisms
There are no independent voices in the program, although Ms. Manahan raises all the familiar criticisms of Mr. Kean in her questions: that he was lucky that most of his term was in good economic times, that he was not aggressive enough in fighting for his programs and that he has failed to support tax reform.
Mr. Kean said the sound economy helped, but said he used the added state income to reduce business taxes and provide a healthy business climate that is enabling New Jersey to weather the current slump better than other states in the Northeast. New Jersey is the only state east of the Mississippi with an AAA bond rating, he said.
He said he was as aggressive as he had to be when fighting for issues like a bill to take over failing schools, but said he did not like applying pressure and preferred to rely on persuasion rather than arm-twisting.
He said it took a year and a half before he was able to persuade some legislators that he would not trade jobs, judgeships or prosecutor appointments for their votes on legislation.
He summed up much of the job of governor as ''trying to persuade people to do things which are right, that they ought to know enough to do without your persuading them.''
Tax reform, he said, is too often used as a euphemism for raising the income tax, calling such a move deadly.
''People like to demagogue the issue and say we should tax the rich,'' Mr. Kean said. ''Hey, the rich will move and they will take their companies with them. That's what happened in other states.''
Mr. Kean said he was ''proudest of the fact that I think we have changed the way people think about the state and the way they think about themselves.''
''We used to be in the shadow of some pretty big neighbors,'' he said, ''but we're not in anyone's shadow anymore.''
He said his biggest failures were in not obtaining meaningful legislation to reduce automobile-insurance premiums or to create a coastal commission to control oceanfront growth.
Mr. Kean said his coastal initiative failed ''because the Legislature was overtly sensitive to special interests looking for profits.'' He said that in the election year just ended the Legislature decided it would rather have ''the campaign contributions of the builders than a clean coast.''
The Governor also discussed why he would never run against Senator Bill Bradley. ''It would be impossible for me,'' he said, ''to run against a friend, and to run against a friend that I also respect a great deal.''
Mr. Kean said he doubted that he would run again for office, but said ''maybe'' about considering a public appointment ''down the road.''
For the present, he is looking forward to his new job as president of Drew University. ''It's a chance,'' he said, ''to think, to write, to talk to young people and to be reinvigorated by their idealism.''
