PUB-DATE: January 8, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1186 words

HEADLINE: REDUCED TAX RATE ON CAPITAL GAINS WIDELY EXPECTED

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
A lower capital gains tax rate, one of President Bush's top legislative priorities, will almost certainly be enacted this year, Administration officials and Congressional leaders say.
The Democratic leaders who fought the capital gains proposals in the fall more or less concede that they do not have the votes to block them again.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader who successfully led the fight against the legislation, said his goal now is to see that whatever capital gains measure is passed encourages investment in small business ventures and does not worsen the budget deficit.
 
Decisions on Details
What is still up in the air, the politicians say, is what the rate will be and how it will be applied. 
Will the new rate be a constant one or vary according to how long an asset is held?
Will the lower rate be allowed on profits from the sale of all kinds of investments or will some be excluded?
Will it be applied only to newly purchased assets or will investments already owned be eligible for a lower tax rate?
Those questions will be at the top of the slate when Congress reconvenes late this month to receive President Bush's budget, which will include his capital gains proposal, and to hear his State of the Union address.
 
Early Hearings Planned
The House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee, the Congressional panels that handle tax measures, are planning hearings early in the new session.
The legislation could move quickly, the leaders say, or it could take all year, depending on how some important political questions are resolved.
Among those questions are what Congressional Democrats will seek in return for their votes for a capital gains cut and whether the bill will serve as a vehicle for those pleading for other tax breaks.
Capital gains are the profits earned from the sale of investments like stocks, bonds and real estate.
Until 1987, gains on assets held more than six months were taxed at a lower rate than other income, like wages, interest and dividends. In 1986, the top capital gains rate was 20 percent; the top rate on other income was 50 percent. The theory was that the lower rate encouraged investments, helped the economy and reduced the effect of inflation on long-term investments.
In the name of equity, the Tax Reform Act of 1986, the most sweeping overhaul of the tax code since World War II, applied the same tax rate to capital gains as to other income.
The law also cut the income tax rate of the wealthiest taxpayers almost in half, to 28 percent. The prevailing argument was that the overall rate reduction more than made up for the elimination of a capital gains differential.
By far most capital gains are earned by the well-to-do. The Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation has estimated that 60 percent of the benefits from a lower rate will go to the two-tenths of 1 percent of taxpayers with incomes over $200,000 and that 80 percent will go to the 1 percent with incomes over $100,000.
 
Republican Dogma
A lower capital gains rate has long been a part of Republican dogma, and President Bush made it a central element of his 1988 election campaign. On taking office last year, he proposed a top capital gains rate of 15 percent. The proposal was limited to profits from the sale of stocks and bonds, excluding those from real estate, timber and other investments, and limited the full benefit to those who held assets for at least three years. The proposal would exclude collectibles, like antiques, and depreciable assets from the favorable treatment.
In the House of Representatives, many Democrats broke ranks and provided a large majority for a measure that would have cut the rate to 19.6 percent, 70 percent of the 28 percent rate, through 1991, and would have applied the break to almost all investments.
Much of the political pressure behind the legislation came from timber and real estate interests.
When the bill reached the Senate late in the session, Democratic leaders filibustered and made the issue a matter of party loyalty. Although supporters of a capital gains cut had 51 votes, a bare majority, 60 votes are needed to overcome a filibuster and the measure died.
 
Lacking the Votes
It would be difficult to sustain such a filibuster for an entire year. Furthermore, the leaders say the new measure is not likely to make the cut merely temporary.
''It's a popular thing,'' Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the Ways and Means Committee chairman, said of a capital gains cut. ''I'm not going to be out there alone again.''
Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee, said he had ''no problem with capital gains in theory'' but was determined to produce a measure that did not lose revenue in the long run.
''I'm deeply interested in putting together a package on savings incentives, and part of that is obviously capital gains,'' Mr. Bentsen continued. Part of the package, he said, should be an expansion of partly tax-deductible individual retirement accounts. Finding the money for the two will be a problem, he acknowledged.
Mr. Rostenkowski suggested, as he has for years, that money be raised by increasing the Federal gasoline tax.
But Mr. Bentsen said he would oppose that. ''A gas tax is fine if you're from an urban Congressional district, but not if you're from a state with substantial rural areas such as Texas,'' he said.
Instead, Mr. Bentsen said, he hoped lawmakers could strike a deal with President Bush ''where we walk the plank together and take the political hits together.''
The President, however, has shown no inclination for raising taxes. The prospect of larger reductions in military spending than were anticipated a few months ago makes it even less likely that Mr. Bush will accept a tax increase to meet deficit targets, Administration officials said.
Expressing confidence that they would win this year, the officials said the capital gains proposal in the President's budget would be modified from the one last year. To widen political support, they said, Mr. Bush would propose extending the capital gains break to timber and real estate and would set the maximum rate somewhat above 15 percent but below 20 percent.
 
Narrower Proposals
Congressional tax experts are working on proposals narrower than the Administration's. They are considering, for example, excluding from the lower rate the profits from investments bought before the beginning of this year. They are also considering a sliding scale, so rates would fall the longer investments were held, and imposing a transaction tax to discourage rapid turnovers of investments. Those ideas would reduce the long-term cost of a lower capital gains tax.
Experts agree that a lower capital gains tax would raise revenues a bit in the first year as taxpayers rushed to take advantage of the new rate.
The Administration maintains that the cost will not be high in the following years, but most Congressional analysts and many outside economists project an eventual cost of many billions of dollars a year.

HEADLINE: Cambodia Emerges - After the Vietnamese Occupation.;
Phnom Penh, Eye on West, Tries To Shed Image as Hanoi Puppet

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia

 BODY:
Since the announced withdrawal of Vietnamese occupation troops in September, the Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen has taken a number of steps to establish Cambodia as a nation reviving politically and economically, ready to change to get rid of its image as a puppet regime. The goal is to gain increased international recognition, especially in the West.
In perhaps the most important change, the Government, under attack by United States-backed rebels, has tried to broaden its base by including many people who served in the non-Communist Governments of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Lon Nol in the 1960's and 1970's.
In addition, Phnom Penh is discarding socialist dogma in favor of free-market economic principles, now on display at hundreds of privately owned shops throughout the capital.
 
U.S. Supports Guerrillas
Washington has no diplomatic relations with the Government here, which it describes as a ''puppet regime'' installed by Vietnamese Army invaders in January 1979. The United States supports a guerrilla coalition - composed of the Khmer Rouge, which ruled the country from 1975 to 1978, and two non-Communist factions - that is trying to unseat Mr. Hun Sen. 
Kung Sam Ol, an alumnus of the University of Georgia who now serves as a Deputy Prime Minister of Cambodia, said the characterization of the Government as a puppet regime was ''out of date.''
Cambodian officials say Vietnam has withdrawn all its troops.
While expressing gratitude to Hanoi for having rescued them from the Khmer Rouge, Cambodians say the historic animosity between the two peoples would make it impossible for the Vietnamese to establish a permanent presence here.
Cambodian officials repeatedly affirmed their intention to hold national elections in 1990 or early 1991, and they said they would welcome observers from the United States and other countries.
Chhang Song, a naturalized American citizen who recently concluded a visit here, has emerged as a pivotal figure in Cambodian politics and as a crucial link to the West for a nation ostracized by most Western governments.
He urged the Phnom Penh Government to hold elections monitored by Western observers who could assess their fairness. In discussions with Cambodian officials, he also encouraged the formation of an opposition party.
Mr. Chhang Song, who served as Cambodia's Information Minister from 1973 to 1975, in the American-backed government of Lon Nol, said the current Government was receptive to his suggestions.
Dozens of interviews with Cambodian officials, people on the street, shopkeepers, students, prisoners of war and foreign diplomats here produced these findings:
* The Government is accepted as legitimate in most of Cambodia. There is no sign that it will collapse without the support of Vietnamese troops, as some American officials had predicted. Foreign investors and foreign governments in many Western countries express a growing desire to do business with Cambodia. Singapore and Thailand are already actively trading with Cambodia, and Australians have shown interest in developing economic ties.
* Except in three provinces along the Thai border, where there has been fierce fighting, security is not a major problem. Cambodians and foreign visitors can move about freely and talk with anyone they want. The guerrillas say they have made substantial gains in hit-and-run operations over the last three months. Cambodian military officials express little concern about the two non-Communist guerrilla armies supported by the United States - the Khmer People's National Liberation Front led by former Prime Minister Son Sann and a group loyal to Prince Sihanouk - but warn that those armies provide cover for the Communist Khmer Rouge to send infiltrators deep into Cambodia.
* Growing numbers of people who served in the non-Communist Governments of Prince Sihanouk and Mr. Lon Nol, as well as people who went to school in those years, now hold positions of power and influence in Cambodia. These men and women, many of whom were trained in Europe or the United States, suffer no apparent discrimination because of their background. Mr. Hun Sen estimates that people who served under Prince Sihanouk and Mr. Lon Nol now account for more than half of his Cabinet.
* The Government is rapidly reducing state control of the economy and is permitting private ownership of land and other property. It initially tolerated the development of private enterprise and open markets and now encourages them on the ground that they are more efficient than state-owned industries, which still produce textiles and steel, for example. Cambodian officials and Europeans who work for humanitarian organizations here estimate that 30 percent of the economy is controlled by the Government, while 70 percent is privately held.
* Local editors and journalists say Cambodian newspapers now openly criticize the Government, publishing evidence of official corruption, nepotism, police brutality and other abuses. In the last year, members of the National Assembly have also become more independent and assertive in criticizing the Government.
 
U.S. Policy
Calls for Change Across Spectrum
In the United States Congress, liberal Democrats like Senator Alan Cranston of California and Representative Chester G. Atkins of Massachusetts have denounced the Bush Administration for supporting Prince Sihanouk and his demand that the Khmer Rouge have a role in an interim coalition government. Now some American conservatives are also calling for a change in policy.
Michael J. Horowitz, a conservative Republican who served in the Reagan Administration and visited Cambodia with Mr. Chhang Song, said: ''The reality I see here is profoundly different from the conventional wisdom described to me in Washington by American officials. I see strong support for private property, open markets and internationally supervised elections.''
Mr. Horowitz said American policy toward Cambodia, already subject to criticism by liberals, needed to be scrutinized by American conservatives, particularly in the light of ''its deference to the demands of China,'' the chief supporter of the Khmer Rouge.
If the Phnom Penh Government continues to move toward internationally supervised elections, he said, ''I cannot see any basis for U.S. isolation of Cambodia and for U.S. support of China and Prince Sihanouk, who has always followed China's line.''
For more than a decade, some American officials have viewed Cambodia as a battleground for a proxy war between Moscow and Beijing in which China deserved American support.
The charge d'affaires at the Indian Embassy here, Rinzing Wangdi, said: ''There is a widespread perception that, as a result of the Vietnam syndrome, you in the United States have allowed China to be the steering wheel of American policy in this region.''
In early 1989, the State Department said there were ''widespread abuses of human rights in Cambodia'' stemming from its occupation by Vietnamese troops and from an indigenous Communist ''civil-military control apparatus.''
There is disagreement among Western human rights groups about Phnom Penh's record, and the Government says it is trying to make arrangements for human-rights observers to inspect prisons and assess the situation.
Chea Sim, an influential official who serves as chairman of the National Assembly and chairman of the United Front for the Construction and Defense of Cambodia, said he was concerned about reports of human-rights abuses in Cambodia and acknowledged that some had occurred. In an interview, he said such violations did not represent ''the policy of the regime.''
''We are taking stringent measures to correct the abuses,'' he declared, saying the Government was training soldiers in the proper treatment of prisoners and clarifying the penalties for violations.
 
Pol Pot's Legacy
'We Cannot Forget' The Crimes
Eleven years after Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge were removed from power, their legacy pervades all aspects of politics and family life in Cambodia.
Nearly everyone has a personal story of suffering and loss, of parents, children or siblings killed by the Khmer Rouge, who presided over a brutal restructuring of society in which more than a million people died from April 1975 to January 1979.
The Khmer Rouge is the strongest of the three guerrilla factions. Western diplomats often discuss its participation in a coalition government as a theoretical possibility. But most Cambodians do not even entertain the idea.
The national resolve is summarized in an inscription at Choeung Ek, a village on the outskirts of Phnom Penh, where the Khmer Rouge ran an extermination camp.
''The people of Cambodia always inscribe themselves with this suffering and wrath against the genocidal and criminal clique of Pol Pot and Ieng Sary,'' says a sign at a pagoda filled with hundreds of skulls. ''We cannot forget it. We are absolutely determined not to let this genocidal regime reoccur in Kampuchea.''
Phnom Penh is still an isolated third world capital with few telephones and inadequate electric power. It is under a 9 P.M. curfew, designed to prevent infiltration by guerrillas.
But the city, which was reduced to a ghost town by the Khmer Rouge, shows new signs of vitality.
In the last year, several movie theaters have opened. Seventy-five private companies now produce and sell videos. The Government has just abolished the official exchange rate, allowing the private market to decide the proper number of riels to the dollar.
In addition, the Government has lifted rules that required foreigners to live in a few designated apartment buildings, and it has eliminated restrictions on contacts between Cambodians and citizens of other countries.
In the National Assembly, legislators have accused Government officials of nepotism, graft and corruption.
Kung Sam Ol said the Government was worried about such charges and was trying to weed out corrupt officials.
 
Signs of Change
A Looser Hand On the Economy
Dozens of posters have sprouted up in Phnom Penh offering instruction in the English language, which is more popular than French among students in this former French colony.
''In the near future, we will have English courses on television,'' Mr. Hun Sen said.
Cambodian officials boast that they had ''tropical perestroika'' before the Soviet Union began to restructure its economy. ''If we had wanted to prevent a free-market economy, it would have been very easy for us to do so,'' Mr. Hun Sen said in an interview. ''It is now the policy of the Government to encourage further opening of the market.''
Asked whether such an approach was consistent with Marxism, Nguon Nhel, the Communist Party chief for the city of Phnom Penh, said, ''If people enjoy prosperity, I don't think we are deviating from Marxism.''
Cambodian officials said there was much less official control of the economy now than in the Sihanouk era, when the Government controlled such industries as rubber, sugar, jute and glass, as well as foreign trade.
Cambodians say they are mystified by American policy toward their country.
''Nobody understands why there has been this vindictivess and punishment toward Cambodia since Pol Pot was deposed,'' said Long Visalo, a Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs.
On one hand, Washington says the Khmer Rouge must never return to power. On the other hand, Cambodian officials note, the United States supports the two non-Communist factions loosely aligned with the Khmer Rouge against Phnom Penh.
The nominal leader of the guerrilla coalition, Prince Sihanouk, has argued that the Khmer Rouge should have a role in any transition government, and the United States has acquiesced in his demand, saying it ''went along with his judgment.''
''Why does the United States support the Khmer Rouge in this way?'' asks Kung Sam Ol, the Deputy Prime Minister. ''It is because of your friendship with China.''
 
Charting the Future
Plan for Elections And an Old Culture
Representatives of the Cambodian Government and the three rebel factions plan to meet soon in Jakarta, Indonesia, to see if they can agree on a formula for elections and a political settlement.
Cambodian officials say they are determined to hold elections even if there is no agreement on such a formula.
Prince Sihanouk, often described as the father of Cambodia's independence and a symbol of national unity, has not indicated if he would return to his homeland to take part in elections.
The Prince, who was overthrown in 1970, is remembered with nostalgia by some older Cambodians. But they account for a dwindling proportion of the population.
People of all ages said they were dismayed by his continuing association with the Khmer Rouge.
Prince Sihanouk's cousin, Lyda Sisowath, who supports the current Government, said, ''The old generation is dying off, and to many young people, Sihanouk is only history.''
While trying to rebuild their country, Cambodian officials have made assiduous efforts to rediscover and revive their ancient culture, devastated by the Khmer Rouge.
No man has done more to salvage the arts than Chheng Phon, the Minister of Information and Culture. ''Ninety percent of the artists, dancers, and musicians were destroyed by Pol Pot,'' he said in an interview. ''Everything was uprooted. Now we must replant.''
He has tried to preserve the stylized classical dance even though it was closely associated with the royal court.

HEADLINE: The Man Who Saved the Subways

 BODY:
When David Gunn took over as president of the New York City Transit Authority six years ago, the subway system was a municipal embarrassment, a shabby symbol of a city in decline. As he leaves there is broad agreement that it has staged a remarkable recovery. That's a proud legacy. 
Mr. Gunn arrived in New York City two years after approval of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's five-year, $6 billion capital spending plan. Shortly after his arrival, a new bus, one of a fleet financed by the Federal mass-transit agency and made by a subsidiary of New York's Grumman Corporation, caught fire.
The public sensed steel in Mr. Gunn's decision, over vigorous Washington opposition, to stop using any such Grumman buses. He would run the shambling, economically underfed New York systems his way: safety first.
Besides leadership, he brought a contagious enthusiasm, fascination with transit intricacies, and the shrewd ability to focus simultaneously on a whole problem and its details. Even while rationalizing the awkward command structure of the T.A., Mr. Gunn needed to put new equipment to work and revamp maintenance systems. He knew that it would take a long time to create visible progress while new equipment came to one line at a time. So to demonstrate his determination in the meantime, he took on what many had written off as a lost cause: subway graffiti. Mr. Gunn pioneered the use of solvents to clean cars, protected cars in storage yards, and ordered daily removal of graffiti in order to deny the destructive ''artists'' their exposure. Before long he won a clear-cut victory and strong public support.
He leaves, for personal reasons, two years after the approval of a second $6 billion capital plan. He is quick to agree that the transit system remains imperfect. It remains plagued by fare collection delays, turnstile jumping and encamped armies of the homeless. And the equipment improvements that have rescued major lines lag on those less traveled. The public continues to resist necessary route changes and fare increases.
Yet there is no denying the basic achievement: David Gunn gave New Yorkers a better transit system - and hope that skill, money and public support can solve daunting problems.

HEADLINE: U.S. Mustn't Stop Insisting on Trade Fairness;
Bad Press for Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your report that Japanese real estate deals in New York City are breeding jokes and anger (news article, Dec. 18) makes me once again amazed and dismayed at the paranoia Americans have about the Japanese presence in this country and how the press continues to single them out and feed upon this paranoia.
Why is it that when a Canadian company such as the Campeau Corporation buys a well-known ''trophy,'' such as Bloomingdale's, along with the chain that owns Abraham & Straus and Jordan Marsh, and then proceeds to run them so far into the ground that they may have to go bankrupt and put thousands of Americans out of work, no one says a word.
Nor did anyone say a word when an Australian company, L. J. Hooker, bought the chain that owns Bonwit Teller and B. Altman, and also ran them into the ground. 
However, when the press got wind that perhaps some Japanese companies might be interested in purchasing Bloomingdale's, thus saving those thousands of American jobs, the headlines once again were that the Japanese were buying up America and our national treasures. Buried deep within that report, it was mentioned that the chairman of Bloomingdale's, Marvin Traub, actually went to Japan in search of investors.
How many of our average citizens know that before Mitsubishi bought its interest in Rockefeller Group that the Rockefellers offered several American companies the opportunity to buy, but all turned it down. It was then that the Rockefellers pursued Mitsubishi, not the other way around.
Many foreign companies in New York own far more real estate than Japanese companies do. Olympia & York, a Canadian company, is considered one of the largest owners of New York property, including the World Financial Center. London & Leeds and HRO, both English companies, own numerous buildings in New York. I could cite German, French, Spanish and Taiwanese ownership not only of American real estate, but of American businesses as well.
I think it is time for everyone to hear the other side of the Japanese real estate story, a side that hardly gets any attention. Yet the sheer number of the transactions involved dwarfs the dollar value of all the highly publicized acquisitions.
That other side is the Japanese as tenants. Almost 2,000 Japanese companies occupy office and warehouse space in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut area alone, with more than 8,000 Japanese companies nationwide.
The vast majority of these companies do not own the space they are in, but rent it, mostly from American owners. There are numerous Japanese trading companies, banks and insurance companies that occupy multiple floors in some of our most prestigious office towers. These are dollars that flow into this country from Japan and end up in American pockets. These companies also hire mostly American staffs.
All of this bodes well for the New York metropolitan area, especially in light of recent contractions in the financial community, the downturn in our economy and the general softness of the real estate market.
Rather than focus on perceived negatives, we should concentrate on the positive contributions the Japanese make to our country, its people and economy.
 
JEFFREY A. LANDERS
White Plains, Dec. 20, 1989
 The writer heads a commercial real estate company.

HEADLINE: In Chile, Economic and Political Success Go Hand in Hand;
Tell the Whole Truth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As historians and journalists should know, a partial truth can be an untruth; half the story is not the whole story. Thus, your ''history'' of the military coup against Salvador Allende (front page, Dec. 15) is both bad history and bad journalism. You describe the military coup that brought Augusto Pinochet to power in Chile this way: ''with the country in economic chaos as the result of strikes, inflation, property confiscations and shortages, the armed forces took power with broad public support.''
You omit the role of the United States, managed by the Central Intelligence Agency and the National Security Council, in creating that economic chaos (for example, by denying Chile access to international credit and embargoing copper, Chile's main export). The United States also secretly paid for work stoppages and strikes and supported opposition to Allende by covert financing of political parties, news-papers, television and radio stations, to the tune of $8 million.
While the United States labored away at destabilizing the government Chileans had freely elected in 1970, it was strengthening those who would illegally overthrow that government with $15 million in military aid in 1971 and '72.
This information and more is easily available. For starters, see the reports of the United States Senate Intelligence Committee, ''Covert Action in Chile, 1963-73'' and ''Alleged Assassination Plots Involving Foreign Leaders.''
 
JUDITH PAPACHRISTOU
Bronxville, N.Y., Dec. 15, 1989
 The writer is a professor of history at Sarah Lawrence College.

HEADLINE: Violence at Discotheque Mobilizes Neighborhood

BYLINE: By MICHAEL FREITAG

 BODY:
Like many of the people waiting to enter the Underground on Friday night, Yvette Garner knew that three young men, including two bystanders, had been shot in front of the nightclub a week before.
And Ms. Garner, a 21-year-old resident of the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, knew that the shootings, which left two of the men dead and the third seriously injured, were just the latest in a series of violent episodes at the club in recent months. But she was not afraid. ''I don't think it's going to happen two weeks in a row,'' Ms. Garner said as she waited for a friend by the Underground's entrance at 860 Broadway, opposite Union Square in Manhattan. ''And there's never trouble inside. Just out here.'' 
There has been a good deal of trouble outside the two-story, block-long discotheque. In 1989, five people were killed, another eight were injured in stabbings or shootings, and dozens of others - including a group of farmers setting up a stand across the street - were assaulted in or near the Underground, the police said. Patrons of the Underground and spokesmen for the club contend that angry neighbors are using it as a scapegoat for crimes that afflict any urban area. But to a coalition of Union Square residents, shopkeepers, community leaders and politicians, the Underground is a magnet for violence and an impediment to their efforts to rebuild the neighborhood. They want the club closed. ''My wife and I can't go out after 11 at night without a fear of being shot,'' said Mik Cribben, a 42-year-old film maker who lives in a loft on East 17th Street near the club. ''There's an undeniable pattern of violence there that dates back at least three years.''
 
'Focal Point' for the Police
Officer Dennis Ostermann of the 13th Precinct described the Underground as a ''focal point'' for police activity. ''There are definitely more criminal complaints there than at the other clubs in the precinct,'' he said.
On Dec. 30, at 3:30 A.M., a young man who had apparently been ejected from the Underground returned with a gun and fired at a man he had been arguing with inside. The target of the attack was killed, as was a bystander, Stephen H. Pleasants, a 30-year-old paralegal in the Queens District Attorney's office. Another bystander, Richard Lyn-Cook, a 19-year-old sophomore at Yale University, was shot in the head and is partly paralyzed on the left side.
On Oct. 1, Wesley Morales was shot and killed in a fight several blocks from the club. The police believe Mr. Morales and his assailant had just left the club. In February, Keith Headley, 17, was killed by a shotgun blast as he left the club at 3:30 A.M. On Jan. 29, a 23-year-old bouncer, Timothy Lorenzo, was shot in the face and killed in front of the club after an argument with a patron.
And about 6:30 A.M. on Aug. 12, three farmers setting up their stands at the Greenmarket in Union Square Park were beaten by a group of youths who had just left the Underground.
''I can't help but be a little leery about that place,'' said Kenneth R. Hanley, a poultry farmer from Columbus, N.Y., who received 13 stitches in his left ear as a result of the attack. ''The gangs come out of there and flood through the park when we are setting up.'' Mr. Hanley said he still comes to the city at least twice a week.
 
'Absolutely Out of Control'
Although Mr. Cribben and other neighbors had complained about the Underground for nearly a year, it was the attack on the farmers that seemed to get the attention of community leaders and politicians.
''In the last four months, that place has been absolutely out of control,'' said Robert W. Walsh, the executive director of the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation and an informal leader of the coalition opposing the Underground.
Mr. Walsh said he was concerned that the violence would scare away people interested in moving into the neighborhood, which has seen an explosion of economic growth in recent years that coincided with the refurbishing of the park.
Since early December, the coalition, which includes representatives of New York University, the New School for Social Research, the Greenmarket and Rothman's clothing store, has been pressing the State Liquor Authority to revoke the club's liquor license.
 
Charges Are Pending
Last February, the authority charged the club with serving alcohol to minors and with being a focal point of police activity, but the case has had repeated delays. The next hearings are scheduled for Jan. 17 and 18. If the club is convicted, its license could be revoked or suspended and the owner could be fined.
Richard E. Chernela, a spokesman for the Liquor Authority, said: ''I can certainly understand the frustrations of people who live around the premises who are concerned about the violence. But they must also understand that anybody who is charged in this matter is entitled to due process and that we must look at these things objectively and dispassionately.''
Warren B. Pesetsky, the club's lawyer, said the charges by the Liquor Authority and the community are unfair.
Almost all of the incidents have taken place outside the club and many of the people involved had been ejected, Mr. Pesetsky said. Bouncers are always stationed at the door and inside, he said, and all patrons are searched.
''I'm not minimizing what happened or the loss of life, but I don't think the club could have done anything differently,'' Mr. Pesetsky said.
On Friday, Mr. Pesetsky met with Mr. Walsh, Mr. Cribben and other members of the community coalition. He told the group that the club had decided to hire uniformed guards to patrol outside the club. The guards probably will be armed, he added.
Mr. Pesetsky also said the club may change the way it is marketed, to draw an older, more affluent crowd. On Friday nights, he said, the club features reggae music and attracts a younger crowd. On Saturday nights, it features pop music and attracts an older group.
Mr. Walsh said most of the people who attended the meeting with Mr. Pesetsky were not satisfied with his responses and have vowed to continue their efforts to close the Underground. But the group is not sure who owns the 10-year-old club, Mr. Walsh said.
Mr. Chernela of the Liquor Authority said the Underground's owner of record is the 860 Broadway Restaurant Corporation, a holding company whose sole shareholder is Ronna Juliano. Mr. Pesetsky said Friday that Mrs. Juliano was not available to comment.

HEADLINE: Digital Tape Machines Expected by July

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Digital audio tape recorders, which could become the next major advance in home stereo equipment, should begin reaching the American market by the middle of this year, two leading manufacturers said this weekend.
The statements by the Sony Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, known for its Panasonic and Technics brands, are the first concrete indication of when the machines will reach the market since equipment manufacturers and record companies reached an agreement on copyright protection in July.
''We believe it's reasonable to assume we'll have D.A.T. products in the first half of the year,'' said Neil Vander Dussen, president of the Sony Corporation of America. Matsushita's Technics division went even further, announcing a price of $1,200 to $1,300 for a recorder that will go on sale in the summer. 
The announcements were made at the Consumer Electronics Show, the semiannual industry extravaganza that this year features television screens as large as walls and digital sound systems that can make a living room or automobile interior sound like a cathedral or concert hall at the push of a button.
Yet the show has a somewhat somber tone this time. Industry executives said they expected little growth in the coming year because of weakness in the economy. The Electronic Industries Association, the trade group that sponsors the show, said factory sales of consumer electronics in the United States grew 6 percent in 1989, to $32.2 billion, and are expected to grow only 4 percent this year.
Digital audio tape machines offer the same high-quality sound as digital compact disks but allow users to record their own music. Compact disk players can only play pre-recorded material.
The recorders have been kept off the American market for three years because of opposition from record companies, which fear the machines will lead to widespread taping of compact disks, hurting sales.
In July, however, record companies agreed to drop their opposition if the tape machine manufacturers would include special copyright protection circuitry in their machines. The circuitry, known as the Serial Copy Management System, will allow consumers to make direct digital copies of compact disks in unlimited quantities, but will prevent them from making tapes of those tapes.
 
Act of Congress Is Needed
Legislation is still needed to enforce the agreement. Manufacturers hope that a bill will be introduced after Congress reconvenes this month.
There is some thought that even if the legislation is not passed by the summer, some manufacturers will introduce their machines anyway. But the companies are reluctant to say this, and it is possible that they will change their plans if the legislation bogs down in Congress.
Many other manufacturers are cautious as well. They showed digital tape machines on the exhibit floor but declined to say when they would bring them to market.
There is also caution about how quickly the new machines will catch on. Sales are expected to go slowly at first because of the high price of the recorders and because there are still few pre-recorded tapes available to play on the machines.
 
TV Sales Continue to Grow
Despite the somber outlook for the industry, sales of color television sets continue to grow, with 22 million sets sold to dealers in the United States in 1989, up from 20.2 million in 1988. Camcorder sales grew to 2.3 million, from 2 million, though growth was slower than some industry executives had anticipated.
But sales of videocassette recorders, once the industry's star product, declined again to 12 million units, from 12.8 million in 1988.
Compact disk player sales grew strongly to 6.5 million units in 1989, from 5 million in 1988, though growth is expected to moderate somewhat in 1990. Other fast-growing categories included video games, telephones, cellular telephones and home office equipment like facsimile machines.
With the exception of digital tape machines, the products that electronics companies are pushing are generally more expensive and sophisticated versions of existing equipment.
 
'Home Theater' Gets Attention
One concept receiving a lot of attention this year will be ''home theater,'' in which large-screen televisions are combined with powerful audio systems to give viewers the feeling of being at the movies.
This idea has been around for several years, and executives say the equipment is improving enough to make it practical, though only for consumers willing to spend at least several thousand dollars.
Conventional picture tube television sets with 30- to 35-inch screens are becoming more popular. Projection television sets with even larger screens are improving in quality.
Taking the trend to its extreme, Mitsubishi introduced here a rear-projection television with a 120-inch screen. The set, which measures 8 feet wide by 6 feet high and 6.5 feet deep, comes in five pieces and must be assembled inside the home. The price will be $18,000 to $20,000.
Mitsubishi said 37 percent of the wealthy video enthusiasts that it surveyed indicated they would be willing to remodel their homes to accommodate such a behemoth.
 
'Surround-Sound Audio'
Home theaters use ''surround-sound audio,'' in which several speakers are used to make the sound engulf the viewer. One new category of product in this class is the digital signal processor, which uses special computer controls and software to simulate the echoes and sound patterns of different listening environments.
The Yamaha Corporation and Sony have begun marketing home systems, which sell for $1,000, and many more companies are expected to enter the market.
Eclipse, a unit of Fujitsu Ltd., as well as Technics and others, are introducing such systems for cars. Listeners can give themselves the illusion that they are sitting in an intimate jazz club or huge concert hall.
''You're in St. Patrick's right now,'' said Rick Del Guidice, car audio products manager for Technics, as organ music reverberated through a compact car as if it were resonating through a huge cathedral.
 
Some Offbeat Products
As in previous years, this year's show has its share of novel and somewhat offbeat products.
Technics is introducing a car radio that enables listeners to find stations they like in strange cities. By punching in the name of the city and the desired format, the radio will scan only the rock stations in that city, or only the classical music stations, and so on. The key is a data base on more than 9,000 stations compiled by the PRS Corporation of New York.
Sega Enterprises Ltd., a maker of video game machines, is introducing Michael Jackson's Moonwalker, a video game in which the rock star struts, spins and dances villains to death to save the world's children.
A Chatsworth, Calif., company called With Design in Mind is showing a $50 low-power broadcasting machine that will enable people to play disk jockey, transmitting voice and sound effects to an FM radio within their home.
The company is also displaying something called the Sunsquirt, intended to keep sunbathers from overheating. ''Put this down and every three minutes or every five minutes, whatever you set it for, it will spray a fine mist over your body,'' said Barry R. Benjamin, a vice president.

HEADLINE: U.S. Farm Credit Agency to Price Its Bonds

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, Wednesday's auction of seven-year notes and Thursday's auction of one-year bills.
By late Friday the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.54 percent, while the six-month bill was bid at 7.46 percent. One-year bills were bid at 7.28 percent, and in when-issued trading the seven-year note was being offered at a price to yield 7.99 percent.
Among Government agency financings expected this week is a $635 million financing by the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation, which plans to price bonds with maturities of three years and five years on Wednesday.
Today the Student Loan Marketing Association plans to announce the interest rate for a $500 million issue of short-term floating-rate notes due on July 12, 1990. The notes, to be offered through various securities dealers, will be priced at a spread to the bond equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill, with the interest rate adjusted the day after each Treasury bill auction.

HEADLINE: What Price Art? Ask Japanese Collectors.

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Japanese art buyers may have become a dominant force in Western auction houses, but in Japan this flood of money is increasingly a source of gloom for many members of the art establishment.
Japanese buyers spent a remarkable total of $230 million in a series of auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York in November, mostly for Impressionist works. Afterward, many museum curators, critics and some dealers here said that not only was the price spiral freezing public institutions out of the market, but that the Japanese public, which is still becoming acquainted with Western paintings, was being encouraged by the publicity to relate to these artworks largely on the basis of their price tags.
''What is happening to the market has been disastrous for all Japanese museums,'' said Nobuo Abe, chief curator of the Bridgestone Museum of Art in Tokyo, which specializes in Western art, especially Impressionism and modern works. Mr. Abe said he can no longer compete for top works. 
 
Competing With 'Speculators'
That is a remarkable setback for a museum that, just a few years ago, was jarring the art world with its audacious purchases. Although its acquisitions budget is a relatively modest $1 million a year, it could spend up to $10 million by spending money unused in previous years or by borrowing from future budgets. The Bridgestone, a prominent corporate collection open to the public, paid $3.3 million for a Picasso in 1980 and $10 million for a Renoir in 1986. Mr. Abe said those figures made him something of a Little Leaguer compared with today's buyers, a group to which he referred as ''those typical real estate speculators.''
Tomonori Tsurumaki, a slight, impatient real estate magnate who recently paid $51.3 million at the Drouot auction house in Paris for the moody ''Pierrette's Wedding'' by Picasso, is precisely the kind of collector Mr. Abe had in mind.
Mr. Tsurumaki, an otherwise terse man, beamed when given a chance to describe his trophy and the conspicuous manner in which he acquired it. He grew animated in reliving the four minutes it took him to outbid his rivals for the Picasso by telephone. He won the bidding in the middle of a party he was giving at a Tokyo hotel for 500 guests, including a former Prime Minister, Noboru Takeshita. The event was duly recorded in Japanese gossip magazines, along with comments about Mr. Tsurumaki's reputed links to Japanese yakuza, or organized crime figures, and his arrest on gang-related extortion charges in 1986. (There was no indictment, and the charges were dropped.) .
 
'Pierrette' and Corvettes
But Mr. Tsurumaki was proudest when describing the museum where he said he will house the painting - at a huge resort he is building in the middle of a national park in mountainous southern Japan, centered on an auto race track. The Nippon Autopolis, as it is called, is being marketed with a video that alternates computer graphics and photographs of vintage Corvettes and Thunderbirds with Picassos and Magrittes from his art collection.
Mr. Tsurumaki also displayed a copy of a letter from the Los Angeles County Museum of Art appealing for the loan of one of his Braques for a future show.
''History shows that good artworks will drift into countries with strong economies, so it's natural for pieces to come to Japan one after another,'' said Fumio Hayakawa, chief curator of the Yamanashi Prefectural Museum west of Tokyo, which was the first of Japan's regional museums to begin spending huge sums for medama - eye-catching pictures to attract crowds - by acquiring a Millet in 1979 for nearly $1 million.
''But as a museum curator I can only sigh and say that I feel helpless with what is happening to prices,'' he added.
The medama trend received its biggest boost in 1987 with the acquisition at Christie's in London of van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' for $39.9 million by the Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance Company in Tokyo. The purchase was made to celebrate and publicize the company's centenary. Today, some critics describe the painting as a ''hostage,'' as one put it, outclassing and out of place with the rest of the company's collection on public display in Tokyo.
 
A Market That 'Never Grew Up'
Some curators, dealers and critics admit that they share blame for the inflation of art prices. They say their narrow and highly public pursuit of a short list of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist and modern masters has turned names like Picasso, Renoir and Monet into popular emblems of respectability for those eager to clean up or establish reputations.
Many of the new collectors, they add, are merely emulating a pattern that the museums legitimized earlier. They appear unwilling to venture more widely in the kinds and periods of art they purchase because the museums, the arbiters of taste, have not.
''It's an immature market,'' said Ryuichiro Mizushima, a Tokyo art dealer. ''It never grew up.'' Plenty of experts share that view. Toshio Hara, head of the respected Hara Museum of Contemporary Art in Tokyo, lamented the fact that young Japanese artists find little support because collectors and museums generally prefer a minor work by a well-known name to that of a budding contemporary artist. In fact, some curators admitted that they had filled their museums with second- and third-rate paintings at great cost because of their parochial interest in names rather than quality.
Kazuo Fujii, a Tokyo gallery owner and head of the Five Cities Art Dealers Association, the leading trade group in Japan, said that several years ago he bought works by well-known American artists like Jasper Johns, Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein. Mr. Fujii, speaking in his small office in the Ginza shopping district and surrounded by a Picasso, a Renoir and a Cezanne, said he eventually resold the contemporary works to Americans after failing to attract Japanese buyers.
Yoshiaki Tono, a critic and art professor, said of the new collectors, ''Contemporary art is too cheap to satisfy their ambitions.''
And Haruo Arikawa, curator of the National Museum of Western Art in Tokyo, said his museum has been struggling for years, with very limited success, to generate interest among the Japanese public in Old Masters and classical Western paintings, which it has been collecting in part because they are less expensive than the Impressionists.
 
The Exceptions
To be sure, there are collectors with broader tastes. Prominent among them is Shigeki Kameyama, a dealer who has been paying big prices throughout the 1980's for works by postwar American artists and others. He recently paid a record price for a painting by a living artist when he bought Willem de Kooning's ''Interchange'' for $20.7 million. Mr. Kameyama also paid $26.4 million for Picasso's ''Mirror.'' Both purchases were made at Sotheby's in New York.
Japan has a long and sophisticated esthetic tradition of its own; calligraphers' brushes were dancing across geometric-patterned scrolls centuries ago, creating provocative, fluid images that would have done the Abstract Expressionists proud. There is also an equally long history of patronage and collecting. In fact, prices for Japanese art - sold discreetly at dealers' offices rather than at auctions - have also been rising.
 
Economic Factors
To a great extent, there is a simple economic explanation for the trend in art buying. Japan's soaring economy and booming real estate market have put tens of billions of dollars of profits in the hands of entrepreneurs.Then there is the rising value of the yen, which has more than doubled its buying power in dollar terms since 1985.
But what has struck the experts as unusual is how these collectors have for the most part narrowly followed the old orthodoxy in taste. As Mr. Arikawa and others pointed out, today's collectors are pursuing precisely the same kinds of paintings that wealthier Japanese were buying up in large quantities before World War II. In fact, they said, Japanese tastes in Western painting today seem eerily frozen in that time.
One leading new collector is Yasumichi Morishita, whose principal business has been making personal loans at very high interest. Mr. Morishita has a record of two criminal convictions for fraud and extortion. He owns Aska International, which operates a gallery in Tokyo. Along with a list of works by modern artists he has been buying furiously, he recently acquired a 6.5 percent share in Christie's, the auction house.
Mr. Morishita has said he paid $100 million for 100 Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings at sales in New York in November. He is said to own 20 Renoirs as well as paintings by van Gogh, Degas, Monet, Vuillard and Gauguin. Other dealers complain that his flamboyant mass purchases of paintings that are not worth the money have contributed to the wild prices in the art market.
 
The New Leader
But the unacknowledged leader of the new collectors may be Mr. Tsurumaki, who is 46 years old. After asking a visitor to view the marketing video for his Autopolis theme park in a room dominated by a huge video screen, a Picasso painting and a collection of crystal model cars, he led the way into his blond wood-paneled office.
He said he made his original fortune in a steel products wholesaling business before branching out into real estate. He added that he had been collecting art for several years and had been the underbidder on several major auction sales in recent months.
Mr. Tsurumaki said his Autopolis, which is expected to cost hundreds of millions of dollars, will provide a much-needed outlet for the pent-up yearnings of Japan's youth.
''People are frustrated with their lack of ability to drive fast in Japan,'' he said. ''I want to provide a healthy way to allow them to do so.'' The museum will provide a place of repose for these racers when they want a break, he said.
While some in the art world turn up their noses at Mr. Tsurumaki, they admit that in an odd way he and the other new buyers may be forcing a much-needed broadening in Japanese tastes for Western art.
''It is impossible for us now to purchase important Impressionist paintings,'' said Mr. Abe of the Bridgestone Museum. ''So we have to make our acquisitions in a new field, the pre-Impressionists and perhaps modern art from the 1950's and 1960's. We are expanding our interests; we have to.''
Mr. Hara of the Hara Museum said that younger people especially are growing restless for new images and new ideas. ''It's not easy to see, but there have been changes,'' he said. ''Younger people really do want to establish their own values.''
Mr. Arikawa of the National Museum of Western Art was much more guardedly optimistic. ''We are hoping to lead tastes toward a broader appreciation for Western art, but it will take 20 or 30 years, about two generations,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Politics, Flight and Sanctuary in 'De Donde?'

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Illegal immigration from Mexico to Texas has traditionally been a search for economic opportunity - migrants looking for farm work - but increasingly it has become a case of political necessity, as people run for their lives from repressive Central American regimes. This is the basic premise of Mary Gallagher's compelling new play, ''De Donde?,'' which opened Thursday night at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, as part of the company's 30th anniversary season.
Though the play is drawn from documented sources, gathered during the playwright's research in the Rio Grande Valley in Texas, it has been transformed into visceral theater. While addressing issues, ''De Donde?'' does not succumb to polemical techniques and keeps its focus on the humanity and the individuality of its characters. Because of the subject and the economy of execution - 13 actors double in more than 40 roles - the play should have a special appeal to other institutional theaters equally interested in provoking audiences into political awareness. 
Crossing the border, the characters in the play are met by a divided reception. There are those who regard the refugees as aliens to be prosecuted, while others consider their escape heroic. Those with the best of motives sometimes blunder, and United States citizens of Hispanic origin can be overcome by snobbery toward the more recent arrivals. Recent world events give Ms. Gallagher's work an additional immediacy. At least indirectly, the play is concerned with United States policy in Central America. In assessing the immigration situation, the author traces the problems to the legal inequities of the naturalization system and its administrators.
The approach is exploratory rather than hortatory - the opposite, in other words, of a Costa-Gavras film. Ms. Gallagher does not lose sight of the abuses of liberty, some of them absurd. One of her strongest suits as a playwright is her sense of irony, which asserts itself even in tense situations.
A young woman (Socorro Santiago) who has fled her country after a threat of rape and acts of violence against her family, is denied asylum. But when a lawyer is told that the woman's brother was tortured to death, he says, unblinkingly, ''Him we could get asylum for.'' ''De Donde?'' is filled with such ''Catch-22'' quandaries, leaving immigrants, many of them unable to speak English, confused about which option to take. Often the easiest course is to return to one's home country, even though retribution awaits.
The title of the play is crucial -''De Donde?,'' or, freely translated, ''Where do you come from?'' The unasked question is ''A donde?,'' or, ''Where do you go?'' The response would be, ''Anywhere but home.''
Repeatedly the refugees try to explain to officials the pressing reasons for their flight, and they are met with indifference.
Those who want to provide assistance are trapped by a legalistic bureaucracy. A concerned paralegal (Bill Cwikowski) with a high sense of purpose must accede to the pragmatic wishes of the lawyers who employ him. An elderly nun must weigh questions of conscience against the possibility of reprisals against her sanctuary. As they realize, the most that can be hoped for is not a change of policy but ''buying people time.''
Under the direction of Sam Blackwell, the actors double on all sides of the battle lines. Scenes are counterpointed and overlap. In the background there are several songs by Ruben Blades (more would give the play added flavor). Demarcations are drawn less by the sparse scenery than by the lighting, as the play moves swiftly from border patrol to internment camp. One could envision a more detailed production, but Mr. Blackwell's staging has an efficiency that does not intrude on the cinematic crosscuts.
Most of the actors in the largely Hispanic cast skillfully delineate their various characters, including Marie Barrientos, Enrique Munoz and Betty Miller. Mr. Cwikowski and Ms. Santiago, the only actors who do not double, are particularly moving as the paralegal and the refugee he protects.
Ms. Santiago is so frightened that she remains silent in the face of interrogation, and in so doing unwittingly furnishes herself with a legal defense. If authorities do not know where detainees come from, they may not be able to initiate deportation proceedings. Ms. Santiago's eventual recounting of her ordeal in Central America pierces the play with a cry of helplessness.
Necessarily certain relationships are simplified, as in a romance between a border guard and a young Hispanic woman - and a vaudeville interlude in a holding station does not achieve the desired black comic effect. But Ms. Gallagher's accomplishment is considerable. ''De Donde?'' is an outspoken act of social consciousness in a career that, up to now, has been profitably concerned with matters of marriage, home and family (most recently Off Broadway with ''How to Say Goodbye'').
In her work, the playwright has expressed a fierce loyalty to moral principles, even as people are carried away to excessive behavior, as in her satire, ''Dog Eat Dog,'' in which suburbanites combat the recession by becoming supermarket thieves.
''De Donde?'' is a most effective kind of political theater. It encourages the audience to use deductive reasoning to arrive at an inescapable conclusion: in the present handling of illegal immigration to the United States, injustice is being served.
 
NO WAY OUT - DE DONDE?, by Mary Gallagher; directed by Sam Blackwell; set by Jay Depenbrock; costumes, by Laura Crow; lighting, by Kirk Bookman; stage manager, Bruce E. Coyle. Co-produced by Clark, Schaefer, Hackett & Company. Presented by the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, Worth Gardner, artistic director; Kathleen Norris, managing director. At Cincinnati.

HEADLINE: WITH DEATHS TIED TO SALVADOR ARMY, AID FIGHT IS LIKELY

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Responding to a Salvadoran statement that military men were involved in the killing of six Jesuit priests in November, Administration officials acknowledged today that future aid to El Salvador would hinge on satisfying Congress about the progress of the investigation.
But the Administration said it did not think that aid to El Salvador should be directly tied to the inquiry, setting the stage for a battle with Congressional Democrats, many of whom insist that the case serve as a test of whether the United States should support the rightist Government in San Salvador.
 
U.S. Pressure Called Factor
In a televised announcement Sunday night, President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador said ''some elements of the armed forces'' were behind the killings, which took place on Nov. 16. A Congressional critic of United States policy in El Salvador and officials of the Bush Administration said today that American pressure was partly responsible for that announcement. 
Administration officials said they kept pressure on El Salvador to investigate the killings in part to forestall efforts by Democrats in Congress, who want to halt American aid to the Salvadoran military, which has long been tied to human rights abuses.
 
Obstacles to Prosecution
The White House officials also said they genuinely wanted those responsible brought to justice, but diplomats and lawyers in San Salvador said today that there would be many obstacles to a successful prosecution. [Page A10.] A housekeeper and her daughter were also killed in the attack, which came six days before Congress adjourned. Legislators expressed deep outrage at the time, and there were unsuccessful attempts in the Senate and the House to restrict aid.
Many legislators expressed concern that the killings were ''most likely carried out with American-supplied weapons,'' in the words of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York.
Representative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts, who leads a committee investigating the killings, said in an interview today that he was ''very happy about the announcement'' by Mr. Cristiani because it suggested that the Salvadoran Government was making a diligent investigation. The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, appointed the committee.
Mr. Cristiani ''knows that Congress is serious about reviewing American aid if these killings are not solved, with the right people indicted and sentenced,'' Mr. Moakley said. ''Many people will make up their minds on further aid to El Salvador based on the way this case is handled.''
Mr. Moakley, who is chairman of the House Rules Committee, has been a critic of American policy in El Salvador for a decade. He said that Mr. Cristiani was ''cooperating fully'' with Congressional efforts to monitor the investigation.
''The Speaker's involvement put additional pressure on El Salvador,'' Mr. Moakley said. Closer Review Called Necessary With most members of Congress out of town, it is difficult to determine whether Mr. Cristiani's announcement will stave off new Congressional restrictions on American aid. While pleased with the investigation so far, members of Congress said they needed to review the inquiry more closely before deciding whether to restrict aid.
The Bush Administration said today that Mr. Cristiani showed ''great courage'' in declaring that military men were responsible for killing the priests. Mr. Cristiani is the leader of a rightist alliance that has been accused of backing paramilitary death squads.
Administration officials said the vigor of the official Salvadoran investigation showed that there was no reason for the United States to reduce or restrict aid to El Salvador, as some Democratic members of Congress have demanded.
Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said the Administration hoped that the future of American aid ''would not be linked'' to the investigation.
''While identifying these alleged individuals is a decisive and necessary first step, the Salvadoran Government must now take actions to prosecute'' those responsible for the crime, Miss Tutwiler said. ''I have no reason to believe'' that El Salvador will not fully investigate the ''horrendous murder'' of the priests, she said.
 
'Salutary,' Rights Group Says
Americas Watch, a human rights group, said, ''The Cristiani Government's admission of military involvement is an important and salutary development.'' But noting that there have been no indictments or arrests, the group said the Bush Administration must ''maintain sufficient pressure to see that all those responsible are tried and punished.''
Miss Tutwiler said she did not know the rank of the Salvadoran soldiers suspected in the killings.
Mr. Moakley said his independent inquiry strongly suggested that ''the responsibility goes extremely high'' in the Salvadoran armed forces.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation is providing laboratory services to the Salvadoran Government to help with the inquiry. F.B.I. officials declined today to give details of the bureau's help. Mr. Cristiani asked for such help in a letter sent to President Bush on Nov. 19.
El Salvador received $298 million in economic aid and $80 million in military assistance from the United States last year. In the last eight years, Washington has provided more than $3.2 billion of aid to El Salvador, about $1 billion in military equipment. The Government has been fighting a civil war against leftist rebels for more than a decade, and the priests' killings came during a rebel offensive in the capital. A strict curfew was in place at the time, during which only the military was allowed to move freely. #47 Are Confined to Base Just after the killings, the Bush Administration adamantly opposed Congressional efforts to curtail aid to El Salvador, even though it now appears that such efforts were partly responsible for the Salvadoran Government's professed commitment to investigate.
Members of the elite Atlacatl battalion are among those suspected of being involved in the killings. Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, the head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in El Salvador, said on Sunday that 47 members of the battalion were being confined to their base even though they had not been arrested or formally charged.
Many members of the battalion have been trained by the United States. But an American official said, ''Just about every battalion in El Salvador has received U.S. training of one type or another.''
Anne Manuel, the research director of Americas Watch, said the Atlacatl battalion was implicated in the 1981 massacre of more than 700 peasants in the Salvadoran province of Morazan. It has also been accused in the killings of at least 68 people in Cabanas province in 1984 and the massacre of at least 50 in Chalatenango province in 1984.
Its record cast doubt on ''the theory promoted by successive U.S. administrations that U.S. training brings about improved human rights behavior,'' she said.
Without naming those responsible for killing the priests in November, Miss Tutwiler said, ''We are pleased that the Salvadorans have made this important breakthrough in identifying alleged perpetrators of the despicable slayings of the Jesuit fathers.''
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said the White House had no independent information about who carried out the slayings.
''Cristiani has shown great courage,'' he said. ''We asked that the investigation be thorough and the prosecution move ahead, and it looks like that's the course he is on. He deserves a lot of credit.''
