HEADLINE: Uranium Miners Inherit Dispute's Sad Legacy

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
From 1947 until the early 1960's, two Federal agencies struggled in secret over the fate of thousands of men who were being exposed to hazardous levels of radiation while mining uranium for the nuclear weapons industry.
The Atomic Energy Commission prevailed in the battle over mine safety with the Public Health Service. The result has been a widening trail of deaths and disabilities from lung cancer across Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico and Utah, according to Federal and state researchers.
Across the four-state region, once-robust mining towns like Naturita and Uravan in Colorado and Marysvale in Utah are becoming ghost towns inhabited by widows and aging men who live with one lung and the daily worry of developing cancer in the other.
Federal and state officials believe that about 15,000 men worked in the mines at one time or another from the late 1940's until the mid-1960's, when uranium mining stopped because the Government had stockpiled all it needed. Almost 4,200 miners who worked full time hauling uranium ore from the mountains and deserts were secretly studied over the years. More than 400 have died of lung cancer - five times the number expected in a similar-size group of American men, according to the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health and the New Mexico Tumor Registry. 
 
Sad History Slowly Emerges
Hundreds of other men have been disabled by the disease. In the next two decades, the total of confirmed lung cancer deaths among the West's uranium miners could double, Federal and state researchers say.
The history of lung cancer deaths and disabilities among uranium miners, which has been unfolding in public documents and Congressional hearings since 1959, is still largely unknown outside the sage-cloaked plains and rugged canyons of the four-state mining region known as the Colorado Plateau. It is the most thoroughly documented evidence yet made public of how a secret Government policy to put production ahead of safety in the nuclear weapons industry jeopardized the health of thousands of workers in jobs which, like all mine work, was dangerous under the best of circumstances.
The plight of the miners and the secret bureaucratic struggle of years ago is attracting renewed attention in the West and in Washington. Two Utah Congressmen, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Republican, and Representative Wayne Owens, a Democrat, have proposed legislation to compensate miners and survivors.
In the last month, The New York Times has interviewed former Public Health Service officials and studied documents from the Department of Energy, from Public Heath Service researchers, and from Stewart L. Udall, the former Interior Secretary who in the 1980's brought two lawsuits on behalf of miners and survivors against the Government and mine operators. Perils Were Perceived But Not Addressed The documents show that the Public Health Service, now an array of world-renowned institutes but at the time a small research and inspection agency, predicted as early as 1949 that radioactive gas and dust in the mines at levels far in excess of Federal safety standards would cause an epidemic of lung cancer unless conditions were improved. The agency continually recommended, with the explicit approval of the Surgeon General's office, that mine conditions be made better.
The documents and interviews revealed several important details about the struggle over mine safety:
* The attempts to improve conditions failed because of the willingness of the Public Health Service to abide by the Atomic Energy Commission's demands for secrecy.
* The Atomic Energy Commission, one of the most influential agencies in the Government, amassed its experts in radiation-related illnesses to discount evidence collected by its less-powerful rival. The Atomic Energy Commission feared that installing equipment would not only alarm miners but would halt production in many mines when the agency was rapidly expanding uranium mining.
* The Atomic Energy Commission, the predecessor of the Department of Energy, rejected as too expensive the Public Health Service's plea to require mine operators to install ventilation equipment until the early 1960's.
Several Public Health Service researchers and at least one Atomic Energy Commission official who sought to make public the plight of the miners were censured or lost their jobs in the late 1940's and early 1950's.
Caught between the Atomic Energy Commission and their belief that radiation in mines would produce an epidemic of lung cancer, the Public Health Service launched the country's first prospective epidemiology study to medically evaluate thousands of miners and follow them through their lives. By the early 1960's, more than 4,000 miners had been examined and were being tracked by epidemiologists.
But in a pact that they now acknowledge was fraught with moral and ethical implications, the health specialists agreed not to tell the miners why they were undergoing periodic physical exams, chest X-rays, and blood, urine, and sputum analyses.
The epidemiology study, still overseen by researchers at the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health in Cincinnati, is considered by radiation-research specialists to be among the most important studies showing a direct relationship between exposure to radiation and disease. 'We Were Essentially Watching Them Die' ''Looking at it with the standards of today, you could take the attitude that the miners were being used as guinea pigs, and we were essentially watching them die,'' said Dr. Victor E. Archer, the principal investigator for the study from 1956 until he retired from the Public Health Service in 1979.
Dr. Archer, now a clinical professor of occupational medicine at the University of Utah School of Medicine, added in a December interview: ''At the time, the situation was that we couldn't do anything to alarm the miners or we wouldn't get our studies done. We needed the studies to convince regulatory authorities that it was necessary to control radon in the mines.''
The result of the bureaucratic struggle is a legacy of disease and death on the Colorado Plateau that will last well into the 21st century. One of the most graphic examples is in a narrow, stony valley 190 miles south of Salt Lake City where lung cancer has turned Marysvale, once a thriving mining town, into a dying settlement of some 350 residents, most of them widows and injured miners.
The list of miners dead from lung cancer in Marysvale and in several surrounding towns numbers at least 31, according to relatives and surviving miners. The few surviving miners in Marysvale count four others who died of respiratory diseases, and seven more who have lost a lung or are developing signs of lung cancer.
''They started dying off here in the early 1960's,'' said Arden M. Higgens, a 56-year-old miner from Marysvale who lost most of his right lung to cancer in 1983 even though he had never smoked. ''Byron Anderson. K. Snow. Daddy Palmer. Seems like it's gotten almost everybody who worked up there in the 1950's. It makes me feel awful depressed.''
Marysvale, settled in the 1840's as a gold and silver mining center and accustomed to the booms and busts of a mineral-based economy, flourished for the last time in the uranium boom, which ended when the mines closed in 1966.
In 1948, at the start of a Government program to promote the development of a domestic source of uranium, the radioactive metal was discovered beneath the barren flanks of the Antelope Range seven miles north of Marysvale. The claims were leased to the Vanadium Corporation of America. By 1952, the Prospector, Freedom, and Bullion-Monarch mines in Marysvale were among Utah's largest producers of uranium.
What the Government, the Vanadium Corporation of America, and Utah officials kept secret from miners was the lethal levels of radon, a colorless and odorless radioactive gas, that contaminated the Marysvale mines.
Radon is formed from the decay of radium contained in uranium ores. In 1951, the Atomic Energy Commission confirmed scientifically that radon itself decays into radioactive particles that become attached to dust inhaled by miners. These particles emit alpha radiation, and once the particles became lodged in a miner's lungs, the radiation had the potential to alter the chromosomes of neighboring cells and initiate cancers. Pioneering Studies Were Done in Europe The first formal scientific studies of the problem, published in Europe in the 1920's, reported that 50 to 75 percent of the deaths among Czech and German miners working with ores containing uranium were from lung cancer. The European studies, considered by American health authorities to be an extraordinarily well-documented case of an occupational hazard, raised alarms in the Public Health Service and among health officers of the Atomic Energy Commission in the late 1940's.
The Government also was concerned about radiation surveys conducted since 1947 that showed the radon levels in many Colorado Plateau uranium mines, including those at Marysvale, exceeded the radon levels in the Czech and German mines. Dr. Archer calculated that during a single day a Marysvale worker could absorb 25 rems of radiation to his lungs - five times the dose now considered safe for an atomic worker for a year.
''We never knew a thing about it,'' said Rell Frederick, a 57-year-old former miner from Marysvale who worked on and off in the uranium mines from 1950 to 1966.
Mr. Frederick, who smoked a pack of cigarettes daily, developed cancer and lost his left lung in 1980. In December, while showing a reporter the rusted steel frameworks and wind-torn timbers of the abandoned mines, Mr. Frederick remarked, ''If they'd said, 'If you work here under these conditions, you'll die an early death,' I don't know what a lot of us would have done. We lived dangerously as miners. But they owed us the truth about what they were up to. They owed us the chance to make our own decisions.''
Duncan A. Holaday, 82, a former Public Health Service sanitary engineer who was one of the first Federal investigators to warn of the danger, said, ''By the late 1940's, there was no question in anybody's mind that radiation in the mines was a real problem.''
''It was quite well understood,'' he said. ''But nobody in the Atomic Energy Commission wanted to pay attention.'' Just Pennies a Pound For Safety Equipment In 1954, Mr. Holaday and several colleagues calculated that if the Atomic Energy Commission paid an extra 5 cents to 6 cents for every pound of processed uranium it bought, mine operators could afford to install ventilation equipment. That year, the Atomic Energy Commission bought more than three million pounds of processed uranium for an average price of $12 a pound, according to production records. But the Atomic Energy Commission and mine operators rejected the pleas and determined that ventilating the mines was unnecessary and too expensive.
The Atomic Energy Commission, the sole buyer of ore and processed uranium, also concluded that even if there was to be a health problem, the agency was not responsible. Lawyers for the Atomic Energy Commission maintained that under the Atomic Energy Act the Federal Government's jurisdiction of uranium began only after it arrived in processing mills.
The documents show that the Public Health Service was also stymied by the Atomic Energy Commission's division of biology and medicine, considered one of the world's leading authorities on the health effects of radiation. The agency's medical authorities said the experience in the European mines was an exception and could not be repeated in the United States. The medical officers also discounted the threat from radon and repeatedly said there was no evidence that a single miner had been harmed by excess radiation.
Dr. Archer, the principal investigator for the study for 23 years, said in an interview that influential researchers, including Dr. Wilhelm C. Hueper, a top scientist at the National Cancer Institute, was barred from traveling to the West after speaking in public about the problem. ''That was enough to scare me,'' Dr. Archer said. ''I wanted to stay out here and make studies. I had to officially take the position that we suspected that uranium miners may have health problems, and we were doing the study to find out what they were and how severe they would be. But we knew what they would be.''
In 1958, just as Dr. Archer, Mr. Holaday and their colleagues had predicted, four lung cancer deaths appeared among a group of 50 uranium miners under study. In 1959, Public Health Service epidemiologists identified five more lung cancer deaths, and in 1960 nine more miners died of lung cancer.
The rising toll, first discussed in public during a hearing of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy in 1959, persuaded the Eisenhower Administration to bring the Governors of Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico and Utah to Denver in December 1960 in a little-publicized meeting. At Last, the Levels Of Radon Drop Off The states agreed to sharply increase their enforcement, and the Atomic Energy Commission agreed to pay for it. The documents show that radon levels in the mines began to steadily fall in the 1960's as a result.
In Congress, Representative Owens and Senator Hatch have proposed legislation to pay injured miners or survivors up to $100,000 in compensation. An estimated 500 families would be eligible. The Bush Administration opposes the measure.
Some Marysvale miners or survivors have already been compensated. In 1985, 32 miners and survivors settled for $1.1 million a lawsuit against the Foote Mineral Company, a Pennsylvania mining company that bought Vanadium Corporation of America. Awards ranged from $3,000 to $135,000.

HEADLINE: Reviving Affirmative-Action Issue, Court Will Decide on F.C.C. Rules

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Setting the stage for a renewed debate over Government-sponsored affirmative action, the Supreme Court today agreed to decide the constitutionality of two Federal programs aimed at increasing the number of radio and television stations owned by minorities.
The possible effects of the two cases are greater than it might appear from the highly specialized world of broadcast regulation in which they arose.
For the first time since a conservative majority gained control of the Court's civil rights agenda, the Justices will consider what limits the Constitution places on the Federal Government in devising programs that give minorities a preference in competing for Government benefits.
 
Precedent in Rulings of 1970's
At issue are precedents dating from the late 1970's in which the Court held that increasing racial diversity is an important goal of public policy and that the Federal Government has greater discretion under the Constitution than do state or local governments to devise affirmative action programs. The cases give the Justices their first opportunity to apply at the Federal level their 6-to-3 ruling last year that declared unconstitutional a minority set-aside program in Richmond. 
The Bush Administration sought to avoid reopening the affirmative action debate, urging the Court in briefs filed last month not to hear either of the two broadcast cases. But on its first day back from a four-week recess, the Court announced it would rule on both. Furthermore, the Court ordered the lawyers to meet an accelerated timetable, with opening briefs due in a month rather than the usual six weeks, so that the cases will be ready for argument in March.
The cases concern two policies that the Federal Communications Commission adopted in 1978 in an effort to increase minority ownership of broadcast outlets, then about 1 percent.
One, known as the ''distress sale'' policy, was offered as an option to station owners whose broadcast licenses were in danger of not being renewed, for failure to adhere to regulations or other deficiencies. Ordinarily, loss of a license under these circumstances is a total economic loss for the license holder. But station owners were given the chance to sell their license to minority-owned businesses at 75 percent of market value, a considerable incentive.
The policy was challenged by a businessman in Hartford, Alan Shurberg, after the Federal Communications Commission rejected his application to operate a television station there in 1984. Instead, the commission permitted the company operating the station, Channel 18, to make a distress sale to the Astroline Communications Company, whose principal general partner is Hispanic.
Mr. Shurberg, who is white, argued that the policy violated his constitutional right to equal protection of the laws. Last spring, by a vote of 2 to 1, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit agreed, declaring the distress sale policy unconstitutional. The Supreme Court today agreed to hear Astroline's appeal, Astroline Communications v. Shurberg, No. 89-700. A month after the appellate panel struck down the distress sale policy, a separate panel of the same appeals court, also by a 2-to-1 vote, applied a different constitutional analysis and upheld the commission's other affirmative action policy.
Under this second policy, the commission awards what it calls a ''plus-factor'' to minority-owned companies when deciding among competing applications for new broadcast licenses. The plus-factor does not guarantee the minority applicant's success, because it is one of many factors that the commission weighs. In the case the Court accepted today, Metro Broadcasting Inc. v. F.C.C., No. 89-453, the commission chose a Hispanic-owned partnership, the Rainbow Broadcasting Company, to operate a new UHF television station in Orlando, Fla.
Rainbow beat out two other minority applicants. The losing applicants appealed. In upholding the program, the appeals court stressed that the program was flexible and did not impose a quota.
The commission's affirmative action policy has been the focus of a prolonged dispute between Congress and the executive branch. The policy was adopted in President Jimmy Carter's Administration. Under the Reagan Administration, which opposed many affirmative action programs, the commission disavowed the policy and let it be known that they planned to dismantle the programs.
But in 1987, as part of an appropriations bill, Congress forbade the commission to spend money to re-examine or repeal the policy. That prohibition has been renewed several times and is still in effect.
In upholding the affirmative action policy in the Metro Broadcasting case, the appeals court panel found it significant that Congress had given its ''express approval'' to the policy.
In an important 1980 decision, Fullilove v. Klutznick, the Supreme Court upheld a Federal public works program that set aside 10 percent of the available funds for minority contractors. The Court held that Congress had special authority under the Constitution to enact such programs.
Last year, the Court declared unconstitutional a similar contracting program that had been put in place by the City Council of Richmond. At issue since then has been whether that ruling, Richmond v. Croson, was an end to Federal affirmative action programs as well. The new cases give the Court its first opportunity to re-examine the 1980 precedent.
The commission's affirmative action program has increased minority ownership of broadcast outlets only slightly. Of more than 9,000 broadcast license sales since 1978, only a few dozen were distress sales to minority-owned companies. The low figure is due in part to the anti-regulatory attitude that prevailed in the Reagan Administration. Since very few license holders were ever threatened with losing their licenses, few needed to sell at distress prices.
The Court acted today in another case concerning a commission policy. Without comment, the Court refused to review the commission's repeal of the fairness doctrine, which required broadcasters to air a variety of views on controversial topics. The repeal was upheld last year by the Federal appeals court here. (Syracuse Peace Council v. F.C.C., No. 89-312.) The fairness doctrine is popular in Congress, which will consider legislation this year to force the commission to reinstate it. Such a bill passed both Houses in 1987 but was vetoed by President Ronald Reagan.
Other opinions today included the following: National Guard The Court agreed to decide whether the Federal Government has the constitutional authority to force Governors to permit the mobilization of state National Guard units to active duty overseas.
At issue, in an appeal by Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota, is a 1986 Federal law known as the Montgomery Amendment that prohibits governors from witholding their consent for such mobilization.
The amendment was passed when several Governors were objecting to their units being sent on Central American maneuvers in aid of the Nicaraguan rebels. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts unsuccessfully challenged the amendment two years ago.
The legal argument of Governor Perpich and the other Governors is that the Constitution's ''militia clause,'' in Section 8 of Article I, which reserves to the states ''the authority of training the militia,'' makes the Federal legislation unconstitutional. (The term ''militia'' is generally understood to mean a state's National Guard units.) A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, which includes Minnesota, first agreed with the Governor and invalidated the amendment.
But the full 10-judge court then re-examined the issue and upheld the legislation under the constitutional authority of Congress to ''raise and support armies.'' In part, the constitutional dispute reflects the fact the National Guard is a Federal-state hybrid in which members have a dual enlistment in both the state and Federal service. (Perpich v. Dept. of Defense, No. 89-542.) Union's Duty The Court agreed to decide whether workers injured on the job may sue their labor unions for negligence in failing to carry out the safety provisions of a collective bargaining agreement.
The case, United Steelworkers v. Rawson, No. 89-322, is an outgrowth of a 1972 fire in the Sunshine silver mine in Kellogg, Idaho, in which 91 miners died. Under the miners' labor contract, three union representatives sat on a six-member safety committee at the mine.
After the fire, the families of four miners sued the union on the ground that it had undertaken to protect its members but negligently failed to do so. The lawsuit has yet to go to trial, but the Idaho Supreme Court finally permitted it to do so in a ruling last year.
The legal question is whether state courts may permit a lawsuit of this type, which would not be permitted in Federal court under principles of Federal labor law. Under Federal law, a union that is alleged to have breached its ''duty of fair representation'' of its members may be sued for dealing with its members in bad faith, but not for negligence.
 
Libel Judgment
Without comment, the Court refused to hear an appeal by an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation whose $25 million libel suit against Peter Mattheissen, the author of a book about violence on the Pine Ridge Indian reservation in South Dakota in the 1970's, was dismissed by a Federal appeals court.
The agent, David Price, was also unsuccessful in his suit against Viking Penguin Inc., publisher of Mr. Mattheissen's book, ''In the Spirit of Crazy Horse.'' The book focused on a 1975 shoot-out in which two F.B.I. agents and an Indian were killed. Mr. Mattheissen gave a sympathetic portrayal of the Indian cause and an unsympathetic portrait of Mr. Price.
In dismissing the suit, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit said the statements challenged by Mr. Price were constitutionally protected either as opinion or as ''neutral reportage,'' in which the author transmitted the views of others. In his appeal, Price v. Viking Penguin, No. 89-741, Mr. Price argued that the appeals court had created an ''insurmountable hurdle'' for plaintiffs in libel cases.

HEADLINE: LARGE BANKS CUT KEY LENDING RATE TO 10% FROM 10 1/2%

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The nation's largest banks yesterday reduced the prime rate to 10 percent, from 10 1/2 percent, the first cut in the closely watched lending rate since July.
The First National Bank of Chicago led the way, and was quickly followed by Citibank, the nation's largest, and other major banks around the country. The cut in the prime, which analysts had expected for nearly two months, comes amid widespread signs of a weakening economy. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to continue reducing short-term rates in an effort to prevent the economy from slipping into a recession. 
 
'Process of Improvement'
''By itself, the change in the prime rate is not going to change loan demand or do much for the economy, but it is part of the process of improvement,'' said James E. Annable, senior vice president at First National. ''What the economy needs is more spending, and to get that we expect that the Federal Reserve will be reducing interest rates, perhaps not right away, but not too far in the future.''
The prime rate is a benchmark used by banks to set interest rates on a wide range of borrowing by individuals and small and medium-sized businesses. About half of the $100 billion of home equity loans outstanding have interest rates pegged to the prime. And interest rates on many automobile loans and credit-card borrowings are also adjusted according to changes in the prime.
The cut in the rate will affect these loans over the next few months, easing somewhat the debt burden of millions of Americans and freeing funds that might be spent to keep the economy growing.
 
Lower Rates Expected
The lowering of the prime rate caused the dollar to fall sharply against the West German mark and other European currencies. Traders said the drop in the prime was a reminder that American interest rates are expected to head lower, which will make the dollar less attractive relative to other currencies.[Page D16.] Although for weeks analysts have been predicting a cut in the prime rate, large banks did not move quickly because of erratic moves in short-term rates in recent months. After falling rapidly about the time of the last cut in the prime, in late July, when the rate was reduced from 11% to 10 1/2 percent, some rates increased during the autumn and only recently fell back to the levels of late July and early August.
Several bankers who asked not to be identified added that the prime rate was slow to fall because of their desire to help the banks' earnings at a time when costs are rising in other parts of their business. Some costs, like growing losses on loans for construction and real estate development, have emerged in the last year. But others, like the rising portion of bank deposits held in interest-bearing accounts rather than interest-free checking accounts, have been under way for several years.
How much lower the prime rate falls in coming months depends on declines in other short-term interest rates that are controlled by the Federal Reserve Board. Since May, the Federal Reserve has gradually eased monetary policy to reduce short-term rates by about one and a half percentage points.
''The Fed will be willing to ease some, to guard against the risk of a more severe downturn in the economy,'' said Donald Fine, chief market strategist at Chase Manhattan Bank. He estimated that the Fed might push down the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market to 8 percent by the end of the month and perhaps to 7 3/4 percent afterward, from around 8 1/4 percent now. But larger, more rapid moves to reduce interest rates are not likely, he said, unless new evidence emerges that the downturn in the automobile industry is spreading to other sectors of the economy.
Without increases in unemployment, many economists said they do not expect consumer and business spending to fall enough to produce a full-blown recession. They said the most recent employment report, for December, which showed a gain of only 142,000 workers on payrolls, less than expected, coupled with a further decline in manufacturing jobs was a sign of weakness but not recession. The unemployment rate was stable at 5.3 percent.
The December numbers were weak enough to cause some economists to predict that the gross national product in the fourth quarter will show no growth. When the G.N.P. data are announced on Jan. 26, some analysts expect that pressure on the Fed to ease monetary policy and reduce short-term interest rates will be even greater.
 
'In a Mild Recession'
Other analysts foresee spreading signs of economic weakness, with greater declines in short-term interest rates.
Gary Ciminero, chief economist at Fleet/Norstar Inc., a banking company based in Providence, R.I., said, ''The economy is in a mild recession, with flat to lower growth in both the fourth quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year.'' He said the January employment statistics, which will be published in early February, ''will be disastrous,'' with declines in the payrolls of auto makers of 120,000 workers, plus payroll cuts at companies that supply car makers.
The Fed will respond to the weaker employment statistics by reducing short-term interest rates a percentage point or more, Mr. Ciminero said, bringing the prime rate down to 9 percent by late spring or early summer.

HEADLINE: U.S. Falls Short On Its Debt Plan For Third World

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
In the 10 months since it was announced, the Bush Administration's strategy for easing third world debt has fallen well short of its stated objective.
The strategy called for cutting the commercial bank debt of 39 countries, chiefly in Latin America and Africa, by 20 percent. Had it reached that goal, roughly $100 billion of debt would have been eliminated.
To date, a final debt reduction package has not been concluded with any country. An agreement that would reduce Mexico's debt by $7.5 billion is expected next month and progress has been made toward financing packages in Costa Rica, the Philippines, Chile, Venezuela and Morocco. 
The stakes are especially high for the 414 million people of Latin America, whose governments and banks hold about two-thirds of the total $1.3 trillion debt.
 
Per-Capita Output Down 7%
Saddled with debt they could not pay, Latin countries saw per-capita output fall by 7 percent in the decade, according to the Inter-American Development Bank, after an increase of 40 percent in the previous decade.
Today countries like Argentina and Brazil are struggling to fend off economic collapse. In Buenos Aires, for example, prices fell 53 percent yesterday when the stock market reopened for the first time since Dec. 28. [Page D1.] The plan introduced in March by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady offered to forgive debt to countries willing to undertake tough reforms intended to foster a market-oriented economy.
''I think there was a hope that there would be a much more rapid and definitive conclusion of debt agreements with a large number of countries, and that hasn't happened,'' said Karin Lissakers, professor of international banking at the Columbia University Graduate School of International Affairs.
She said this ''means that uncertainty continues to hang over the debtor countries and their economic prospects.''
Yet for the country the Administration has most wanted to help, Mexico, the plan has been a boon, spurring a sharp decline in interest rates, repatriation of private capital and a welcome increase in foreign investment.
The improved economic situation in Mexico and the progress in other nations have led some American and international officials to agree that while the strategy has been slow to take hold, it has begun to work.
''In view of the magnitude of the changes that have to be made, I think that progress of the Brady plan has been pretty reasonable,'' said Stanley Fischer, chief economist of the World Bank.
 
Mexican Pact Expected Soon
Charles H. Dallara, Assistant Treasury Secretary for monetary affairs, and William R. Rhodes of Citibank, who heads an advisory group representing 450 bank creditors to Mexico, predicted in separate interviews that a Mexican package would come together within the next month.
Such a package would cut $7.5 billion from Mexico's $48.5 billion of commercial bank debt, and with reductions in interest rates on some debt as well, would knock nearly $2 billion from the $9 billion a year that Mexico pays in interest.
''We expect to have the documentation out within a week and a signing before month's end,'' said Mr. Rhodes, the chairman of the restructuring committee at Citibank. ''Virtually all of Mexico's 450 current bank creditors are participating. There are basically no free riders.''
Treasury and banking officials said there was a $300 million financing gap that still had to be filled before the Mexico deal could be concluded.
 
No Subsidies to Be Sought
But officials involved in the negotiations said that the banks and Mexico would split the difference and that in no way would American taxpayers be called on to subsidize the agreement. The Wall Street Journal reported today that a Treasury plan to sell bonds to assist Mexico would cost American taxpayers at least $500 million.
''At this stage we're maintaining a close monitoring of the situation,'' said a senior Treasury official who asked not to be identified, ''but the Mexicans and bank leadership are doing their job to try to bring the final deal together.''
The introduction of the Brady plan reflected an acknowledgement that the earlier strategy, developed in 1985 by James A. Baker 3d, then the Treasury Secretary, had failed. Mr. Baker's plan called for additional bank lending to countries engaging in a full-scale economic overhaul.
Although the Baker plan bought time for economic reforms to work in some countries and for banks to shore up their reserves and capital against bad loans, it led to ever-mounting debt that seemed to be preventing a return to economic growth.
 
Requirement for Growth
The new Treasury approach marked Washington's first official recognition that the $1.3 trillion third world debt, nearly twice the total in 1982, when the debt crisis began, had to be cut back for growth to resume.
Recovering from hip surgery, Mr. Brady has been out of Washington for the last month and could not be interviewed. But in comments in September before the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, he noted that the plan had generated ''improving expectations,'' which reversed what had earlier been a ''growing sense of hopelessness'' about the debt situation. Now he said these expectations had to be ''tempered by realism.''
Assisted by two deputies, David C. Mulford and Mr. Dallara, Mr. Brady worked out a program to accelerate the pace of voluntary, market-based debt reduction packages that banks and governments were already engaged in.
Most banks felt that debtor countries had resources to repay their loans and should not be let off the hook. Those willing to engage in limited debt reduction transactions chafed at the steepness of the discounts.
 
Partial Guarantees Offered
To induce banks to sell more of their loans, the plan offers partial financial guarantees on the debt that remains, theoretically reducing the risk of future trouble.
Over all, about $30 billion of financial support from the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and Japan backs guarantees aimed at cutting $70 billion off the $350 billion that commercial banks are owed by the 39 developing countries.
The Bush Administration, strengthening economic ties with Mexico, hoped that Mexico could stimulate its economic growth if its debt burden could be eased.
While the July accord has already had some of the desired economic results, the deal is still not complete. The reason for the extended delay goes to the heart of the plan's weakness, bankers said.
Banks were given an option of accepting a 35 percent reduction in principal owed, a similar cut in interest payments, or making new loans to Mexico. Most banks chose the first two options.
 
Supplement Funds
The bank money was to supplement $7 billion from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as collateral to back debt reduction. But because not enough banks were willing to make new loans, the collateral turned out to be insufficient to complete the deal.
Horst Schulmann, managing director of the Institute of International Finance, which represents 200 United States and foreign financial institutions, warned that if the Brady plan led to a situation in which private creditors would no longer provide new money, the debtor countries ''inevitably will become wards of the taxpayers of the rich countries.''
Another point at issue is the arm-twisting by the Treasury to get the banks to increase their loans to Mexico. Bankers said they cannot justify putting money at risk just because the the United States Government is concerned.
Treasury officials said they saw no inconsistency in asking the banking community as a whole to look at putting up new money. As one Treasury official commented, ''Different banks have different circumstances and appetites.'' Citibank, citing its optimism over Mexico's future, was one of the banks that chose the loan option.
 
Treasury Cajoling
Treasury officials conceded that there had been some ''cajoling'' of the banks, but noted that this was merely to point to pending Congressional legislation that would penalize banks that do not participate in debt reduction arrangements.
While they may complain, banks probably have little choice but to cooperate with the Government, most analysts believe.
''The debt for all these countries cannot be serviced, except possibly for Venezuela,'' said Christopher T. Mahoney, vice president of Moody's Investors Service. ''So it has to be reduced one way or the other. It has to come out of either government or bank pockets. Governments are not going to give the money, so it has to come out of the pockets of the banks.''

HEADLINE: Refugees Report Liberian 'Scorched Earth' Drive on Rebels

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Refugees fleeing fighting in northeastern Liberia have told of a ''scorched earth'' policy by the Liberian Army, sent into Nimba Province to put down an insurgency that started there two weeks ago.
The refugees told a reporter for Agence France-Presse that the army had entered villages in the northeastern region with mounted machine guns and opened automatic fire.
Those who managed to escape across the river into the neighboring Ivory Coast said they had seen friends and relatives shot by the soldiers. The villages were then burned and terrified inhabitants chased into the bush, the refugees said. 
Ivory Coast officials have said up to 10,000 Liberian refugees have arrived in the Ivory Coast, but other reports have put the figures much lower.
Fighting began on Dec. 24, when insurgents opposed to the West African country's leader, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, entered Nimba, the site of previous rebellions against General Doe.
 
Led by Ex-Minister
The rebellion is apparently led by Charles Taylor, a former minister in the Doe Government who fell into disfavor and fled the country after being charged with corruption. A man claiming to be Mr. Taylor phoned the BBC a week ago and said the rebels were seeking to overthrow General Doe.
Mr. Taylor said his forces numbered 1,000. The Doe Government has said there are 200 insurgents.
The Government has said the rebel forces destroyed two towns, Kahntle and Butuo, in the initial incursion.
General Doe, who as a master sergeant came to power in a violent coup in 1980, warned a rally in the capital, Monrovia, on Saturday that if anyone was caught harboring rebels, ''we will treat you as a rebel.''
''We will carry out a massive search,'' he said. ''Furnish us with information if you want to be on the safe side.''
General Doe, who accused the Ivory Coast of harboring the insurgents, warned his neighbor that Liberian forces would pursue the rebels back over the border.
Gen. Edward Smith, in charge of crushing the uprising, was quoted by Radio Elwa in Liberia as saying that among the more than 200 men, women and children killed by the rebels were 7 people shot while praying in a mosque.
 
Prominent Figure Killed
While Monrovia was apparently unaffected by the fighting in the northeast, there was concern that the killing of the great-grandson of a former Liberian President on Thursday might be connected with the events in Nimba.
The victim, Robert Phillipa, found beheaded with his wrists cut at his home, was one of the main defendants in the 1985 treason trial that followed a coup attempt against General Doe.
Liberia, founded by freed American slaves in 1847 and long run by their descendants, has been the closest ally of the United States in West Africa. The relationship grew especially warm during the Reagan Administration, when General Doe received nearly $500 million in aid from Washington, making Liberia the largest per-capita recipient of American aid in sub-Saharan Africa.
A United States military communications station and transmitters for Voice of America broadcasts to Africa are situated in Liberia. It is the only country in West Africa where United States military planes can land with just 24 hours' notice.
But Congress has become increasingly disenchanted with the Doe Government, particularly its refusal to clean up a corrupt economy or markedly improve its human rights record. Military aid has been steadily decreased to zero over the last several years, and economic aid was cut to $31.5 million last year.

HEADLINE: THE U.S. AND PANAMA: THE MILITARY;
Pentagon Looks for Ways To Stave Off Budget Cuts

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
As the annual ritual of presenting and selling the Defense Department budget to Congress approaches, the Pentagon is searching for new ways to help justify its spending plans.
Government and private experts agree that the threat of war with the Soviet Union is diminishing. As a result, the nation's military services argue that a portion of the Pentagon budget in the 1990's must be devoted to combating drugs and being prepared to bring American military power to bear in the third world.
Specifically, Pentagon officials say politically popular actions like the invasion of Panama and the dispatch of a Navy aircraft carrier to the coast of Colombia to detect planes carrying drugs are harbinger of a new era and arguments against sharp cuts in the Pentagon budget. 
In addition, the officials say, the Soviet military forces, as now constituted, continue to represent a formidable opponent that must be matched, even if the prospects of a confrontation are at a low point.
 
'A Real Soul-Searching'
Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said in an interview last week that only massive repression in the Soviet Union and a complete change in its foreign and security policies could reverse the momentum in Congress toward cuts in the military budget.
''The military,'' Representative Aspin said, ''is going through a real soul-searching. They are looking for a mission.''
''I know the Pentagon thinks that Panama is going to change the outlook on defense spending,'' he continued. ''They're looking at this as a way to argue for a robust defense budget. In fact, it's marginal. I don't think it will change the size of the budget, but it may change the shape.''
Indeed, some independent analysts said in interviews that the Army's success in Panama, using mobile, lightly armed troops, suggests the possibility of larger troop cuts from a military largely trained and armed for a strike in Europe by Soviet troops using conventional weapons.
Pentagon officials disagree. One official said Panama is a good example for the budget debate because ''it proves we're worth the investment.'' The Panama operation, another official said, will be an important illustration when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney explains his new vision for the military.
Pentagon officials, who all spoke on condition of anonymity, noted that although the Soviet threat may be lessening, countries like Iran, Iraq and Syria have begun an ambitious arms buildup that includes ballistic missiles and chemical weapons. Syria, for example, has 4,000 modern battle tanks and a formidable air force, while Iraq late last year tested its first intermediate-range missile.
 
New Uses for Old Weapons
As the United States reorients its military thinking, Pentagon officials see new uses for old weapons. Battleships intended for shore bombardment in a conventional war might be used to launch a cruise missile strike at terrorist training bases, they said.
The Bush Administration's budget for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, asks Congress for $295 billion, about $4 billion more than was approved this year but about $6 billion, or 2 percent, less than what would be needed to keep up with inflation. The Administration is expected to propose its budget to Congress on Jan. 29.
Despite Presidential requests for more money each year, Congress has reduced the Pentagon's budget by an average of 2 percent, after accounting for inflation, each year since 1985.
Senator William S. Cohen, a Maine Republican who is a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, warned that the Pentagon will have to do more than explain the success of the Panama operation to deflect the pressure for deeper cuts.
 
'What Is Driving the Strategy?'
''We want to know what is driving the strategy,'' Senator Cohen said. ''Is there a conceptual rationale to support why we arrived on a 2 percent cut? If there's not, we're going to have trouble on the Senate floor because some will argue, 'If you can accept 2 percent, why not 4 percent?' ''
Representative Dave McCurdy, an Oklahoma Democrat who serves on the Armed Services Committee, said in an interview today that the real test will be how Mr. Cheney presents the case for the Pentagon's expensive, strategic weapons systems, like the B-2 bomber.
''If he says we need to have the B-2 to be secure as a nation, I think he will lose,'' he said.
The lessons of Panama are being interpreted in various ways.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said at a news conference last week that he believed Panama was not instructive as Congress considers the future direction of the American military.
''It's unique in the sense that we had people on the ground,'' he said. ''We had bases there. We had 13,000 people permanently deployed there. We knew where all the facilities were. We knew exactly what we were facing in terms of the materiel and equipment. We had the ability of getting forces in there in advance.''
Senator Nunn said the Panama operation had two clear lessons: the need for better intelligence gathering and the usefulness of lighter weapons. He noted that the Army moved its older, lighter tanks into Panama rather than the more modern M-1 battle tank.
 
Potential for Deep Cuts Is Seen
Lawrence Korb, a Pentagon official in the Reagan Administration who is now at Brookings Institution, a research organization in Washington, said the success of lightly armored Army troops in Panama points up the potential for more far-reaching troop cuts than the Pentagon envisions.
Mr. Korb, who has emerged as a prominent advocate of budget stringency, said: ''This was the biggest American military operation since Vietnam. How many troops did we use? Twenty-five thousand. If that's the case, why do we need more than 1.5 million men and women in uniform? Why do we need a B-2 bomber? We didn't even use an aircraft carrier in Panama or the M-1 tanks.''
In response, a Pentagon official said the troops sent to Panama were appropriate for that operation and that the military still needs to have on hand the firepower to counter countries with heavy armament. He said several countries, including the Soviet military, retain such capabilities.
As the focus shifts from the Soviet threat to the problems of instability in the third world, the military services, particularly the Navy, have moved to gain a share of the money from the drug interdiction programs, which are one of the only growth areas in the Federal budget.
Mr. Korb recalled: ''I couldn't get the services to do anything. Now that there's no Soviet Army to speak of, people look around and see it has become much more palatable.''

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OPENS LEGISLATIVE DRIVE

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 8

 BODY:
President Bush opened the legislative battle of 1990 today, attacking ''demagogues'' in Congress, renewing his demand for a cut in the capital gains tax and calling for a new five-year farm bill that would allow grain farmers more choice in deciding what crops to produce.
Mr. Bush's comments marked the start of a strong White House effort to use the President's popularity, in the aftermath of the Panama attack, to sell the Administration's legislative program. Congress reconvenes Jan. 23, and White House officials have said that issues like a lower capital gains tax rate will be top priorities on the President's agenda.
Mr. Bush's visit here, where he toured Disney World's Epcot Center, was his first trip out of Washington since he returned from his New Year's vacation in Texas. He made scant mention of the invasion of Panama as he spoke to the farm group in this city some 250 miles north of Miami, where Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is being held before a trial on Federal drug charges. 
Mr. Bush's remarks expressed a lingering frustration about his troubled relationship with Congress in 1989.
 
Pledge of Cooperation
He repeated his Inaugural Day promise to extend ''the hand of cooperation'' to lawmakers. ''I put my hand out to Congress, to the Democratic majority, and reminded us all that the American people did not send us to Washington to bicker,'' he said.
''Now a year has passed; a new year has begun,'' Mr. Bush went on.
''We are always willing to listen to ideas and alternatives,'' he said. ''We are not willing to compromise on fundamental principles.''
As he did in 1989, Mr. Bush signaled that a cut in the capital gains tax rate would be a top priority this year. Last year the House of Representatives passed a cut in the tax rate, to 19.6 percent from 33 percent, but the Senate killed the bill in procedural wrangling over another bill reducing the Federal budget deficit.
Although Congressional leaders who fought the cuts last year have more or less conceded that they do not have the votes to block them this year, and Mr. Bush seems likely to prevail on the issue in 1990, he grew angry and punched his hand in the air today when he raised the subject.
 
'The Fight Isn't Over Yet'
''For us to reap the full benefits of a competitive economy, we must cut the capital gains tax rate,'' the President said. ''The fight isn't over yet, and I am sick and tired of the demagogues who call this a tax cut for the rich.''
Mr. Bush has long argued that cutting the tax rate on profits from sales of things like stocks or real estate would bring widespread benefit to taxpayers, increase employment and generally give the economy a lift. The proposal is popular among farmers, for whom land sales are a critical issue, but by far most capital gains go to the well-to-do.
Mr. Bush also complained that Congress had not acted on his proposals on amending the Clean Air Act and stiffening penalties against drug dealers.
''Brave citizens everywhere are standing up to crime,'' he said. ''And it's a time for Congress to act quickly and responsibly because the war on drugs and crime will not wait.''
After the speech, Mr. Bush toured the Land and Living Seas pavilions at Epcot Center. As about 150 tourists applauded loudly, he watched two scuba divers playing with two dolphins at the aquatic exhibit and spoke by radio to a third diver. ''Thanks a lot,'' he said. ''Good luck in there.''
 
Signal on Bush Policy
The address to the Farm Bureau conference here was Mr. Bush's first speech on domestic policy in the new year and contained his first major statement on farm policy, which opened the debate over the law that will be drafted this year to replace 1985 legislation that expires in 1990.
The President touched on the three major points of controversy in the new bill: flexibility in crop production, efforts to increase ground water quality and regulation of the use of pesticides and growth-enhancing chemicals. Mr. Bush seemed to signal more flexibility on those issues than had been the policy in the Reagan Administration, but he offered no specifics to his audience.
On agricultural policy, Mr. Bush sounded a generally upbeat tone, talking of the accomplishments of the 1980's, of declining surpluses of produce, the returning of fallow land to production and increases in net farm income. But a videotape shown just before he took the stage painted a bleaker picture. In the tape, farmer after farmer interviewed during the conference complained of high interest rates, low prices for their produce and ''depression'' in the farming industry in general.
Mr. Bush pledged to work for a comprehensive, innovative farm bill, although he drew an appreciative laugh when he joked that ''getting a farm bill through Congress is like milking a bull.''
 
Goal of Farm Flexibility
Touching on the primary areas of dispute in the new farm legislation, Mr. Bush said, ''We must have market-oriented farm policies that allow producers more flexibility to decide what crops to grow.''
But he did not say exactly how he would amend rules in the 1985 law that penalize farmers who change their grain crops from year to year.
Mr. Bush also said he believes ''productive agriculture and a sound environment can be compatible, especially in terms of water quality,'' and that ''we must also make sure that all Americans are confident in the safety of our food supply.''
But he did not say how far he was willing to go in regulating the use of chemicals in agriculture.
Mr. Bush also said Florida citrus growers, whose crops were badly damaged by a recent frost, could count on the Department of Agriculture ''to be in there fighting with you.'' He did not offer the orange growers in the region where he spoke any money to help overcome the effects of the frost.

HEADLINE: 2 Studies Rate U.S. and States On Meeting Children's Needs

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The Federal Government and 44 states are not providing adequate programs to help children in need and the nation is falling behind other industrialized countries in reducing infant mortality, the Children's Defense Fund said today.
The Washington-based fund, which lobbies for social welfare programs, said the United States was trailing most other industrialized nations in categories like immunization against polio and other childhood diseases and preventing teen-age pregnancy. It issued its 1990 report today.
The study also ranked the 50 states and the District of Columbia according to their efforts in child welfare. 
 
Similar Report Is Issued
Another Washington-based group, the Center for the Study of Social Policy, made public a similar ranking today. The center is a research group that does no lobbying.
Both studies listed Massachusetts, Connecticut and Vermont as making the greatest effort for children. The fund listed Maine, Minnesota and Delaware as making at least an ''adequate'' effort. The center ranked New Hampshire and Wisconsin among the top states.
The lowest ranking on the fund's list were New Mexico, South Dakota, Kansas, Idaho and Colorado. The center ranked as lowest Louisiana, Mississippi, Georgia, Alabama and the District of Columbia.
New Jersey ranked near the top on both lists; New York was near the top of the fund's list and near the middle of the center's list.
 
How Figures Were Created
The fund rated states on whether they had achieved the Surgeon General's goal of reducing infant mortality by 1990 to 9 or fewer deaths per 1,000 live births - or reducing to no more than 5 percent of all births the proportion of infants born at low-birth weight.
The fund also studied whether states had reduced the percentage of children in poverty or had seen to it that 90 percent of babies were born to women who began prenatal care in the first three months.
Each study used as indicators the percentage of children living below the poverty line, the percentage of births to teen-age mothers, the unemployment rate among teen-agers and the rate of high school graduates.
 
Study on Aiding Children Set
The fund also considered states' performance in programs like supplemental Medicaid assistance and nutrition assistance for poor children and pregnant women. The director of the Center for the Study of Social Policy, Tom Joe, said his group was undertaking a five-year, $5 million project to collect data on how children are served. He said it would be financed by the Annie E. Casey Foundation.
Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, said the figures demonstrated that ''the mounting crisis of our children and our families is a rebuke to everything America professes to be.'' She warned that failure to see to it that children are well cared for will ''bring America to its economic knees and states.''
She said the United States had the highest teen-age pregnancy rate of six industrialized nations, comparing it with France, England, Canada, the Netherlands and Sweden. Polio immunization rates for American children, she added, rank behind those of 14 countries and the rates for non-white American children are behind those of 48 countries.
Mrs. Edelman's group said that from 1979 to 1986 there was a 66 percent increase in reported cases of child abuse or neglect. Since 1973, when she founded the fund, Mrs. Edelman said, young men's marriage rates declined by one-third and the proportion of births outside marriage doubled.
 
The Mother With a Job
The fund said the nation had not adequately recognized the needs of children whose mothers work outside the home. Half the pre-school age children today are in that situation and by the end of the century, the report said, the figure will rise to 70 percent.
Mrs. Edelman said that the actual number of children was dwindling and that by the year 2000 there would be 4.1 million fewer Americans between the ages of 18 and 24 than there were in the mid-1980's. ''Increased competition abroad means that every one of them must be fully productive,'' she said.
''Only 2 of 10 new work force entrants in the 1990's will be white males born in the United States,'' Mrs. Edelman said. ''If we are to compete effectively in the world economy, we need minority and poor youngsters to produce, rather than become dependent on us or shoot at us.
''Those who do not want to invest in black or brown or poor children must remember this.''

LENGTH: 529 words

HEADLINE: A Seductive Tax Cut; Dangerous, Too

 BODY:
Last week every American worker began paying higher Social Security taxes. Suppose someone proposed to cancel the increase to help low-wage workers and also expose the true size of the Federal deficit. An irresistible offer, right? Wrong. 
Senator Daniel Moynihan of New York and others make just such a proposal. But the offer is deceiving. By cutting tax revenues, the proposal would mean increased Federal borrowing. That would mean siphoning private savings from corporate investment in order to pay the Government's bills. The gravest threat to the long-term health of the economy is too little savings. Mr. Moynihan's proposal would make this problem worse.
The Jan. 1 rise in payroll taxes is part of a plan worked out in 1983 to save the Social Security system. The idea was to generate annual surpluses large enough to pay for a bulge in retirement benefits expected around 2020. Mr. Moynihan, an architect of the original plan, would wipe out these surpluses and, instead, boost tax rates when the retirements actually occur.
The Senator is justifiably frustrated that an increasing share of Federal tax revenues is generated by the regressive Social Security tax. Because the flat-rate tax applies only to the first $51,300 of earnings, it hurts low-paid workers more than high-paid ones. And because employers bear part of the tax, it discourages employment. Mr. Moynihan's plan would soften these blows - until 2020 or so, when the rates would have to be raised.
Senator Moynihan is also justifiably chagrined that Social Security surpluses have been used to mask the Federal deficit. The surpluses, used in large part to fund various forms of public consumption, now do little to provide for future retirees. If, instead, the revenues were invested in new productive capacity, the economy would grow and provide future retirees with the goods they will want to buy.
Yet Mr. Moynihan's tax cut would make matters worse. Lowering taxes is exactly the wrong prescription for an economy that already suffers from frighteningly high deficits and alarmingly low savings. Perhaps the Senator's purpose is to create a budgetary panic that would compel Congress to respond with higher income taxes. But such kamikaze tactics can backfire if politicians continue to read President Bush's lips and refuse to enact new taxes.
Political candor is needed. There's a clear way to lessen the regressivity of the current tax system without widening the deficit: Cut the Social Security payroll tax and raise income taxes accordingly. This swap need not be politically suicidal. The necessary income tax hike would be minuscule. By one estimate, the 28 percent tax rate on high incomes would have to be raised only a fraction of 1 percent to fund Mr. Moynihan's plan.
But even that swap would not be nearly enough. The country would still be left with an abysmally low savings rate, due in part to an undiminished Federal deficit. What's needed are even higher taxes.
It's O.K. to lower taxes on the working poor. And it's O.K. to unmask the size of the Federal deficit. But it's not O.K. to tantalize voters with the prospect of a tax cut that cannot be sustained.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Opposition to Nuclear Power Grows Stronger

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Nuclear power may not be inherently unworkable, but it is being rejected worldwide for precisely those reasons you mention in ''Revive the Atom'' (editorial, Dec. 8): bad economics, poorer safety and a lack of trust by the public.
You imply that the antinuclear movement is a United States phenomenon, but nuclear power has never faced such determined opposition around the world.
In Western Europe, France remains the only country with an active nuclear construction program, but France plans to order only one new plant in the next four years. The country has also seen an upswing in demonstrations - from across the political spectrum - against nuclear plants and waste dumps. 
Britain's hopes for a new line of plants, based on the Sizewell-B P.W.R. reactor, have collapsed. This followed government attempts to get a resistant financial community to swallow the uneconomic nuclear stations. Elsewhere in Europe, the talk is of wastes and decommissioning, not construction of new plants.
Glasnost in the Soviet Union has been harsh on nuclear power advocates, with at least 10 plants closed or canceled in the last two years. This month, Hungary canceled plans to build four Soviet-style nuclear plants.
Faced with the largest popular movement since World War II, Japanese industry and government are scaling back ambitious nuclear expansion plans. Taiwan saw its third attempt to construct more plants stopped by domestic opposition this year. South Korea saw its first anti nuclear demonstration a year ago; now the government faces a coalition that has succeeded in halting planned expansion and is calling for shutdowns.
The notion that there are new environmentally benign and safe designs of nuclear plants that will alter public opposition is misconceived and not even shared by some in the industry. A study by the British Atomic Energy Authority found that the new designs may be just as vulnerable to structural failures as the old. Even the industry's trade journal, Nucleonics Week, states that ''experts are flatly unconvinced that safety has been achieved - or even substantially advanced - by the new designs.''
If companies say the newly designed nuclear power plants will be cheaper to build than coal-fired power plants, I say let them pay for them on their own. We've already poured a trillion dollars into nuclear power since World War II.
I'd rather spend the money on cleaning up nuclear wastes and decommissioning the numerous civilian nuclear plants that are being closed, including Rancho Seco in California and Fort St. Vrain in Colorado, an ''advanced'' high-temperature, gas-cooled reactor that didn't work.
You call for environmentalists to help create conditions for public acceptance of nuclear power. I remain doubtful that safe and cheap nuclear power, free of waste and proliferation problems, exists. The last 40 years haven't taught me otherwise. Until the manufacturers put their money where their mouth is, all I'll see is one more handout for another white elephant.
 
NICHOLAS LENSSEN
 Takoma Park, Md., Dec. 21, 1989

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

The Economy
The nation's largest banks reduced the prime rate to 10 percent, from 10 1/2 percent. It was the first cut in the closely watched lending rate since July. The reduction comes amid widespread signs of a weakening economy. [Page A1.] 
Americans took out $4.24 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in November, the largest increase in outstanding debt in nine months. [D2.] A significant number of consumer loans made by commercial banks are turning sour, the Comptroller of the Currency told a group of bankers. [D2.]
 
International
The Bush Administration's strategy for easing third world debt has fallen well short of its stated objective. The strategy called for cutting the commercial bank debt of 39 countries, chiefly in Latin America and Africa, by 20 percent. Had it reached that goal, roughly $100 billion of debt would have been eliminated. While some progress has been made, in the 10 months since the strategy was announced, no final debt reduction package has been concluded with any country. [A1.]
Prices on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange plunged an average of 53 percent in value. [D1.]
 
 
 
Companies
UAL asked its advisers to explore a recapitalization of the airline company. Through such a move, UAL, which owns United Airlines, would borrow money to buy back a large chunk of its 21 million outstanding shares. [D1.]
G.M.'s board said management succession was its responsibility, responding to requests from two large institutional shareholders that they be consulted on finding a successor to Roger B. Smith, who is retiring as chairman and chief executive. [D1.]
As deadlines loom for Campeau to come up with the money to meet its obligations, the company has given no indication of how it intends to address its problems. [D7.] First Boston finds itself uniquely exposed as a result of Campeau's problems. [D7.]
Unisys said it was engaged in ''constructive talks'' with the Justice Department aimed at a settlement of charges in the department's long-running inquiry into Pentagon fraud. [D11.]
Dawn Steel resigned as president of Columbia Pictures. She is expected to set up her own production company. [C15.]
A group of limited partners of Ivan F. Boesky received a $248 million payment yesterday, in the culmination of a complex settlement reached over the last few months.[D7.]
Intel introduced a supercomputer that analysts said should gain a share of the growing commercial market. [D4.]
Nissan plans to introduce a less expensive Infiniti model later this year. [D4.]
 
 
 
Markets
Stock prices rose moderately, spurred by futures-related buying about an hour before the close. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 21.12 points, to 2,794.37. [D8.]
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell again, as dealers sold securities in the wake of a big drop in the dollar and were unimpressed by a half-point cut in the prime lending rate. [D15.]
The dollar fell sharply in active trading, skidding to a 20-month low against the West German mark. [D16.] Energy prices continued to plunge amid unseasonably warm weather. [D16.]

William Farley appears unable to complete his purchase of West Point-Pepperell. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
How will the Government manage the sale of thousands of properties overseen by the Resolution Trust Corporation? Lamar C. Kelly Jr. provides some answers. Talking Business. [D2.]
