HEADLINE: Crucial Time for New York Stores

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
In the embattled terrain of New York-area retailing, seven key department-store groups remain in the fight not only for customers but for survival itself in the most difficult period American retailing has faced in decades.
Years from now, many will probably wonder how the survivors made it through the New York ''store wars.'' The future is uncertain, if not worrisome, or so retailing analysts, store executives and consultants said in more than a dozen interviews. If recent trends hold, most of the big stores will probably change hands by the mid-1990's and revamp their strategies several times.
The watershed year of 1989, which sorted the quick from the dying retailers, will likely be followed by at least two more years of turmoil for the seven main survivors among New York department stores: R. H. Macy, Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue, Abraham & Straus, Lord & Taylor, Stern's and Bergdorf Goodman. 
 
More Discounting Is Likely
Still, the New York retailing companies that emerge will be a resilient breed, having demonstrated an ability to adapt, to function under great pressure and to avoid wilting under heavy burdens of debt.
The aggressive price-cutting that shoppers saw this holiday season is likely to become the norm as stores try to appeal to a broader range of customers, retailing analysts say. But this two-pronged push to the consumer midstream will likely invite new competition at both the high and low ends of the retail marketplace.
And with the need to keep cash flowing in to pay debt, the New York market is likely to become much more distinctly layered among low-,> medium- and high-priced outlets. Analysts who follow retailing say the department-store groups will each have to hone their marketing strategies carefully to prevail in the 1990's.
''Market forces have drastically changed the composition of New York retailing,'' said Walter K. Levy, a retail marketing consultant. ''Severe competition has forced out the businesses that had no real clear differentiation or critical mass. But I am more disturbed by the financial entrepreneurs who have bought good retail stores and compelled them to pay more attention to cash flow to pay debt than to their store business.''
''If retailers are distracted from concentrating on the future,'' he added, ''they aren't likely to have one.''
Indeed, almost all of the leading retailers in New York, the country's biggest market, have been unable to escape financial pressures, to avoid making huge debt payments, or to prevent their being put up for sale:
* Macy's, after recently reporting losses, remains under pressure from creditors to meet payments on the large debts created by its 1986 leveraged buyout, a technique that permits investors to use company assets as collateral to finance the company's purchase. Macy's added another $1 billion in debt when it acquired the California-based Bullock's and I. Magnin stores in 1988.
* Bloomingdale's was put up for sale by its owner, the Campeau Corporation, in September. Six bids are under consideration and a sale of ''Bloomie's'' has been expected in February. But people in the trade speculate that most of the bids placed so far are inadequate, raising the possibility that Bloomingdale's might be taken off the market and other Campeau units offered for sale in its place.
* Saks Fifth Avenue is also for sale by its owner, B.A.T. Industries. The bidding will not officially get under way until mid-January or early February.
* Abraham & Straus and Stern's, both also owned by Campeau, are under heavy pressure to produce strong sales and profits to keep the parent afloat. Both chains are faring relatively well and complement each other in the same market areas, with A.&S. selling slightly higher-priced merchandise.
 
Wide Economic Impact
The fortunes of these stores affect far more than the profits of the companies that own them. The New York economy is heavily dependent on the big stores for employment and for supporting hundreds of businesses, including suppliers, service contractors, advertisers and newspapers.
Despite their burdens, these stores are better off than many others in the New York market. With closed storefronts on empty buildings and thousands of layoffs, New York retailing resembled a business war zone as 1989 slid into history.
The biggest recent casualty was B. Altman & Company, which closed six stores of its century-old business on Dec. 30, including the sprawling flagship store at 34th Street and Fifth Avenue. ''New York City has lost its grand old lady, not to mention the more than 1,000 people who worked there,'' said Joseph E. Brooks, chairman of Ann Taylor stores, formerly chairman of Lord & Taylor.
Bonwit Teller, now on the auction block after losing $23 million in the last three years, is likely to close the doors of its 16 stores if it does not attract a buyer. The 11 stores owned by Alexander's Inc. may soon be put up for sale. The developer Donald J. Trump, who owns 27 percent of Alexander's, has said he may buy the entire company.
The 17 Alcott & Andrews clothing stores, which catered to executive women, have been closed. TSS-Seedman, a venerable discount chain, is holding its final sales, as are the Bond men's clothing stores. J. W. Mays, a discounter that catered to low-income customers, ceased operations in its last four stores. And the Crazy Eddie electronics chain, which relied heavily on its ''insane'' advertising, has closed its 30 stores.
 
'Unusual Number of Failures'
''Considering the great size of the New York metropolitan market - 8.5 million people and retail sales of about $5.7 billion - the area has had an unusual number of failures,'' said James Posner, a New York retail marketing consultant and former retailer. ''Their bones litter the streets. One has to wonder why so many fail amid plenty.''
Mr. Posner, for one, sees two reasons for the havoc in New York retailing: the need to become more aggressive in view of rising costs and tougher competition, and a shift by consumers from conventional department stores to specialty stores.
Unlike retailers in other cities with smaller bases of customers, however, stores in New York need not capture a large market share to be big, profitable or successful, Mr. Posner said. ''The sales potential is that big,'' he explained.
Sales at New York-area stores operated by the three largest retailers, for example, are huge. Macy's is the largest by far in sales, with estimated annual revenue last year of more than $2 billion. Bloomingdale's is second, with 1989 sales of about $1.6 billion. And Abraham & Straus is third at $800 million.
But sheer volume of sales and a long history do not safeguard a company from losses or liquidation. From conversations with many analysts, store executives and consultants, a consensus emerges on the strategies of the seven big retailers and the areas they may seek to emphasize to try to prevail.
 
R. H. Macy & Company
Sales Are Huge, But So Is Debt
Still loaded with heavy debt, Macy's nonetheless remains New York's most vigorous retailer, and industry analysts predict that it will probably continue promotions like big one-day sales to fill its immense Herald Square flagship store and its area branches with shoppers. More than any other local retailer, Macy's, a private company led by Edward S. Finkelstein, has diversified its appeal to a broad group of shoppers.
Mr. Finkelstein is expected to continue his policy of invigorating the six formerly staid New York-area stores with the trendy leisure fashions that had turned the Macy's stores in the San Francisco area, which he once managed, into the Bloomingdale's of that region.
Macy's profits improved under his tenure, and the gains would likely have continued, except for the 1986 leveraged buyout led by Mr. Finkelstein, together with some 350 associates. Since then, profits have alternated with losses, and a steady flow of cash has become crucial in making debt payments.
With a big Hong Kong buying office, Macy's expanded its private-label business in the 1980's to enjoy the higher profit margins made possible by its more than 40 store brands. But when Macy's bought the California-based Bullock's and I. Magnin stores, it added another $1 billion in debt to its existing $7 billion. When sales of women's clothes stalled, Macy's had to cut back sharply on its private labels.
Macy's chances for success appear reasonably good, retailing people say. This promises to be a crucial year for the chain, as it seeks to improve its bottom line and prove that its leveraged buyout was a smart business decision.
 
Bloomingdale's
The Cutting Edge Is Paring Profits
For years viewed as the leading-edge department-store operator in America for its skills in tapping trends, Bloomingdale's will be hard put in the next few years to recover from the slippage that began in the last year, Wall Street analysts say. As many of its loyal customers have grown older they have lost their zest for products in the ''big brown bag'' that has become a company symbol.
There are fewer of the young, affluent consumers now than in past years, data show. In the years ahead, regardless of who buys the chain, Bloomingdale's will likely have to find some new strategy - probably something between the classic approach of Saks and its own trendy ways - that will bring it back to its former heights.
Like Mr. Finkelstein at Macy's, Marvin S. Traub, with his bubbling persona and his talent for creative merchandising, has become closely linked to Bloomingdale's. The store's chairman and chief executive, Mr. Traub is leading an investor group trying to buy the company.
But some reports from Tokyo, where Mr. Traub went to attract Japanese retail financing, indicate that he failed to find backers for the several hundred million dollars in equity that he needs. The Japanese retailers he approached said the $1 billion-plus asking price was too high for a company whose business seemed lackluster to them.
At a time when millions of working women want serviceable, classic clothes, retail analysts say Bloomingdale's biggest challenge will be to become a bit less trendy and a bit more practical.
The flagship store has sales per square foot of $800, one of the highest in American department stores, while its estimated overall sales of about $400 a square foot well exceed the industry average for such stores, about $225 a square foot.
In its pricing and fashion approach, Bloomingdale's straddled Bergdorf Goodman on the high end and Saks Fifth Avenue on the slightly lower end. But these days, as it promotes heavily to help Campeau, its financially strapped parent, its image has become fuzzy, retail executives say.
 
Saks Fifth Avenue
Seeking to Grow As Incomes Rise
Along with Nordstrom Inc., of Seattle, Saks Fifth Avenue is probably the nation's most respected fashion-apparel chain. But it will have to ferret out some new approaches to keep its current customers and to attract the younger, professionally employed shoppers whose incomes are expected to swell further as they get older. Since these affluent professionals prefer designer and national brands, Saks may have to re-examine its house brands, which dominate its inventories, analysts say.
Like some of its prime competitors, Saks has added more moderately priced goods in reaction to the race for market share and to the demand by its British parent, B.A.T. Industries, for higher sales and profits.
But company executives say that any effort to broaden its pricing is minimal and that Saks continues to carry out its mission statement of being a ''high-service, national marketer of top-quality merchandise.'' Its primary customers, they insist, remain in the upper income bracket. Saks sells more than $1 billion of merchandize in its 46 stores nationwide, with profits ''well above'' the 4 percent level on sales for similar retailers. The company's bottom-line performance slipped somewhat in 1988, but picked up in 1989.
Saks is also expanding its flagship store on Fifth Avenue in the conviction that it is a vital showpiece for the company.
 
Abraham & Straus
Manhattan Store And Momentum
 
Perhaps the only large New York retailer that is markedly turning around, Abraham & Straus is expected to gain more momentum through an approach that combines brand names with discounted fashions to appeal to middle-income shoppers and young couples.
A decade ago, the most profitable division of Federated Department Stores - well before that company was acquired by Campeau - the 15-store Abraham & Straus fell on a long, unhappy stretch of unprofitable years. It regained minimal profitability until 1986, when its earnings markedly improved. Under Chaim Edelstein, the former executive vice president who became its chairman that year, the Brooklyn-based chain has taken on new life, with improved sales and respectable profits.
The company still faces problems with depressed local markets for its two biggest stores, the Brooklyn flagship on Fulton Street and the vast suburban branch in Hicksville, L.I. But by drastically reducing store space and opening new outlets, including a store at the old Gimbels site in Manhattan, A.&S. has again become an important force in New York retailing. Mr. Edelstein says the new store, a scant two blocks from Macy's flagship store, is ''exceeding all expectations.''
With Gimbels gone for almost five years, A.&S. is emerging as Macy's biggest head-to-head competitor. This is the old Macy-Gimbel rivalry reincarnated, something of a twist in that before the turn of the century the Straus merchant family owned virtually all of both Macy's and A.&S.
 
Lord & Taylor
Setting Prices To Foster Sales
Analysts and professional retailers say that aside from the Campeau-owned local trio of Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus, and Stern's, Lord & Taylor may be the under the most pressure to sharpen its strategy. Its future growth will hinge on new merchandising and marketing techniques to achieve higher sales and profits, they say.
Acquired in 1986 by the May Department Stores Company, of St. Louis, as part of May's purchase of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, Lord & Taylor has been influenced and molded by the parent to pursue high sales volume with popular-priced goods that are aggressively promoted. May's highly successful formula has been to ferret out price brackets that appeal to many customers, emphasizing moderate prices and aiming at maximum sales. This is the reverse of Macy's approach, which has been to move toward higher prices.
By dropping most home furnishings, Lord & Taylor has become essentially a specialty clothing retailer, limiting its appeal to the general public. Yet like Saks Fifth Avenue, Lord & Taylor remains one of the best-known fashion retailers, with strong links to the designer community and the potential to be expanded to other cities.
 
Stern's
Filling a Niche In the Middle
With stores in New Jersey, New York City and state and on Long Island, Stern's will coast into the 1990's as one of those conventional department stores that used to rank a distant second or third. But Stern's has filled a niche, and its future appears bright as a store that offers name brands and constant price promotions for the middle-income consumer.
Twenty years ago, Stern's closed its longtime Manhattan flagship store on 42d Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, reluctant to continue paying high rent for a business that flourished only with lunchtime office workers. But it has since proved that a department-store chain does not necessarily need an urban anchor to survive and grow. It is now a 24-store chain based in Paramus, N.J. Sales are almost $700 million a year and Lawrence Stone, the company's chairman, says profits are ''very good.''
Under the ownership of Allied Stores, the seven Stern's stores in New Jersey were merged in 1982 with Allied's Gertz division of eight stores in New York City and on Long Island. After being renamed Stern's, the combined division in 1986 bought nine Gimbels locations, closed five stores and later opened three new units in New Jersey.
Offering moderately priced, almost exclusively national-brand goods, Stern's operates as a bridge between discounters like Caldor and Bradlees and higher-priced department stores like Abraham & Straus and Macy's. Disputing the contention that Stern's has filled the vacuum left by Gimbels' demise in 1986, Mr. Stone says: ''We are very different than they were. They operated almost entirely with big 'price events,' but while we certainly promote, we have a good, sound, everyday business irrespective of that. And unlike Gimbels, we make an above-average profit.''
 
Bergdorf Goodman
Top-Rung Profits In High-Rent Area
Bergdorf Goodman will finally add another store this year, and its enviable profits are expected to rise because of it.
Although bigger rivals sometimes shrug off the company because it has remained a one-store business in an era of great retail expansion, others see it differently. Admirers see it as the only New York retailer, and one of the few in the country, that has stayed on the ''high ground,'' referring to its focus on top-quality designer names. But perhaps for that reason, Bergdorf's profitability is among the highest in the industry, reaching 13.6 percent of sales before taxes in the fiscal year ended in July, on sales of $175 million. Sales are more than $1,000 per square foot of selling space.
How can a retailer that sells women's clothes for thousands of dollars and a men's custom-made suit for $2,000 avoid the slumping sales of expensive cars and furs? Bergdorf's location may be a partial answer. The 140,000-square-foot store, on the northwest corner of 58th Street and Fifth Avenue, is within five blocks of 10 of the city's most expensive luxury hotels. And it is only a few blocks from the exclusive residential neighborhoods of Central Park South and upper Fifth Avenue.
Asked to comment on the location, Ira Neimark, Bergdorf's chairman, said, ''Perhaps it's as one customer put it to me - 'you're in a tall, blonde, mink-coated gridlock.' ''
Bergdorf, owned for many years by Carter Hawley Hale Stores, was acquired in August 1987 by the Neiman-Marcus Group, a company created by a spinoff from Carter Hawley Hale. A new Bergdorf men's store, which will open in the old F.A.O. Schwarz building across Fifth Avenue from the main store, will open in August with 40,000 square feet.
In an era of troubled giants, Bergdorf has an intriguing tiny success on its ground floor. Its most productive department is only 3 feet long by 2 feet wide. It is a counter selling women's and men's belts designed by Barry Kieselstein-Cord, where the sales are four times the store's norm, or a stunning $5,000 per square foot.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about competition among New York department stores misstated the amount of debt held by R.H. Macy & Company when it bought the California-based Bullock's and I. Magnin stores in May 1988. It was $3.5 billion, not $7 billion. Macy's current debt is $4.8 billion.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Rises At 7.2% Rate

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Americans took out $4.24 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in November, the largest increase in outstanding debt in nine months, the Federal Reserve reported today.
Some analysts said the jump reflected consumer optimism despite pockets of sluggishness in the economy.
''It presents a clear picture that consumers are back on track, even if they had slowed down earlier in the year,'' said Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington forecasting firm. ''They're starting to spend again. We also saw this in the Christmas sales, which were pretty good.'' 
 
Highest Since February
The Fed said that consumer credit in November advanced at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.2 percent, on top of a 5.4 percent gain in October. It was the highest level of consumer debt since February, when $5.38 billion was posted.
Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages. In November, consumer debt totaled a seasonally adjusted $711.8 billion.
The pace of auto loans slowed to a 2.2 percent increase, or $519 million, on an annual basis, reflecting the November slump in the automobile industry because of an absence of sales incentives and the presence of price increases for 1990 models.
Auto loans increased 4.1 percent in October, but analysts said that reflected a lag in credit applications made in September but not approved until the next month.
Auto sales remained depressed until late December, when car buyers took advantage of incentives that expired at the end of the year.
''Consumers didn't like the prices and knew they would come down,'' Mr. Evans said, describing the situation in the auto industry as a pricing problem, not an economic one.
 
Revolving Debt Climbs
The debt category that includes credit-card purchases jumped to a 17.2 percent annual rate of growth, from a 6.6 percent rate in October. Total revolving debt rose $2.8 billion, compared with $1.08 billion the previous month.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose $1.33 billion, an 8 percent annual rate of growth, compared with a gain of $1.17 billion, or 7.1 percent, in October.
Debts outstanding on mobile homes fell again, down $424 million, or 22.2 percent. The rate of increase in these debts had fallen for seven consecutive months until a one-month gain in September.
